Introduction. In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. Praise be to Allah who made satisfaction for lovers in the rulings of passion, and endeared death to them in the love of those they desire; so do not be, O young man, objecting with blame. For how many among them are a lover and a truthful admirer: He saw, so he loved, so he sought union, but they refused... So he sought patience, but attaining it exhausted him, so he passed away. I praise Him with the praise of one who feared the station of his Lord and forbade the soul from desire, and composed poetry mentioning his beloved, whether Tihami in Hijaz or Shami in distance: A mount of faith if you meet a Yemeni... And if you meet a Ma'addi, then Adnani. And I bear witness that there is no god but Allah alone, with no partner, the Praiseworthy, the Glorious; a testimony of one whose death due to his distance has become closer than the jugular vein, and who said to his blamer: You have known that we have no right to your daughters, and indeed you know what we want: If what ailed me was from a veiled beloved... I would be excused, but it is from a turbaned beloved. And I bear witness that Muhammad is His servant and Messenger; a testimony of one who was sincere in his allegiance and absolved himself of sin when his beloved turned away from him, with the seal of his Lord and his innocence. May Allah bless him and his family and companions, those whom He loves and who love Him, and who stop at what He commanded them and do not transgress it, as long as a sun rises and a lover wanders. As for what follows, this book of ours is as it was said: A book containing the news of those killed by passion, and travelled with them in love in every doctrine. Its stanzas are like connected ropes, wherein one never ceases to compose poetry about Al-Rabab and Zaynab. They are what they are; you know them by their marks. Passion has left them like the dry stubble of the enclosure builder. They have become, due to the illness of intense love, of two types: some of them have fulfilled their vow (died), and some of them are waiting. They are between slain and martyred, and wretched and happy, despite the difference of their classes and forms, and the variance of their ranks and conditions, and other things by which its leaves become ripe with fruit, and its pages become such that on every side of its face is a moon. So if you look at existence in its entirety, you witness all beings as beautiful. However, a group of contemporaries have overcome those who preceded in authoring in this chapter, and most of them did not distinguish in their poetry between Zaynab and Al-Rabab: And everyone claims connection to Laila... But Laila does not acknowledge that for them. So the quarter of this book of ours is flooded with the mention of the Ameriyyah (Laila), and regarding what Shihab Mahmud authored, it is thanked. Whoever reads it knows the correctness of this statement. And recited to me in verification of this claim: If Hitham speaks, believe her. The author of 'Tawq al-Hamama' (The Ring of the Dove) relative to his partridge hops, and the author of 'Manazil al-Ahbab' (The Dwellings of the Loved Ones) is among those who knew the place but stayed short of the house. 'And I excused your phantom in its harshness... It travels by night but morning comes whilst it is stages away from us.' Another regarding 'Ya Daraha' (Oh her house) in the Khafif meter: Indeed, her visiting place... is near, but before that are terrors. If you say the merit belongs to the predecessor, and 'Did the poets leave anything to be patched?', I say yes: In wine there is a meaning not found in grapes, and the most beautiful thing in the peacock is the tail. So leave every voice after my voice, for I am the imitated cry and the other is the echo. How much the first left for the last! And there is no consideration for the saying of the poet: 'Transfer your heart wherever you wish among desires... Love is only for the first lover. How many a home on earth the young man acts familiar with... But his longing is ever for the first home.' For he has failed in his argument, and it was said in response to him: 'Take pride in the last one you were tasked to love... There is no good in the first lover. Do you doubt that the Prophet Muhammad... Mastered creation while being the last messenger?' Dik al-Jinn al-Homsi said, refuting Habib (Abu Tammam) in his aforementioned statement: 'Those who spoke of passion lied... There is no doubt in it for the first lover. Why should I yearn for a desolate ruin... Whose landmarks have been erased as if it was never inhabited?' So Habib said when he heard the saying of Dik al-Jinn mentioned: 'Those who conjectured in their saying lied... Love is only for the future lover. Is what you have tasted of food... tastier, or the taste of what has not yet been eaten?' So Dik al-Jinn said again when this saying of Habib reached him: 'Turn away from the old, first love... And stick to the resumed, future one. Transfer your heart wherever you wish, for you will not see... Like a new passion or a future union.' Abu al-Barq spoke and took the path of fairness between them, and his saying must be acknowledged because he spoke best where he said: 'They added to the meaning, so everyone is a doer of good... And the truth in it is a saying not ignored. Love is for the beloved at the hour of his union... Love in it is not for a last nor for a first.'

However, I did not deny what is in 'Manazil al-Ahbab' regarding the mention of a beloved and a home, nor did I bear prejudice against its author—oh wonder at my bearing heart! But I intended to alert that good composition is a gift, and people have schools of thought regarding what they adore. It is known that madness has arts, and every party rejoices in what they have. This book of ours remained in its drafts for years, and its verses in their meters were in depths; I did not permit the 'dwellings of the loved ones' within it to any dweller, nor did I enable a lover to pass by those places: 'I become jealous if I hear a moan in the tribe... cautious and fearful that it might be for his love.' Until the Noble Decree of the King Al-Nasir—may Allah perpetuate the spreading of his banners and never empty a quiver of his arrows as long as the decrees of the arrows of the eyes are effective and the stature of the beloved by whom time has become pleasant and moderate bends—came out requesting it. So I hastened to prepare it and cast its pure gold according to the Decree and the Noble Metal without delay or affectation. I did not permit the flowers of its prose to any of the people other than his Noble Presence, because it used to be said: 'Everything suitable for the Master is forbidden to the slave.' No wonder it came, with his happy gaze, a delight for the sight. The one standing at his threshold said that happiness indeed glances at the stone. It is a garden for the Sultan, a solace for the lover, a compatible companion for the truthful admirer, a high ground for the abandoned, a coffee for the drinking companion, a reminder for the forgetful, an insight for the blind, the verse of the poem for the excellent poet, a proverb for the skilled writer, stories for the narrator, choking grief for the envious, an alert for the jurist, and a simile for the beloved with the moon: 'His initiatives hasten to him with the full moon... And his anecdotes are sweet to him upon passing. In it, for him every day and night... is a visiting beloved or a companion conversing at night. I have verse in it, if its fragrance spreads... Within its fold is sweet speech and rare. I have prose in it that became in his station... And the scent of its light is the fragrance of the radiant garden. I have in it from the magic of expression letters... If the fawn-eyed one, his magic, treats me harshly. I have in it the secrets of letters because... My tears dot it, so its secrets appear. The scattering of my tears is like the arrangement of its lines... My cheeks when his notebooks are written on them. The pens of his guidance extend the ink of tears... So my tears are my ink and the blackness is his inkwells. I served in the Diwan al-Sababa (Register of Ardent Love) as a worker... So his glance undertook my killing from my sleep. Were it not for passion, a lover like me would not have died... Nor would his graveyards have been populated by the Ameri (Majnun). And in my ghazal (love poetry) is the mention of the gazelle and a quarter... Even the wild calves are flown by the conversation in it. I elevate it above the description of Unayzah's howdah... And a desolate wasteland from which her camels marched. Its rhymes drag high meanings by which... Jarir became like a slave shackled by his crimes. The temples of Al-Walid turn grey because of it... As it travels while the wing of the night has black braids. I do not see a day at Darat Juljul... Except a poet upon whom misfortunes turned. If the mention of a beloved and a home is forgotten... Then I, for the one I love, will remain a rememberer as long as I live. I neighbor neighbors at the foot of Al-Muqattam... Oh how excellent is the beloved when you neighbor him. O phantom of the one I love, if my eye dozes off... Do you abandon him, by Allah, or are you visiting him? By your right, if you traveled with him for part of a night... You would have traveled with caravans marching in love. Oh pride of a phantom from your imagination knocking... So he lowers his head in reverence as if you were present. I have one whom the branch goes on pilgrimage to the spear of her stature... If she spends the night in the fresh garden with her look. If she is kissed on the jewelry and perfume, it is said to me... Your beloved is a garden whose flowers diffuse scent. If I sought from her, while she is angry, a turn... She bent her affections towards the gazelle consulting him. Does what I suffer from the heat of her abandonment cool down... While her mid-day heats have intensified against me one day? I fortified myself in the fortress of passion against my blamers... And an army of worry spent the night besieging my heart. If my blamer were not blind of insight... His eyes would not have been blind to whom I loved. He compares her to the branch, while the branch, when with her... Witnesses her, lowers its eyes, and casts down its gaze. Does the branch have a cheek like the anemone when it appears... And hair like the wing of night, its braids black?

If my humiliation in her love is pleasant, then I am... By your right, made victorious by one who is mighty in Egypt. A king who shakes the spear of his stature's sides... As a branch shakes, flying in love. A king, you show him before it happened, that it is existing... His insight is double what his eyes see. He is close to you if you come to him, good in meeting... Glorious of countenance, excelling in beauty, dazzling. A king, if he becomes like the full moon in the darkness... Then his children are like the stars traveling with him. A king, around whom I see every scholar... Mentioning in knowledge what he mentions. A king, who has for every day and guardian... A bringer of glad tidings, whose tidings follow in succession with congratulations. A king, whom the lions of the forest fear his might... Because the kings of the earth all fear him. The meteors of the sky and its lightning frighten them... And they are but his tawny spears and his sharp swords. If you opened the forms of the state of their gathering... Then which conscience did not hide its secret in it? Which brave men did not fear his combat in its sea... And which place did not have his pulpits ascend it? And which poem in its sea did not please him... While the diver of my thought is the arranger of the pearls, scattering them? I have in it five of the best compositions... And this one, Tawq al-Hamama (Ring of the Dove), is the tenth. The prose diffuses scent in it like flowers when... The east wind alternates and comes early to it. How many a dancer I have in it around a singer... By his erotic poetry in the tribe, his flute player delights. If it were not like the Sugardan (Sugar bowl), it would not become... In his presence one day, its civilizations pleasant. Yes, I authored it in the name of our Master the Sultan in the... explained manner, and undertook its work myself for his sake, so it came as was said, a work... ... .... ... ... ... Spirit to Spirit. I wander in love with whom the beloved wandered in love... Oh, wonder at this chained passion. I followed in its composition brevity... And restriction to short anecdotes, because it used to be said: Fabrication is of two types... A fabrication that has pride and a fabrication that has origin. Yahya bin Khalid said to his son: 'Write the best of what you hear, memorize the best of what you write, speak with the best of what you memorize, and take a part of everything, for whoever is ignorant of a thing is an enemy to it.' I named it 'Diwan al-Sababa' (Register of Ardent Love) so that the one who stands upon it becomes enamored and knows that if I am not for ardent love, who is for it: 'No one knows longing except the one who endures it... Nor ardent love except the one who suffers it.' Yes, by Allah, rarely does the obedient to his passion leave... Sufficing as one of ardent love and madness.

I arranged it into an Introduction, thirty Chapters, and a Conclusion. As for the Introduction, it is regarding the definition of Ishq (Passionate Love), its derivation, what has been said about its mark and description, its causes, signs, ranks, names, praise and dispraise, and the mention of people's disagreement on whether it is voluntary or involuntary, and similar matters. As for the Chapters: Chapter 1: On the mention of Beauty and Comeliness, and what has been said about them in detail and summary. Chapter 2: On the mention of Lovers and Wits among Kings and Caliphs. Chapter 3: On the mention of those who loved upon Hearsay and fell into conflict from yearning for the beloved. Chapter 4: On the mention of those who looked the first look and burned from the cheek of the beloved with an ember. Chapter 5: On the mention of the changing of colors upon witnessing (the beloved), such as pallor and fear, and redness and shame, and what carries that meaning regarding tongue-tiedness and magic of expression. Chapter 6: On the mention of Jealousy and what it contains of confusion, and the 'Knocking of the Tooth of Dik al-Jinn' (Regret). Chapter 7: On the mention of Divulging the Secret and Concealment from the people of the time. Chapter 8: On the mention of Tricking the Beloved, appeasing him, and remedying his anger and deviation. Chapter 9: On the mention of Messengers and Letters and gentleness in means. Chapter 10: On the mention of Tricks on the Phantom of Imagination and other things said about it with differing meanings. Chapter 11: On the mention of the Shortness and Length of the Night, the dyeing of its twilight and its fading, and what carries that meaning. Chapter 12: On the mention of the Lack of Intellect of the Blamer and his excess of curiosity. Chapter 13: On the mention of Allusion to Union and Visiting. Chapter 14: On the mention of the Watcher (Raqib), the Talebearer (Nammam), and the Slanderer of many words. Chapter 15: On the mention of Admonition at the gathering of loved ones and what carries that meaning regarding satisfaction and forgiveness for what has passed. Chapter 16: On the mention of Aiding the Poor Lover when the knife reaches the bone. Chapter 17: On the mention of the Medicine for the Illness of Passion and what the people of love endure. Chapter 18: On the mention of the Beloved's Obstinacy against the Yearning Lover and other divisions of abandonment and the patience of the one pulsing in it on embers. Chapter 19: On the mention of Supplication against the Beloved and what it contains of inverted jurisprudence. Chapter 20: On the mention of Submission and the Shedding of Tears. Chapter 21: On the mention of Promises and Wishes and what relief they hold for the sufferer. Chapter 22: On the mention of Satisfaction from the Beloved with the easiest request. Chapter 23: On the mention of the Mixing of Spirits like the mixing of water with wine. Chapter 24: On the mention of the Lover's Body becoming like a toothpick and a phantom of imagination, and what carries that meaning regarding the slenderness of the waist and comparing the buttocks to a sand dune. Chapter 25: On the mention of what one endures in seeking loved ones of difficult matters. Chapter 26: On the mention of the Goodness of the Memory of a Beloved. Chapter 27: On the mention of a small portion of Excellent Stanzas and Elegant Ghazal containing roses of cheeks and pomegranates of breasts and other things there. Chapter 28: On the mention of a small portion of the News of Excellent Singers among men and beauties, and what carries that meaning regarding mentioning their Mawwals and describing their instruments. Chapter 29: On the mention of those afflicted in this time with the love of women and boys. Chapter 30: On the mention of those characterized by Chastity with the best descriptions. As for the Conclusion, it is on the mention of those who died of their love and came to their Lord, rich and poor, great and small, despite their different types and varying quests. For the sake of mentioning them, I established the foundations of this book and entered it from a door and exited from a door. From here we begin mentioning what brings comfort like fans of coarse linen, and serves upon reading like the vanguard for the army. This Introduction is regarding the description of Ishq, its mark, its praise and dispraise, and the mention of people's disagreement on whether it is voluntary or involuntary. It includes five sections: Section One: The Definition of Love, its mark, and what has been said regarding its name. I say: We established this section to mention the definition of Love and its boundaries, the ebb and flow of its crashing sea, and the differing speech and contrasting sayings people have about it. For among them are those who were confused and named it by the name of its cause or by the name of what it leads to of error, and other things in which the answer and hitting the truth were confused for them. Their apparent excuse is the saying of the poet: 'People say: If only you described Passion to us... By Allah, I do not know how to describe it to them. For there is no limit to define any part of it... Nor is there a timed time for any part of it.'

Among its beautiful definitions and correct descriptions is the saying of Pythagoras, who took from the companions of Solomon son of David, peace be upon them both, as mentioned by Sa'id in the Book of Classes: 'Love is greed that is generated in the heart, moves and grows, then breeds. Materials of eagerness gather to it, and whenever it strengthens, its owner increases in agitation, persistence, continuation in greed, thought, wishes, and eagerness for the quest, until that leads him to disturbing grief. The burning of the blood at that point is by the transformation of black bile (melancholy) or the inflammation of yellow bile and its turning into it. It is the nature of black bile to corrupt thought, leading to loss of reason, hoping for what cannot be, and wishing for what cannot be completed, until that leads to madness. At that point, the lover might kill himself, or die of grief, or look at his beloved and die of joy, or gasp a gasp so his soul suffocates and he remains for twenty-four hours, so they think he died and bury him while he is alive. Or he might sigh deeply so his soul suffocates in the pericardium of his heart, and the heart closes over it and does not open until he dies. You see him, if he remembers the one he loves, his blood flees and his color changes.' Imam Ibn the Imam Muhammad bin Dawud al-Zahiri said repeatedly: 'If that is so, then the removal of the hateful thing from one in this state has no way through the management of medicines, and there is no cure for him.' In a copy, Fazari said: 'Except by the kindness of the Lord of the Worlds. That is because the hateful thing occurring from a single cause standing by itself can be managed by removing its cause. But if two causes occur, and each one is a cause—so if black bile is a cause for continuous thought, and continuous thought is a cause for the burning of blood and yellow bile and their turning into strengthening the black bile—then this is the incurable disease which doctors are unable to treat.' Among them is the saying of Plato, who took wisdom from the aforementioned Pythagoras: 'Love is an instinctual force generated from the whispers of the ambitious and the ghosts of imagination, growing by the connection of the natural structure, creating boldness for the brave and courage for the coward. It clothes every human with the opposite of his nature until it reaches the psychological illness and longing madness, leading him to the incurable disease for which there is no cure.' Among them is the saying of Aristotle, who took wisdom from the aforementioned Plato: 'Love is the blindness of the lover to the faults of the beloved.' This is like his saying (the Prophet), peace be upon him: 'Your love for a thing blinds and deafens.' And the saying of the poet: 'I do not see the fault of a friend at all... Nor some of what is in him when I am satisfied. The eye of satisfaction is blunt to every fault... But the eye of discontent reveals defects.' And the saying of another: 'The eye of discontent sees every fault... And the eye of the brother of satisfaction is blind to that.' Among them is what Abu Ali Ibn Sina and other doctors followed: 'Love is an obsessive disease resembling melancholia, which a person brings upon himself by focusing his thought on the approval of certain forms and figures. It may be accompanied by sexual desire, or it may not.' Some witty literati said: 'Love is an expression for seeking that specific act from a specific person.' This is witty. Al-Junayd said: 'Love is a Merciful intimacy and a longing inspiration which the Generosity of Allah Almighty obligated upon every possessor of a soul, to obtain the Greatest Pleasure which cannot be matched except by that intimacy. It exists in souls according to the ranks of their owners. No one is without love for a matter by which the extent of his class among creation is indicated. For that reason, the noblest ranks in the world were the ranks of those who renounced it despite it being visible, and inclined towards the Hereafter despite it being reported to them in the form of words.' Al-Asma'i said: 'I asked a Bedouin woman about Love. She said: It is too majestic to be seen and hidden from the eyes of mankind. It is latent in the chests like the latency of fire in stone; if you strike it, it ignites, and if you leave it, it hides.' Some said: 'Madness has arts, and Love is one of its arts.' He argued with the saying of Qays (Majnun): 'They said: You became mad with whom you desire. I said to them... Love is greater than what is with madmen. Love—its companion never recovers forever... While the madman is struck down only at times. I have become mad, so bring the one I became mad with... If she can negate my madness, do not blame me.'

It was said to Abu Zuhayr al-Mada'ini: 'What is Love?' He said: 'Madness and humiliation, and it is the disease of the witty folk.' It was said to Abu Wa'il al-Awdahi: 'What do you say about Love?' He said: 'If it is not a part of madness, it is the extract of magic.' A Bedouin woman said: 'It is the movement of the static and the calming of the moving.' Al-Ma'mun said to Yahya bin Aktham: 'What is Love?' He said: 'Occurrences that occur to a man, so his heart wanders with them and his soul prefers them.' Thumamah said to him: 'Silence, O Yahya! You only have to answer in a matter of divorce or a pilgrim in Ihram hunting game. As for this, it is one of our matters.' Al-Ma'mun said to him: 'Speak, O Thumamah.' He said: 'Love is an enjoyable companion, a comforting intimate, a possessing friend, and a conquering king. A king whose paths are subtle, whose doctrines are obscure, and whose judgments are unjust. He possessed bodies and their souls, hearts and their thoughts, eyes and their gazes, and intellects and their opinions. He has been given the rein of their obedience, the power of their disposal, and the leadership of their kingdom. His entrance is hidden from eyes, and his path is blinded from hearts.' Al-Ma'mun said to him: 'You have done well, O Thumamah,' and ordered a thousand dinars for him. This amount is sufficient in knowing Love and its definition. Section Two: Its Causes and Signs. I say: We established this section to speak on the psychological causes of Love and its physical signs, although this latter type is numerous and the lovers characterized by it are a large multitude. We will present of that what is sweet to arrive at and for which its banners flutter like the heart of a lover, God willing. Some doctors said: The cause of psychological Love is approval (Istihsan) and thought. Its physical cause is the rising of a bad vapor to the brain from retained semen; therefore, it mostly afflicts bachelors, and frequent intercourse removes it quickly. Ibn al-Akfani said in his book 'Ghunyat al-Labib inda Ghaybat al-Tabib' (Sufficiency of the Intelligent in the Absence of the Doctor) that eating hearing birds inherits Love. He also said in 'Al-Khulasah': Its sign is thinness of the body, hollowness of the eyelid due to sleeplessness and the abundance of vapors rising to it, sunkenness of the eye and its dryness except when weeping, and a smiling movement of the eyelid as if looking at something delightful. Also, breath that is frequently interrupted and recovered, deep sighing, and an irregular pulse, especially when mentioning different names and descriptions; whichever one causes the irregularity of the pulse and change of face to intensify, that is it (the beloved). Aristotle the Astrologer said: Love belongs to the stars Saturn, Mercury, and Venus together. Therefore, if they share in the origin of the birth or gather and correspond in praiseworthy forms, love and affection occur between them in the house of one of them or in his limit, and the lord of the house or the owner of the limit is looking at it, or the mentioned planets are looking in praiseworthy forms or are conjunctions. Saturn prepares thought, wishing, greed, worry, agitation, sorrows, obsession, and madness. Mercury prepares poetry composition, arranging letters, flattery, licentiousness, embellishing speech, abasement, and gentleness. Venus prepares for Love, infatuation, wandering, and tenderness, and incites the soul to enjoy looking, intimacy in conversation, and flirtation which incites lust and arousal, and calls to mirth and listening to songs and what resembles it. Ptolemy said: Its cause is that the sun and moon are in one sign or corresponding in trine or sextile. Whenever it is so, they are naturally disposed to mutual affection because their lots of fortune in their births are in one sign, or the two lots correspond in trine or sextile, provided the lord of the lot of love and friendship looks on. That indicates that these two newborns, their love is from the aspect of benefit, and their benefit is from one direction. If one of them benefits from the affection of his companion, the benefit brings about love and affection between them and they mix. This is supported by the saying of Al-Khayarzi: 'But the souls of lovers meet... If the bodies are asleep away from them. And I consider our two souls originally one... But it is divided between us. Were this not so, my soul would not feel pain... For him in the unseen when he is in pain.' Among its signs is the lover lowering his gaze when his beloved looks at him and casting his glance towards the ground; that is out of awe of him, shyness from him, and his greatness in his chest. For this reason, kings disapprove of one who addresses them while staring sharply at them; rather, he should be lowering his gaze to the ground. Allah Almighty said, informing about the perfection of the manners of His Prophet, peace be upon him, on the Night of Isra: 'The sight did not swerve, nor did it transgress.' This is the utmost manners, for the sight did not swerve right nor left, nor did it aspire beyond what was there. Among them is a disturbance that appears to the lover upon seeing someone who resembles his beloved or upon hearing his name, as was said: 'A caller called while we were at Al-Khayf in Mina... So he stirred the sorrows of the heart while not knowing. He called by the name of Laila someone else, so it was as if... He flew with Laila a bird that was in my chest. He called by the name of Laila—may Allah heat his eye... While Laila is in the land of Sham in a desolate country.'

Among them is that he requests to hear the name of his beloved and delights in speaking about his news. He loves the family of his beloved, his relatives, his servants, his neighbors, and whoever lives with him, as the poet said: 'O dwellers of the banks of the Tigris, all of you... To the heart, for the sake of the beloved, are beloved.' Another said: 'I love, for her love, the black people until... I love, for her love, the black dogs.' Among them is his excessive jealousy over him, love of killing and death to reach his satisfaction, listening to his speech if he speaks, finding everything he brings strange even if it is the essence of absurdity, believing him even if he lies, agreeing with him even if he wrongs, testifying for him even if he is unjust, following him however he proceeds, hastening to walk towards the place where he is, intentionally sitting near him and approaching him, casting aside busying matters that distract from him, asceticism regarding them and desiring away from them, underestimating every grave matter calling for separation from him, slowing down in walking when leaving him, and being generous with everything he can of what he used to enjoy before that, as if it is gifted to him. This is before the fire of love ignites. If it becomes established, he turns away from all that and replaces it with asking and begging as if he takes it from the beloved, to the point that he sacrifices himself for his beloved, just as the Companions used to sacrifice themselves for the Prophet, peace be upon him, in war until they fell around him, as was said: 'A lover ransoms you with his soul, if he had... Something dearer than his soul, he would ransom you with it.' Among them is excessive expanding joy, cramming in a wide place, fighting over something one of them takes, frequent hidden winking, leaning, intentionally touching the hand during conversation, touching what is possible of the visible limbs, and drinking what the beloved left in the vessel. I say: Among them is kissing his sandal in his absence. I have seen one who did this, so I reprimanded him for it. He said: 'Silence, O so-and-so, you do not know the pleasure in this.' Then I found this mentioned person in Mecca, and he sent a letter with me to his mentioned beloved because he was staying there (Mujawir). I said to him: 'How was patience possible, O Zaid, from Amr?' He recited: 'By Allah, I have a side I do not waste... And for amusement and licentiousness, I have a side.' Among them is kissing the wall of the house, as was said: 'I kiss this wall and that wall... I pass by the dwellings, the dwellings of Laila. It is not the love of dwellings that enraptured my heart... But the love of the one who dwelled in the dwellings.' Among them is the agreement occurring between the lover and the beloved, especially if the love is a love of resemblance and suitability. Often the beloved speaks words or wants to speak them, and the lover speaks the exact same words. Often the lover falls ill due to the illness of his beloved. I say: This happened more than once to Sultan Al-Malik Al-Nasir Ahmad when he was in Karak with his beloved Al-Shuhaib; he would fall ill for his illness and recover for his health. I was told this by one whose word I do not doubt among those who were in his service attending him. As for the occurrence of this for the predecessors, it is frequent. Of that is what is told about Abu Nuwas, that he fell ill, and some of his friends entered to visit him and found him slightly better. He said: 'Be at ease with us,' and said: 'Where did you come from?' We said: 'From Anan, the slave girl of Al-Natiqi.' He said: 'Was she ill?' We said: 'Yes, and she has recovered now.' He said: 'By Allah, I denied this illness of mine and did not know a cause for it, other than I imagined that it was due to an illness that befell some of whom I love. I have found relief this day, so I rejoiced hoping that Allah healed him from it before me.' Then he called for his inkwell and wrote to Anan: 'I developed a fever and did not feel your fever... Until my visitors spoke of your complaint. So I said: The fever would not have visited me... Without a cause, except for your fever. And a trait in which I was not accused... Allah healed me from it when He healed you. Until my soul and your soul agreed in... This and that, and in this and that.'

Among them is that if asked about a matter, he answers with the opposite. Excessive yawning, stretching, and laziness if he looks at his beloved. Scratching the ground with his big toe. This happens often to women. Biting her lower lip, striking her upper arms or breasts, revealing her beauties to the one she desires, making him imagine she sees that for some of her family, looking at her sides, and placing speech out of context—'I mean you, so listen, O neighbor.' Among them is submission to the beloved in all that he chooses of good and evil. If the beloved is fond of knowledge, the lover strives in seeking it more intensely than his striving. If he is fond of anecdotes, good stories, and pleasant news, the lover exaggerates in seeking and memorizing them. If he is fond of a craft or industry, he strives to learn it if possible. The beneficial love is that a person falls upon a complete love that carries him by his love to seek perfection. The calamity, the whole calamity, is that a person is afflicted with the love of an empty, idle person, void of all good, so his love carries him to resemble him. In the news of lovers, a lover loved trousers (Sirwal) because of the trousers of his beloved, so twelve loads and a sack of trousers were found in his estate; Al-Saymari mentioned it. Another loved mortars (Hawun) because of the sound of his beloved's mortar, so ten thousand of them were found in his estate. I have come across many things of this sort; madness has arts. Section Three: Its Ranks and Names. I say: We established this section to mention the ranks of love, its context, its names, and its derivation according to different languages and the agreement of its narrators. It is known that if a thing was great among the Arabs and its importance grave—like the lion, the spear, wine, the sword, the calamity, and burning love, and what makes you know what it is—they placed many names for it and their care for it was famous. Nothing equals their care for Love which steals the core (intellect). The first of its ranks is Hawa (Desire/Air), which is the inclination of the soul. It may be used to mean the beloved himself. The poet said: 'Indeed, she who claimed your heart got bored of her... Was created as your desire (Hawa) just as desire was created for her.' Then 'Alaqah (Attachment), which is the love adhering to the heart, as the poet said: 'I wanted patience away from you, but hindered me... An attachment ('Alaq) in my heart from your love, old.' It was named 'Alaqah for the heart's hanging onto the beloved. Then Kalaf (Infatuation), which is the intensity of love. Its origin is from Kulfa, which is hardship. It is said 'Kallafahu taklifan' if he ordered him with what is hard for him. It is as if the beloved tasks the lover with what he cannot bear, ignoring His saying Almighty: 'Allah does not charge a soul except [with that within] its capacity.' It was said it is taken from the 'Kalf' (freckle/mark), which is something that appears on the face like sesame seeds. Kalaf is also a color between blackness and redness, which is a murky redness. Then Ishq (Passionate Love), which is a name for what exceeds the amount called Hubb (Love). In 'Al-Sahah', Ishq is excessive love. According to doctors, it is among the types of Melancholia. The meaning of Melancholia is the change of assumptions and thought from the natural course to corruption. This is the matter of these names. The Arabs rarely pronounced it (Ishq); as if they covered its name and alluded to it with these names. They hardly explicitly mentioned it, nor do you hardly find it in their ancient poetry. Rather, the later ones became fond of it. This word did not occur in the Quran nor in the Sunnah except in the Hadith of Ibn Dawud al-Zahiri as will be explained. Ibn Sidah said: Ishq is the lover's admiration of the beloved; it is in the violence of love and its terror. It was said: 'Ishq' is the noun and 'Ashaq' is the source. 'Ashiq' is one with much love. A woman is 'Ashiq' (lover). And a tree is called... It was said 'Ashiqa' (Ivy/Bindweed) turns green then becomes thin and small. Al-Zajjaji said the derivation of 'Ashiq' is from that. Al-Farra said: Ishq is a sticky plant, so the love a man has for his wife was named Ishq for its sticking to the heart.

Ibn al-A'rabi said: The 'Ashiqa' is the Lablab (Ivy); it turns green and yellow and clings to whatever tree is next to it. 'Al-Ashiq' (The Lover) was derived from that. Mentioned in Diwan al-Ashiqin. 'Ashiq' is used for the doer (lover) and the object (beloved). The plural of Ashiq is 'Ishq' and 'Ushaq'. It is said regarding a woman 'Ashiqa' and also a woman 'Ashiq' (masculine form), and that has been mentioned previously. Allah knows best. Then Shaghaf (Enamoredness). Al-Azizi said in 'Gharib al-Quran': 'Shaghafaha hubban' (he inspired her with love) means his love hit the pericardium (Shaghaf) of her heart. The Shaghaf is the covering of the heart. It is said it is the kernel of the heart, which is a black clot in its core. 'Shaghafaha hubban' means his love rose to the highest place in her heart, derived from 'Shaghaf al-Jibal', meaning their peaks. Their saying 'So-and-so is Mashghuf' means love took him to the furthest extents. As for Sha'af (Infatuation) with the undotted 'Ayn', it is the burning of the heart by love. He said in 'Al-Sahah': 'Sha'afahu al-hubb', meaning it burned his heart. It has been read both ways: 'Shaghafaha hubban' and 'Sha'afaha'. Likewise is Law'ah (Anguish) and La'ij (Burning). I mean like Shaghaf in burning. La'ij is an active participle from their saying 'The blow la'ajahu' if it pained him and burned his skin. It is said 'Hawa La'ij' for the burning of the heart from love. In 'Al-Sahah', 'Law'at al-Hubb' is its burning. So this is the Burning Desire. Then Jawa (Ardency), which is the inner desire. In 'Al-Sahah', Jawa is the burning and intensity of emotion (Wajd) from passionate love or grief. Then Tatayyum (Enslavement by Love), which is that love enslaves him. From it 'Taym Allah' was named, meaning Servant of Allah. From it is said a man is 'Mutayyam'. Then Tabl (Sickness by Love), which is that desire makes him ill. From it a man is 'Matbul'. In 'Al-Sahah', 'Tabalahum al-dahr' and 'atbalahum' if it annihilated them. Then Tadlah (Bewilderment), which is the loss of reason from desire. It is said 'Dallahahu al-hubb', meaning it bewildered him. Then Huyam (Wandering), which is that he goes on his face due to the overwhelming desire upon him. From it a man is 'Ha'im'. 'Al-Hiyam' with Kasra is thirsty camels, and a people 'Him', meaning thirsty. Sababa (Ardent Love) is the tenderness of longing and its heat. Maqah is Love, and Wamiq is the Lover. Wajd (Emotion/Passion) and Husran (Grief/Regret), and mostly it is used in grief. Danaf (Emaciation/Sickness) is hardly used by the Arabs regarding love; rather the later ones became fond of it. The Arabs used it regarding illness. Shajw (Anxiety) is love followed by worry and sadness. Shawq (Longing) is the travel of the heart to the beloved. He said in 'Al-Sahah': Shawq and Ishtiyaq are the soul's yearning for a thing. It came in the Sunnah: 'And I ask You for the gaze upon Your Noble Face and the longing (Shawq) for meeting You.' It was disputed regarding Shawq: does it vanish with union or increase? A group said it vanishes because it is the travel of the heart to the beloved, so if it reaches him, the journey ends, so it throws down its staff and the distance settles with it. Just as the traveler is delighted by the return. A group said: Rather, it increases. They argued with the saying of the poet: 'And the greatest that love is one day... Is when the tents draw near to the tents.' They said: Now Shawq is the burning of love and the inflammation of its fire in the heart of the lover, and that is something which nearness and connection increase. The correct view is that the Shawq occurring at meeting and connection is different from the type that was during absence from the beloved. Ibn al-Rumi said: 'I embrace her while the soul is still longing... For her; is there closeness after the embrace? And I kiss her mouth so my ardency may vanish... But the wandering I suffer intensifies. It is as if my heart's thirst is not quenched... Except by seeing the two souls mix.' Balbal (Anxiety) is worry and the whispering of the chest. Balabil is the plural of Balbalah. It is said 'Balabil al-Shawq', meaning its whisperings. Tabarih (Hardships) are severities and calamities. It is said 'Barraha bihi al-Hubb wal-Shawq' if the Barh (Hardship) afflicted him from it, which is severity. Ghamrah (Flood/Overwhelming) is what overwhelms the heart of love, drunkenness, or negligence. Shajan (Sadness/Need) is the need wherever it is, and the lover's need is strongest for his beloved. The Rajiz poet said: 'I will reveal to you in what I reveal... I have two needs (Shajnan): A need in Najd? And a need for me in the lands of Sindh.' Another said: 'My companions traveled and did not find my passion (Wajd)... And people have needs (Shujan) and I have a need alone.' Wasab is the pain of love and its sickness, for the origin of Wasab is illness. Kamad is suppressed sadness, and Kamad is the change of color. Arraq (Sleeplessness) and Sahar (Wakefulness) are among the necessities of love. Hanin (Nostalgia) is longing. The root of its matter is covering. Excessive love covers the intellect so the lover does not reason what benefits him nor what harms him. It is a branch of madness, and some love is madness. Wudd (Affection) is pure love, its subtlest and most tender. It is to Love as Ra'fah (Compassion) is to Rahmah (Mercy). Khullah (Friendship/Intimacy) is the unification of love. The Khalil (Intimate Friend) is the one who unifies his love for his beloved. It is a rank that does not accept partnership. For this reason, the two Khalils, Ibrahim and Muhammad, blessings of Allah be upon them both, were distinguished by it in the world, as He said: 'And Allah took Ibrahim as a Khalil.' And it is authentic from the Prophet, peace be upon him, that he said: 'Indeed Allah took me as a Khalil just as He took Ibrahim as a Khalil.' And in the Sahih from him: 'If I were to take a Khalil from the people of earth, I would have taken Abu Bakr as a Khalil.' It was said it was named Khullah because love permeates (takhallal) all parts of the spirit. The poet said:

'You permeated the place of the spirit in me... And for that, the Khalil was named Khalil.' One who has no knowledge claimed that the Habib (Beloved) is better than the Khalil, saying Muhammad is Habibullah and Ibrahim is Khalilullah. This claim is false because Khullah is specific, which is the unification of love as mentioned, and Mahabbah (Love) is general. Allah Almighty said: 'Indeed, Allah loves those who are constantly repentant and loves those who purify themselves.' It is authentic that Allah Almighty took a Prophet as a Khalil, so he obtained the blessings of general love upon the specific and the general: 'You settled in this place, then a place... In this, so both valleys became pleasant.' Gharam (Infatuation/Debt) is necessary love. It is said a man is 'Mughram' with love, meaning love has stuck to him. In 'Al-Sahah', Gharam is fondness, and the Gharim is the one who owes a debt, and it may be the one to whom the debt is owed. Kuthayyir said: 'Every debtor paid off his creditor... And Azza is procrastinating, causing her creditor to suffer.' Walah (Bewilderment) is the loss of mind and confusion from intense passion. It has names other than these which I omitted fearing elongation. Mahabbah (Love) is the mother of all these names. It was said Shawq (Longing) is a genus and Mahabbah is a type of it. Do you not see that every love is longing but not every longing is love? The author of 'Al-Manzum wal-Manthur' disagreed with that. He said: They claimed that Ishq, Wajd, and Hawa are to desire a thing and follow it whether in error or guidance, and Hubb (Love) is a letter that organizes these three. It may be said regarding the 'Ashiq' (Lover), 'Wajid' (Passionate), and the one who desires a matter, that he is a 'Muhibb' (Lover). People have many words regarding the definition of Mahabbah. It was said: It is the permanent inclination of the wandering heart. It was said: It is your standing for your beloved with all that he loves from you. It was said: Mentioning the beloved to the count of breaths, as Al-Mutanabbi said: 'It is desired from the heart to forget you... But natures refuse the transfer.' It was said it is accompanying the beloved constantly, as was said: 'It is a wonder that I yearn for them... And ask about them whoever I meet while they are with me. My eye seeks them while they are in its pupil... And my heart longs for them while they are between my ribs.' It was said it is the presence of the beloved with the lover constantly, as the other said: 'Your phantom is in my eye and your mention is in my mouth... And your abode is in my heart, so where do you disappear?' Regarding its derivation, there are also opinions. It was said it is derived from 'Habbat al-Qalb' (Grain of the Heart), which is its core, and it is said its fruit; so Love was named that for its reaching the grain of the heart. It was said it is derived from necessity and stability; from it 'Ahabba al-Ba'ir' (The camel knelt) if it knelt and did not stand. It was said from 'Hubab al-Ma'' (Bubbles of water) - with Fatha on Ha - which is its main part, or what rises on water during heavy rain. According to this, Love is the boiling of the heart. It was said: From 'Hubb al-Ma'' (Water Jar) in which it is placed, because it holds what water is in it and has no room for other than it if it is filled with it. Likewise, if the heart is filled with Love, there is no room in it for other than the beloved. Mentioning the water jar which Egyptians call 'Al-Zir', how beautiful is the saying of Judge Muhyi al-Din Abd al-Zahir riddling about the Zir jug, containing an objection that mars it and good composition that adorns it: 'Possessor of an ear without hearing... He has a heart without a heart. If he takes over a Hubb (Jar/Love)... Then say what you wish about the Sabb (Pouring/Lover).' Chapter Four: Its Praise and Dispraise. I say: We established this section for the praise of Ishq and its dispraise, its antidote and its poison. How many a wise man praised it and a pseudo-wise dispraised it. Alas, the one who dispraised the Desired One missed out, and from where do sins come to the beautiful face? Among its praiseworthy characteristics and existing virtues is what the scholar Qudamah said: 'Ishq is a virtue that produces cunning, encourages the coward, makes the hand of the miser generous, clears the mind of the stupid, unleashes the tongue of the stutterer with poetry, and incites the determination of the helpless. It is a mighty thing to which the might of kings lowers itself, and the assault of the brave humbles itself. It is the caller to literature, and the first door by which minds and intellects are opened, and by which the intricacies of plots and tricks are extracted. To it ambitions rest, and repulsive morals and characters settle. It entertains its companion and comforts its intimate. It has a joy that roams in souls and a happiness that dwells in hearts.' It was said to a scholar: 'Your son has fallen in love.' He said: 'Praise be to Allah, now his edges will soften, his meanings will become subtle, his gestures will become witty, his movements will become elegant, his expressions will become good, his letters will improve, and his character will become clear. So persevere in the beautiful and avoid the ugly.' It was said to another similarly, and he said: 'No harm, if he loves, he becomes subtle, witty, precise, and tender.' It was said to Buzurjmihr: 'When does a youth become eloquent?' He said: 'If he authors a book or describes a desire or a beloved.' Al-Abbas ibn al-Ahnaf spoke truly when he said: 'People are none but lovers possessing desire... And there is no good in one who does not love and fall in passion.' Another said: 'It would not please me that I am free of desire... Even if I had what is between east and west.' Another said: 'There is no good in the world without ardent love... Nor in a bliss in which there is no beloved.' Another said: 'Dwell with a companion you delight in his love... Time has gone while you are empty and solitary.' Another said:

'If you do not taste in this abode a youthful passion... Then your death in it and life are equal.' Another said: 'There is no good in the world if you do not visit... A beloved, nor does a beloved come to you.' Another said: 'No one tasted the misery of living and its bliss... In the past if he did not fall in love.' Al-Mutanabbi said: 'I blamed the people of love until I tasted it... Then I wondered how one who does not love dies.' I said, including Al-Mutanabbi's saying with an addition of double entendre (Tawriya): 'If you ask about what I encountered of desire... Then I am the one who practiced it and knew it. You disagreed regarding the sipping of saliva and its taste... And I blamed the people of love until I tasted it.' It is told that King Bahram Gur had one son, and he wanted to nominate him for kingship after him, but found him of low ambition and base soul. So he set slave girls and singers upon him, and he fell in love with one of them. King Bahram was informed of this and rejoiced. He sent to the one it was said he loved: 'Transgress against him and say: I am only fit for one of noble soul and high ambition, a king or a scholar.' When she said that, he reviewed knowledge and the high ambition kings are upon until he excelled in that and took over the kingdom, becoming one of their best. He recorded that in wisdom to Kisra: 'A king does not become complete except after his love, and likewise the scholar.' They said: Permissible love is something the lover is rewarded for, as Sharik said when asked about lovers: 'The most intense of them in love has the greatest reward.' They said: The souls of lovers are fragrant and subtle, their bodies are weak, and their souls are slow to submit to anyone who leads them except their dwelling (beloved) to whom they dwelt and upon whom they tied their love. The speech of lovers and their companionship increase intellects, stir souls, delight spirits, bring joys, and create longing for the endeavors of their news among kings and those below them. It suffices the poor lover who was not mentioned with kings and brave heroes that he loves and becomes famous for love, so he is mentioned in the gatherings of kings and caliphs and those below them; his news circulate and his poems are narrated, and love remains for him an eternal mention. Were it not for love, no name would be mentioned for him, no trace would occur for him, no head would be raised for him, nor would he be mentioned among people. Al-Marzubani said: Abu Nawfal was asked: 'Has anyone escaped love?' He said: 'Yes, the rude churl who has no virtue nor understanding. As for one who has the slightest wit in his nature or has the gentleness of the people of Hijaz and the wit of the people of Iraq, he does not escape it.' Some said: No one is free of youthful passion unless he is coarse in creation, deficient, of diminished structure, or contrary to the composition of moderation: 'Oh wonder at time, not a soul is free... Of love, until even water is loved by wine.' It suffices the lover that he is eager for kindness and aiding the distressed, as was said: 'He is eager for kindness in seeking heights... That his character may be praised one day before Laila.' Abu al-Najab said: I saw in the Tawaf (circumambulation of Kaaba) a youth thin of body showing weakness, seeking refuge and praying, saying: 'I wished that love were gathered entirely... And thrown into my heart and the chest splits. What is in my heart of desire does not end... Nor my joy in love, or life ends.' I said: 'O young man, does this Structure (Kaaba) not have a sanctity that prevents you from this speech?' He said: 'Yes, by Allah, but love filled my heart so I wished for death. By Allah, what is in my heart of it does not please me (to exchange) for what the Commander of the Faithful has of kingship. I pray that Allah establishes it in my heart for my life and makes it my bedfellow in my grave, whether I know of it or not. This is my prayer, and for it I aimed, and in it I desired from what Allah gives the rest of His creation.' Then he passed on. I say: I mentioned here what Al-Akhtal said when Abd al-Malik blamed him for wine. He said: 'I wonder what pleases you in it... Its beginning is bitterness and its end is a headache.' He said: 'But between them, by Allah, is a euphoria I would not sell for your Caliphate, O Commander of the Faithful.' The poet took it and said: 'If the beginning of wine is hateful... Or the end of wine is a headache. Then it has between this and that trifles... Describing them with joy will not be possible.' As for what came in its dispraise and the spreading of its poison, it is more than can be counted. How many a rich man it left a pauper, and an owner a slave, as was said: 'He remained from the excess of his love a slave (Mamluk)... While he was before that a king (Malik). The fawns of the palace left him a youth... Wandering on the ground, left alone.' These verses are by one of the kings of Andalusia, and their mention will come in the second chapter of this book, God willing. How many a lover wasted on his beloved his wealth, honor, and soul, and lost his family and the interests of his religion and world, and fell into what he refuses. Yes, by Allah. 'And love drags souls to destruction... By nature, and oh my envy for the one who did not love.'

They said: How many a lover fled from love to positions of destruction to escape destruction by destruction. Regarding this is the story of Di'bil the poet. He said: I was at the frontier when the call to arms was sounded. I went out with the people, and there was a youth dragging his spear before me. He turned and looked at me and said: 'Are you Di'bil?' I said: 'Yes.' He said: 'Listen to me,' then recited: 'I am in my matter rightly guided... Between love and jihad. My body raids an enemy... And desire raids my heart.' Then he said: 'What do you think?' I said: 'Good, by Allah.' He said: 'By Allah, I did not go out except fleeing from love.' Then he fought until he was killed. Al-Wawa al-Dimashqi said: 'The path of desire is rugged and the sweet of desire is bitter... And the cold of desire is heat and the day of desire is an age.' Another said: 'Love is a distraction from every righteous deed... And a drunkenness of love negates the drunkenness of slumber.' Abd al-Muhsin al-Suri said: 'What is with me started as jest... But when it took hold, it became madness. I used to think desire was easy... Then I encountered from it a humiliating punishment.' Muhammad al-Yazidi said: 'How can people bear describing desire... While it is majestic and has no measure? Rather, how can love be pure for the ally of desire... When in it are separation and abandonment?' How excellent is the saying of Abdullah bin Isbat al-Qayrawani: 'The empty one said desire is impossible... So I said: If you tasted it, you would know it. He said: Is it other than occupying a heart... If you do not please it, you dismiss it? And is it other than a sigh and a tear... If you do not want its flow, you stop it? I said: After every description... You did not know love when you described it.' Note: 'Hawa' (Desire) is mostly used for blameworthy love. Allah Almighty said: "But as for he who feared the position of his Lord and prevented the soul from [unlawful] inclination (Hawa), then indeed, Paradise will be [his] refuge." It may be used for praiseworthy love in a restricted usage, and from it is the Hadith: "None of you believes until his desire (hawah) is in accordance with what I have brought." Ibn Abbas said: Hawa is a worshipped god, and he recited: 'Have you seen he who has taken as his god his desire (hawah)?' So it is summarized from the Noble Verse and the Noble Hadith that Hawa is divided into two types: Praiseworthy Hawa, which is in goodness and righteousness, and Blameworthy Hawa, which is in evil and corruption. In the book 'Al-Sahl al-Muati fi Fada'il Ibn Mamati': Some Sufis said: It was named Hawa (Desire/Falling) because it makes its owner fall (yahwi) into the Fire. I said: If he had said it makes its owner fall into the Abyss (Hawiyah), it would have been more appropriate. Some said Hawa is Hwan (Humiliation) with the Nun added, as was said: 'So I asked her with a signal about her state... And against me regarding her the slanderers have eyes. She sighed deeply and said: What is Hawa... Except Hwan (Humiliation) with the Nun removed from it.' And His Almighty saying: "He adhered to the earth and followed his desire (hawah)." It was said adhered to the earth means he settled to it and descended by his nature upon it, so his soul was earthly and lower, not heavenly and upper. According to how much the servant adheres to the earth, he descends from the sky. Sahl said: Allah apportioned for the limbs from desire a share for each limb. If a limb among them inclines to desire, its harm returns to the heart. The soul has seven heavenly veils and seven earthly veils. Whenever the servant buries his soul earth by earth, his heart ascends sky by sky. If he buries the soul under the soil, his heart reaches the Throne. The result of the issue is that Love and Desire are the root of every calamity, and in it is the humiliation of every proud soul. The Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "It is not fitting for a man to humiliate himself." Imam Ahmad said its interpretation is to expose himself to affliction he cannot bear. This corresponds to the state of the lover, for he humiliated himself for his beloved, as was said: 'Submit and lower yourself to whom you love, for there is not in... The law of desire a nose that is raised and knotted.' Another said: 'Poor represent the people of love, even their graves... Upon them is the dust of humiliation among the graves.' Sheikh Sharaf al-Din bin al-Farid said: 'It is Love, so submit your heart; desire is not easy... So no one exhausted by it chose it while he has a mind. And live empty, for love's comfort is fatigue... Its beginning is sickness and its end is killing.' Its beginning is sickness and its end is killing. Chapter Five: People's disagreement on whether it is involuntary or voluntary. I say: This is a section we established for what was previously mentioned, and its dawn shone like the morning. For people have speech regarding it from both sides and swagger between the two ranks. One saying it is involuntary and one saying it is voluntary. Each of the laws has a pleasant face...

...and a preponderant amount. We mention of that what benefit is general, and speak of its length and width by the fathom and cubit. Of that is what Judge Abu Amr Muhammad bin Ahmad al-Nawfani said in his book 'Tuhfat al-Zurraf': Lovers are excused in every case, forgiven for all words and deeds, for Love only struck them without choice, rather it afflicted them by compulsion and force. A person is only blamed for matters he is capable of, not in what is decreed. Upon him be blessings and peace: 'She lays down her burden.' How do you see this one, did she lay it down by choice from her was that, or by compulsion? No, indeed by compulsion and loss of ability. This is something in which there is no doubt nor confusion, nor does its opposite flutter in a heart. I said: It came in the interpretation of His saying Almighty: "And when they saw him, they greatly admired him (akbarnahu)," meaning they saw him as great in their eyes. It was said they menstruated out of astonishment. Ibn Abbas said they emitted semen and sperm out of astonishment, and cut their hands thinking they were cutting the citrons, and did not feel pain from cutting their hands due to the ignition of their hearts with his beauty. Wahb said: They were forty women, and nine of them died out of passion for Joseph and grief over him. How excellent is the saying of one of the Banu Udhra, when an Arab said to him: 'What is with one of you dying of love in desire for a woman he is familiar with? This is but weakness of soul, softness, and frailty found in you, O Banu Udhra.' He said: 'By Allah, if you saw the arched eyebrows above the large black eyes, beneath which are the spaced teeth, you would have taken them as Al-Lat and Al-Uzza.' Al-Fudayl bin Iyad said: 'If Allah granted me an answered prayer, I would pray to Allah with it to forgive the lovers, because their movements are involuntary, not voluntary.' Abu al-Sa'ib al-Makhzumi, who was a man of knowledge and religion, was seen clinging to the curtains of the Kaaba saying: 'O Allah, have mercy on lovers and strengthen their hearts, and incline the hearts of the beloveds towards them.' He was asked about that. He said: 'By Allah, praying for them is better than an Umrah from Al-Ji'ranah.' Then he recited: 'O Abandonment, desist from desire and leave desire... For lovers to be pleasant, O Abandonment. What do you want from those whose eyelids... Are ulcerated and the stuffing of their hearts is ember? Withered from desire, their colors... From what their hearts hide are yellow. And the flowing tears upon their cheeks... Are pearls overflowing as if they are rain.' It appears that his saying 'better than an Umrah from Al-Ji'ranah' is what emboldened Al-Fath bin Khaqan to say in verses: 'O lover, tormented, have patience... For the sins of the people of desire are forgiven. A sigh in desire puts down more sin... Than a ghazwa (raid) and an accepted Hajj.' I said: He exaggerated in this speech until he deserved blame. Would that he sufficed with what was said in representation: 'Although I am content to bear desire... And be free of it, neither against me nor for me.' It appears that what drove him to this is what Al-Shafi'i held, that the one who dies of love is among the martyrs, due to the Hadith reported regarding that, and its mention will come in the Chapter of Chastity, God willing. Al-Tamimi said in his book 'Imtizaj al-Arwah' (Mixing of Spirits): Some doctors were asked about Love. They said that its occurrence to its people is not by their choice nor by their greed for it, nor is there pleasure for most of them in it, but its occurrence to them is like the occurrence of debilitating ailments and destructive diseases. He said: There is no difference between it and that. Al-Mada'ini said: A man blamed a man from the people of desire. He said: 'If the one who desired had a choice, he would not desire, but the one who desired has no choice.' They said: Love is a type of torment, and a rational person does not choose torment for himself. Regarding this, Al-Mu'ammil said: 'Looking on the day of Al-Hirah cured Al-Mu'ammil... Would that Al-Mu'ammil had not been created with sight. Suffice the lovers in the world their torment... By Allah, Hellfire will not torment them afterwards.' It is told that he attained what he wished, for he went blind after his saying. Abu Muhammad bin Hazm said: A man said to Umar bin Al-Khattab: 'O Commander of the Faithful, I saw a woman and fell in love with her.' Umar said: 'That is of what cannot be controlled.' Kamil said regarding Salma: 'They blame me for the love of Salma as if... They see desire as something I wished for intentionally. Lo, indeed the Love that cracked the vitals... Is a decree from the Merciful testing the servant.' Sheikh Shams al-Din Ibn Qayyim al-Jawziyya said: Many of the predecessors interpreted His saying Almighty: "Our Lord, and do not burden us with that which we have no ability to bear" as Love (Ishq). They did not intend restriction by this, but representation, and that Love is among the burdens that cannot be borne. The burdening meant here is the Predestined Burdening, not the Legislative Command Burdening. End of his words.

Ubayd Allah bin Tawus said regarding His saying Almighty: "And mankind was created weak." He said: If he looks at women, he does not have patience. Sufyan bin Sa'id reported it from him in his Tafsir. They said: We have seen groups of lovers circulating around those who pray for them that Allah heals them from Love. Had it been voluntary, they would have removed it from their souls. From this, the error of many blamers becomes clear, and it appears that their blaming of this state is like blaming a sick person for his sickness. How excellent is the saying of some: 'O my blamer, while the matter is in His hand... Why did you not blame while the matter was in my hand?' Indeed, blame should be before this disease attaches to the heart and the tears of the pouring lover pour forth. A group of doctors and others held that it is voluntary, not involuntary. It was previously mentioned in the definition of Love mentioned by Ibn Sina and others that it is an obsessive disease a person brings upon himself by focusing his thought on the approval of certain forms and characteristics. This is a declaration from them that the human is the chooser in Love by focusing his thought which falls into the seas of his drunkenness. They said: Because Love (Mahabbah) is a strong will, and a servant is praised and blamed for his will; for this reason, the one desiring good is praised even if he does not do it. Allah Almighty dispraised those who love that immorality should spread among those who believe, and informed that their punishment is painful. Had Love not been owned, He would not have threatened them with punishment for what does not enter under their ability. From it is His saying Almighty: "And forbade the soul from desire (Hawa)." It is impossible that a human forbids himself from what does not enter under his ability. They said: Rational people entirely agree on blaming the one who loves what harms him by his love. This is a nature Allah created creation upon. If he excused himself saying 'I do not own my heart', they would not accept an excuse from him. I said: The correct saying in which there is no rejection nor turning away from a beloved is the detailed explanation. It is that Love varies according to the variation of humans and what they are created upon of subtlety, thinness of sides, thickness of liver, hardness of heart, aversion of natures, and other things. Among them are those who, if they see a beautiful image, die from the intensity of what arrives upon their heart of astonishment, as preceded regarding the women who died when they saw Joseph, peace be upon him. Mus'ab bin al-Zubayr used to be such that if a woman saw him, she would be overwhelmed by his beauty. The poet says of him: 'Mus'ab is but a meteor from Allah... By whose light the darkness is revealed.' Among them are those who, if they see a beautiful person, fall from their stature and do not know their sandal from their turban. The poet said: 'It is only that he sees her suddenly... So his legs knock together and he falls to the side.' This one and his likes, his love is involuntary, and disputing it is stubbornness against the tangible. Among them are those whose beginning of love is approval of the person, then a will to be close to him occurs to him, then affection (Mawaddah) which is that he wishes he possessed him, then affection strengthens and becomes love (Mahabbah), then becomes intimacy (Khullah), then becomes desire (Hawa), then becomes passionate love (Ishq), then becomes enslavement (Tatayyum). Tatayyum is a state where the beloved becomes the owner of the lover. Then enslavement increases and becomes bewilderment (Walah). Walah is exiting the limit of arrangement and the suspension of discrimination. This one and his likes, the beginning of his love is voluntary because it was possible for him to repel that and cut off its material. However, this type also, if it ends with its owner where we mentioned, becomes involuntary, as the poet said: 'Love is first jest... Then when it becomes established, it becomes a busy occupation.' For this reason, some philosophers said: I have not seen a truth more resembling falsehood nor a falsehood more resembling truth than Love. Its jest is serious and its seriousness is jest. Its beginning is play and its end is destruction. The poet said: 'He became fond of love until he loved... When he became independent with it, he could not bear it. He saw a depth he thought was a wave... When he became established in it, he drowned.' The author of 'Rawdat al-Muhibbin' said: This is like drunkenness with drinking wine. For taking the intoxicant is voluntary, and what is generated from it of drunkenness is involuntary. So whenever the cause occurs by his choice, he is not excused in what is generated from it without his choice. There is no doubt that continuing the look and sustaining the thought is like drinking the intoxicant, so he is blamed for the cause. For this reason, if love occurs for a non-prohibited reason, its owner is not blamed for it, like one who loved his wife or slave girl then separated from her, and her love remained inseparable from him. This one is not blamed for that, as in the famous story of Mughith and Barira. It has appeared by this that Love is sometimes involuntary and sometimes voluntary, and that is according to the perfection of the lover as preceded. Thus, the claim of the one who said it is absolutely involuntary or absolutely voluntary is not accepted by those of intellect. And Allah Almighty knows best. I say: And here ends the speech on these chapters whose time was pleasant and moderate, and by which the red of shame appeared in the cheek of the rose. Nothing remains but to enter the Chapters in the suggested manner and bring what Allah Almighty opens, and whoever knocks on the door of a Generous One, it opens. Chapter One: Mention of Beauty and Comeliness.

And what has been said about them in detail and summary. I say: We established this chapter to speak on Beauty and its divisions, and the beloved and his speech. Especially if he smiles revealing bubbles (of teeth/saliva), and the cold (freshness) ripples in his mouth. So his kissed place becomes sweet, and his beauty is equal in the present, his past, and his future. There, he encompasses of Beauty the two divisions which are the Apparent and the Hidden, the Departing and the Resident. The Hidden Beauty is praiseworthy for itself, like knowledge, skill, generosity, and courage. The Apparent Beauty is what appears of the branch of his moist stature, and his face which surpassed the full moon without the absence of the sun at sunset. At that point, he gloats over the full moon with his beauty marks (shamat), and says to his cheek which increased in beauty by them: Whoever increases, Allah increases his good deeds (hasanat). Therefore, it was said: Pure Beauty is what makes mouths speak with glorification (Tasbih). It was said rather it is as was said: 'Something by which mankind is tempted other than what is claimed as beauty, and I do not know what it is.' I say: And this is the correct view because its essence is not known nor its semblance recognized. So it is as if it is an idea that cannot be defined, and an unknown that is not known. Therefore, some said: Beauty has a meaning that expression cannot reach nor description encompass. It was said Beauty (Husn) is derived from Hasana (Good deed). I say: It appears that for this meaning beauty marks (Shamat) were called Hasanat (Good deeds/marks). Some said regarding a beautiful black woman: 'O Lord, a black woman reveals... By her beauty, the darknesses. What do they fault in seeing her... When all of her is Hasanat (Good deeds/marks)?' I said: 'And a face whose luster vanished so... Its beauties became defects with his beard. Unlucky with beauty marks, he became... So his Hasanat are nothing but sins (Dhunub/Tails).' It was said Beauty is a matter composed of things: brightness, morning-like fairness, good formation, planning, and blood-color in the skin. It was said Beauty is the proportion of creation, its moderation, and its straightness. Many a form is proportionate in creation but not much in beauty. Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, said: 'If the whiteness of a woman is complete with the goodness of her hair, then her beauty is complete.' Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, said: 'Whiteness is half of beauty.' They said regarding a slave girl: 'Jamila' (Beautiful) from afar, 'Maliha' (Pretty/Salty) from near. The Jamila is the one who takes the whole of your sight, but if she nears you she is not so. The Maliha is the one who, whenever you repeat your sight on her, increases you in appreciation of beauty. It was said Jamila implies fatness, from Jamal (Camel) which is fat. Maliha is also from Mulha which is whiteness. And Sabihah (Morning-like) likewise from Subh (Morning) due to its whiteness. Some said: Wit is in the stature, skill in the neck, thinness in the extremities and waist, and the whole matter is in speech. The best beauty is what is not brought by adornment. Imru' al-Qais said: 'I found goodness in her even if she did not wear perfume.' Another said: 'The Maliha is she whom her jewelry adorns... Not she who became adorned by her jewelry.' Some philologists said: Arabs say sweetness is in the eyes, prettiness (Malaha) in the mouth, beauty (Jamal) in the nose, and wit (Zarf) in the tongue. From it is the saying of Al-Hasan, may Allah be pleased with him: 'If the thief is witty, his hand is not cut,' meaning if he falls, he defends himself with the fluency of his tongue and logic. How excellent is the saying of some: The body contains the face and the extremities. In the face are the beauties, and towards them is the aspiration. In the beauties are the points (Nuqat) which are the utmost in approval and wit. Like Malaha in the eye, and the point of Malaha is Da'aj (Intense blackness with whiteness). And like Hasan in the mouth, and the point of Hasan is Falaj (Gap between teeth). And like Talawa (Grace) in the forehead, and the point of Talawa is Balaj (Separation of eyebrows/brightness). And like Rawnaq (Luster) in the cheek, and the point of the cheek is Darih (Smoothness/Transparency). What is considered beautiful in a woman are four long things: her extremities, her stature, her hair, and her neck. And four short things: her hands, her feet, her tongue, and her eyes. The meaning of this moral shortness is that she does not squander what is in her husband's house, does not leave her house, does not chatter with her tongue, and does not covet with her eye. And four white things: her color, her parting (of hair), her teeth (Thaghr), and the white of her eye. And four black things: her eyelashes, her eyebrows, her eyes, and her hair. And four red things: her tongue, her cheek, and her lips with dark red hue (La's) and mingling of her whiteness with redness. And four thick things: her leg, her wrist, her buttocks, and what is there. And four wide things: her forehead, her brow, her eye, and her chest. And four tight things: her mouth, her nostril, her ear canal, and what is there, which is the greatest intent from a woman. It was said a slave girl was found in the time of the Sassanids with all these mentioned attributes. How worthy she was that it be said in her right: 'If Azza judged the sun of the forenoon... In beauty before a successful judge, he would judge for her.' It is told that Ya'sur, one of the kings of China, gifted to Kisra Anushirwan, the King of Persia, a gift including a slave girl who disappears in her hair and glitters with beauty. So Kisra sent him a gift including a slave girl seven cubits tall, her eyelashes striking her cheeks, as if between her eyelids was the flash of lightning, with joined eyebrows, having braids she drags when she walks.

Section: The author of 'Rawdat al-Muhibbin' said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, used to call people to inner beauty through outer beauty, as Jarir bin Abdullah said. Umar bin Al-Khattab used to call him the Joseph of this Ummah. He said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said to me: "You are a man whose creation Allah has made beautiful." Some wise men said: A servant should look every day in the mirror; if he sees his image is beautiful, he should not mar it with his ugly deed. And if he sees it ugly, he should not combine ugliness of form and deed. Some have put this into verse saying: 'O beautiful of face, beware of ugly deeds... Do not spoil the adornment with disgrace. And O ugly of face, be a doer of good... Do not combine two uglinesses.' Since beauty is, by its nature, beloved to souls and magnified in hearts, Allah did not send a Prophet except beautiful of face, noble of lineage, and good of voice, as Ali bin Abi Talib said when asked: 'Was the face of the Messenger, peace be upon him, like a sword?' He said: 'No, but like the moon.' In his description, peace be upon him: 'As if the sun runs in his face.' He was as his poet Hassan bin Thabit said: 'Whenever his forehead appears in the pitch-black darkness... It shines like the lamp of the blazing darkness. So who was or who might be like Ahmad... An order for truth or a punishment for an aggressor.' He also said: 'More beautiful than you my eye has never seen... And more perfect than you women have not given birth to. You were created free from every defect... As if you were created as you wished.' Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with him, used to say when he saw him: 'Trustworthy, chosen, calling to good... Like the light of the full moon when darkness leaves it.' Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, used to recite Zuhair's verse when he saw him: 'If you were anything other than a human... You would be the illuminator of the night of the full moon.' Aisha looked at him one day then smiled. He asked her about that. She said: 'It is as if Abu Kabir al-Hudhali meant you by his saying: And if you looked at the lines of his face... They flashed like the lightning of the pouring cloud.' In summary, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was at the highest peak of beauty. It was narrated that some Companions met a monk who said: 'Describe Muhammad to me as if I am looking at him, for I saw his description in the Torah and the Gospel.'
