He said: 'He was not excessively tall nor short above medium height, white in color imbued with redness, curly haired not frizzy, his hair reaching the lobe of his ear, solid forehead, distinct eyebrows, black-eyed, aquiline nosed, with spaced front teeth, as if his neck were a silver pitcher, his face like the circle of the moon.' So the monk embraced Islam. He, peace be upon him, with this beauty, had love and awe cast upon him; whoever's eyes fell upon him loved him and held him in awe. Allah Almighty completed for him the ranks of perfection outwardly and inwardly, so he was the best of Allah's creation in form and character, image and meaning. Likewise was Joseph, peace be upon him. Rabi'a said: 'Beauty was divided into two halves; between Sarah and Joseph was half of beauty, and half of beauty was between the rest of people.' In the Sahih from him, peace be upon him, that he saw Joseph on the Night of Isra and he had been given half of beauty. The Prophet, peace be upon him, appreciated that a messenger be handsome of face and good of name. He used to say: 'If you send a messenger, let him be handsome of face, good of name.' Al-Khara'iti narrated from the Hadith of Ibn Jurayj from Abu Mulayka raising it: 'Whoever Allah gives a handsome face and a good name and places him in a position not disgraceful to him, he is among Allah's chosen of His creation.' Wahb said: David said: 'O Lord, which of your servants is most beloved to You?' He said: 'A believer of handsome form.' He said: 'Which of your servants is most hateful to You?' He said: 'A disbeliever of ugly form.' It is mentioned from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, had a group of his companions waiting for him at the door, so he began looking in the mirror (or water vessel) and smoothing his hair and beard, then went out to them. She said: 'O Messenger of Allah, even you do this?' He said: 'Yes. If a man goes out to his brothers, let him beautify himself, for Allah is Beautiful and loves Beauty.' Mu'awiyah said to a man who entered upon him, seeing in his face something he disliked which could be removed: 'What prevents one of you, when he leaves his house, from attending to the skin of his face?'

Section: His Almighty saying: "We have certainly created man in the best of stature (Taqwim)." Meaning in the best adjustment of his stature and image, and goodness of his appearance, upright, eating his food with his hand, adorned with intellect, not like animals. Regarding this is the story of Al-Rashid when he was alone with his wife on a moonlit night. He said to her: 'If you are not more beautiful than this moon, then you are divorced.' The scholars of his time issued a fatwa that the oath was broken (divorce occurred), except Yahya bin Aktham, for he said: 'Divorce does not fall upon him.' It was said to him: 'You contradicted your sheikhs.' He said: 'The fatwa is by knowledge, and One who is more knowledgeable than us has given a fatwa on it, and He is Allah Almighty where He said: "We have certainly created man in the best of stature."' The interpretation of His saying Almighty "He increases in creation what He wills" came as the beautiful voice and the beautiful face. For this reason, Abu Firas said: 'He surpassed the moon of the sky in beauty... While people in his love are equal. So his Lord increased him with cheek-hair (Idhar)... By which beauty and splendor were completed. Do not wonder, our Lord is Capable... He increases in creation what He wills.' It was told about a woman who used to pray much at night. She was asked about that. She said: 'It beautifies the face, and I love that my face be beautified.' It is told that Al-Ma'mun reviewed an army. A hideous man passed by, so he asked him to speak and found him stuttering. He ordered him dropped. He said: 'If the soul's effect falls on the exterior, it is fairness (Sabaha), and if its effect falls on the interior, it is eloquence (Fasaha). This man has neither exterior nor interior.' But a person has two judgments: One from the side of his body, which is his appearance, and the other from the side of his soul, which is his substance. They often accompany each other. Therefore, physiognomists finished knowing the states of the soul from the bodily form, to the point that some wise men said: 'Rarely is a beautiful form found governed by a bad soul.' He, peace be upon him, said: 'Seek needs from those with beautiful faces.' All this indicates that beauty and physical perfection are virtues. Indicates it His saying Almighty: "And He increased him extensively in knowledge and body." Beauty is the first happiness of man because Allah Almighty, by the subtlety of His wisdom, did not create a form with chosen attributes, safe from defects, except that He added to it what suits it of intellect and attributes. Rarely do you find character except following creation (physical form), a consistent proportion, a principle that does not reverse, and a consensus that does not isolate. Allah never created a Prophet except that he dazzled the people of his time with his beauty and benevolence. If you look at him the first time, you see him the best of them in form and the most perfect in structure. He is the worthiest of rank and the highest in merit. He, peace be upon him, said: 'Allah does not punish the beautiful of faces, the black of eyes.' Imam Fakhr al-Din al-Razi said in 'Asrar al-Tanzil' summarized: Beauty of form, although it is a desired matter, beauty of conduct (Sirah) is among the demands of wisdom. There is no doubt that wisdom is better than desire, so beauty of conduct is better than beauty of form inevitably. Among that is that Joseph, peace be upon him, combined beauty of form and beauty of conduct. Then, because of beauty of form, he fell into types of calamities. Among them is that his father loved him more than his brothers, evidenced by His saying: "When they said, 'Joseph and his brother are more beloved to our father than we.'" So they intended to kill him, evidenced by His recounting of them: "Kill Joseph or cast him out to some [other] land; the face of your father will be yours alone." Among them is that he fell due to beauty into the captivity of slavery, the seduction of the Aziz's wife, and his entering prison because of that. But when the King knew after that his beauty of conduct, he chose him for himself and said to him: "Indeed, you are today established, trusted," and did not say "fair, pretty." This indicates that beauty of conduct is better than beauty of form. It is known that beauty of form only remains for a few days, whereas beauty of conduct, its effect does not vanish nor its result become void. I say: Among those who were harmed because of their beautiful form was Nasr bin Hajjaj. That is because Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, passed by at night and heard a woman saying: 'Is there a way to wine so I may drink it... Or is there a way to Nasr bin Hajjaj?' So he called for Nasr bin Hajjaj, who was from Banu Sulaym, and saw him as the most beautiful of people in face and having beautiful hair. So he shaved his hair, but he was more beautiful without hair. He said: 'Do not live with me in a city.' Nasr pleaded with him not to expel him from Medina, but Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, did not accept. When Nasr bid him farewell, he said to him: 'O Commander of the Faithful, you have sentenced me to kill myself.' Umar said: 'How is that?' He said: 'Allah Almighty said: "And if We had decreed upon them, 'Kill yourselves' or 'Leave your homes'." So He coupled this with this.' Umar said: 'You are not far off, but I say what Shu'ayb, peace be upon him, said: "I only intend reform as much as I am able. And my success is not but through Allah." I have doubled your stipend for you so that may be a compensation for you.' I say: I remembered by his shaving of his hair 'but he was more beautiful without hair' the saying of some in that: 'They shaved his head to increase him in ugliness... Out of jealousy from them over him and stinginess.

'It was a morning over which was a pitch-black night... So they erased his night and left him as morning.' How excellent is the saying of Al-Siraj Al-Warraq regarding a handsome Qalandari: 'I loved from his saliva a wine... While he had at that time no mustache. O Qalandar, they shaved an eyebrow... Of his like the Nun of calligraphy from a scribe. A Sultan of beauty increased in his justice... So he chose to remain without a doorman (Hajib/Eyebrow).' Ibn Sana' al-Mulk said: 'I imitated my body towards you... So did you fall in love with your beauty? Your eyelid was exhausting... So you became entirely your eyelid. And the illness increased you in beauty... By Allah, indeed you are you.' Section: It has been mentioned what is admired in a woman. Let us mention here what poets said in comparing body parts to letters, for they did much of that. They compared the eyebrow to the Nun, the eye and temple curl to the Waw, the mouth to the Mim and Sad, the teeth to the Sin, and the braided forelock to the Shin. Among the best said in that is the saying of Mahasin al-Shawwa: 'He let down a lock (Far') and twisted, deserting me, a temple curl (Sudgh)... So he exhausted a describer with both. So I thought that one, due to his creation, a snake... Striving, and this a scorpion stopping. Possessor of an Alif not for union, and possessor of a Waw... But not the Conjunction (Atifah).' And the saying of another: 'Ya-Sin is her forelock and Sad is her eyes... I seek refuge for her with Surah Ta-Ha.' And the saying of Ibn Matruh: 'The Alif of the cheek-hair on his cheek told us... In the Mim of his mouth is the cure for the thirsty.' And the saying of Ibn Naqada: 'He gathered beauty, so a Sad from her eye... And the Nun is her eyebrow dotted with a mole. And the Mim is her mouth, so the letters combined... Written, and patience regarding them is scraped off.' And the saying of another: 'Do not say No to me, for it is written on... Your face radiating with light: Yes (Na'am - Nun, Ain, Mim). With letters formed by decree... Upon which a pen never ran. Its Nun is the eyebrow, and the Ain (Eye) is... Your enchanting glance, and the Mim is the mouth.' Shihab al-Din Ahmad bin al-Khaymi said: 'Indeed the temple curl of the beloved and the mouth and the cheek... From him are Waw, Sad, and Lam (W-S-L = Wasl/Union). It is a union between beauties when... It completed beauty, and with the cheek-hair is the completion (Tamam). Except that I see it as a union of farewell... Leading to our separation and peace (Salam).' I said: 'A beloved who came high when I described him... And the spear of his stature said: What stands? And the line of my cheek-hair dotted the Lam of the mole... And I did not know that the Lam in script is dotted.' I also said: 'He gazes at me with an eye whose eyebrow is a Nun... Like the bow piercing the targets while it twangs.' I also said, in the reverse of this meaning—which is comparing letters to body parts—in evaluating a poem with which I praised our Master the Sultan Al-Malik Al-Nasir Hasan: 'How many an Alif in it became... A slender stature, fresh? And how many a Shin in the margin of the... Book you imagine as a forelock? And an Ain became in the eye... Like the gold and the silver.' I also said: In evaluating a letter that arrived from some loved ones from a missive he opened with a poem, of which is: 'I rejected sleep after you, O Ali... So do not wonder at my tears that they followed in succession. And a letter came to me from you, high... Its Alifs resembled the long brown spears. How much handwriting I have seen, but... Your example, I have not seen an example like it. Softness by which the Alifs became willow branches... So how many a union in it guaranteed Union (Wisal)? And how many an Alif in it appeared for union... Like the Ban tree branch in softness and moderation. Its Lam embraces it sometimes right... And at times embraces it left. I thought the Lam in it was the cheek-hair of a cheek... And I imagined the dots above the cheek were moles. And the rising of the Ta's in it became... Teaching its softness the branch of perfection.' Judge Al-Fadil said in a letter he wrote to Muwaffaq al-Din Khalid al-Qayrawani, having seen a letter of his written in gold, part of it: 'From Alifs whose branches the Hamzas habitually frequent like doves. And from Lams after which the lover envies them for embracing their soft statures. And from Sads that quenched the thirst of thirsty hearts and hovering eyes. And from Waws that reminded of what is in the surface of temple curls of bends. And from Mims to whose mouth mouths drew near to obtain the harvest of sips. And from Sins like the teeth in those mouths. And from Dals indicating obedience to their writer by the bending of backs. And from Jims like beaks hunting hearts that flutter for the frights of approval like birds. In it is what souls desire and eyes delight in. And Khalid is therein eternal (Khalid), and his greeting therein is praiseworthy (Mahamid), and his hand strikes in melting gold while people strike in cold iron.'

Chapter Two: Mention of Lovers and Wits among Kings and Caliphs. I say: We established this chapter to mention the best of kings in nature, the longest of them in reach, the most pleasant of them in living, the most frivolous of them, the softest of them in poetry, the most precise of them in thought, the nearest of them in return, and the most fond of the beloved among them. For they are, in reality, the most worthy of people for that, and the most deserving of sleeping on those couches. That is according to what their souls seduced them with and their sitting companion adorned for them, as was said: 'Do not ask about the man, but ask about his companion... For every companion imitates the one he accompanies. If you are among people, accompany the best of them... And do not accompany the worst, lest you perish with the destroyed.' Among them are those who were content regarding their beloved with looking... Until he died of grief and joined the likes of Nur al-Din the Martyr among the martyrs. His story will come in the Chapter of Chastity, God willing. Among them are those who became less than him in chastity, and set up the saliva of his beloved in the place of wine. Among them are those who cast off restraint and argued with the saying of the poet regarding liquor: 'Leave off blaming me, for blame is incitement... And treat me with that which was the disease.' So he combined the possessor of necklaces (woman) and the daughter of the bunch (wine), but with maintenance (of dignity) and return to religion. He, even if the session was long for him, shortened it, and if he committed a crime in it against his beloved, he apologized, as was said: 'If I committed a sin while drunk... Then pardon me, O rest of souls. What mind remains there for one like me... Between the drunkenness of passion and the drunkenness of wine?' Among them are those who attained with wine the forbidden pleasure, and brought out by it the cheek of the beloved from an image to an image. So he raced the drinking companion in the crimson wine, and ascended to the beloved like the ascent of bubbles of water, state upon state. This led him to his destruction and the corruption of his kingdom, as happened to Al-Amin son of Al-Rashid and others. Al-Rabi' said: Al-Amin sat one day for the people wearing a blue shawl with a white felt under it. He signed eight hundred petitions. By Allah, he hit the mark and did not err, and was fast and did not slow down. Then he said: 'O Rabi', do you see me not good at management and politics? But I found smelling myrtle, drinking the cup, and lying down without slumber more desirable to me than meeting people.' Likewise, Al-Walid bin Yazid cast off restraint before him, and Al-Mutawakkil after him, and others among the Caliphs and Princes who preferred the comfort of the soul over the fatigue of politics. What I see is releasing what they went to explicitly, and separating from all on a beautiful face, as was said: 'If my blamer saw the face of a beloved... We would have separated on a beautiful face.' How excellent is the saying of Abu al-Fath al-Busti: 'If a king becomes occupied with amusement... Then judge upon his kingdom with woe and war. Do you not see the sun descending in Libra... When it became the sign of amusement and music (Tarab)?' From here we begin mentioning those who humbled themselves to their beloved among kings, so he became, despite being his owner, like the owned. They are in that, despite their severity, contrary to what people are upon. This and that is because Love and its people are ranks. Among them are those for whom Love is not pleasant except with humiliation, and this is dominant over lovers truthful in affection, as Sheikh Sharaf al-Din bin al-Farid said: 'Even if Love is mighty in it, my passion is humble... And were it not for humiliation in Love, I would have no glory.' As was said: 'Humble yourself to whom you desire to gain glory... For how much glory a man attained by humiliation.' Among them are those who see the unification of the beloved and the absence of a partner, as was said: 'There is no place in the heart for two beloveds... Nor can two manage the affair. Just as the Intellect is one and does not know... A Creator other than One, Merciful. So too the Heart is one and does not desire... Other than a single individual, distant or near. And so Religion is one, straight... And a disbeliever is one who has two religions. He is, in the law of affection, a polytheist... Far from the correctness of faith.' So whoever is contrary to this, seeing a partner in love like Al-Rashid and others as will be explained in his chapter, is not a lover in reality. This is dominant over kings due to the abundance of what they have and the variety of forms available to them, as was said: 'Move, for the pleasures of passion are in moving... And drink every pure (water), do not stop at one watering place.' For kings are not like others due to their ability over whom they love with ready cash and piled quintals of gold and silver. Yes, a great king may fall in love, but his love does not lead him to abandon the management of his kingdom. Rather, what appears most from the matter of kings is that they place their beloved in the station of their owner while they own him, as Al-Hakam bin Hisham, King of Andalusia, said: 'He remained from the excess of his love a slave (Mamluk)... While he was before that a king (Malik). The fawns of the palace left him a youth... Wandering on the ground, left alone... Placing the cheek upon soil...

...For the one who makes silk a couch... Thus humiliation becomes beautiful with the freeborn when passion is owned (Mamluk).' Al-Rashid said, having loved three slave girls: 'The three sociable ones possessed my rein... And settled in my heart in every place. Why does all creation obey me... While I obey them and they are in disobedience to me? That is only because the Sultan of Passion... And by it they became strong, is mightier than my Sultan.' Al-Musta'in Billah bin Al-Hakam Al-Umayyad, one of the Caliphs of the West (Andalusia), said and did well: 'Wonder! The lion fears the edge of my spear... And I fear the glance of languid eyelids. I fight terrors, not fearing... Anything from them except avoidance and abandonment. Three like statues possessed my soul... Radiant of faces, soft of bodies. I judged in them regarding consolation to Youth... So it judged with a Sultan against a Sultan. So they permitted the sanctuary of my heart and left me... In the glory of my kingdom like the suffering captive. Do not blame a king who humbled himself to Passion... The humiliation of Passion is glory and a second kingdom. What harm is it that I am their slave out of ardent love... While the sons of the time and they are my slaves?' I said: And how many like him, a conquering king and capable sultan... The heavens humble to his awe and the deadly ones submit to his power... Passion destroyed his pillars and humiliated his glory and authority. So his eyelid fell short in the long nights... And he fell with his mind, Beauty (Al-Hasan) in the captivity of detention. So he said: 'Does it not suffice you that you own me... And that all people are my slaves? And that if you cut off my hand and my foot... I would say out of satisfaction: You did well, increase it!' It was said they are by Al-Rashid, and it was said by Al-Ma'mun, and it was said by Al-Mahdi. Sheikh Athir al-Din Abu Hayyan said: Sultan Abu Abdullah Muhammad bin Sultan Al-Ghalib Billah, one of the kings of Andalusia, was beautiful, of good policy, appearing religious. I saw him repeatedly in Granada and recited poetry to him and attended the recitation of poets with him. Of his poetry: 'O mistress of the howdah who took away my asceticism... In any case, I must have you. Either by humiliation, which is more fitting for Passion... Or by might, which is more fitting for Kingship.' Al-Malik Al-Amjad said: 'Who is like me in my age... My gardener in my palace. My beloved is my slave... He sang to me from my poetry.' Al-Malik Al-Zahir said regarding his Mamluk Aybak the Jamdar: 'I am the owner (Malik) of a slave (Mamluk), a tender gazelle... And among the wonders is an owner owned (Mamluk). I am the youth, although I am, regarding his union... Among creation, a destitue pauper. How much blood I shed with a sword by force... And my blood by the sword of his glances is shed.' Al-Malik Al-Ashraf said regarding his Mamluk who was his treasurer, a Dubayt (couplet): 'I ransom a moon in whom description is confused... He is generous with my blood while he is a trustworthy trustee. What wonder! He guards my wealth and sees... My soul perishing by him and does not turn.' The rest of what he has of stanzas I mentioned in Chapter One of 'Naql al-Kiram fi Madh al-Maqam', and I also mentioned therein the story of his beloved, the son of his Mamluk, and what appeared in it of his good conduct, which is among the strangest tales told about kings. King Tamim said: 'By Allah, grant me a promise of truth... And leave this coquetry from you. And do not leave me complaining... The like of your face is not complained of.' It is told that Al-Ma'mun got angry at his slave girl 'Arib al-Mughanniyah', and he was fond of her. So he turned away from her and she turned away from him. Then passion handed him over and longing unsettled him until he sent to her asking for reconciliation. When they met, she did not pay attention to him, and he spoke to her but she did not answer. So he began reciting: 'Speak, speech does not hurt you... Nor does peace detract from your beauties. I am Al-Ma'mun and the Gallant King... But I am for your love a wandering admirer. You have the right not to kill me... So the people remain having no Imam.' She said to him: 'O Commander of the Faithful, your father the Commander of the Faithful Harun Al-Rashid was more of a lover than you where he says: "The three sociable ones possessed..." the aforementioned verses.' The completion of her story I mentioned in Chapter Two of 'Al-Sukardan', and it is a very pleasant story. Al-Ma'mun also saw one day a beautiful boy belonging to Ahmad bin Yusuf. He said: 'What is your name?' He said: 'Fath.' Al-Ma'mun said: 'O Fath, O opener (Fatih) of my tribulation... And O Knower of the length of my complaint. Praise be to Allah, no partner has He... Your master is my slave and you are my master.' That reached Ahmad, so he gifted the boy to him. I said: So it was as was said:

'Everything suitable for the Master... Is forbidden to the slave.' His father Al-Rashid sat one day with Zubaydah, and her slave girls were with her. He looked at a slave girl standing at her head and signaled her to kiss him. She excused herself with her lips. He called for an inkwell and paper and signed in it: 'I kissed her from afar. She excused herself with her lips.' Then he handed her the paper, and she signed in it: 'So I did not leave my place... Until I jumped upon him.' When he read what she wrote, he asked Zubaydah to give her to him, so she gave her. He went away with her and stayed with her for a week, their place unknown. Zubaydah wrote to him: 'A lover fond of his beloved... It is as if their two hearts are a heart. Their two spirits are a spirit and their two souls... Are a soul; thus let love be.' Abu Ja'far narrated saying: While Muhammad son of Zubaydah (Al-Amin) was walking in a palace of his, he passed by a slave girl of his who was drunk, wearing a silk shawl, dragging her skirts out of pride. He solicited her for herself. She said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, you have abandoned me for a period and I did not know of your coming. So grant me respite tonight until I prepare to meet you and I will come to you tomorrow.' When morning came, he waited for her but she did not come. He stood and entered upon her and asked her to fulfill the promise. She said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, did you not know that the speech of the night is erased by the day?' He laughed and went out of his council. He said: 'Who is at the door among the poets?' It was said to him: Mus'ab, Al-Raqashi, and Abu Nuwas. He ordered for them, so they entered. When they sat before him, he said: 'Let each one of you say a poem ending with "The speech of the night is erased by the day".' Al-Raqashi began saying: 'When will you sober up while your heart is flown... And stability is denied so there is no stability? And a young woman who does not visit nor is visited... Has left you a wandering admirer. If you ask her to fulfill the promise... The speech of the night is erased by the day.' Mus'ab said: 'Do you blame me while my heart is flown... Depressed, no stability settles for it? For the love of a pretty one who hunted my heart... With glances mixed with intense blackness. When I extended my hand to her... To touch her, aversion appeared from her. So I said to her: Promise me a promise... She said: Tomorrow is the visit from you. When I came demanding (fulfillment), she answered... The speech of the night is erased by the day.' Abu Nuwas said: 'And a maiden came in the palace drunk... But dignity adorned the drunkenness. The robe had fallen from her shoulders... From scratching, and the wrapper came loose. The wind shook heavy buttocks... And a branch on which were small pomegranates. I intended her, and the night was a cover... So an excuse rose for her regarding the meaning. She said: Tomorrow. So I went on until... The time came in which was the visit. I said: The promise, my mistress. She said... The speech of the night is erased by the day.' He said to him: 'Woe to you! Were you looking at us or were you the third of us in the palace?' He said: 'No, by Allah, O Commander of the Faithful, but I looked at you and knew what was in your soul and expressed what was in your conscience.' He ordered four thousand dirhams for him and the like for his two companions. I mentioned here what I said regarding Ibn Nahar (Son of Day): 'I say to my appointed time: Visit at night... He appeared like the full moon in it then vanished. The speech of the night, O Ibn Nahar, increases... When the sun rises upon it, it melts.' I said: 'Do you spend the night with eyelids quenched of slumber... While I spend the night awake regarding you with my night-companions? And you blame if I become, on the day of aversion... The Majnun of Laila regarding you, O Ibn Nahar?' It is told that Al-Mutawakkil had a boy named Shafi' who was one of the most beautiful youths. Al-Mutawakkil was madly in love with him. He wanted one day to drink with Husayn bin al-Dahhak and see what remained of his fame, as he had aged. He summoned him and gave him drink until he was drunk. He said to Shafi': 'Give him drink.' So he gave him drink and greeted him with a rose. Shafi' was wearing rose-colored clothes. Husayn extended his hand to Shafi's arm. Al-Mutawakkil said: 'Do you scratch the sole of my foot in my presence? How then if I were alone with him? How much you need discipline!' Al-Mutawakkil had winked at Shafi' to tease him. So he called for an inkwell and wrote: 'And like the red rose, he greeted with a flower... Of roses, walking in tunics like roses. I wished to be given a drink by his eyes... Reminding me of what I had forgotten of the covenant. May Allah water a time in which I did not spend a night... Empty, but with a beloved on a promise.' Then Shafi' gave it, and gave it to Al-Mutawakkil. He found it pleasant and said: 'You did well, O Husayn. If Shafi' were of those whose gifting is permissible, I would have gifted him to you. But by my life, O Shafi', be his cupbearer for the rest of our day.' And he ordered a lot of money for him. Shafi' used to write on the embroidery of his right coat: 'A full moon on a fresh branch... Soaked the upper chest with perfume.'

And he writes on the left embroidery: 'The page of his face was written... In the page of the illuminating moon.' Among the strange things told is that Yazid bin Abd al-Malik bin Marwan was enamored with Hababah his slave girl. He secluded himself one day in amusement with her and said: 'I will surely belie the saying of the one who said that time does not clear for anyone for a day.' He summoned his doorman and said to him: 'Do not allow anyone to enter upon me nor inform me of news, even if it involves the loss of my kingdom for the duration of this day.' He stayed with her in the most complete state. She took a pomegranate and choked on it, dying instantly. A bout of grief seized him, coming between him and patience. He forbade her burial until a group of Banu Umayya asked him to bury her and were gentle with him in that. So he ordered her burial and said: 'If the soul is consoled of you or leaves desire... Then by despair it is consoled of you, not by fortitude.' It was said he did not stay after her except seven days and died of sorrow over her. Similar to his action in not burying his beloved is what I recounted in 'Naql al-Kiram fi Madh al-Maqam' in Chapter Four about Sultan Jalal al-Din Khwarizm Shah. When his Mamluk Falaj died, he forbade his burial and he used to be carried with him in a litter. Whenever food was placed before him, he said: 'Carry this to Falaj.' Some Emirs said to him: 'O King, Falaj has died.' So he struck his neck. There is no power nor strength except in Allah. I mentioned the completion of his story in the mentioned book. Chapter Three: Mention of those who loved upon Hearsay and fell into conflict with the beloved. I say: We established this chapter to mention those who loved before seeing, so what happened happened when his tears flowed as they flowed. He became restless after having been content ('Qarir al-Ain'), and testified against his eyes regarding what they did not see. He was like one tasked to tie two barley grains. How many a night he danced upon hearing (Sama'), and a week of whose nights he stayed awake two, three, and four. He is of a class (different) from those who loved by touch or others of the remaining five senses. It appears that this is due to a resemblance between him and the beloved in the matter itself or a prior acquaintance in the World of Particles (Alam al-Dharr), as Sheikh Fath al-Din bin Sayyid al-Nas said in 'Al-Iqtibas': 'A love whose consolation time has not known... Flows to the soul or flows with the soul. It has no end, but its beginning is... A prior acquaintance in the Presence of Holiness. In the World of Particles the bringer of glad tidings confided it to me... Welcome to its pact, pure from filth. More desirable to the heart than safety in fear... And than the roaming of slumber in sleepy eyes.' My saying 'due to a resemblance between him and the beloved' etc., contains an indication that you do not find two who love each other except that there is resemblance and agreement between them in some attributes; this is inevitable. For this reason, Hippocrates took advantage when a man of deficiency described to him that he loved him. He said: 'He did not love me unless I agreed with him in some of his morals.' This is supported by the saying of the Prophet, peace be upon him, when he asked Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, about a woman who used to enter upon the women of Quraysh making them laugh. She arrived in Medina and stayed with a woman who made people laugh. He said: 'Upon whom did so-and-so descend?' She said: 'Upon so-and-so, the one who makes people laugh.' He said: 'Praise be to Allah, souls are conscripted soldiers; what they recognize of each other they coalesce with, and what they reject of each other they differ with.' Tarafa recited: 'The souls of men recognize each other if they meet... So among them is an enemy to be feared and a friend.' Abu al-Hudhail al-Allaf said: 'It is not permissible in the rotation of the sphere, nor in the composition of nature, nor in analogy, nor in sense, nor in the possible, nor in the necessary, that there be a lover towards whom his beloved has no inclination.' It appears that this is due to the secret we mentioned of the existence of resemblance between them. If you say: We have seen one who loved someone who does not love him nor turn to him. I say: Answers were mentioned for that, the best of which is to say Love is of two types: Type One: Purpose-driven love. Partnership is not required in this; rather, it is often met with the beloved's loathing and hatred for the lover, unless he has a purpose with him similar to his purpose, so he loves him for his purpose from him, as is between a man and a woman because each has a purpose with the companion. Type Two: Spiritual love, caused by resemblance and agreement between the two spirits. This cannot be but from both sides inevitably. If a lover with true love searched the heart of his beloved, he would find there love for him similar to his, or above it, or below it. Some mentioned that the cause of love is three things: either seeing a form, hearing a melody, or hearing a description. These three are the origin of the spring of love, as no one's love is devoid of relying on one of them. It has been said there are three loves: Love of attachment, love of flattery, and love that is killing. People's conditions differ in that. Among them are those who love by mere description without sighting, so he perishes for one described to him as a love, while he has not seen him, but a describer described him to him, as was said:

'I missed seeing the dwellings with my eye... So perhaps I see the dwellings with my ear.' Judge Al-Fadil took it and said: '...Distract me regarding Al-Sham (Damascus/Syria) with a mention, for my heart is full of longings for it. Memory represented it to my hearing as if... I walk there with my eyes.' Some wise men said that Allah Almighty made the Heart the commander of the body and the king of the limbs. All limbs submit to it, all senses obey it, it is their director, and by its will they emanate. Its vizier is the Intellect, its supporter is Understanding, its scout is the two Eyes, and its vanguard is the two Ears. They (Eyes and Ears) are equal in the chapter of transmission; they do not hide anything from it nor fold a secret from it. It was said to Plato: 'Which is more harmful, hearing or sight?' He said: 'They are to the heart like the two wings to the bird; it does not rise except with both of them, nor does it become independent except by their strength. Perhaps one is clipped, so it bears upon the other with fatigue and hardship.' It was said: 'So why does the blind man love without seeing, and the deaf man love without hearing?' He said to him: 'Therefore I said: The bird may rise with one of its wings but does not become independent in flight. If they gather, its going is more effective and its flight strong.' It used to be said: Love, its beginning is hearing then looking, just as the beginning of fire is smoke then sparks. It is told regarding Abu Tammam that he heard a slave girl singing in Persian, and her voice moved him. He said: 'I did not understand her meanings but... She moved my heart so I did not bear her moving. I was as if I were a blind, suffering man... Who loves beauties and does not see them.' Ibn Tahir said: I said to Abu Tammam: 'Did you take this meaning from anyone?' He said: 'Yes, from the saying of Bashar: O people, my ear is in love with some of the tribe... And the ear falls in love before the eye sometimes. They said: You desire someone you do not see? So I said to them... The ear is like the eye, it fulfills to the heart what was.' I said: It appears that Bashar took his saying from the speech of the wise man mentioned previously. Abu Ya'qub al-Khuraymi followed him and said: 'She said, mocking me the morning I met her... Oh men, regarding the youthful passion of the blind! I answered her: My soul is your ransom, truly... My eye and my ear in love are equal.' Bashar also said: Love is only generated by the heart and thought, and he recited regarding that: 'A group makes me abstain from the love of Abdah... Their hearts regarding her are contrary to my heart. So I said: Leave my heart and what it chose and approved... For by the heart, not by the eye, does the intelligent one love. And what the eyes see in the place of desire... The ears do not hear except from the heart.' Al-Husri said, and he spoke true in what he uttered: The five senses only sense by the mediation of the soul. Al-Khalil bin Ahmad said: 'If you are not with me, then the memory of you is with me... My heart observes you even if you are absent from my sight. The eye sees whom it desires and loves... And the eye of the heart is not devoid of looking.' Muzaffar bin Ibrahim the Blind said in apologizing for love despite blindness: 'They said: You loved, while you are blind... A dark fawn-eyed gazelle. And his ornaments, you have not viewed them... So you say imagination has enamored you. And his phantom is with you in sleep... But it did not visit nor descend. From where did he send an arrow to the heart... While you did not look at him? And when did you see his beauty... Until his love clothed you in illness? And by which limb did you connect... To describe him in prose and verse? While the eye is the caller of passion... And it reveals it if it completes.' So I answered that I am marked (Mawsam)... By love through listening and understanding. I love with the limb of hearing... And I do not see the essence of the named.' Al-Madani said: 'O you who blamed me for the love of... One whom my eye did not see. You have exceeded in your description... Of me in love with weakness. So say, do you know Paradise... One day by other than description?' How excellent is the saying of Al-Muhadhdhab Ibn Al-Shihna from a poem praising our Master Sultan Al-Malik Al-Nasir Salah al-Din Ayyub, beginning with: 'And I am a man who loved you for virtues... I heard of them, and the ear loves like the eye. And hopes said to me: If you are joining... The sons of Ayyub, you are the successful one.' I said from a poem praising our Master Sultan Al-Malik Al-Nasir Hasan, containing a good addition, beginning with: 'By the life of your face which is a shining full moon... My heart for you, as you knew, is compassionate. O you who, if the myrtle of his cheek-hair appears... I become having in life a leafy branch. Your cheek did not appear written on by the cheek-hair... Except I thought it was freed (Mu'taq - meaning free or aged wine).' And from it:

'How much I danced upon hearing his mention... And the ear before the eye, they said, falls in love.' The summary of the issue is that among people are those who fall in love upon hearing and perish in the love of one they have not seen but was described to them. For this reason, the Prophet, peace be upon him, forbade that a woman be described to other than her husband as if he is looking at her; the Hadith is in the Sahih. He said in 'Al-Wadih Al-Mubin': Among them are those who fall in love with a trace they saw. It is told that a man loved the trace of a woman's palm he saw on a wall. When his family despaired of his recovery, they left him until he died. Among them are those who love in sleep a figure they do not know, so they wander for it, as was said: 'I wish I knew who... She was and how she traveled by night. Was it the rising of the sun... That was, or is she the moon? I think the Intellect... Its management showed her. Or the form of the Soul... Thoughts showed her. For sight was bewildered in... Perceiving her. Or if it was not all this, then she is an accident... Fate brought her as a cause for my death.' Among them are those who fall in love by touch; it was said it is the head of lust. Among them are those who fall in love by smell, as was said: 'And the eye loves what it desires and sees... Likewise, the nose and the ear love in you.' Among them is one who told me that he entered a bathhouse and saw in it a long black hair of some woman and did not know whose it was. So he took it and it stayed with him for a time, and he was afflicted with the love of its owner, which brought him to the verge of destruction, as was said: 'I perished by a hair and heard another... Say: I was blinded by my destruction for a hair.' Among them are those who fall in love with a female Jinni they saw in their sleep, and she described herself to him and came to him more than once according to his claim. As Abu al-Faraj al-Umawi narrated that Ja'far al-Mansur used to love among the Jinn until his fondness for that increased, so he began to have seizures in sleep multiple times until he died of that. Abu Ja'far grieved for him severely. Ja'far was licentious and impudent. When Al-Mansur forbade Muti' bin Iyas from accompanying his son Ja'far, he said: 'And what is rectifiable in him? And what limit has he not reached in corruption?' He said: 'Woe to you! And by what is this?' He said: 'He claims he loves a woman from the Jinn and he strives to propose to her. His habit is gathering sorcerers for her, and they promise him and give him hope. By Allah, there is no virtue in him for other than that, seriousness nor jest, nor disbelief nor faith.' From his poetry regarding her: 'For the daughter of the Jinni in the tribe are traces... Effaced signs, obliterated like defects.' I said: This is regarding whom it is said: Madness has arts. Similar to this is what our companion Jamal bin Abdullah told me. He said: Al-Tha'alibi said in 'Fiqh al-Lugha': They claimed that intermarriage has occurred between Humans and Jinn due to His saying Almighty: "And share with them in wealth and children." Because female Jinn strike men of Humans with love and corruption is pleasant (to them), and likewise men of Jinn to women of Adam. Section: Mention of what falls into the category of Love upon Hearsay and Testimony on the Absent. Like the saying of Dik al-Jinn, and it was said Abd al-Muhsin al-Suri: 'By my father! A mouth for which the conscience testified... Before tasting that it is sweet. Like my testimony to Allah purely... Before seeing that He is Lord.' How excellent is the saying of the other: 'I yearn for the sweetness of his saliva... As lovers yearned for Al-Udhayb. I testified for it and have not tasted it... Certainty, but from the unseen is an unseen.' Bashar bin Burd said: 'O most pleasant of people in saliva, untested... Except for the testimony of the tips of toothsticks (Miswak).' Al-Mutawakkil al-Laythi said: 'As if a pure reddish wine... Shimmering between a curtain and a jar. The teeth of Sulayma are justified by it... The physiognomy of my eye and the correctness of my guess.' Imru' al-Qais said: 'And she has a mouth, pleasant, clear... Delicious in the kissing place and the smiling place. I have not tasted it other than my guess of it... And by guess one judges what I conceal.' Ibn Hamd al-Siqilli said: 'I did not taste her mouth but I... Transmitted the testimony of the Arak wood (Miswak).' Al-Baha Zuhayr said: 'I was tempted by a sweet, pretty one, so they spoke... With a wonder: How is he sweet and salty (pretty)? The toothstick testified with me to his goodness... And I have not seen a witness (Adl) while he is overflowing drunk.' Ibn al-Naqib said: 'They said so-and-so forges lies... Clothed from his words with sweetness. Sweet of speech. So I said: Who guarantees for me... If he is truthful in sweetness (of taste)?'

I said: There remains here a story related to those who loved upon hearsay among the fools and the simpletons, which is what Al-Jahiz narrated. He said: I passed one day by a teacher and found him in good appearance and fine clothes. He rose to me and seated me with him. I opened a discussion with him on Readings (Qira'at), and behold he was skilled in them. I discussed with him something of Grammar, and found him skilled in it. Then in Arabic poetry and Language, and behold he was perfect in all that is desired of him. I said: By Allah, my resolve to tear up the book of teachers (stereotypes about teachers' stupidity) has strengthened. I used to sit with him and visit him every day. He said: So I came some days to visit him and found the school (Kuttab) closed. I asked his neighbors about him. They said: 'Someone died at his place.' I said: 'I will go console him.' I came to his door and knocked. His slave girl came out to me. She said: 'What do you want?' I said: 'I want your master.' She said: 'My master is sitting alone in mourning; he gives no one a way to him.' I said: 'Tell him your friend so-and-so seeks you.' She entered and came out to me and said: 'In the name of Allah.' So I crossed to him, and behold he was sitting alone. I said: 'May Allah make your reward great. "There has certainly been for you in the Messenger of Allah an excellent pattern." This is a path that is inevitable, so upon you is patience.' Then I said to him: 'This who died, is it your son?' He said: 'No.' I said: 'Then your father?' He said: 'No.' I said: 'Then your brother?' He said: 'No.' I said: 'Then who?' He said: 'My beloved.' I said to myself: 'This is the first of the misfortunes.' Then I said: 'Glory be to Allah, women are many and you will find another and your eyes will fall on one more beautiful.' He said: 'And as if you thought I had seen her?' I said to myself: 'This is a second misfortune.' Then I said: 'And how did you love one whom you did not see?' He said: 'Know that I was in the balcony (Taramah) and suddenly a man passed singing and saying: "O Umm Amr, may Allah reward you with a bounty... Return to my heart wherever it was." I said to myself: Were it not that this Umm Amr has no equal in the world, this poetry would not have been said about her. So I loved her. Two days later, that man passed singing and saying: "The donkey went away with Umm Amr... So she did not return, nor did the donkey return." So I knew she died, so I grieved and sat in mourning for three days for this day.' Al-Jahiz said: So my resolve returned and my determination strengthened to tear up the book (about teachers' intelligence) because of the story of Umm Amr. Chapter Four: Mention of those who looked the first look and burned from the cheek of the beloved with an ember. I say: We established this chapter to mention those whom looking dropped into the harm leading to sleeplessness, for it is the caller of insomnia and the fuel of burning. How often it called to the prohibited intercourse by consensus! It is a poisoned arrow and a blameworthy act. In its beginning, its rectification is possible, and its captive hopes for release. But if repeated, it leads to what is described as such and such. Do you not see the rope by its repetition cutting the house (stone)? As was said: 'All incidents, their beginning is from looking... And the bulk of the fire is from small sparks. How many a look wreaked havoc in the heart of its owner... The havoc of arrows without a bow or string. A man, as long as he has an eye he turns... Among eyes, is standing in danger. His eye pleases what harms his soul... No welcome to a pleasure that came with harm.' My saying 'And in its beginning, its rectification is possible' etc., that is because a man passes by a woman, and her apparent appearance, shape, and form are compatible with his nature, so his soul stirs and his interest is aroused from the first look. If his look at her is repeated, his love for her increases. If he sits until he sees her, what is in him becomes double what it was. If she looks at him once, he is tempted by her beauty and falls into the captivity of her ropes and enters the number of lovers. This supports the saying of those who held that Love is voluntary because he did not become a lover except after the occurrence of these introductions, and it was possible for him to cut off the material of that after the first look, except in rare cases as preceded in the mention of the women who died when they saw Joseph, peace be upon him, so they were tempted from the first look. It used to be said looking from the lover is an urgent death and from the beloved is a killing arrow. It used to be said many a love was planted by a glance and a war harvested by a word. It used to be said whoever releases his glance increases his regret. It used to be said whoever's glances are many, his sorrows endure. A Bedouin said: Love is a plant whose seed is looking, its water is visiting, its growth is union, its killing is abandonment, and its harvest is accusation. Al-Suri said: 'You planted desire with a glance then belittled it... And neglected it, getting familiar, lenient. You did not know until its trees ripened... And the winds of passion blew in it impregnating. So you became drawing patience near from a distance... Upon you, and summoning sleep from afar.'

Al-Asma'i said: I was at some Arab waters and heard people saying: 'She has come.' People moved, so I stood with them. Behold, a young girl had arrived at the water; I had never seen her like in the beauty of her face and the perfection of her creation. When she saw the abundance of people looking at her, she let down her veil, so it was like a cloud covering a sun. I said: 'Why do you prevent us from looking at this beautiful face of yours?' She recited saying: 'And you were, whenever you sent your glance as a scout... For your heart one day, the scenes tired you. You saw what you are not capable of entirely... Nor are you patient regarding some of it.' Then a Bedouin looked at her and said: 'I, by Allah, am of those whose patience is little.' And he recited: 'O wild one of the eyes, where is the family for you... Did they settle in the rugged ground or is their place the plain? And which land brought you out, for I... See you from Paradise if the origin is searched. Stop and tell us what you ate and what... You drank and from where the caravan departed with you. Because the signs of Paradises are clear upon you... Even if the form resembles the form.' I say: This, by Allah, is the lawful magic and the sweet fresh water. It contained the school of speech magic and the sublime full moon. As if I am with her and she has mentioned the family to him and described of her tribe and her cheek the rugged and the plain. There, he comes to her striving on his head, not striving on foot, and her cheeks are more beloved to him than red camels. And he recites: 'Show me the place of the full moon if the full moon sets... And stand in the place of the sun if the dawn is far. For in you is the sun's light... And it (the sun) does not have your smiling and mouth (Thaghr).' It is told that a singer entered Isfahan singing these two verses: 'Listen, O servants of Allah, to me... And desist from observing the beauties. For love, its end is death... And its beginning resembles jesting.' I said: In this is evidence that the Eye is what brings the Time (of death). Since it is so, let us mention here a debate that occurred between the Heart and the Eye, and the blaming of each of them by its companion, and the judgment between them. When the Eye was excessive and the Heart's love excessive, and this (Eye) had the pleasure of looking and that (Heart) had the pleasure of triumph, they were in Love partners in the rein and two horses in a race. When they fell into sleeplessness and burning, and insomnia harmed their owner, the Heart spoke. Al-Arjani says to his criminal glance: 'You two enjoyed, O my eyes, a look... And brought my heart to the most evil of watering places. O my eyes, desist from my heart, for it is... Of injustice, the striving of two in killing one.' Abu al-Tayyib al-Mutanabbi said: 'And I am the one whose glance attracted death... So who is the demanded, and the killed is the killer?' Another's saying: 'My heart was punished and my eye committed the crime... And perhaps the one who did not commit the crime is punished.' Another's saying: 'The looking of eyes at eyes is what... Made destruction a path to the heart. Glances ceased not to raid his heart... Until he wallowed among them, slain.' Another's saying: 'O you who sees my illness increasing... And my ailment baffled my doctor. Do not wonder, for thus... Eyes commit crimes against hearts.' Ibn Mudrik said: 'I wounded with my glance the cheek of the beloved... So the acting Eye was not demanded. But he exacted retribution from my soul... Thus are blood monies upon the female clan ('Aqilah).' When the Eye heard his recitation and understood his intent, she signaled to him and began denying him. She said: 'Oh wonder at an oppressor complaining and a mute speaking! Is it not from the news that spread and circulated that you are the King and we are the followers? You send me in what you want like lightning and follow that with threats. Did you not hear the saying of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him: The heart is a King and the limbs are his soldiers; if the King is good, his soldiers are good, and if the King is bad, his soldiers are bad. And the Master of Mankind said, upon him be the best blessings and peace: In the body is a morsel, if it is sound, the whole body is sound, and if it is corrupt, the whole body is corrupt. So between my sin and your sin at that time is as between my blindness and your blindness. The Knower of the Unseen said: "For indeed, it is not eyes that are blinded, but blinded are the hearts."' When the Soul heard the argument that revolved between them, she said immediately: 'I am between two enemies... They are my heart and my glance. The glance looks and the heart desires... And the intention is my death.' Another said: 'My heart says to my glance when it wept in anxiety... You cry while you are the one who burdened me with the pain? So my glance said to it while scolding it: Rather you burdened me with hopes and greed... Until when each was alone with his companion. Both of them were content with long illness... My liver called out to them: Do not blame, for indeed...

...You have cut me with what you encountered into pieces.' Another said: 'I blamed my heart when... I saw my body emaciated. So the heart stuck it to my glance... And said: You were the messenger. My glance said to my heart... Rather you were the guide. So I said: Enough, both of you... You have left me slain.' I said: So they were as the commoners say: A back of the neck between two slappers. How excellent is the saying of the other: 'By Allah, I do not know: my soul should I blame... For love, or my eye is wounded, or my heart? If I blame my heart, it says to me: The eye saw... And if I blame my eye, it says: The sin is the heart's. So my eye and my heart have shared in my blood... So O Lord, be a help against the eye and the heart.' Section: On the mention of the magic of eyes and the arrows of eyelids. I said: And the Judge between them is the one who judges between the Spirit and the Body if they dispute, as reported in the tradition from the Master of Humans: 'Dispute will not cease on the Day of Resurrection between creatures until the Spirit and the Body dispute. The Body says to the Spirit: You are the one who moved me, ordered me, and directed me, otherwise I would not have moved nor done anything without you. So the Spirit says to it: And you are the one who ate, drank, and enjoyed, so you are the one deserving punishment. So Allah Glorified and Exalted sends an angel to judge between them. He says: Your likeness is like a paralyzed seer and a blind walker who entered a garden. The paralyzed said to the blind: I see fruits in it but cannot stand. The blind said: I can stand but see nothing. The paralyzed said: Come, carry me; so you walk and I reach. Upon whom is the punishment? They say: Upon both of them. He says: So likewise are you.' Section: Mention of the magic of eyelids and the arrows of eyes. Of that is the saying of Bashar, which is the most flirtatious verse poets have said according to what the Chief Judge Shams al-Din bin Khallikan recounted: 'I, by Allah, desire the magic of your two eyes... And fear the death-grounds of lovers.' Our Sheikh, the Hafiz Shams al-Din al-Dhahabi, transmitted in 'Tarikh al-Islam' from Ibn Hayyus that he said: The most flirtatious I know is the saying of Abd al-Muhsin al-Suri: 'By the One who inspired my torment... Your front teeth (sweetness). What did your eyes say... To my heart so it answered?' I said: They are from the saying of Jarir: 'Indeed, the eyes in whose glance is intense contrast (Hawar)... Killed us then did not revive our dead. They strike down the one of intellect until there is no movement in him... While they are the weakest of Allah's creation as humans.' The author of 'Al-Murqis wal-Mutrib' recited: 'If I did not die by the glance, the blamer said... What is the value of the sword that does not kill?' Ibn Sahl al-Ishbili said in the opening of his Muwashshah: 'Her glances for killing... Have in her ball the fullest share. She shoots and all of me is a killing spot... And all of it is a hitting arrow.' King Al-Nasir Dawood, Lord of Karak, said: 'By my father! A slender one, if I sought from him... Kissing a mouth, he repels me from my intent. He protected his cheek with a wall of cheek-hair... His eyes became upon it my archers (Marami).' Section: Description of Narrow Eyes and others. Ibn al-Nabih said: 'He repels with his Turkish glance from me... You spoke truth, indeed narrowness of the eye is stinginess.' He also said: 'From the sons of the Turks, soft of side, hard of heart... Easy of deception, difficult of docking. Narrow of eye, which is an attribute of stinginess... So if he is generous, it is against analogy (Qiyas): He drew the bow so his cheeks were clothed... In a robe of roses whose embroidery is myrtle. And he shot from two bows two arrows, this one... In my heart and that one in the target.' Ibn Qarnas said: 'I was attached to a Tatar... And he grieves hearts with his separation. Generosity is not hoped from him... In union, due to the narrowness of his eye.' Sheikh Jamal al-Din bin Nubata said: 'The blamer was confounded when he saw his glances... Turkish, leaving the forbearing one foolish. So he turned the blame and said: Take him and the sorrow... These are narrows (straits) I do not enter.' Sheikh Safi al-Din al-Hilli said: 'I have a fawn among them, if I flirted with him... His glances almost spoke with magic. If he wishes to meet me with a wide character... At the meeting, a narrow eye forbids him.' Al-Khara'iti told about some Alawite who said: While I was standing over Al-Hasan ibn Hani (Abu Nuwas) while he was reciting: 'Woe to me upon the wide of eyes... The buxom, the slim of bellies. Those speaking upon the conscience... To us with the tongues of eyelids.'

A Bedouin stood over him with a son of his and said: 'Repeat to me.' So he repeated to him. He said: 'O nephew, woe to you alone from this? Woe to me and you, and woe to this son of mine, and woe to this group, and woe to all our neighbors.' Sibt al-Ta'awidhi said: 'Between swords and his eye is a partnership... For its sake scabbards were called eyelids (Ajfan).' Rashid al-Din al-Fariqi said: 'Indeed in your eyes is a meaning... The narcissus spoke of. Would that I had from its freshness... An arrow, then in my heart from it.' Muhammad bin al-Afif al-Tilimsani said: 'Your glances are masculine swords, so why do they... As they claimed, possess the like of widows?' And he also said: 'O lovers, beware... Of one smiling from his mouth. For his enchanting glance, since... You doubted his command. Wants to drive you out... From your land with his magic.' He also said: 'Judges of Beauty! What is my doing with a glance... The nurtured fawn wished for its like? It shot and hit my heart, a judicial effort... You spoke truth, every Mujtahid (striver) is right.' I said from my poetry: 'A beloved descending in every heart... And the sword of his glance loves combat. He sees the killing of the lover without proof... Especially if he shows coquetry. If you faced the sword of the glance from him... You would see death from its sharpness immediately.' I also said from a poem: 'The sun is jealous of her when she appears... Like the Ban branch in green garments. With fingertips red from henna... And glances black like Indian swords.' I also said from a poem: 'His glances swore against the people of passion... That they would see no killing without a sword. He gazes while the sword of his glance is in his eyelid... Sharp of edge and not touched by kohl. So if he strips it for the lover, do not ask... About a sword of an eyelid like a stripped sword.' I also said from a poem: 'My gazelle raided me with glances because... If he appears in the heat of war, he is a lion. His glances speak to me with their swords... And you have not seen before me a dead man speaking.' I said from a poem: 'She draws swords from the glances of her eye... But the habit of the eyelid is sheathing. She strips them while the tears are flowing like the Nile... So she did not bend me except Sayhan (river) was frozen.' I also said from a poem: 'He gazes at me with an eye whose eyebrow is a Nun... Like the bow piercing the targets while it twangs. A Prince of Beauty from the Turks, his eyebrow (Hajib)... Over the lover of him in Egypt has authority (Sultan). His glances raided the people of Egypt just as... Ghazan raided the people in the land of Sham.' As for Hawar (Intense whiteness and blackness of eye), people differed regarding it. Abu Ubaida said: The Hawra is the one intense in the whiteness of the eye in intensity of the blackness of its black. Ya'qub said: Hawar is the wideness of the eye, the largeness of the eyeball, and the abundance of whiteness. Qutrub said: The Hawra is the one with beautiful eye-sockets, whether the eye is small or large. Abu Amr said: The Hawra doe is the black-eyed one with no whiteness in her eye; this does not occur in humans, only in wild animals. The derivation of Hawar indicates the correctness of what Ya'qub and Abu Ubaida said, because they mostly apply it to whiteness, like the Huwari flour (fine white flour). Rarely does whiteness of the eye coincide except with intensity of its blackness, because its whiteness with blueness is not there in purity. Poets have abounded in describing the eye with Hawar and blackness, and the description of the blue eye is rare in their poetry. However, it came in the Hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, from the Prophet, peace be upon him, that he said: "Blueness in the eye is a blessing (Yumn)." Some Arabs said: 'I love you if they say in your eye is blueness... Likewise the falcons of birds, their eyes are blue.' From here Al-Abdi took his saying when Mu'awiyah said to him: 'You are red.' He said: 'And gold is red.' He said: 'You are blue (eyed).' He said: 'And the hawk is blue.' Chapter Five: Mention of the Changing of Colors upon Witnessing, such as Pallor and Fear, and Redness and Shame, and what carries that meaning regarding tongue-tiedness and magic of expression.

I say: We established this chapter to mention the changing of the two lovers' colors when eye falls upon eye, and the blood flees to the net of the brain, so the barrier says to it: Where to? Doctors have stated the text regarding the cause of that, and cleared the blackness of every dark (night) from the yellowing of the lover and the reddening of the beloved. I present here what they said verbatim, and set it like the gemstone in the ring, and follow it with the mention of the colors of beauties with the best explanation and clearest clarification. This, along with what is dragged in the tail of that regarding the detail between browns and whites, and the falling of the lover of plumpness of hair and buttocks into the long and wide (trouble). I conclude that with a section on mentioning what afflicts the lover of palpitations of his heart and the flight of his mind and core. So I say, and success is through Allah. Some doctors said: The cause of the yellowing of the lover's face is fear, for blood does not settle with fear. Perhaps the beloved looks at the lover suddenly, so his heart palpitates and the heat ignites then extinguishes. If it extinguishes, the pericardium cools. If the pericardium cools, the blood congeals and the color transforms to blackness and greenness, then settles and becomes yellow. As for the reddening of the beloved's face, it is from shame. Shame is a symptom of the movement of the heart's pericardium; it transforms the blood and refines it, so it appears in the thinnest place in the face. That is upon the treatment of the accidental heat and its struggling with the blood when it is pushed, seeking escape until it reaches below the head, so the barrier prevents it from passing through, so it descends to the face, and the face reddens. They said: The face with thin skin and clear surface, if it feels shame, it reddens, and if it fears, it yellows. From it is their saying 'Brocade of the Face', meaning its coloring due to its thinness. The poet said: 'Redness mixed with yellowness in whiteness... Like what a weaver of brocade wove.' They said: The redness of a human's color is generated by joy, health, and grace. The yellowness of his color is generated by fear, misery, grief, and illness. As for the best of colors, it is red, evidenced by the fact that blood is the friend of the soul and redness is its color. The best and most luxurious ruby is the red. The best gold is its red. The best honey is the golden and ruby-colored. The earth is praised by the redness of the soil. The noblest horses are the sorrel (blonde/red), and gold is its brocade. The noblest camels are the red ones, which the Prophet, peace be upon him, said while magnifying the value of that: 'Even if I had the red camels,' and 'Even if I had the earth full of gold.' The best flowers are the rose, the anemone, and the pomegranate blossom. The best dyed garments are the safflower-dyed, and the best of them is what is dyed with crimson (Kermes). The best wine is the red; therefore poets described it with the color of fire, dragon's blood, safflower, ruby, and 'Abqar. The best of created colors is fire. For that reason, Abd al-Uzza bin Abd al-Muttalib was nicknamed Al-Lahab (The Flame), and he was nicknamed before that Abu Utbah, because he was one of the most handsome people in face, and they used to compare the redness of his face to the flame of fire because he was radiant of face, glowing. As the Prophet, peace be upon him, hinted that he said: 'The two reds destroyed men, and the red things destroyed women.' The two reds are wine and meat. The red things are gold, saffron, and wine. Wine and meat: The poet said: 'Indeed the three reds wasted... My money, and I was of old fond of them: Wine, fat meat, and what is painted... With saffron; so I remain startled.' The Prophet, peace be upon him, liked the red bird. Wahb bin Abdullah said: 'I have not seen a person with a forelock in a red suit more handsome than the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him.' Al-Mutanabbi said: 'Of the fawns in the guise of Bedouins... Red of ornaments, mounts, and robes.' As for the poet's saying: 'White (Hijan) upon her is redness in her whiteness... She pleases the eyes with it, and beauty is red,' he meant by it the beauty in the redness of color with whiteness, excluding other colors. Ibn Abd Rabbihi said: Beauty is red. The description might be struck in it due to long staying in the universe and anointing with perfume. A Bedouin said: 'I was not consoled regarding a yellow one adorned... Like ivory, nothing yellowed her but saffron (Wars) and perfume.' Another said: 'As if the color of eggs in the hatching place... Is your color were it not for the yellowness of the Jawi.' He means she anoints herself with Jawi, which is saffron, and the description of the egg does not reach its yellowness. They said the beautiful girl colors like the coloring of the sun; she is white in the forenoon and yellow in the evening like the day. The poet said: 'White is her morning and yellow... The evening like the day.' Bashar bin Burd said: 'So take beauties of adornment... And safflower-dyed ones, they are more splendid. If we reach (maturity), then enter... Into the red ones; beauty is red.' Al-Hariri said in 'Durrat al-Ghawwas': As for their saying 'Beauty is red', its meaning is that what possesses beauty is not acquired except by enduring hardship from which the face turns red. Just as they called the drought year 'Red'. They alluded to the difficult matter as 'Red Death', as was said:

'If your eyes see a black gaze... Know that there is a red death.' The best adornment of women on their bodies is dye (Henna), and for that poets elaborated on it and compared it to jujube and other things. Abu Nuwas said regarding it: 'O moon I saw at a funeral... Mourning with grief among peers. Weeping, so shedding pearls from narcissus... And slapping the rose with jujube.' Ibn Ukasha said: 'From the palm of a girl whose fingertips seem... Of silver, collared with jujube.' How excellent is the saying of Al-Wawa al-Dimashqi: 'So she rained pearls from narcissus and watered a rose... And bit on the jujube with hail (teeth).' Al-Marzubani said: Ibn Durayd told me: I stayed up one night. When it was the end of the night, I closed my eyes. I saw a tall man, yellow-faced, with a sparse beard, entering upon me. He took the door jambs and said: 'Recite to me the best of what you said regarding wine.' I said: 'Abu Nuwas left nothing for anyone.' He said: 'I am more poetic than him.' I said: 'Who are you?' He said: 'I am Ibn Najiyah from the people of Sham.' And he recited to me: 'And red before mixing, yellow after it... Appeared between robes of narcissus and anemone. It imitated the cheek of the beloved pure, so they imposed... A mix upon it, so it clothed itself in the color of a lover.' I said: 'You arranged badly.' He said: 'Why?' I said: 'Because you said "And red" presenting the red, then said "between robes of narcissus and anemone" delaying the redness. Why did you not present it over the other?' He said: 'What is this scrutiny at this time, O hateful one?' Then he left. Al-Mutanabbi said: 'She said, having seen my yellowing: Who is with him?... And she sighed, so I answered her: The Sigher.' The other took it and said: 'She said to a peer with her, denying... My standing: Who is this we see? She said: A youth complaining of passion, enslaved... She said: With whom? She said: With whom? She said: With whom?' Ibn al-Nabih said: 'And in the red tent is a white young girl... With blue eyes the brown spears protect her tents.' Imad al-Din Ibn Dabuqa said from verses: 'I see the necklace on his chest tight... Showing the sound ones from the jewel. And the completion of beauty is its clarification... We narrated it from your radiant face. And the scattering of my tears became red... Upon the myrtle of your green cheek-hair. And I sold my guidance for the error of desire... For your sake, O rising of Jupiter.' I said from a poem: 'By your life, there is no Zaid nor Amr... Nor a mouth, except beneath kissing it is a mouth (Thaghr). No whites except my luck is black with her... Nor browns except beneath her brown sides.' Badr al-Din bin al-Muhaddith said: 'My color turns yellow when I look at a cheek... From which the fresh rose learns its beauty. Time perishes while his love does not perish... And I have bent while I do not see him bending.' It is told about Abu Ayyub, the Vizier of Al-Mansur, that when Al-Mansur called him, he would turn yellow and tremble. When he left his presence, his color would return. It was said to him: 'We see you, despite your frequent entry upon the Commander of the Faithful and his intimacy with you, change when you enter upon him.' He said: 'My likeness and your likeness in this is like a falcon and a rooster debating. The falcon said to the rooster: I know none less loyal to his owners than you. He said: How? He said: You are taken as an egg, your family incubates you, and you emerge on their hands. They feed you with their palms until when you grow up, no one approaches you but you fly from here to there and scream. Even if you ascend a wall of a house you were in for years, you fly from it and leave it for another. As for me, I am taken from the mountains when I have grown old. My eyes are sewn, I am fed little, kept awake and prevented from sleep. I am tamed for a day and two days, then released upon the prey alone, so I fly to it, take it, and come to my owner.' The rooster said to him: 'The argument is gone from you. By Allah, if you saw two falcons on a skewer, you would never return to them. And I see the skewers full of roosters every day. So do not be forbearing at the anger of another. If you knew of Al-Mansur what I know, you would be in a worse state than me when he seeks you.' I said: And what he fled from, he fell into, according to the correct famous (report). He did not cease to turn yellow from him until he made him taste the red death. This was after he took his wealth and left him in the worst state. It is told that he used to oil his eyebrow with an oil in which Al-Mansur is enchanted, so he cannot (harm) him if he sees him, until he became a proverb, so it was said: 'Oilier than Abu Ayyub.' That availed him nothing, because he did to him what he did and met him with what he had no power against. Section: Preference between Whites and Blacks, and Browns with Breasts. This last type is what Egyptians are inclined to mostly. And people have schools of thought in what they adore. What was said in preferring Browns: 'I do not love the white puffed with fat... But I love the lean browns.

'I am a man who rides the lean colt in... The day of the race, so leave me and ride the elephant.' Ali bin al-Jahm said: 'And a faulter of the Browns out of his ignorance... O you who prefer the Whites, possessing contention. Say to him: Leave us! Are you not ashamed... Of making camphor like musk?' Abu Ja'far al-Shatranji said: 'Musk resembles you and you resemble it... Standing in its color, sitting. No doubt since you two are one... That you are from a single clay.' Al-Sharif Al-Radi said in detailing the Blacks: 'I love you, O color of blackness, for I... Saw you in the eyes and the heart as twins. And the arrow of the eye would not have been, were it not for its blackness... To reach the grains of the hearts when it shot. If you love the dark-lipped fawns, do not blame... My madness over the fawn that is all dark-lipped.' Maslamah said: 'The blamers blamed regarding a jet-black one... As if she is a statue in the blackness of the heart. People fell in love with the mole, and did not know... That I wander in love with a person who is entirely a mole.' Ibn Rashiq said: 'Beauty called by you, so answer... O musk in dye and scent. Haughtily rise above the Whites and lengthen... The pride of youth over greyness. And let not blackness of color frighten you... Like the eye of the nurtured fawn.' Another said: 'Indeed the blackness of the eye in the eye is its light... And the whiteness of the eye has no light, so know.' I mentioned the rest of what was said in this type of excellent stanzas in 'Al-Sukardan' when mentioning Al-Malik Al-Kamil Sha'ban, may Allah have mercy on him. As for what was said in preferring Whites over Blacks, it is more than can be mentioned by a witness or a helper's arm extended to it. Al-Jahiz said: Arabs praise with whiteness and satirize with blackness. But perhaps they praised with blackness, but the principle they build their matter upon is dispraising it. Kushajim said: 'O you who resembles in his deed his color... You did not exceed what the division necessitated. Your character is extracted from your creation... And injustice (Zulm) is derived from darkness (Zulmah).' As for the short, thick woman, she is a blameworthy type according to the owner of every prose and verse. The poet said: 'You are the one who made every short one beloved... To me, and the short ones did not feel that. I meant the short ones of the chambers, and did not intend... The short of women, the worst of women are the Buhatir.' The Buhatir are the short thick ones. Some of the predecessors said: Allah placed splendor and rashness with tallness, and cunning and ugliness with shortness, and goodness is between that. How witty is the saying of Al-Sharif the Copyist: 'Alas for the love of a short one... In the earth she has a thousand thousand statures. If her glance looks at the light letters (Khaffaf)... The rhymes say: Writer of Safety.' Some people prefer fat ones and say: Fatness is half of beauty; it covers every defect in a woman and shows her beauties. It was said for this reason she was called 'Jamila' because the Jamila is the fat one, from Jamal which is fat (Shahm). This has been mentioned previously. Section: Mention of what afflicts the lover of yellowing of his color upon seeing his beloved, and palpitations of his heart and flight of his mind and core. The author of 'Rawdat al-Muhibbin' said: It was disputed regarding the cause of this fright, fear, and disturbance. It was said its cause is that the beloved has authority over the heart of his lover greater than the authority of the subjects (over them). If he sees him suddenly, that frightens him just as one who sees someone he magnifies suddenly is frightened. For the heart magnifies the beloved, submissive to him. A person, if the magnified one surprises him, is frightened by that. It was said its cause is the opening of the heart to him and its hastening to receive him, so the blood flees from it, so it cools and trembles, and disturbance and trembling occur, and perhaps he dies. In summary, this is a matter of taste and feeling (Wijdani), even if its cause is not known. Among the best said in apologizing for the heart's palpitations upon seeing the beloved is the saying of Al-Warraq al-Khatiri: 'He says to me when he arrived: You attained what you hope for. So why does your heart, when I came... Palpitations afflict it? I said: Your union is a wedding... And the heart dances in it.' Similar is the saying of the other: 'Do not deny the palpitations of my heart... While the beloved is present with me. The heart is but his house... In which the drums of good news were beaten for him.' How excellent is the saying of Ibn Sana' al-Mulk: 'By Allah, were it not for fear of your anger... What I encounter from your tribe would be easy for me. You possessed the two palpitating ones (East and West/Heart) and boasted in wonder... Yet they are nothing but my heart and your earring.' Mu'in al-Din said: 'I did not forget him when he said: Where do you settle me... Fearful for me of the phantom knocking? I answered: In my heart. So he said in wonder... Have you seen your life dwelling in a palpitating (Khofiq)?'
