Another said: 'And you dwelt in a palpitating heart... Despairingly, as we were in other than a dweller.' Al-Tughra'i said: 'The breeze fell ill and recovered, and the disease which... I complain of, no separation is hoped for it. This is the flashing of lightning, and the disease which... My ribs enclosed is palpitating (Khaffaq).' Ibn al-Abbar cited in 'Tuhfat al-Qadim': 'Until when the year of slumber inclined with him... I moved him slightly while he was embracing me. I distanced him from ribs that yearn for him... So that he does not sleep on a palpitating pillow.' Then he said: Some people of our age attributed Ibn Taqi to roughness in his saying 'I distanced him from ribs that yearn for him'. Had he said... 'I distanced from him ribs that yearn for him', it would have been better. Then he mentioned after it what they preferred over the saying of Ibn Taqi mentioned, the saying of Ibn al-Hakam Ja'far bin Anan: 'If there must be slumber... Then take my ribs for a pillow. And sleep on their palpitating quietly... Like the child in the rocking of the cradle.' Ibn al-Athir said in 'Al-Mathal al-Sa'ir' regarding the verses of Ibn Taqi mentioned: This is of beauty and prettiness in the utmost place. His meanings were light on the hearts until they almost danced a dance. The last verse is the one described with innovation, and by it and its likes the eyes acknowledged the merit of hearing. I said, agreeing with the people of that age in refuting Ibn Taqi: 'A visitor came resembling the crescent moon... And followed it with aversion and elongation. I said to him... He said: No, no... Prolonging the union inherits boredom for you.' Chapter Six: Mention of Jealousy, and what it contains of confusion and the knocking of the tooth of Dik al-Jinn. I say: We established this chapter to mention the jealousy of the lover over the beloved even from himself and the sons of his gender. Lovers in it are two types, and those beaten by its whips are two kinds. The first is loved by Allah and His Messenger, and by it the messenger is completed for the lover. The second is blameworthy and its owner is blamed. The loved type of it is to be jealous when suspicion arises. The blameworthy type is to be jealous without suspicion, but from mere bad thought. This jealousy corrupts love and leaves not a grain of it, because it causes enmity between the lover and the beloved, and perhaps drives him to fall into what he accused him of. Many corruptions result from it leading to the corruption of the image. The stories in this chapter are famous. The Prophet, peace be upon him, narrated in the Sahih: "There is jealousy that Allah loves and there is that which Allah hates. The jealousy Allah loves is to be in suspicion, and the jealousy Allah hates is jealousy without suspicion." Abdullah bin Shaddad said: Jealousy is two jealousies: jealousy by which a man reforms his family, and jealousy that enters the Fire. The author of 'Rawdat al-Muhibbin' said: He who loves Allah and His Messenger is jealous for Allah and His Messenger according to the measure of his love and reverence. If his heart is devoid of jealousy for Allah and His Messenger, he is far from lovers. So he lied who claimed love for a beloved among people while he sees another violating his sanctity, striving to harm and anger him, and belittling his command, and he is not jealous for that, rather his heart is cold. So how can it be correct for a servant to claim the love of Allah while he is not jealous for His prohibitions when they are violated, nor for His rights when they are wasted? And the least of states is that he be jealous for Him from himself by leaving the commission of His disobediences and negligence in His right. As for jealousy over the beloved, it is praised where exclusivity with him is praised and partnership in him is dispraised legally and rationally, like a man's jealousy over his wife and his slave girl and the thing he specifically owns. This jealousy is specific to created beings and is not conceivable regarding the Creator, because He, Glory be to Him, it is obligatory upon all creatures to love Him, remember Him, worship Him, and praise Him. Contrary to some ignorant Sufis who, if they saw someone mentioning Allah or loving Him, became jealous of him, and perhaps silenced him if possible, saying 'The jealousy of Love carries me to this.' That is only envy, transgression, aggression, a type of enmity to Allah, and opposition to the path of His messengers, which they brought out in the mold of jealousy and compared His love to the love of a form. This jealousy is only good in the love of one in whom partnership in love is not good, like a human's jealousy over his beloved among humans as previously mentioned. Al-Qushayri said: It was said to some: Do you love to see Him? He said: No. It was said: Why? He said: I declare that Beauty above the look of my like.

Sheikh Shams al-Din Ibn Qayyim al-Jawziyya said: This is also a corrupt jealousy. The utmost for its owner is to be pardoned, and for that to be counted among his blameworthy surface expressions (Shathat), and to be counted among his virtues and merits that it be said to him: Do you love to see your beloved? And he says No. No? While His vision is the highest bliss of Paradise, and He, Glory be to Him, loves for His servant to ask Him for the look at Him. It has been established from the Prophet, peace be upon him, that it was among his supplications: 'O Allah, I ask You for the pleasure of looking at Your face and the longing to meet You.' The saying of this sayer 'I declare that Beauty above the look of my like' is from the deceptions of Satan and the soul. It is similar to what is told about some that it was said: Do you not mention Him? He said: I declare Him above that His mention should run on my tongue. Some fell into something of that, so they blamed him, and he recited: 'They say visit us and fulfill the duty of our right... But my state has dropped their rights from me. If they saw my state and did not disdain it... And did not disdain me, I disdained them for myself.' And some of them left Hajj out of jealousy for His House that his like should visit it. I blamed a person for leaving prayer. He said to me: I do not see myself worthy to enter His house. So look at Satan's playing with these. As for jealousy over the beloved among humans, we have types in it, and good deeds mostly sins. Among them are those who are jealous over the beloved from the passing breeze or hearing that he is in the path: 'I become jealous if I hear a moan in the tribe... Cautious or fearful that it might be for his love.' Another said: 'Her protectors are jealous of the visiting phantom... And her jealous one gets angry at the breeze.' Ibn al-Athir said in 'Al-Mathal al-Sa'ir': I traveled to Sham in the year five hundred eighty-seven and entered the city of Damascus. I found a group of its masters fond of a verse of poetry by Ibn al-Khayyat, which is: 'I become jealous if I hear a moan in the tribe...' the aforementioned verse. I said to them: This verse is taken from the saying of Abu al-Tayyib al-Mutanabbi: 'If I said to the yearning sick one: I ransom him... From what ails him, I would tempt him with his ransom.' And Al-Mutanabbi took it from the saying of Al-Abbas bin al-Ahnaf: 'I did not meet a possessor of sorrow revealing his love... Except I thought you were that beloved. Caution for you, while I am confident in you... That other than me obtains a share of you.' Among them are those who join in jealousy their day with their yesterday, and are jealous over the beloved from their own words, as Al-Buhturi said: 'I envy my glance upon you... Until I close my eyes when I look at you. And I see you striding in your characteristics which... Are my temptation, so I am jealous of you from you. And if I could, I would prevent your utterance out of jealousy... So that I do not see it kissing your lips. Passion became pure for you and my affection chose you... Until I became jealous of you from your owning you.' Among them are those who are jealous over him... from his buttons and wearing his wrapper (Izar). 'I see the buttons on Laila so I envy them... Indeed the buttons over what they embrace are envied.' I said: For this verse is a pleasant story, which is what is told about Al-Hasan bin Zaid, the Emir of Medina. He said one day to Abu al-Sa'ib—and he had beautified him and clothed him so he would ride with him in his procession, and he greeted women if he passed by them, so the Emir forbade him from that. He rode with him one day wearing a tall cap (Qalansuwah) and did as was his habit. So the Emir recited to him: 'I see the buttons on Laila...' the verse. Abu al-Sa'ib said to him: 'May my father and mother be your ransom. Who said this verse?' He said: 'Qays.' So Abu al-Sa'ib lagged behind from riding with him, then caught up with no cap on him. The Emir said to him: 'Where is the cap?' He said: 'I gave it as charity to the devil who cast this verse on the tongue of Qays.' Among them are those who are jealous over him from sipping wine, as Kushajim said: 'And a branch in a dune (figure) tortured me... Softness and compactness shared in him. I became jealous when he brought a cup near his mouth... Over pearls being kissed by glass. And I fear if the lamp nears him... For a full moon being faced by a lamp.' Al-Mutanabbi took it and said regarding his praised one: '...I am jealous of the glass when it runs on the lip of the Emir Abu Husayn.' He was faulted for that because he addressed his praised one with what the beautiful woman is addressed with. Among them are those who place themselves in the position of the stranger, so they are jealous over the beloved from themselves, as Abu Tammam said: 'By my soul! Regarding whom I am jealous from myself... And I envy an eye that looked at him. And if I were able, I would obliterate from him... The eyes of people out of my caution for him. A beloved who spread his desire in my body... And held my soul as a pledge with him. So my spirit is with him and the body is empty... Without a spirit, and my heart is in his hands.' He also said:

'I am jealous over you from my heart... Even if you gave me my hope. And I fear to see your cheeks... Set up as sites for kisses.' Another said: 'O you who, when his name is mentioned in a gathering... The conversation becomes sweet by it and the gathering pleasant. Indeed, regarding whom I look at I am jealous, and indeed I... Am more miserly with you from other than me among mankind.' Among them are those who are jealous over him from his union with him, fearing it might be a key for others, as Ali bin Abdullah al-Ja'bari said: 'Perhaps your intentional turning away pleased me... And your dismissal and forbidding yourself from me. Caution lest I be a key for another... So if I am alone, you were the wish.' Another said: 'And when she threw a glance at another I thought her... Just as she affected with the eye, she affects the heart. And I hope she persists in her distance... But bad thoughts are from the intensity of love.' Ibn Matruh exaggerated where he says: 'If he insisted on my destruction... I would say: My torturer, by Allah, increase me! And do not permit your union for me, for I... Am jealous over you from you, so how about from me?' Among them are those who refrain from mentioning their beloved fearing exposing him to the love of others for him, as Ali bin al-Rafi'i said: 'I am not one day describing a beloved... Exposing him to the desires of men. Why should I make another's heart yearn... While between his union is the curtain of the chambers?' Many ignorant people described their wife and her beauties to others, so that was the cause of her separation and connection to the one described to; that is from his lack of intellect and his stupidity. I have seen a group with this description. Among them are those who exaggerated in jealousy until they killed their beloved fearing that they might die and others would enjoy their beloved after them, as mentioned about a group including Dik al-Jinn al-Homsi. I devoted a separate treatise to his story and named it 'Qar' Sinn Dik al-Jinn' (The Knocking of the Tooth of Dik al-Jinn/Regret). I wrote it to our Master Sultan Al-Nasir Hasan in the year seven hundred and sixty while he was in Siryaqus. I entered upon morning while what necessitated that had preceded. Therefore, I opened the mentioned treatise with my saying: He kisses the ground and informs that the mentioned Dik al-Jinn, among his madness, was that he loved a slave girl and a boy of his. Due to the intensity of his love for them and his jealousy over them, he feared that he would die and someone else would enjoy them after him. So he turned to them and slaughtered them with his sword, burned their bodies, and made from the girl's ashes a jar for wine and from the boy's ashes another jar likewise. He used to place them in his gathering of intimacy on his right and left. Whenever he longed for the girl, he kissed the jar made from her ashes, filled his cup from it, and recited: 'O face upon which death rose... And gathered the fruits of destruction for it with its hands. I quenched the dust with her blood, and long did... Passion quench my lips from her lips. And I roamed my sword in the field of her neck... While my tears flow upon her cheeks. So by the right of her sandals, and nothing trod the soil... Dearer to me than her sandals. Her killing was not because I did not... Weep if dust fell upon her. But she was stingy with her beauty to other than me... And disdained the looking of eyes at her.' And if he longed for the boy, he kissed the jar made from his ashes, filled his cup from it, wept, and recited his saying regarding him: 'I feared that Time would return with its treachery... Or I would be afflicted after union with his abandonment. A moon I extracted from his darkness... For my calamity, and stirred him from his chamber. So I killed him, and he has a dignity upon me... So mine are the vitals and his is the heart entirely. My pledge with him dead is like the best sleeper... While the eye sheds my tear on his throat. If the dead knew what is after him... With the living regarding him, he would weep for him in his grave. Choking griefs from which his soul almost overflows... And his heart almost exits his chest.' I say: This is what is said about it: Madness has arts. So to Allah we belong and to Him we return from the deed of this madman. Despite that, he is one of the softest people in poetry and most mentioning of the beloved. Of his poetry and elegant verse is his saying in supplicating against the beloved: 'How is the supplication against one who betrayed or wronged... While my owner is unjust in all he judged? May Allah not punish the one I desire for his harshness... To me, nor exact retribution for me from him, nor take revenge.' I say: The seeker became sought, and this is inverted jurisprudence. What guaranteed it is that he did to the loved ones what dogs do not do, so that he does not say 'May Allah not punish the one I desire for his harshness' and mix the softness of his poetry with his cruelty. He is in lightness and recklessness and killing the beloved, not in 'Aysh' (life) nor upon 'Aysh'. For he whom his desire overcame as you see, so he did to his beloved what he did and substituted his striking with the sword for kissing:

'His loved ones, why do you do to his heart... What his enemies do not do to him?' This treatise was affirmed in full in the First Chapter of my book 'Mir'at al-Uqul'. Falling into the line of this story is what Sheikh Athir al-Din Abu Hayyan narrated in his Tafsir at His saying Almighty: "Joseph, ignore this. And [O woman], ask forgiveness for your sin." He reported about Al-Aziz that he had little jealousy, and the soil of the region of Egypt necessitated this, meaning lack of jealousy. Then he said: And where is this from what happened to some kings of our lands? He was with his boon companions specified to him in his gathering of intimacy, and his slave girl was singing from behind the curtain. Some of his seated companions asked the slave girl to repeat two verses, and she had sung them. Not long after, the head of the slave girl was brought cut off in a basin, and the King said to him: 'Listen to this head.' That man who asked for the repetition fell down and was ill for the duration of that King's life. I said: If he had died, he would have been excused. There is no power nor strength except in Allah the Most High, the Great. Similar to this is also what Ja'far bin Sulayman did. That is, when he bought his slave girl Al-Zarqa', and she was a slave girl of high price, for eighty thousand dirhams, and she was of the beautiful young women with melodies. He said to her one day: 'Did anyone who loved you succeed in getting seclusion or a kiss from you?' She feared that something she had done in the presence of a group might reach him or had reached him. So she said: 'No, by Allah, except Yazid bin Awn al-Abbadi kissed me and paid for a pearl he sent thirty thousand dirhams.' Ja'far did not cease seeking him and plotting for him until he fell into his hands (literally: blood money), so he beat him with whips until he died. I said: He rested, by Allah, from all this headache. Abd al-Muhsin al-Suri recited where he said regarding lack of jealousy over his beloved: 'I became attached to him drunk from the wine of youth... Having heedlessness of my anguish and wailing. And every noble person shared with me in his love... Sharing with me in my soul a portion. So do not bind me to a jealousy I am not accustomed to... For my beloved is whoever my beloved loves.' The other reached (a limit) where he said boasting of pimping: 'I pimp, praise be to Allah, not out of hatred... While others are pimps against their will.' How excellent is the saying of Abu al-Husayn al-Jazzar: 'I said when the cupbearer poured... The wine on the ground. Out of jealousy from me over it... Would that I were dust.' Nur al-Din al-Ash'ari said, and excelled as he wished: 'The wind inclines the branches gently... Just as liquor inclined its drinker. It gathers between them after distance... And the leaves of the branches are a wrapper for them. They flutter in jealousy at meeting... So have you seen a pimp who is jealous?' Chapter Seven: Divulging the Secret and Concealment when Impossible. I say: We established this chapter to mention divulging the secret and its opposite, and the jest of each and its seriousness. For lovers have two schools in them. Among them are those who permitted its permissibility and saw their comfort in divulging it. And among them are those who saw its concealment as part of religion, so they settled in the ranks of love in the dearest place, where he said: ... Majnun of Amir divulged his desire... And I concealed desire so I died of my passion. So when on the Day of Resurrection it is called... Who is the victim of desire? I step forward alone. Yes, among people are those who concealed it, so his concealment showed him its non-existence. And among them are those who divulged it, so they fell into what they feared. For each of the two schools there is a witness and a sea of increasing tears whose drowned one is not saved nor is his path treaded. The lover of them is between two diseases, both dangerous, and two swords; he must be killed by one of them according to the correct famous (opinion), as Shihab al-Din al-Suhrawardi said: 'And mercy for the lovers! They bore... The secret of love, while desire exposes. In the secret, if they divulge, their blood is shed... And likewise, the blood of lovers is shed. And if they conceal, talking about them... With the slanderers is the shedding tear.' What I see regarding that - for him is discernment and simpler than dew - is that the lover, if he knows from his beloved loyalty and lack of aversion, then it is obligatory upon him to divulge the secret to the beloved and show the illness to the doctor, as was said: 'And reveal secrets to his people... And beware of revealing to others.' Abu Ja'far al-Shatranji triumphed where he said: 'Say to whom you wish that I am fond of you... Then leave him for Iblis to tame.' Some who practiced love and attracted its clever ones said: The lover divulging his secret to the beloved and complaining of what he endures is a type of magic. I said: Rather it is magic, the bulk and majority of it, and he knows that who tried it and whom love disciplined and refined.

Regarding this is the story of Ahmad bin Wasil. He said: When Abassa daughter of Al-Mahdi fell in love with Ja'far after Al-Rashid married him to her and conditioned on him not to approach her, her passion for him and love for him intensified. He did not comply with what she loved and feared for himself from Al-Rashid lest her matter appear. So she wrote to him: 'I resolved upon my heart to conceal desire... So it shouted and called out: Indeed I am not doing (so). If you do not contact me, I will divulge the secret by force... Even if my blamers embraced me in your love. Even if it is death, I will not die with my choking grief... And I admitted before death that you are my killer.' So she attained from him what she wanted. Did she obtain that except by divulging her secret and complaining of her harm? Ibn Shadhan the scribe said: 'Arib, the slave girl of Al-Ma'mun, said to me: I was with Al-Wathiq while he was touring the chambers of his slave girls when he went out to Al-Anbar for recreation. He entered upon Farida his slave girl, and he loved her very much. He also loved a maid of hers, but no one knew that other than me. When she saw him with her mistress, she entered her closet and stood at her head, wearing a headband on which these two verses were written in gold: "My eyes weep fearing separation... How hot is separation to the eye. I have not seen in love and its anguishes... More painful than the separation of the two friends (Ilfayn)." Al-Wathiq said to me: "Did you understand, O Arib?" I said: "Yes, my master." So he wrote on the ground with a stick in his hand: "Desire appeared and its curtains were torn... And the best path of love is its declaring. So disobey the blamers in your desire publicly... For the sweetest life of the wandering admirer is its publicity." She memorized the verses and they laughed together. Farida realized, so she said: "O my master, I knew what you two are in, so favor your maid by accepting her." Al-Wathiq said: "I have done so; take her to you, O Arib." So I took her hand, and he could not control himself until he left quickly from behind me, and was alone with her and ordered a thousand dinars for me.' Among them are those who do not run the mention of love on their tongue at all, and keep silent as if they had a silence disease. I have not seen regarding that, among what competitors compete in, better than the saying of Ibn Qalaqis: 'I concealed desire from the blamers, being protective... Of them regarding whom I yearn for and love. If I said I am a lover, they would roam with it... For their knowledge that none is loved but him.' Among them are those who bear his sin... And see declaring his name. 'So declare the name of whom you desire and leave me from nicknames... For there is no good in pleasures with a curtain before them.' Ibrahim bin Abdullah said: 'I saw on the cheek of a slave girl... Written with civet (Ghaliya) every day: I melt from the pain of longing... And my heart from aversion is ulcerated. I did not find seclusion with you to complain... What is in my heart, perhaps it would rest. Woe to my heart, as if it is the niche of a grave... That enclosed the limbs of a dead person with a soul.' In the second verse of these verses is a reminder that divulging the secret to the beloved can only be in seclusion. So no friend nor companion should know of it as long as he finds a way to that, as was said: 'O you who kindled the fire flaming on my liver... To you I complain of what afflicts me, not to anyone. To you I complain of what afflicts me of your love, for I... Sought other than you for the complaint but did not find.' Al-Ahwas said: 'By your life, I did not entrust my secret and her secret... To other than us, cautious lest the secrets be lost.' Of the witty things that passed me in this chapter is that some lover recited one day to his beloved the saying of the poet: 'My secret and your secret, no one felt it... Except the God, and you, then me.' She said to him: 'Do not forget the pimp, for she must know our secret and look into our matter.' Of the best I heard in dispraising the divulger of the secret is the saying of Al-Husayn bin Bishr: 'May Allah curse a man you entrusted a secret... To conceal it, and may Allah break his mouth. For he, with what you filled him of it... Is more leaking than glass regarding what it contained.' I said: It is not unlikely that one characterized by this attribute is of the offspring of the one who said: 'I do not conceal secrets but I gossip them... Nor do I leave secrets boiling on my heart. For of little intellect is he who spends his night... Secrets turning him side to side.' Where is this from the saying of the one who said: 'A sayer said: Why is your body not seen... Sick, while the bodies of lovers sicken? I said to her: My heart did not reveal your love... To my body, so my body does not know of the desire.' It is told that Sukayna bint al-Husayn bin Ali, may Allah be pleased with them, passed in her slave girls by Urwa bin Udhayna while he was singing. She said to her slave girls: 'Who is the Sheikh?' They said: 'Urwa.' So she turned towards him. She said: 'O Abu Tammam, you claim that you never loved? How, when you say: She said: And I spread my secret to her so I revealed it.'

'And you were, with me, loving the veil, so veil yourself. The veil (is) seeing who is around me.' I said to her: 'Your love covered what I meet from my sight.' She said: 'All you see around me of the slave girls are free if this speech ever came out of a sound heart.' It is told about Ahmad bin Abi Uthman the Scribe that he was a friend of Abu al-Fadl Abd al-Ghaffar al-Ansari. Ahmad loved a slave girl of Umm Ja'far named Nu'm and wandered in love with her. He informed him (Abd al-Ghaffar) of his secret and described her to him. So Abd al-Ghaffar al-Ansari loved her and fell ill with a long illness. His news reached Umm Ja'far, and she thought he had a (physical) illness, so she sent a doctor to him. He recited: 'Umm Ja'far sent a doctor to me... To treat me, excess of knowledge of the doctor. While my medicine and the origin of my disease are with her... In the hand of a deceived, nurtured fawn. Inform her that Nu'm is my medicine... To treat her patient soon.' Umm Ja'far heard the verses and asked about his story. When she understood it, she gifted him the slave girl. Ahmad abandoned Abd al-Ghaffar and said: 'I made you a place for my secret, so you spoiled (it) for me.' The corruptions resulting from divulging the secret to others are many. For this reason, Abu al-Ala al-Ma'arri said: 'Think evil of all brothers... And do not trust a heart with a secret.' Sahib Muhyi al-Din al-Jazari said in a letter: 'Oh wonder! How does he whom I do not name not realize, and not split (from grief) due to the abundance of my hovering around speech regarding him without fulfilling it? If I explained, souls would overflow, let alone eyes, and thoughts would throw themselves into the abysses of sin. If I showed some of it, I fear people would realize, and if I poured forth in it, I fear paper would not contain it.' Among the best I heard in concealing the secret is the saying of Al-Nabigha. Imam Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, used to quote it as a proverb: 'Do not divulge your secret, not (even) to you... For every adviser has an adviser. For I have seen the slanderers of men... Not leaving a hide intact.' Abd al-Malik bin Marwan wrote them to Al-Hajjaj, having asked him to keep a matter secret in a letter he wrote to him, but it appeared. Amr bin Al-Aas said: 'I never entrusted anyone with a secret and he divulged it, and I blamed him, because I was narrower of chest with it than him when I entrusted it.' The poet took it and said: '... If the chest of a man narrows from his own secret, then the chest of the one entrusted with the secret is narrower.' Another said: 'If you do not guard its secret for yourself... Then your secret among people is more spread and lost.' Abu Ja'far al-Shatranji said: 'Do not inform of your secret, but kill it... And make from your vitals a veil for it. I have never entrusted a secret like the soul... Nor closed a door like the chest.' Al-Mawardi narrated that Abdullah bin Tahir discussed keeping secrets in his gathering. He said: 'And one entrusting me with a secret, I guaranteed its covering... So I deposited it from the resting place of the vitals into a grave.' His son Abdullah, who was a boy, said and excelled as he wished: 'The secret in my heart is not like possessors of a grave... Because I see the buried waiting for the Resurrection. But I hide it until it is as if I... Never encompassed any knowledge of it from time.' Another said: 'O you who entrusted me with his secret... Do not hope to hear it from me. I did not run it later in my mind... As if it never passed my ear.' Bashar said: 'I will surely leave the world while your love... Is between the ribs; no one knew of it.' Talha bin Abi Bakr said: 'Do not show love for a beloved... Or you will see with your eyes every wonder from him. I showed my affection to a beloved one day... So I took a share of his abandonment.' It was said a man confided a speech to a man. When he finished, he said: 'Did you memorize?' He said: 'Rather, I forgot.' Ibn al-Mu'tazz said: 'Whenever the treasurers of secrets increase, its loss increases.' From the words of the wise: 'Guard your gold (Dhahab) just as you conceal your school of thought (Madhhab).' And: 'A man's killing place is between his jaws.' From the words of Judge Al-Fadil: 'Kill secrets in your heart and bury their dead in your side. For it is ugly for you that a secret is seen of you except by your Lord.' A Bedouin described a people saying: 'Their swords are the banes of lives, and their chests are the graves of secrets.' How excellent is the saying of Ibn Mamati from verses: 'The prison narrowed on me until it was as if I... Settled in it for narrowness in the chest of a resentful one. Oh would that I were like the tear in the eyelid of a lover... So I exit, or like the secret in the chest of a fool.' Al-Abbas bin al-Ahnaf said: 'My tear divulged, so it does not conceal a secret... And I found the tongue possessing concealment. I was like the book, its folding hid it... So they found indication of it by the address.' Chapter Eight: Tricking the Beloved, Appeasing him, and Remedying his Anger and Deviation.

I say: We established this chapter to mention tricking the beloved regarding himself, and joining his day with his yesterday. It is one of the greatest chapters in content, most numerous in bribery, best in invention, most in deception, most eloquent in gathering firewood (rhetoric), and most in hitting the mark. We will present of that what is sweet to present and good to recite for the people of composition, so they know that the writer tricks the beloved and races with the delicacy of his words the crimson wine. Of that, and it is among the best I heard in tricking the beloved: 'Rise with us, O light of my eye... Let us make doubt certainty. ... Until when, O my beloved... Will the killer sin regarding us?' Similar is the saying of the other: 'I do not forget, I do not forget her saying at Mina... Woe to you, the slanderers have worked. And a slanderer gossiped about us, so I said to her... Do you have (interest), O Hind, in what they claimed? She said: For what do you see? I said to her... So that the thoughts and accusations are not wasted.' Al-Abbas bin al-Ahnaf said: 'As if there was no desire between me and you... And my rope was not connected to your rope. And I am ashamed for you of a narrator... Narrating about you boredom and procrastination.' Another said: 'I was attributed to a sin while I was not a sinner... And you burdened me in love with what I cannot bear. And my seeking of union is not greed for survival... But it is a reward I drive to you.' I said: 'He is not satisfied to go equal for equal... Until I drive the reward to him also.' Among what I said in this meaning: 'I did not request union for my sake, may I be your ransom, O... One who increased my luck in blackness with moles. But I feared that you be afflicted with the love of a fawn... Who exacts retribution for me from you, and the world is requital.' Another said: 'People have increased types of talk about us... And people separated their sayings about us, a separation. So a liar threw suspicion on other than you... And a truthful one does not know that he spoke truth.' Another said: 'O my master, you have a wrong against me... So ask Ibn Abi Khaythama for a fatwa regarding it. For he narrates it from his grandfather... And his grandfather narrates it from Ikrimah. From Ibn Abbas, from the Chosen One... Our Prophet sent with mercy. That the cutting off of a friend from his friend... Above three (days), our Lord forbade it. And you have been abandoning us for a month... Do you not fear Allah regarding us? So stop!' Jamil said: 'And what might the slanderers say... Other than to say that I am a lover ('Ashiq) of you? Yes, the slanderers spoke truth, you are beloved... To me, even if the traits were not described of you.' I said: This is how I saw it in most of the copies of Al-Hamasa I stood upon and heard from the mouths of the people of literature, meaning the rhyme of the first verse is 'Ashiq'. The correct is that it is 'Wamiq', because the meaning according to that is its explanation is that the 'Wamiq' is the lover without suspicion, and the 'Ashiq' is the lover with suspicion. Since that is so, the trickery is not valid except by his saying 'And what might the slanderers say other than that I am a Wamiq of you', meaning a lover without suspicion. Ibn Rawaha al-Hamawi said: 'If my killing is sweet to you... Then increase the abandonment in my torture. Perhaps the standing between me... And you before Allah in the Reckoning will be prolonged.' It is told that some recited to a youth he loved: 'What will you say when we meet tomorrow... And I say to the Merciful: This is my killer?' And I say to the Merciful: This is my killed. The youth said to him: 'I say this wanted to... so I enabled him.' Ibn Sana' al-Mulk said: From a letter: 'And I, by Allah, am overcome in your matter. The reason is that I am the lover (Muhibb) and you are the beloved (Mahbub). I do not strive against you, deceiving you and betraying your love, nor do I affect against you, cheating you and grieving your heart. Do what you wish, for I am the patient, and kill how you wish, for I am the thankful. Say to me, for I have a hearing that loves your speech, and turn, you will see my hopes fluttering around you. So do, for you are the excused, and lengthen (the arrogance), for I am not the harmed but the pleased. And return to the affection that is between us, for every sin of yours is forgiven.' He also said: 'And I seek refuge in Allah from a sin that necessitates your blame, hints at your punishment, turns your heart away, makes you bend your side (in arrogance), and changes you against your slave: I am not strong in endurance of your abandonment... Nor fully armed against your blame.' Ibn al-Sawadi, the famous poet, said: 'I complain to you, and of your aversion I complain... And I think due to my fondness that you are fair to me. And I turn away from you fearing lest be seen... Aversion from you, so he who gloats gloats.' Judge Abu Amr Muhammad bin Yusuf al-Azdi narrated saying: I was walking with Abu Bakr Muhammad bin Dawud al-Isfahani in Baghdad, and behold a slave girl singing from poetry:

'I complain to you of a heart you are its destroyer... The complaint of a sick one to an intimate tending him. An illness whose abundance increases with days... And you, in the greatness of what I encounter, belittle it. Allah forbade my killing in love foolishly... And you, O my killer, unjustly make it lawful.' Muhammad bin Dawud said: 'What is the way to retrieve this?' I said to him: 'Far from it! The riders have traveled with it.' Abu Abdullah said: 'My heart is softer for you than your cheeks... And my powers are weaker than the powers of your eyelids. Why do you not have mercy on one whose heart you torture... Unjustly, while his desire inclines him towards you?' Nasir al-Din bin al-Naqib said: 'Zakat has become obligatory upon your beauty... And in it, like what is in wealth, is a right. So do not deviate with it from me, for I am... Its poor deserving recipient.' Judge Shams al-Din bin Khallikan, may Allah have mercy on him, said from a poem: 'Were I not in a rank for which I observe... The old covenant preserving the position. I would have torn my veil in your love, and to my humiliation... Cast off restraint, and my blamer would have persisted regarding you. But I feared that my blamers would say: This Sheikh has gone mad for this boy.' Another said: 'My arguments against you when you are alone are many... And when you are present, I am defeated. I cannot say you wronged me... Allah knows that I am wronged.' Al-Mukarram said: 'People have sinned regarding us by their suspicion... And believed what I know and you know. What harms you in confirming their suspicion... By us realizing what they say about us? My bearing and your bearing of a single sin, trusting... In forgiveness, is more beautiful than the sin of mankind regarding us.' Al-Mutanabbi said: 'Supply us from the beauty of your face as long as it lasts... For the beauty of faces is a changing state. And connect us with your union now in the world... For the stay in it is little.' I say: This last verse is good in its chapter regarding tricking the beloved and appeasing him. As for the first, it contains alienation. Would that he rested and relieved and left mocking beautiful faces. However, Al-Tala'fari imitated him in mocking his loved ones. Possessor of a verse said: 'O leaver of the quarter of patience in me destroyed... There is no coming seen for an absent union. Describe your Lord to the lovers and be gentle with them... And do not think that the state of beauty lasts.' Chapter Nine: Messengers and Letters, and Gentleness in Means. I say: We established this chapter to mention correspondence with loved ones and complaining of ardency in the reply. It is a trodden path, a selling market. Often the lover presented the commodity of emaciation to the messenger in it. Especially one whose patience failed and whose matter became famous, so he became thrown in the house, and used even the wind in corresponding with the beloved, as was said: 'O breeze of the East, you are the messenger to him... And Allah knows that I am jealous of you. Convey my greeting to one whom I do not speak to... That I am angry at that angry one. No, O messenger, do not mention my anger to him... For that is from me camouflage and falsehood. And how can I be angry? No, by Allah, no anger... Indeed, I am rejoicing at what he intended of my killing. Is there every day for us messengers going back and forth... And every day for us types of blame? I use the wind to carry peace to you... As if I am in the time of Solomon.' He is halved by desire and on a journey from establishing abandonment. No stability settles for him, and he does not warm himself by the fire of his beloved's cheek. No wonder he distracts himself with the gentle breeze and says regarding inhaling a little of it: 'Your little cannot be called little.' Among the best I heard in this chapter is the saying of Al-Wawa al-Dimashqi: 'By Allah, your Lord, turn to my dweller... And blame him, perhaps blame bends him. And speak to him and say in your speech... What is the matter with your slave, with abandonment you destroy him? If he smiles, say in kindness... What harm if you aid him with a union from you? And if anger appears to you in his face... Then deceive and say: We do not know him.' He took it from the saying of Umar bin Abi Rabi'a from verses describing his pimp: 'So a knowledgeable doctor came to her... Mixing seriousness repeatedly with play. She roughens speech if she softens to her... And slackens at the fits of anger.' It is said that Ibn Atiq said to Umar when he heard this saying of his: 'How much the Muslims need a Caliph to manage their affair like this pimp of yours.' Similar to Al-Wawa's saying is the saying of the other: 'lo, O breeze of the wind, convey my message... To Sulayma and compensate with me as if you are joking.

'And if she turns away from me, then camouflage deceivingly... With another, and say: The wailing women wailed over him.' And the saying of the other, a Dubayt: 'With kindness, if you meet the one I desire... Blame him and tell him what I encounter. If union angers him, deceive him with it... Or if he softens, say: Your slave, do not forget him.' Abu Firas said: 'A northern wind blew on us... Linked to the heart by causes. It performed messages of love between us... I knew it from among my companions.' Al-Sahib bin Abbad, may Allah have mercy on him, used to sway when he heard these two verses. I have dedicated a separate chapter to the Breeze in my book 'Suluk al-Sunan fi Wasf al-Sakan' and mentioned in it things fitting for this chapter. Among them is the saying of Amin al-Din Ibn Ataya: 'I desire the branch of the dune (Naqa) and these... While my heart in his love is in the wilderness. O breeze of the East, be gentle with him... And be kind to him and do not harm him. And carry a message; there is none but... You, a trustee in carrying it whom I approve. And if a breeze is not my messenger... Towards the branch of the dune, who will bend him?' Ibn al-Khayyat al-Dimashqi said: 'O breeze of the East fond of my passion... How excellent you would be if you passed by Hind. And your scent made me doubt, so by Allah when... Was its covenant with the ruins of Najd?' Mahyar al-Daylami said: 'Load the breeze of the East with your scent... Before it carries wormwood and lavender. And send me your phantom in the darkness... If you permit my eyelids to sleep.' It is told that Nur al-Din Ali bin Sa'id al-Maghribi, author of 'Al-Murqis wal-Mutrib', passed with a group of Egyptian literati, among them Abu al-Husayn al-Jazzar. They passed in their way by a handsome youth sleeping under a tree, and the wind blew and uncovered his clothes from him. Abu al-Husayn al-Jazzar said: 'Stop, so each of us may compose something on this.' He said: Not long after, Nur al-Din mentioned said: 'The wind is the greatest pimp because it... Reveals the secrets of the buttocks and the folds of the belly. And it sways the branches when it blows... Until the faces of the streams kiss. Therefore, lovers take it... As messengers to loved ones and homelands.' Abu al-Husayn al-Jazzar said: 'None of us remains who can come up with the like of this, so let us go.' Ali al-Saffar said: 'If a breeze blew with good scent... I rejoiced and said: Welcome, O Messenger. Except that I am jealous because in it... Is your scent and it is sick like me.' Judge Muhyi al-Din bin Abd al-Zahir used to love a young singer named Nasim (Breeze) and has several stanzas about him, including his saying: 'If lovers, out of their longings... Made the breeze a messenger to the beloved. Then I am the one who recites to them: Would that I... Had taken a path with the messenger.' I said, as if present addressing him implying (quotation): 'If you are in the love of Nasim (Breeze/Name) enslaved... And claimed that his desire (air) is not destructive. Then I say to one who provoked love... You exposed yourself to wear, so be a target.' Judge Muhyi al-Din also said regarding his beloved Nasim: 'O you who became to me from the storms... Of abandonment, the barren wind. Do you think he treats my love... And it is said: The Nasim (Breeze/Patient) has softened?' I said as if present addressing him: 'By Allah, if the Nasim softened and subsided... A fire kindled by the hand of torment. Transfer your heart wherever you wish from desire... And leave the blamer and his saying in the wind.' Judge Muhyi al-Din also said: 'Thanks to the breeze of your land... How much greeting it conveyed from me. And to you it prolonged, rather made pleasant... In its intelligent messages. No wonder if it memorized the... Hadiths of Love, for it is intelligent (Dhakiyyah - also implies fragrant).' Salah al-Din Khalil bin Aybak al-Safadi from the people of the age took it and said: 'O good scent that blew to me from your land... So it stirred the hidden of my anguish and my exposure. It gifted your greeting and resembled your kindness... And narrated your scent; indeed this is an intelligent (Dhakiy) wind.' I said when I stood upon this saying of his and the saying of Judge Muhyi al-Din preceding him: 'Indeed the son of Aybak, his thefts ceased not... To come with every ugly and ugly thing. He attributed meanings in the breeze to himself... Ignorantly, so his speech went in the wind.'

I have mentioned regarding the Breeze pleasant things in my book 'Suluk al-Sunan' mentioned, and restricted myself from them to this amount here fearing elongation. The messenger must be of the people of maintenance (of dignity) and of those who refer to religion, lest he covets and becomes an intimate friend after being a messenger, as happened to the messenger of Ibn Sana' al-Mulk, regarding whom he said: 'He went as a messenger and came back to me a lover... And an obstacle hindered him from my message. And he returned to me not with the answer, but with ardency... That silenced him while passion speaks through him.' Another said: 'The messenger returned to me while he was enslaved.' For this reason, Ibn al-Athir said: 'There is no trust over Beauty, and in its like treachery is excused.' Al-Mutanabbi said: 'What is the matter with us, all of us are Jawwa (Yamamah), O messenger... I love and your heart is the sick one. And whenever he returned from the one I sent to... He was jealous of me and betrayed in what he says. Her eyes corrupted the trusts between us... And hearts betrayed minds.' He rests (meaning): Her eyes by their magic corrupted the trust of the messenger in the message, and hearts betrayed minds, meaning minds separated from hearts because of her. Al-Arjani said: 'An oath, the breeze indeed returned sick... When it traveled from me to you as a messenger. And it knew by your love that it had betrayed me... So it became dragging the tails of life (in shame).' Among the best I heard regarding Letters and Gentleness in Means is what is told about Al-Malik Al-Aziz son of Sultan Salah al-Din. He loved a songstress in the days of his father and was fond of her. Salah al-Din heard (of it), so he forbade him from her company and forbade her from him. He grieved and was unable to meet with her. A period of days passed on that. Then she sent him with a servant a ball of ambergris. He broke it and found in it a button of gold. He did not understand her intent by that. Judge Al-Fadil came to him and he informed him of the shape. He said immediately: 'She gifted you ambergris, in its center... A button of raw gold, thin of welding. So the button (Zirr) from the ambergris (Anbar), its interpretation is... Visit (Zur) like this, hidden in the dark.' Ala' al-Din al-Maghribi said from the 'Letter of the Two Luminaries', which is from the depressed lover to the beloved of the beloved, opening it with his saying: 'He kisses the ground and informs before the Merciful King, the Sultan of Beauties and the Lion of Struggle,' from it: 'The Nile went and returned... And my love continues. Whenever I said tomorrow will... Decrease some of the passion, it increased. Every heart other than my heart... Attained the desire in love. And I, the poor one, alone... Attained stubbornness in companionship.' The narrator said: Then Ala' al-Din said: 'And I, the poor one, alone urinated in the plate of Qata'if (pancakes) and made the vinegar Nataf (sweet). I whistled to Iblis with his accuracy and left him lowering and clapping and singing "Tallalah": O little eyes of the gazelle. May Allah have mercy on who killed me... And what pride is there in killing the like of me? Am I but a little poet, a silly laughingstock, who made his letters his means and his poems his traps? He milks the udder of humility and removes the mask of contentment. If he hungers, he eats from the scansion of meters, and if he thirsts, he drinks from the seas of poetry, in a time where there is no difference among its people between the slanderer and the praiser, and the shouter and the wailer: I tasted from him what... Abu al-Husayn al-Qalla' (the tooth-puller) does not pull from my molar. Rather, what thing is more beautiful than two luxurious fawns, two intimates, suckling the breast of companionship, sipping the cup of love, picking the fruit of union, greeting each other with types of coquetry, describing to each other the burning of desire, and spreading out the spreading of pigeons? Nothing attends them but joking and joy, and nothing kisses them but the cup of wine: Two like one from the length of their embrace, spending the night in a praiseworthy night not dispraised, revealing two luminaries and smiling about two pearls (rows of teeth), and stealing looks with the glances of two wild calves. As if they divided the arts of beauty and benevolence with the two pans of the balance. If they exchange admonition or correspond with a letter, it is scattered decree and magic not forbidden. And if they race in the field of desire or pelt each other with the arrows of ardency, the avenger is avenged and the magician is enchanted.' It is a witty, elegant letter, all of it of this type. I restricted myself from it to this amount (fearing) elongation. I mentioned it in full in the second part of 'Hatib Layl'. I said, from what I wrote to some friends: 'I wrote to you while the lines, their letters... Have eyes gazing at you and glancing. And I have a pen, for whose moist tongue... Is the greeting of a yearning one whom yearning has emaciated.' Chapter 10: Tricks on the Phantom of Imagination and other things said about it with differing meanings.

I say: We established this chapter to mention the visiting Phantom of Imagination (Tayf al-Khayal) and what has been said about its travel in current proverbs. For poets have tricks and subtle beauty in hunting it. Often they increased its mention and extracted it from its nest, so they brought close upon it the distance of the journey and did not loathe appending its augury to physiognomy. Among those famous for excellence in it is Abu Ubadah (Al-Buhturi) and others like Ibn al-Naqib, the tricker in hunting the phantom of the beloved: Where he said and spoke well: 'I set up my eyelids as traps for the phantom... Perhaps a phantom from him presents itself in slumber. And how, if I close them, can I hunt him... While traps are customarily opened for hunting?' How excellent is the saying of Sheikh Jamal al-Din Ibn Nubata in Tawriya (double entendre): 'And one fond of traps... He extends them and nets. The eye said to me: What... Does he hunt? I said: Your slumber (Karak - also implies sandgrouse).' I also said: 'And I swear if the phantom granted a visit... It would encounter the door of the eyelid locked by opening (Fath).' Abu Muhammad Abdullah al-Saruji said and excelled as he wished: 'Grant your union, for this is its time... Sufficient is what I have tasted of abandonment. I spent my life in your love, and would that I... Was given a union for what I spent. O you with whose love I was occupied from others... And I forgot all people when I loved you. You are the one whose face gathered beauties... But upon it I dispersed my patience. How many a knight roamed in the field of your love... With patience from me in your desire I preceded him. The slanderers said he claimed a relation to you... So I was pleased when I said: You believed him. By Allah, if they ask you about me, say to them... My slave and the property of my hand, and I did not free him. Or if it is said: He is longing for you, say to them... I know that, and I am the one who made him long. O beauty of a phantom from your imagination that visited me... From my joy at meeting him, I did not verify him. So he passed, and in my heart is a regret over him... If sleep were possible for me, I would have caught him.' Abu Tammam said: 'The phantom visited for her, no, rather a thought visited for him... If the thought of people slept, he did not sleep. A fawn I hunted when I set up for him... From the end of the night traps from the dream.' He also said: 'O what a pleasure spirits enjoyed... In it secretly from bodies, a gathering. We had no fault in it... Except that we were in the call of dreams.' Al-Buhturi said: And he is among those who did much in describing the phantom, excelling in it. Due to his fondness for it and fame, he became a proverb. So it was said 'The Phantom of Al-Buhturi'. Of that is his saying: 'Whenever slumber gifted her phantom to me... Its nearness cured the agony or quenched the thirst. If an awakening snatched it from my hand... I thought a beloved went from me or ran. I have not seen the like of us nor the like of our affair... We are tortured awake and blessed asleep.' And his saying: 'And I did not forget the aid of slumber by her nearness... And her visit after the quiet, while she did not know. If the night gave us a language of union... The early signs of morning turned us to abandonment.' And his saying also: 'She sent her phantom to me while between me... Is a march of two months for strong camels. They visited here from Al-Sham, so he greeted... A wandering lover in the land of Iraq. So he judged what he judged and returned to her... While the darkness was in the patched garment of worn out (clothes).' And his saying: 'And a night we nodded (in sleep) regarding life, she sent... A phantom of imagination whose falsehood resembles the truth. Were it not for the whiteness of morning, my clinging would have been long... To the sides of a gazelle I spent the night flirting with.' How many a hand of the night is praiseworthy to me... And to the morning is a matter whose consequences are dispraised.' Abd al-Samad bin al-Mu'adhdhal said: 'Sleep connected between us after abandonment... So we met while we were separated. Except that spirits feared a watcher... So they folded their secret from bodies. A view that was the pleasure of the heart except... That it was a view without visual witnessing.' Al-Murtada said these verses are narrated for Al-Humayduni and they are many of his like. Ibn al-Qattan the Baghdadi poet entered one day upon the Vizier Al-Zayni while Al-Hays Bays was with him. He said: 'I have composed two verses for which a third cannot be composed because I have exhausted the meaning in them.' The Vizier said: 'And what are they?' So he recited: 'The phantom visited, stingy like its sender... So the embrace and kisses did not cure me of him. He never visited me except to agree with me... On sleep, so he banishes it and departs.'

The Vizier said to Al-Hays Bays: 'What do you say to his claim?' He said: 'If he repeats them, he will hear a third for them.' So he repeated them. Al-Hays Bays said: 'And he did not know that my sleep was a trick set up... Subtle, when tricks exhausted wakefulness.' Another said: 'Behold, many a phantom of yours spent the night embracing me... Until the caller of the morning called: Come to prayer.' The first to describe the phantom was Amr bin Qami'ah as narrated by Al-Murtada in the book 'Al-Tayf wal-Khayal', saying: 'Umamah distanced herself except for a question... And except for a phantom meeting a phantom. A phantom imagining to me attaining her... And if I were able, I would not imagine attainment.' The first to drive away the phantom was Tarafa bin al-Abd where he said: 'So say to the phantom of the Hanzaliyyah, let him return... To her, for I connect the ropes of the one who connects.' Jarir followed him and said: 'The huntress of the heart knocked (at night), and this is not the time of the visit, so return in peace.' Stranger than Jarir in driving away the phantom is Al-Ra'i where he satirized him saying: 'The phantom circled my companions, so I said to them... Is that Laila who came by night or the Ghoul?' Our Master the Chief Judge Taj al-Din al-Subki refuted Jarir and excelled as he wished where he said: 'I wish I knew, did Jarir love... When he showed his excuse? If his love was true... Then his heart is like stones. Nay, harder in cruelty... So look at him showing his shame. When he said a saying not said by... A lover of affection and boldness: "The huntress of the heart knocked... And (this is) not the visit."' He also said refuting him: 'This speech of yours, O Jarir... Is to me the most hideous that is said. Is there a time not suitable... For the visit and union? Or was it said before you: Return... And for that is a sin not forgiven (said). Or was your love false... So his sleep negates the phantom? Or was your heart of iron... Arrows do not harm it?' I said: 'Shame on you, O Jarir... In gatherings and scenes. The huntress of the heart knocked... So you were a lover (Sabb) not a hunter (Sa'id). So you turned back the phantom of her imagination... This is a corrupt imagination from you. Is the phantom more in love than you when... He came to you while you were sleeping? The like of you has not returned as long as... A visitor for lovers remains among people.' I also said from a poem: 'My heart demands him of me, so it is as if I am... A debtor and my heart in demanding him is a creditor (Mughram - also means fond). I have of him in the night of slumber and its day... A visiting phantom or a greeting beloved.' Shams al-Din Muhammad bin al-Afif al-Tilimsani said: 'O welcome to your phantom as a comer... O best of the world in the world. A phantom whose light manifested shining... Until the eye of the sleeper saw it. O absent one who rules over my soul... Over me the absence of the ruler has prolonged. It is a shame on your beauty that... My lot complains of it that it is my oppressor.' Al-Tihami excelled in preferring the phantom over the reality where he said: 'The union of the phantom and the union of the maiden if she is stingy... Are equal; how similar is finding to non-existence! The phantom is better in union, for its pleasure... Is free of sin, disturbance, and regret.' Kushajim reached the limit in subtlety where he apologized on the tongue of the beloved for the delay of the phantom, saying: 'She was stingy even with a greeting phantom... To me, and said: Mercy for my beloved. I fear for my phantom if it comes knocking... Your pillow, that the phantom of my watcher meets it.' How excellent also is the excuse of Al-Maghribi, and Ibn 'Unayn included it and wrote with it from Yemen to his brother in Damascus: 'I forgave your letters in the estrangement, knowing... That the sheet lacked a carrier. And I excused your phantom in the harshness because... It travels by night but morning comes whilst it is stages away from us.' Another said: 'And the phantom of the one I love visited me cautiously... Of the slanderers, while the caller of the morning had shouted. I almost woke those around me with it out of joy... And the covering of love almost tore due to my fondness. Then I woke up and my hopes failed me... Obtaining the wish, so my envy turned into regret.' Ibn al-Mu'tazz said: 'I saw him in sleep apologizing... To me for what he committed while awake. And he softened until when I intended him... I found him at morning non-existent.'

It was said that it is of the misery of the world that a person sees in his sleep that he smelled perfume, reached a beloved, attained glory, or found a treasure, but when he wakes up he sees nothing of that. Perhaps he saw that he had wet himself, and when he wakes up he sees that surely in his clothes. As was said about it: 'I see in my sleep everything that pleases me... And my vision after sleep is more severe and uglier. If it was good, it is pipe dreams... And if it was evil, it came to me before I woke up.' Al-Ma'arri said: 'To Allah I complain that I, every night... If I slept, I did not lack thoughts of illusions. If it was evil, it is no doubt real... And if it was good, it is pipe dreams.' How excellent is the saying of Ibn al-Tilmidh: 'I blamed when your phantom did not visit in sleep... So my longing for you is robbed. So he visited me gracefully and blamed me... As it is said: Dreams are inverted.' Ibn al-Ahnaf said: 'And I dream in sleep of all good... Then I wake up not seeing it and it not seeing me. And if I saw evil in my sleep... I met evil before the Adhan.' How witty is the saying of Ibn al-Mu'tazz: 'The phantom visited without his praise... And replaced me with union from his repulsion. How many a sleep for me was a pimp... It brought the beloved despite his distance.' Similar is the saying of the other: '... I left satirizing Iblis then praised him... And that matter was hard for me to follow. He brings the one I desire near sometimes, and if he refuses... He imitated him as a phantom in slumber so...'. Some Sheikhs of the age said: 'If your phantom in sleep were my companion... I would not spend the night complaining of my anguish and fever. A moon who circulated upon me the wine of his saliva... And his glances and his intimate speech. My reliance in his nearness and presence... And his loyalty is only upon Iblis.' How excellent is the saying of Judge Al-Fadil, may Allah have mercy on him: 'This is because I do not count a favor for the phantom. Even if he rode the unknowns, cut the stages, stepped over branches of spears to me, waded streams of swords, trod on thorns of blades, stumbled on mountains of imagination, and approached while the eyes of stars around me were gazing and the tips of bows were near. How can I count a favor for him while the thought is civilian (nearby) and I am awake? And he represents what was not of his nearness just as eyes represented of him what was.' It is told about some simpleton that he tired himself in obtaining a woman he desired for a long time. When she was obtained at his house, he put his head down and slept. She said to him: 'Why did you do this?' He said: 'Out of my love for you I sleep, perhaps I see your phantom in sleep.' It is told about some miser that he said to his beloved: 'I put my cheek on the ground so that you may be pleased.' She said: 'Give me a dinar so I let you put your cheek on my cheek.' The saying of the poet reached the limit of kindness: 'She said to a phantom of imagination that visited me and left... By Allah, describe him and do not decrease nor increase. He said: I left him such that if he died of thirst... And I said: Stand (stop) from arriving at the water, he would not arrive (to drink). She said: You spoke the truth; loyalty in love is his habit... Oh the coolness of what she said on my liver.' And the saying of the other: 'Why did you not prevent, since you prevented her speech... A phantom coming to us from a distance, guiding?' ... 'May Allah water ruins in the courtyards of the Hima... Even if they have shown the people a condition... Dwellings, if my funeral passed by them... The echo (owl/thirst) would say: O my two companions, descend with me.' Tawba bin al-Humayri said: 'If you prevent Laila and the goodness of her speech... You will not prevent me from weeping for the rhymes. So why did you not prevent, since you prevented her speech... A phantom coming to us from a distance, guiding?' Chapter Eleven: Shortness and Length of the Night, Dyeing of its Twilight and its Fading, and what carries that meaning. I say: We established this chapter to mention one whose sleeplessness of his short eyelid became long, so he reached evening having no ambassador but the unveiling of the morning. So he recites from the intensity of burning and abundance of insomnia: 'O Night, be long or do not be long... I must keep vigil with you. If my Moon (beloved) spent the night with me... I would not spend the night tending to your stars (moon).' Lovers have never ceased complaining of the night and its length, describing it with blackness of face upon its arrival. Their excuse in that is clear. How not, when the poet said regarding it: 'The darkness died in a night... Which I revived when it darkened (As'as). If the night had a morning... That lived, it would have breathed.' Sharaf al-Din Ahmad bin Munqidh said: 'When I saw the star with a wondering eye... And the Pole had cast a drowsiness upon it. And the Daughters of Na'sh (Ursa Major) in mourning, unveiled... I became certain that their morning had died.' He also said: 'And many a night in which its star got lost... I cut it with sleeplessness, so it lengthened and darkened. And I asked it about its morning, so it answered me... Had it been in the bonds of life, it would have breathed.' I say: Before beginning to cite the stanzas of this chapter, a pleasant story relating to the length and shortness of night is mentioned here. It is what Abu Muhammad Ismail bin Mansur al-Jawaliqi narrated. He said: A youth stood over my father while he was sitting in a circle in which students were reading to him. He said: 'O my master, I heard two verses of poetry and did not understand their meaning.' He said to him: 'Say.' So he recited: 'The union of the beloved is Gardens of Eternity he inhabits... And abandonment is the Fire; he burns us with the Fire. For the sun is in Sagittarius in the evening while it is descending... If he does not visit me, and in Gemini if he visits.' He said: When my father heard them, he said to him: 'O my son, this is something of the knowledge of stars and their movement, not of the craft of the people of literature.' So the youth left without gaining benefit. My father was ashamed because he asked about something he had no knowledge of. He swore to himself not to sit in a circle until he looked into the science of stars and knew the movement of what was asked. (It means) that if the sun is in the end of Sagittarius, the night is at the extreme of length because it is the end of the autumn season. And if it is in the end of Gemini, the night is at the extreme of shortness because it is in the end of the spring season. As if he says: If he does not visit me, the night for me is extremely long, and if he visits me, the night for me is extremely short. The one who said (the following) was fair: 'I do not wrong the night nor claim... That the stars of the night do not move. My night is as she wished; if she does not visit... It is long, and if she visits, my night is short.' How excellent is the saying of Al-Arjani: 'Our night is but equal, but... Its difference is that we stayed awake and you slept.' Among the best said regarding the shortness of the night: The saying of Abu Ishaq al-Suli... 'And a night of the nights of Venus (Zahr)... In which I met its full moon with my full moon. It was nothing but twilight and dawn... Until it turned away while it was the virgin of time.' Al-Radi said: 'O night, due to its shortness, almost... The Isha (evening) stumbles in it on the Sahar (pre-dawn).' Another said: 'I asked the night why it turned away defeated... While the beloved spent the night at my suggestion. It said: My stars sank and traveled... Plotting against me until the morning.' Among the best said regarding the length of the night is the saying of Al-Abbas bin al-Ahnaf: 'O sleepers around me, aid me... Against the night and leave excuses. Tell me about the day, a hadith... Describe it, for I have forgotten the day.' Another said: 'My covenant with us is behind the night wrapping... And the night is longest like the glance of the eye. And now my night since they departed, may I ransom them... Is the night of the blind, so my morning is not awaited.' Ibn al-'Attariyah said: 'The eyes of darkness stayed awake with me... And the eyes of the beauties slept on me. Whenever the night complained of the abandonment of the morning... I complained to Allah of the abandonment of the beautiful (Sabah).' Ibn al-Zaqqaq said: 'I have a dwelling which estrangement made distant... My eyes were generous to it with rain. The dawn was not beautiful nor did it please me... Its whiteness since he departed in the caravan. As if the morning for us after him... Is an eye that turned white from grief.' How excellent is the saying of Judge Al-Fadil: 'We spent the night in a state where desire delights... And perhaps explanation is not possible. We guarded the night and said to it... If you leave us, the morning attacks.' Yaqut said: 'As if the Pleiades is a palm spanning the darkness... To know if the night is long or has become wide. So a night you see between east and west... Being measured by a span, how is its expiration hoped for?' Sheikh Sadr al-Din bin al-Wakil took it and said: 'By the palm of the Pleiades, while it is amputated, is measured for me... The width of darkness extended from East and West. Even if they measured it by the cubit, it would not end... So it does not end by night or my death ends.' Al-Arjani excelled in apologizing for the length of the night, saying: 'I do not claim the injustice of time nor do I see... My night increasing in length over nights. But the mirror of the morning breathed (sighed)... For worry, so it rusted its polished face.' Mudar bin al-Faq'asi said: 'And a night, people say from its darknesses... The healthy of eyes and the one-eyed are equal. As if we had from it fortified houses... Haircloth their tops and teak wood their fractures.'

And the daughters of Na’ash in mourning were unveiled … I realized that their morning was approaching. He also said: 'And sometimes a night in which its star gets lost … spent in sleeplessness and vigilance.' I asked him about its morning, and he replied: 'If it were alive, it would breathe.' Before presenting sections of this chapter, a subtle story should be mentioned related to the length and shortness of night, told by Abu Muhammad Ismail ibn Mansur al-Jawali. He said: My father saw a young man sitting in a circle, reading poetry with students, who said: 'O sir, I heard two lines of poetry but did not understand their meaning.' My father said: 'Recite them.' He recited: 'The beloved reached the gardens of eternity … and the fire's exile reaches us through it. The sun in Sagittarius has set … if it does not visit me, and in Gemini if it visits.' Upon hearing this, my father said: 'My son, this is about knowledge of the stars and their movement, not literary craftsmanship.' The young man left without benefit. My father felt embarrassed for being asked about something he had no knowledge of and resolved not to sit in a circle until he studied astronomy and learned the stars' paths. If the sun is in the last degrees of Sagittarius, the night is very long, at the end of autumn. If it is in the last degrees of Gemini, the night is very short, at the end of spring. So, if the sun does not visit, the night is long; if it visits, the night is short. As the poet said: 'I do not oppress the night nor claim … that the night stars follow my will; if they do not visit … the night is long, if they do, my night is short.' Al-Arjani said: 'Our night is equal, it only differs by whether we are awake or asleep.' Among the best expressions about short nights: Abu Ishaq al-Suli said: 'One night among the nights of spring, I encountered its full moon … nothing but dawn and twilight until it set, the first of time.' Al-Radi said: 'O night, if it shortens, the evening stumbles with the dawn.' Another said: 'I asked the night why it passed quickly … while my beloved slept under my proposal; my stars sped, accompanying me until morning.' Abbas ibn al-Ahnaf said about long nights: 'O you sleepers around me, assist me in the night and leave excuses. Tell me about the day, describe it, for I have forgotten it.' Another said: 'My custom throughout the night … the night is long like a glimpse of the eye. Now my night has passed, and my morning is unawaited.' Ibn al-‘Atariya said: 'The eyes of the darkness kept me awake … while the eyes of the watchers slept. When the night fled the morning, I complained to God.' Ibn al-Zuqaq said: 'I have a dwelling far away … my eyes poured rain for it. How beautiful is the dawn, but my whitened eyes from sorrow perceive it as our morning.' The judge said: 'We spent the night in the state of love’s ease … and sometimes the night is unexplainable. We told the night: if you vanish, morning will intrude.' Yaqut said: 'The Pleiades provided comfort in the darkness … to measure if the night is long or short.' Sheikh Sadr al-Din ibn al-Wakeel said: 'The Pleiades in the palm of the hand, they measure the darkness from east to west. Even if measured by the cubit, the night would not end … and neither does my desire.' Al-Arjani, apologizing for long nights, said: 'I do not claim injustice of time, nor that my night exceeds other nights. But the morning’s mirror breathes, giving light to its polished face.' Mudhar ibn al-Fuq’asi said: 'And the night that people say is dark … the clear-eyed and the blind alike experience. We had fortified houses … with high ceilings and secured rooms.'

Another said: 'And I have a slumber, I do not know what is the slumber of sleep... As if my eyelids are my ears and sleep is a blamer.' I said: 'Since Shams al-Din (Sun of the Religion) was absent from me, my eye... Has not been rimmed with other than the powder of insomnia and sleeplessness. How often I spent the night tending the stars of the night out of my sleeplessness... O most resembling of people, of all people, to the moon.' Al-Sharishi said: As for most poets, they are more fearful of the night and more inclined to the day, because the night is more gathering for the dispersal of worries and thoughts, and more attracting for stray sorrows and memories. Imru' al-Qais said: 'And a night like the waves of the sea lowered its curtains... Upon me with types of worries to test me.' Qays bin Dharih said: 'I spend my day with conversation and wishes... And the night brings me and worry together. My day is the day of people until when appears... To me the night, the beds shake me towards you.' Ibn al-Mu'tazz said: 'Do not meet except at night the one you join... For the sun is a talebearer and the night is a pimp. How many a lover, while the darkness of night covers him... Met loved ones while the slanderers were asleep.' Al-Mutanabbi said: 'How many a visit for you among the Bedouins is hidden... I boast of it, while they slept, over the visit of the wolf. I visit them and the blackness of night intercedes for me... And I return and the whiteness of morning incites against me.' This verse is the prince of Al-Mutanabbi's poetry despite the abundance of good in it. In it is a comparison of five against five. Some took it and said: 'I hate the day when its morning shines... And I remain waiting for the pitch-black darkness. For the morning gloats at me so it comes laughing... And the night pities me so it leaves frowning.' He excelled in taking it, for in it is also a comparison of five against five. Ibn Yahya said regarding the saying of Al-Mutanabbi mentioned that it is taken from the saying of Ibn al-Mu'tazz: 'For the sun is a talebearer and the night is a pimp.' Sheikh Fath al-Din bin Sayyid al-Nas said: Our Sheikh Taqi al-Din bin Daqiq al-Eid said to me: Say to these scholars of Ma'ani, Bayan, and Badi' (Rhetoric): Can you say the like of Al-Mutanabbi's saying: 'I visit them and the blackness of night' the verse? If they say No, say: Then what is the benefit in what you manufacture? He means by that that action is other than knowledge, and practice is below description. Similar to his saying is what some narrated about a preacher who was on his pulpit speaking about Love and matters of Ishq and its states, extending the ropes of verbosity in that. Some of the group stood up to him and said: 'By your life, did you embrace Laila... Before the morning or kiss her mouth? And did the branches of Laila crawl upon you... The crawling of the chamomile in its dew?' The preacher said: 'No, by Allah.' He said to him: 'Then preach.' Al-Mutanabbi said: 'And how many a hand the darkness of night has with you... Telling that the Manichaeans lie. It protected you from the destruction of enemies as you travel to them... And the one of coquetry, the veiled one, visited you in it.' The Manichaeans are a people who believe that all good is from Light and all evil is from Darkness. So he belied them in that he found good in darkness where it covered him from his enemies and protected him from their evil, and was a help to him in visiting the one he loves. Ibn Rashiq said: 'O night, fly without a wing... There is no rest for the eye in the morning. How can I not hate the morning while in it... Those of beautiful (Sabah) faces departed from me?' Al-Asma'i recounted saying: I attended the assembly of Al-Rashid, and Muslim bin al-Walid was with him, when Abu Nuwas entered. He said: 'What have you created after us, O Abu Nuwas?' He said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, even in wine.' He said: 'May Allah fight you, even in wine.' So he recited to him: 'O brother of the soul, who judged... I slept from Laila and did not sleep.' The verses until he came to the last of them. He said: 'You did well, by Allah. O boy, give him ten thousand dirhams and ten robes.' So he took them and left. It is told about Al-Mutarriz the poet that he passed while on his feet were worn-out sandals raising dust. Al-Sharif Al-Murtada saw him and ordered him brought. He said to him: 'Recite to me your verses in which you say: "If my mounts do not reach me to you... Then may they not reach water nor graze on grass."' So he recited them to him. When he reached this verse, the Sharif pointed to his worn-out sandals and said: 'Are these of your mounts?' Al-Mutarriz looked down for an hour then said: 'When the gifts of our Master the Sharif, may Allah support him, returned to the like of his saying: "May Allah support him to the like of his saying... And take sleep from my eyelids, for I... Have bestowed slumber upon the lovers." My mounts returned to the like of what you see, because you bestowed what you do not own upon one who does not accept.' The Sharif was ashamed before him. Sheikh Sadr al-Din bin al-Wakil, may Allah have mercy on him, used to say: 'By Allah, the saying of Al-Mutarriz is to me better than the saying of the Sharif.' Abu al-Bashar al-Muzaffar al-A'ma said

I entered upon Al-Malik Al-Kamil, and he said to me: 'Complete this hemistich: Love has reached its end.' So I said: 'And lovers did not know what it is.' He said: 'My entry deceived them.' So I said regarding it: 'So they wandered in it and got lost.' He said: 'And I have a beloved who sees my humiliation.' So I said: 'And I have not changed from his love.' He said: 'Discipline of the soul is in my endurance.' So I said: 'And the garden of beauty is in his ornaments.' He said: 'A brown one, flexible of stature, dark-lipped.' So I said: 'Everyone who sees him loves him.' He said: 'His saliva is all wine.' So I said: 'Its seal is musk from his dark lips.' He said: 'His night is all slumber.' So I said: 'And my night is all wakefulness.' Then Muzaffar al-Din completed it praising Sultan Al-Malik Al-Kamil, may Allah cover him with His mercy, grace, and generosity. Chapter Twelve: The Lack of Intellect of the Blamer and his excess of curiosity.
