I say: We established this chapter to mention one who increased gossip among the blamers, and deserved by holding his beard while blaming, the plucking of mustaches. How not, while he, due to his excess of curiosity and lack of result, enters between the spirit and the body, and the parent and the child? How often he became among lovers like the back of the neck between two slappers; no door is opened for him, nor is an answer returned to him. 'And the most tiring of those who called you is the one you do not answer... And the most annoying of those who opposed you is the one you do not resemble. And pride is not my character in love other than that I... Am hateful to the ignorant pseudo-wise.' Would that he rested and relieved, and protected his permissible honor. Poets have abounded in refuting him, and lovers have apologized for him, as was said: 'O my blamer regarding his love... If he appears, how can I forget? He passes by me every time... And whenever he passes, he becomes sweeter.' It used to be said: 'Not from justice is the secret of... Blame.' And it used to be said: 'Perhaps a blamed one has no sin.' And it was said: 'Perhaps she has an excuse while you blame.' How many a blamer increased the lover by his blame in persistence... And madness more than the need. 'I will surely exchange love for blame, for it is... Like the wind inciting people to burning.' Another said: 'And my blamer is not forbidding regarding you... But he is commanding patience. He said: Forget them if you cannot bear their abandonment... I said: Fire and not Shame.' Sheikh Jamal al-Din bin Nubata said: 'O you who, if eyes sold their blackness... For a grain (mole) on his cheeks, they would have profited. Blame increases me in torment which I enjoy... So would that the blamers of my heart regarding you never ceased.' How excellent is the saying of our compatriot Muhammad bin al-Afif al-Tilimsani: 'You exceeded in blame and did not fall short... And increased in your blame, O blamer. My soul was pleased with its beloved... But the Master is of much curiosity.' His father said, and excelled as he wished: 'I have rights of love against my blamer... My thanks for him answer some of them. He blamed, but when he saw him, he wandered for him... So I was the cause in his love.' Another said: 'The slanderer strove and came blaming me... And adorned for me false speech with his lies. And he said: Forget about this one and turn away from his passion... So I said to him: This is curiosity itself.' Ibn Waki' recounted that he loved a Christian boy in Tinnis, and some of his friends blamed him for it while not having seen him. It happened that the boy passed by them. When Ibn Waki's friend saw him, he admired him and said: 'If you loved this one, I would not blame you.' He did not know he was his beloved whom he blamed him for. Ibn Waki' said immediately: 'My blamer saw him... And his heart had not seen him. He said: If you loved this one... People would not blame you for his love. Tell me, to whom did you turn away from him... For the people of love have none but him? So he remained, from where he did not know... Commanding the love of whom he forbade.' The Sheikh of Sheikhs in Hama said: 'They claimed that I loved other than you... They lied; I knew nothing but your love. You have known the truthfulness of the messenger of my tear... So ask it if my heart forgot you. My blamer said to me: When will you see guidance... And forget? So I said: The day of your blindness.' He also said: 'Indeed a people who blame regarding the love of Su'da... Hardly understand a speech. They heard her description so they blamed regarding her... They took a good thing and gave a bad thing.' He also said: 'Who will do me justice regarding an ignorant blamer... Who betrays by blame one who does not betray? If I say: Your advice is nothing but harm... He says: And your love is nothing but madness.' Muhammad bin Sharaf al-Qayrawani said: 'Say to the blamer: If you looked at what... I witnessed, what concerns me would concern you. Do you repel me or return me to passion... And blame me in love or incite me? Leave me, for I am not punished for my crime... Since your religion in love is not my religion.' How excellent is the saying of the other: 'The blamer says to me in his blame... And his saying is falsehood and calumny: Is not the face of the one you loved a Qibla?... I said: And your saying is not Quran.' Another: 'Indeed the full moon of darkness startled me with his aversion... And entrusted my eyelids with tending his stars. So O my blamer, leave me, perhaps he returns to me... And O my soul, patience upon what he branded you with.' 'Arqalah said: 'The blamers said: What is it that you admired... In him, and what captivates you? I said: All of him.' Sheikh Jamal al-Din bin Nubata, may Allah have mercy on him, said: 'O disappointment of the blamer who has... Lengthened in blame and became arrogant. He tortured me then said: You forget... The love of Mama? So I said: No, no.' He also said: 'O stupid blamer, contemplate... One in whose attributes the heart has become melting. And wonder at a forelock and a forehead... Indeed in the night and the day are wonders.' Judge Muhyi al-Din bin Abd al-Zahir said: 'How much is upon my blamer and how much is for my beloved... That is a Takbir and this is his Tahlil. O my trustees, and where are trustees from me... Where is he who seeks a means to me? I am dead, so turn me (Qibla) towards him... For my life, by his right, is kissing him.' Al-Nur Al-Is'irdi said: 'I say to my blamer when he forbade me... And he found the speech when he shunned me: I knew that he is bitter in accusation... But you missed that he is sweet of tongue.' Abu al-Fath Qadus said in 'Al-Aktaf': 'Who excuses me regarding a blamer... Who blames regarding the love of a fawn? If I sought his union... He said: Suffice with the tear, checkmate (Sha).' Similar is the saying of the Sheikh of Sheikhs in Hama: 'The lovers were angry at him that I... Did not sell in his love my guidance for error. I said: You have wasted my body. He said: Indeed. I said: So that my soul goes. He said: So that.' He also said: 'They intended my weaning from a love... I was fed with as a child and an old man. So I put my hand in my pocket... And said: Leave me, or else.' Similar is the saying of Al-Wadi'i: 'O my blamer regarding her love... You exceeded in blame ignorantly. No one knows longing except... Nor ardent love except.' How excellent is the saying of Ibn Sana' al-Mulk in this meaning: 'I love the sun (female) and the gazelle (male), and perhaps... I restrained my soul out of chastity and religiosity. And I restrained the rein of my eye striving... Until when I was exhausted, I released the rein.' And his saying also: 'I approached, and drowsiness showed of him what it showed. So I kissed him on the cheek ninety or one (times).' And his saying also: 'And a fawn resembling the Reem of the desert in his aversion... So why did he not resemble it in turning (affectionately)? He repels me from his union with an attack... So would that he repelled with that which (is better).' The Sheikh of Sheikhs in Hama said: 'To you is my migration and my intent... And in you is death and life. I felt safe that you would desolate my heart... So comfort my eye and do not.' Ibn al-Mu'tazz said: 'My sleeve crowded his sleeve so they twisted... My heart agreed with his heart so they equaled. And long did they taste love so they were branded... O delight of the eye and O my worry and O.' Ibn Matruh said: 'By Allah, forgetting has not crossed my mind... As long as I remain in the bonds of life, nor if.' The speech returns to blame. Another said a couplet: 'When the blamers saw my passion, they were dumbfounded... Immediately, and said: Blaming this one is obstinacy. We do not think but that we are blaming him... Hearing one who understands, one who pays attention.' Another said: 'They said: Forget him and cast off his love... For his lie and falsehood have appeared. I said: By Allah, do not prolong... By Allah, by Allah, I will not unfasten it.' How excellent is the saying of Shihab al-Din Ibn al-Khaymi, may Allah have mercy on him: 'And a blamer made me doubt his advice... Every time I increased in refusal, he increased in persistence.

My blamer is none but a lover... Who covered jealousy with blame and concealed.' Another said: 'If my blamer saw my beloved's face... We would have separated on a beautiful face.' Sheikh Burhan al-Din al-Qirati recited to me: 'Life went in blame... And aversion from a gazelle. In the path of love a life... Was lost in gossip.' Sheikh Ibrahim bin al-Mi'mar said: 'If he saw the beauty of his face... My blamer, in smiling. His soul would go just as... It was said regarding the cycle of a dirham.' He also said: 'The blamer insisted and blamed me... Regarding whom I love and scolded. So I intended to slap his head... From what I was filled with of regret. But my hand slipped... And fell on the nape of the neck and he died.' Wittier is the saying of Al-Nur Al-Is'irdi: 'And they said: Leave the beloved and abandon him always... Did you not see him after beauty plucking (hair)? Is he plucked for my sake and tires always... And I abandon him? By Allah, I am not fair.' Another said: 'Say to the blamer: You prolonged blame regarding a moon... Whose beauty increases in light every day. If you claim there is wonder in his beauty... Stand and look at the rose on his cheeks scattered.' Muhyi al-Din al-Baghdadi said: 'If one who did not see him blames me, he has... Been unjust against the absent in judgment. And if one who saw him blames me, he has... Led him astray, Allah, upon knowledge.' Al-Baha Zuhayr said: 'You are the first beloved... And for you is the future love. I have for you the affection which... Is what you knew and more perfect. The heart in you is bound... The tear in you is chained. O you who threatens with aversion... Yes, you say and you do. Your excuse in love is valid... But I distract myself. Say to the blamer: You have prolonged... To whom do you say and blame? You admonished one who does not desist... And blamed one who does not accept. The anger of the blamer is lighter than... The anger of the beloved and easier.' Abu al-Atahiya said: I met Abu Nuwas in the Congregational Mosque, so I blamed him and said to him: Has the time not come for you to desist and be deterred? He raised his head to me and said: 'Do you see me, O Atahi... Leaving those amusements? Do you see me spoiling by... Asceticism my rank among the people?' When I persisted in blaming him, he began reciting: 'Souls do not return from their error... Unless there is for them a restrainer from themselves.' So I wished I had said this verse with everything I said. Juwayan al-Qawwas said: 'I listen to the saying of the blamer with my entirety... Asking him for understanding without boredom. To pick the flowers of the rose of your talk... From between the thorns of the blamers' blame.' I said: This is the lover and the affectionate admirer. Do you not see how he listened to his blamer, the effective maker, and harvested from his blame the harvest of bees mixed with the water of facts? He is in this station among the affirmed, as Abu al-Shis said from verses: 'I find blame in your love delicious... Out of love for your mention, so let the blamers blame me.' Ibn Rashiq said: And Ibn Jabir al-Khuza'i exceeded Abu al-Shis in this saying where he says: 'I was threatened with the Sultan regarding you, but... I fear your aversion, not the Sultan. I love blame regarding you, so that if he knew... The receiver of bribes from me, who blames me. My sufficiency for people's saying after my death... This is a victim in the love of so-and-so. So I will surely spend on you my whole life... And I will surely love for you every humiliation.' I said: What I say in this station is that the author of this speech is a debtor of passion and a drinking companion of cups of wine. Do you not see how he exaggerated until he made for the blamer a wage? So his state became as was said: 'A bundle on a bundle.' He is as some masters of provinces said: 'If the commoners did not know what is in our hearts of the sweetness of pardon, they would draw near to us with crimes.' Similar to his saying 'I was threatened with the Sultan' is the saying of the other: 'If she vowed regarding you my killing in the evening... Then for death I have, in your love, a greeting. And among the strange things is my fear in love... While I have every day in your sanctuary a death.' I said: 'A blamer exaggerated in his blame... And said when my anxiety was stirred. By the cheek-hair of the beloved, will you not end?... I said: Nor by greyness and the governor.' I also said: 'They blamed me for intending my killing in love... Their speech is a type of delirium. They were ignorant and did not know that stabbing regarding the... Beloved is different from stabbing in the battlefield.'

I also said: 'How often the blamers contradicted my saying regarding one who... In every day his beauty increases. If I said: He became in prettiness unique (Mufrad)... They said: His swaying stature bent (Muthanna - dual/bent).' I also said: 'O my blamer, do not blame me... In the love of this Copt. And cut, with a connection between us... By Allah, the head of the cat (Qitt - pun on Copt/Cat).' I also said: 'A handsome Turk, especially the Khatayi... The Sheikh is excused for him for youthful passion. So leave me from your blame, O my blamer... For my love for the Khata (region/mistake) is the essence of correctness (Sawab).' I said regarding one named Hukm al-Hawa (Judgment of Passion): 'Hukm al-Hawa turned away, so I spent the night for that... Wandering from excess of ardent love and desire. O my blamer, do not blame me in her love... The decree was executed, and such is the Judgment of Passion.' I said: 'I say to a fawn whose heart complains of sorrow... It is Love, so submit your heart; desire is not easy. I advised you out of knowledge of love, and what I see is... My opposition, so choose for yourself what is sweet.' I said from a poem: 'I weighed my inclination to the blamer and his stature... And I saw my inclination to the stature preponderant. O my blamer, may the hand of separation not shake yours... Until you are pillowed in the dust a slab. And I have advised the sons of ardent love in passion... But they do not accept an adviser.' I said: From a poem I praised our Master Sultan Al-Malik Al-Nasir with. 'O who came blaming a wandering admirer... Regarding sweet characteristics, how bitter you are.' I said: Also from a poem praising him, may Allah perpetuate his kingdom, beginning with: 'You have from your beloved what you love and desire... So make your wine from his delicious kiss. And if his mouth appears to you smiling... Then laugh at the beard of the blamer and guffaw.' I said: Also from a poem I sent to our Master Chief Judge Taj al-Din al-Subki in Damascus of Sham. 'O dwellers of the slope, I have in Hakim a dwelling... And you are in the core of the heart dwellers. My tear increases like Banas for your slave... And the blamers upon Thawra are oxen.' And from it: 'What was of his abandonment for a time has been... And he has fulfilled now, so may the blamers not exist. I am the one who does not care in passion about what... Fulan narrates nor what Faltan said.' And from it: 'I proved the beauty of the one I desire and said to him... The blamer has no proof for what he said. He has not blamed me since he saw me in love Rajab... Joking Sha'ban, so I did not desire Sha'ban.' Note: The names of months among the Arabs were other than these names used now, because they used to call Rajab 'Al-Asamm' (The Deaf) and call Sha'ban 'Al-Adhil' (The Blamer). By this, the meaning of my saying in the last verse appears. However, poets used this meaning in the past and present. Among the best I heard in it: 'And a fawn smiling revealing bubbles... Rosy of cheek, handsome of mustache. The blamer blames me for his love... And Sha'ban did not know that I am Rajab (Deaf to blame).' I also said: 'He attacks me with coquetry as if he is... Ghazan when he attacks his deprived ones. If the branch of his stature repels me from him... Then I am the one killed by his glance and his explanation. Indeed I, by your right, in his love am an enslaved... Lover (Sabb), I became Rajab to his Sha'ban.' Their saying 'The sword preceded the blame' is a proverb of the Arabs struck regarding a matter that cannot be returned. Its origin is that Sa'd and Sa'id, two sons of Dabbah ibn Udd, went out seeking camels of theirs. Sa'd returned and Sa'id did not return. Abu Dabbah, if he saw a person coming, would say: 'Asa'd am Sa'id?' (Is it Sa'd or Sa'id / Happy or Fortunate?). Then in some of his travels he came to a place with Al-Harith bin Ka'b in the Sacred Month. Al-Harith said to him: 'I killed here a youth whose description was such and such, and took from him this sword.' Dabbah took it and recognized it. He said: 'Indeed conversation has branches (Shujun).' Then he struck him. He was blamed. He said: 'The sword preceded the blame.' Poets circulated that and versified it. Among the best I heard in it is the saying of Al-Siraj Al-Warraq: 'I said when he drew a glance... Whose edge brings death near. O my blamer, desist from me... The sword preceded the justice (Adl - pun on Adhl/Blame).' Mentioning Blame and Reproach, I recalled the saying of Abu Nuwas regarding wine: 'Leave off blaming me, for blame is incitement... And treat me with that which was the disease.' Al-Mufaddal al-Dabbi said: I entered upon Al-Rashid one day. He said: 'Guide me to a verse whose beginning is Aktham bin Sayfi in correctness of opinion and quality of advice, and whose end is Hippocrates in knowledge of medicine.' I said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, you have terrified me.' He said: 'It is the saying of Abu Nuwas: Leave off blaming me... the verse.' I said: And there remains...

...for this verse a pleasant story narrated by Al-Hariri in 'Durrat al-Ghawwas' about Hamid bin al-Abbas. He asked Ali bin Isa in the Ministry Diwan about the cure for a hangover that had clung to him. He turned away from his speech and said: 'What have I to do with this question?' Hamid made fun of him. Then he turned to the Chief Judge Abu Umar and asked him about that. The Judge cleared his throat to fix his voice, then said: 'Allah Almighty said: "And whatever the Messenger has given you - take; and what he has forbidden you - refrain from." And the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Seek help in every craft from its righteous people." Al-A'sha is the one famous for this craft in the Jahiliyyah, and he has said: "And a cup I drank for pleasure... And another I treated myself with from it." Then Abu Nuwas followed him and said: "Leave off blaming me, for blame is incitement... And treat me with that which was the disease."' Hamid's face brightened then, and he said to Ali bin Isa: 'What harm would it have done you, O cold one, to answer with some of what the Chief Judge answered with? He demonstrated in answering the question with the saying of Allah Almighty first, then with the saying of the Messenger, peace be upon him, second, and clarified the Fatwa and performed the meaning and absolved himself of responsibility.' The shame on Ibn Isa from Hamid by this speech was greater than Hamid's shame from him when he initiated the question. Sheikh Sadr al-Din Ibn al-Wakil said: 'Indeed, he who made worries scorpions... Made wine, in reality, their antidote. The filter was not crucified except when... It cut the road for the wine and hindered it. And my blamer regarding wine, if he had tasted it... He would not have blamed me, but he did not taste it. He said: Cast off a yellow one whose wine extinguishes... The flame of hearts when they complain of their burning. I answered him: Taste it and take after that... In the ways of your blame if you want its separation.' The Sheikh of Sheikhs in Hama was fair where he said: 'O my blamer, one like me is not refuted... And one like you is not trusted with my blame. As long as I am empty, you will not cease concerning yourself... I fall in love and your saying is acceptable against me and for me.' Another said: 'If the dove knew my yearning towards you... It would have torn its collars out of joy (Tarab). And if my blamer tasted my ardent love... He would have yearned with me, but he did not taste it.' It is told that Sultan Salah al-Din said one day to Judge Al-Fadil: 'For a period we have not seen Al-Imad the Scribe, perhaps he is weak. Go to him and inspect his conditions.' When the Judge entered the house of Al-Imad the Scribe, he found things he disapproved of in himself, like traces of gatherings of intimacy, perfume, smell of wine, and musical instruments. So he recited to him: 'The secrets of affection from a man did not advise you... As long as he did not reach you with a hateful thing and with blame. My love for you refuses to allow me... To see you upon something of errors.' Chapter Thirteen: Mention of Allusion to Union and Visiting. I say: We established this chapter to mention the Visitor and the Visited, and what has been said about them in verse and prose, and other things regarding visiting the beloved and what indicates him of scents of perfume, as was said: 'If a caravan intended you, your breeze... Would lead them until the caravan is guided by you.' Yes, often the beloved gifted joy by his visit, and merit became his, visiting and visited, as was said: 'So for his merit, the merit in both states is his.' The visit from the beloved is not tired of, even if the heavy rain followed the drizzle in it. Among the best said regarding the visit of the beloved and his return from near is the saying of Al-Ukkuk: 'By my father! One who visited me concealing himself... Fearful of everything, anxious. A visitor, his beauty revealed him... How can the night hide a full moon that rose? He watched for heedlessness until it was possible... And watched the night-talker until he slept. He rode terrors in his visit... Then he did not greet until he bid farewell.' How excellent is the saying of Al-Mu'tazz: 'He visited me while the darkness was black of sides... And the Pleiades in the West were like a bunch of grapes. And as if the crescent was the collar of a bride... Spending the night displayed upon black tunics. O night of union, aid us with length... May Allah lengthen in you the rage of the envier.' Another said: 'She visited due to the heedlessness of the watcher... Like a doe frightened by a wolf. And the time of union from her was... Shorter than the sitting of the preacher.' The Allama Sheikh Ala' al-Din Mughlatay said in his book 'Al-Wadih Al-Mubin': Abd al-Aziz bin Saraya al-Hilli recited to us for himself, claiming it is the truest word the later ones said: 'They say to me: By Allah, what will you do... If the beloved visits you? I said: A...' Ya'qub al-Shaybani said:

'I said when the one I love visited, and the wing of the night... Was a garden showing stars as day. The King of Love was visited by the King of Beauty... So they increased power over existence. So spread the roses as satin when he walks... And make the gold of cups a scattering. And dismiss the eyebrow (Hajib/Doorman) of the crescent, for he has tattled... Traveling to eyes repeatedly. And veil the white of the morning and say... To the Negus of darkness: Be a curtain for the house.' Mentioning the curtain of the house, how excellent is the saying of the other, a Dubayt: 'O night, praise and eulogy befit you... Since you are to the people of love a friend and companion. Since you made the curtain of the house of worry... Do not give the morning a way against them.' Ibn al-Nabih said: 'I said to the night when it granted me a beloved... And singing that captivates minds and wine. You, O night, are my doorman, so prevent the morning... And be you, O darkness, a curtain for the house.' How excellent is the saying of Shams al-Din Muhammad Ibn al-Afif: 'And a handsome one like the full moon visited at night... So his beauty revealed the darkness when it appeared. He did not know my house, but my heart... With the flame of ardency guided him and indicated. And strange from him, an intelligent jurist... By the place of dispute, how did he infer?' Another said: 'O my beloved, and you have... Ceased not to be generous with union. You visited me part of a night... In which I spent the night anxious. When you turned away absent... The full moon set in the sky. I wish I knew who... Learned from his brother.' Bashar bin Burd said: 'O most pleasant of people in saliva, untested... Except for the testimony of the tips of toothsticks. You visited us once in the eternity, a single time... Make it two, and do not make it the egg of the rooster.' It is said the rooster lays an egg once a year; for this reason Bashar said that. Ibn al-Sa'ati said in his history: In the year six hundred ninety-six, a rooster laid an egg in Baghdad. I asked a group about that, and they informed me of it. I said: Some Sufis residing with me at the cistern told me now that a rooster laid a small egg with them and began to crow like a hen, then stayed after that for seven days and died. The speech returns. I said: 'I have a beloved, he has a loyal lover... Every day he comes to him repeatedly. I said: Visit me. He said: My love is with me... Jewelry occupies its people from being lent.' I also said from a poem: 'The beloved visited and the face of the rose was ashamed... So it yellowed when his Ban stature swayed. What was of his abandonment for a time has been... And he has fulfilled now, so may the blamers not exist. The narrowness of my living did not harm me when he joined me... The eye of the needle with loved ones is a field.' Section: Perfume indicated the Beloved. How sweet is the saying of Ibn Sakra: 'Welcome and hello to one who visited without promise... Under the darkness and did not fear the guards. She covered herself with the darkness intentionally but was not covered... And her radiance at night substituted for the firebrand. Even if the darkness folded her from us, she would be revealed by... The lightning of the veil and the perfume of the chest and the breath.' Al-Mu'tamid bin Abbad took it and said: 'Three things prevented her from visiting us... Fear of the watcher and fear of the resentful envier. The light of the forehead, the noise of jewelry, and what... Her sides contain of fragrant ambergris. Suppose the forehead, with the excess of the sleeve, she covers it... And the jewelry she removes; what is the trick for the sweat (scent)?' He said: 'A day the messenger says: She has come near... So come without waiting or clamor. She came falling to their saddles... Gifting to them with her wind the fragrance.' It is said one is guided by perfume to behavior in places where people are not known, like the bathhouse, the battlefield, and the Hajj season. Poets have ceased not to describe the places of the beloved with perfume, as Ibn al-Nabih said in it: 'If one comes seeking a dwelling for them... He says to him: Walk and inhale.' Muhammad bin Abdullah al-Numayri said regarding Zaynab sister of Al-Hajjaj from a poem: 'The valley of Na'man diffused musk when Zaynab walked... In it among shy women. It has a fragrance from Indian incense rising... Its smell comes out from the sleeves. They cover the tips of fingers out of piety... And rise at midnight veiled.' And from it: 'And when she saw the riders of Al-Numayri she turned away... Hating that they meet him, cautious.'

For this verse is a pleasant story that happened to its author with Al-Hajjaj, which is famous among the people of literature. I refrained from affirming it here fearing elongation. Al-Tughra'i said: 'So travel with us in the darkness of the night arbitrarily... For the whiff of perfume guides us to the quarters.' Another said: 'And the breeze of musk is not what you find... But it is that praise left behind.' Another said: 'If a scent of diffusing musk could be found... I would have found it from them miles away.' Ibn al-Rumi said: 'I followed him with a whiff from the goodness of your mention... That almost became your heard praise.' Al-Mutanabbi said: 'And scents diffuse from the goodness of praise... For them in every place, being inhaled.' Section: Among the best I heard in Visiting the Sick is the saying of Al-Tughra'i: 'They informed her that I fell ill, so she said... Is it an illness, fresh of complaint or old? And they signaled that she visit my pillow... She refused while desiring to visit. And she came to me in secret complaining... The pain of longing and the distant visiting place. And she saw me like that, so she could not control herself... But inclined upon me a side and a neck.' Sheikh Jamal al-Din bin Nubata recited to me from his own words for himself: 'And a boring one in love, when she saw... The trace of illness in my broken bone. She said: We have changed. So I said to her: Yes... I with illness and you with diseases.' How excellent is the saying of Ibn al-Sulayman: 'And I am the one you made ill and abandoned... So is there a connection (Silah) or a returner (A'id) from you for the "One Who" (Al-ladhi)?' Another said: 'Do not abandon one who does not get used to your abandonment... While he is the one fed with the milk of your union. And you raised his rank at the beginning... Far be it from you to cut off his origin which is "The One Who" (Al-ladhi).' Among the great things told about Al-Malik Al-Mu'azzam Isa son of Al-Malik Al-Adil is that Sharaf al-Din Ibn 'Unayn wrote to him while he was weak: 'Look at me with the eye of a master who ceases not... To bestow generosity, and rectify before my destruction. I am like "The One Who" (Al-ladhi), I need what he needs... So gain my reward and the ample praise.' So Al-Malik Al-Mu'azzam came to him himself with a purse containing three hundred dinars and said: 'You are "The One Who" (Al-ladhi), and this is your Connection (Silah), and I am the Returner (Al-A'id - relative pronoun).' I said: Ibn 'Unayn used Silah and Mawsool (grammatical terms) and excelled, and Al-Malik Al-Mu'azzam dealt with him in racing to understand his intent the dealing of a generous steed. Had this occurred from the like of Sibawayh, it would have been the greatest proof of his virtue and the correctness of his intelligence. So what about its occurrence from this King, exalted in rank, great in authority? How often he delighted Ibn 'Unayn and paid a debt for him. So the request was expensive with him, and the Returner rejoiced with the Connection by his righteousness, the Connected. No wonder he filled his Diwan with his praises and said about him his resonant poems: 'Generous of praise, naked of shame, brave... Beautiful of face, perfect of goodness and kindness. By your life, the signs of Isa are not hidden... It is the sun, for the furthest its light and for the nearest.' I have from a poem in this meter praising our Master Sultan Al-Malik Al-Nasir, its summary: 'The Ban branch lengthened imitating his stature... I said to it: By Allah, you have come in meaning. But the full moon and the sea fell short... Of Al-Nasir the Sultan in goodness and kindness.' Among the witty things that happened to Ibn 'Unayn this with Al-Malik Al-Mu'azzam is that he attended one time before him with a group of poets. The Sultan said to them: 'You must satirize me to my face.' They kissed the ground and asked to be excused from that. He said: 'It must be.' He insisted on them. Ibn 'Unayn said: 'We are a people who never mentioned a man... At all except he desired that he not see us.' The Sultan said to him: 'You spoke the truth.' He said: 'Our poetry is like the... ...' The Sultan said: 'No, by Allah, may Allah make you ugly.' He said: 'May Allah strike with it the root of our beards.' The speech returns to Visiting the Sick. How excellent is the saying of Al-Siraj Al-Warraq: 'My friend said while he did not visit me... And the symptom of illness was in a trace. Indeed you have changed, O my friend... And Allah knows who changed.' And his saying also: 'I fell ill, to Allah (I complain of) a people... Among them is one who shunned me. They returned (visited) and returned and returned... According to the difference of meanings.' For this verse are likes and parallels I mentioned in my book 'Al-Tari' ala al-Sukardan'. Among them is what is told about Judge Abu Bakr Ibn al-Arabi. He stopped at his circle while busy with knowledge a handsome youth with a spear in his hand. Some jurists said to him: 'Go away with this spear.' He shook the spear and said: 'Now I will strike you with it.' Judge Abu Bakr recited immediately for himself: 'He threatens me with the spear, a slender fawn... Playful with the hearts of creation, messing. If it were one spear I would have guarded against it... But it is a spear, and a second, and a third.' I asked a group of people of knowledge and literature to extract the third from this verse, but none of them answered with something substantial. Ibn al-Naqib said: 'I heard what you complain of and what you find... So the tears of the eye remained shedding on the cheek. And I sent my handwriting in visiting as a deputy... And not every handwriting is fit for visiting.' Al-Mu'tamid bin Abbad said: 'I fell ill so I withheld the visit intentionally... And not out of hatred I withheld it nor abandonment. But I feared to visit you... And see the traces of the eclipse on the full moon.' Al-Shihab Mahmud said in 'Al-Qawl bil-Mujib': 'She saw me when emaciation had taken from me... And my tears overflowed on the cheek an overflowing. She said: By my eye (Bi-ayni - also means with my eye/dear to me) is this illness... I said: You spoke truth, and by the waist also.' Al-Arjani's saying was cited in his book 'Husn al-Tawassul': 'She tricked me when she clothed my body in illness... A clothing she stripped the meat from the bones. Then she said: You are to me in love... Like my eye (Ayni). She spoke truth, but (Ayni as) a sick one.' I said when I stood upon this saying of Al-Arjani, improvising: 'I complained to the beloved of my bad luck... And what I endured of the pain of distance. She said: Indeed your luck is like my eye... I said: Yes, but in blackness.' How excellent is the saying of Mahasin al-Shawwa: 'And when the blamers came to me, I lacked them... And there is nothing in them but for the fever a Fard (old camel/obligatory prayer). And they were dumbfounded when they saw me pale... And said: In him is an eye (evil eye). I said: And a cheek (Arid - also obstacle).' Ibn al-Naqib said: 'And there is nothing in me but an eye that looked at her beauty... And that is due to my ignorance of eyes and my delusion. And they said: In him regarding love is an eye and a look... They spoke truth: the eye of the beloved and my look.' The origin in all this: 'And they came to him with amulets and incantations... And poured water on him for the pain of relapse. And they said: In him is a look from the eyes of Jinn... And if they spoke truth, they would say: In him are eyes of humans.' How excellent is the saying of our compatriot Muhammad bin Afif al-Tilimsani regarding a handsome one who makes Kafiyas (headgear/rhymes): 'The name of my beloved and what he suffers... Has occupied my mind and intellect. They said: Ali. I said: Destiny (Qadran). They said: Kawafi. I said: My heart.' And the saying of Sheikh Sadr al-Din bin al-Wakil: 'And I have one who hardened in heart and softened in side... If I said: Draw me near, he doubles my distancing. He admits to my slavery (Riqqi) when I say I am his... And how often he said it also, but to threaten me.' Al-Siraj Al-Warraq said: 'They said: And all my interests were lost... To the worries of a soul, would that I had not borne it. You had, O so-and-so, a determination... So I answered them: I sold the donkey and sold it (the determination).' Chapter Fourteen: The Watcher, the Talebearer, and the Slanderer of many words. I say: We established this chapter to mention every watcher, jealous of eye, of many lies. He sees the lover with the eye of hatred at all times, and shoots him in presence and absence with every hitting arrow. How often he left the lover emaciated and impoverished him regarding whom he loved, and he did not become rich. He is like the morning, cutter of pleasures, miserable of movements, ugly of appearance, bad of substance, of much persistence, a stone in a glass shop. He and the Talebearer are in harm two racehorses suckling milk. Among the most eloquent I heard regarding the Watcher: 'I and Love were not alone nor for a blink... Of an eye except there was a watcher over us. We were not alone such that time made possible... That I say: You are the beloved. Rather we were alone to the extent that you said: ... My separation has neared. So I said: How is the doctor?' And the saying of Ibn al-Mu'tazz: 'And my tribulation in presence and absence... From a beloved, distant from me, near. The eye did not see the blood of his face except... It choked before drinking it on a watcher.' He also said: 'And the sun approached setting... And my driving to the beloved neared. Blessed is he who lived a tenth of a day... Having a beloved without a watcher.' It was said to some Arab: What is the most enjoyable of worldly pleasures? He said: Joking with the beloved and the absence of the watcher. Al-Sahib Ibn Abbad said: 'He said to me: Indeed my watcher is bad-mannered, so tolerate him... I said: Leave him; your face is the Paradise surrounded by hateful things.' Another said: 'The arrow of love is a wound in my heart... And that wound is from the eye of the watcher. He entrusts his two eyes to us and resembles... The place of the Writers (Angels) regarding sins. If the watcher fell from the Pleiades... He would fall on a lover or a beloved.' Another said:

'He gives you drink from his palm a wine... More delicious than the negligence of the watcher. As if it, when it cleared and thinned... Is the complaint of a lover to a beloved.' Abu Nuwas said: 'I glanced at him so he smiled... And the place was empty so he greeted. And the watcher appeared so I said: No... May the watcher be safe from blindness.' Al-Safi al-Hilli said: 'And a handsome one who has an ugly watcher... Who suffers while other than him enjoys. There is no meaning in him to be said, but... He came for a meaning (Ma'na) at the grammatical syntax (Nahw - pun on direction/grammar).' Another said: 'She said: The time is clear but the watcher is like the mote (in the eye)... I said: If the watcher is absent, satisfy me? She said: If.' Another said: 'I love the blamer for his repeating... The talk of the beloved to my hearing. And I desire the watcher because the watcher... Is (there) if my love is with me.' Abu Ja'far Ahmad bin al-Abbar said: 'He visited me hidden from the watcher, suspicious... The branch complaining of the depressed one. He said to me: Do you not see the watcher overlooking? I said: Visit him, he came to the spacious yard. Give him cups of wine continuously... And circulate them to him, cup after cup. And give it to me drink with the wine of your eyes pure... And make the cup from you a cold mouth. Then when the one we fear slept... And met slumber hearing, answering. He said: You must crawl to him... I said: I seek a fawn and take a wolf? He said: So start with us and double on him... I said: No, I have seen a wonder. So we jumped on the gazelle riding... And we crawled on the watcher crawling. Have you seen or have you heard of a lover... Who f****d his beloved and f****d the watcher?' Ibn Bassam said: Ibn al-Abbar was witty and pious and excelled as he wished and estimated. I think if he had power over Iblis who took charge of this school, he would have crawled on him and he would not have escaped his hand. Ibn al-Mu'tazz alluded and did not declare where he said: 'So there was what was of what I do not mention... So think good and do not ask about the news.' Abu Nuwas said: 'If the sleepers slept, then leave me... And whoever was fit for crawling. The most delicious f*****g is what was by force... With the prevention of love or fear of the watcher.' Abu al-Walid Muhammad bin Hassan al-Hanafi said: 'The spreading of the breeze becomes known by your scent... And the brother of passion is honored by your love. The honor of the enslaved in your love is that he... Sometimes wails and at times regrets. A lover, if he concealed passion and did not reveal... The shedding tears told on him about it. His meanings became subtle so he blew with the east wind... And his watcher blows with it not known. The watcher did not know his visit because he... Is more hidden to him than the breeze and subtler. And as if the breeze comes to your dwellings... And has a stop at those dwellings.' Urwa bin Abdullah said: Urwa ibn Udhayna al-Laythi was staying in the house of Abu al-Aqiq, so I heard him reciting for himself: 'Indeed, she who claimed your heart got bored of her... Was created as your desire just as desire was created for her. So if you find whispers of solace for her... Intercede for a conscience to the heart then ask it. A white one, bliss came early to her so it formed her... With elegance, so it made her fine and majestic. When I presented to a Muslim a need of mine... I fear its difficulty and hope for its solution. She prevented her greeting, so I said to my companion... How much of it was for us and how little. So he drew near and said to us: Perhaps she is excused... In some of her shyness. So I said: Perhaps she is.' Abu al-Sa'ib al-Makhzumi came to me, so I said to him after welcoming and cheer: 'Do you have a need?' He said: 'Yes, verses by Urwa; it reached me that you heard him reciting them.' So I recited the verses to him. When I reached the saying 'So he drew near and said: Perhaps she is excused', he rejoiced and shouted and said: 'This, by Allah, is the enduring of ardent love, the truthful, not like the one who says: If your family prevents you out of desire... From me, then my family is more miserly with me and more desirous.' The Bedouin exceeded his limit. I hope Allah forgives the author of these verses for his good opinion of her and seeking an excuse for her. He said: So I offered him food. He said: 'No, by Allah, I would not mix food with these verses until night.' And he left. Ibn Rashiq said: 'The one I love was harmed by my glance and said to me... I fear from the sitters that they realize about us. And said: If you repeat your glance, excluding them... At me, the proof of our suspicion is not hidden. So I said: We have been afflicted with the watcher. He said: We have not... Been afflicted, but the watcher has been afflicted with us.' Another said:

'If it were one spear I would have guarded against it... But it is a spear, and a second, and a third.' I asked a group of people of knowledge and literature to extract the third from this verse, but none of them answered with something substantial. Ibn al-Naqib said: 'I heard what you complain of and what you find... So the tears of the eye remained shedding on the cheek. And I sent my handwriting in visiting as a deputy... And not every handwriting is fit for visiting.' Al-Mu'tamid bin Abbad said: 'I fell ill so I withheld the visit intentionally... And not out of hatred I withheld it nor abandonment. But I feared to visit you... And see the traces of the eclipse on the full moon.' Al-Shihab Mahmud said in 'Al-Qawl bil-Mujib': 'She saw me when emaciation had taken from me... And my tears overflowed on the cheek an overflowing. She said: By my eye (Bi-ayni - also means with my eye/dear to me) is this illness... I said: You spoke truth, and by the waist also.' Al-Arjani's saying was cited in his book 'Husn al-Tawassul': 'She tricked me when she clothed my body in illness... A clothing she stripped the meat from the bones. Then she said: You are to me in love... Like my eye (Ayni). She spoke truth, but (Ayni as) a sick one.' I said when I stood upon this saying of Al-Arjani, improvising: 'I complained to the beloved of my bad luck... And what I endured of the pain of distance. She said: Indeed your luck is like my eye... I said: Yes, but in blackness.' How excellent is the saying of Mahasin al-Shawwa: 'And when the blamers came to me, I lacked them... And there is nothing in them but for the fever a Fard (old camel/obligatory prayer). And they were dumbfounded when they saw me pale... And said: In him is an eye (evil eye). I said: And a cheek (Arid - also obstacle).' Ibn al-Naqib said: 'And there is nothing in me but an eye that looked at her beauty... And that is due to my ignorance of eyes and my delusion. And they said: In him regarding love is an eye and a look... They spoke truth: the eye of the beloved and my look.' The origin in all this: 'And they came to him with amulets and incantations... And poured water on him for the pain of relapse. And they said: In him is a look from the eyes of Jinn... And if they spoke truth, they would say: In him are eyes of humans.' How excellent is the saying of our compatriot Muhammad bin Afif al-Tilimsani regarding a handsome one who makes Kafiyas (headgear/rhymes): 'The name of my beloved and what he suffers... Has occupied my mind and intellect. They said: Ali. I said: Destiny (Qadran). They said: Kawafi. I said: My heart.' And the saying of Sheikh Sadr al-Din bin al-Wakil: 'And I have one who hardened in heart and softened in side... If I said: Draw me near, he doubles my distancing. He admits to my slavery (Riqqi) when I say I am his... And how often he said it also, but to threaten me.' Al-Siraj Al-Warraq said: 'They said: And all my interests were lost... To the worries of a soul, would that I had not borne it. You had, O so-and-so, a determination... So I answered them: I sold the donkey and sold it (the determination).' Chapter Fourteen: The Watcher, the Talebearer, and the Slanderer of many words. I say: We established this chapter to mention every watcher, jealous of eye, of many lies. He sees the lover with the eye of hatred at all times, and shoots him in presence and absence with every hitting arrow. How often he left the lover emaciated and impoverished him regarding whom he loved, and he did not become rich. He is like the morning, cutter of pleasures, miserable of movements, ugly of appearance, bad of substance, of much persistence, a stone in a glass shop. He and the Talebearer are in harm two racehorses suckling milk. Among the most eloquent I heard regarding the Watcher: 'I and Love were not alone nor for a blink... Of an eye except there was a watcher over us. We were not alone such that time made possible... That I say: You are the beloved. Rather we were alone to the extent that you said: ... My separation has neared. So I said: How is the doctor?' And the saying of Ibn al-Mu'tazz: 'And my tribulation in presence and absence... From a beloved, distant from me, near. The eye did not see the blood of his face except... It choked before drinking it on a watcher.' He also said: 'And the sun approached setting... And my driving to the beloved neared. Blessed is he who lived a tenth of a day... Having a beloved without a watcher.' It was said to some Arab: What is the most enjoyable of worldly pleasures? He said: Joking with the beloved and the absence of the watcher. Al-Sahib Ibn Abbad said: 'He said to me: Indeed my watcher is bad-mannered, so tolerate him... I said: Leave him; your face is the Paradise surrounded by hateful things.' Another said: 'The arrow of love is a wound in my heart... And that wound is from the eye of the watcher. He entrusts his two eyes to us and resembles... The place of the Writers (Angels) regarding sins. If the watcher fell from the Pleiades... He would fall on a lover or a beloved.' Another said:

'He gives you drink from his palm a wine... More delicious than the negligence of the watcher. As if it, when it cleared and thinned... Is the complaint of a lover to a beloved.' Abu Nuwas said: 'I glanced at him so he smiled... And the place was empty so he greeted. And the watcher appeared so I said: No... May the watcher be safe from blindness.' Al-Safi al-Hilli said: 'And a handsome one who has an ugly watcher... Who suffers while other than him enjoys. There is no meaning in him to be said, but... He came for a meaning (Ma'na) at the grammatical syntax (Nahw - pun on direction/grammar).' Another said: 'She said: The time is clear but the watcher is like the mote (in the eye)... I said: If the watcher is absent, satisfy me? She said: If.' Another said: 'I love the blamer for his repeating... The talk of the beloved to my hearing. And I desire the watcher because the watcher... Is (there) if my love is with me.' Abu Ja'far Ahmad bin al-Abbar said: 'He visited me hidden from the watcher, suspicious... And a watcher—may I be deprived of no watcher [like him]... black of face, nape, and attributes. He is like the night in darkness, and to me... he is like the morning, cutting off pleasures. I asked our friend Sheikh Burhan al-Din al-Qirati at that time: 'Do you memorize anything beautiful regarding the satire of the watcher?' He remained silent for a moment, then recited of his own composition: 'A friend said to me desiring a poem... in satire of the watcher, for he is ugly. Do you have anything beautiful regarding the watcher?... I said: There is nothing beautiful about a watcher.' And I said from a poem: 'May I be your ransom, the watcher is gone, so sing to me... and say regarding a heavy bore: his bad luck is absent. A watcher banished from Layla's land in the evening... and he was driven out of it, fearful and vigilant.' And I also said: 'My blamer regarding the beloved, leave me, for... the intensity of love has exhausted me. Observe Allah regarding a loving lover... for the stars of the night are watchers.' And I also said from a poem: 'So I spent the night occupied by a distraction from blame... that drives slumber away from me, a driver of sleeplessness.' And I also said from a message: 'As for the watcher, his matter is strange, and closing the door in his face is a victory from Allah and a near conquest. By day, he is of those who show off, and by night, a son of a whore who does not sleep nor let people sleep. His harm, if it comes from afar, is closer than the jugular vein. Between the lover and the blamer, he utters no word except that there is a watcher ready with him. If he sits, the Resurrection rises, and if he leaves, may Allah not write safety for him.' 

Chapter: The Slanderer and the Informer. 
How witty is what I heard regarding that. My lute said to me in the morning when they saw me... 'What do you desire?' and they pressed me. I said: 'Fried in it are the tongues of slanderers... which they cut into it with wondrous skill. And they added to it the liver of an envious one... upon which the eyes of a watcher were gouged out.' This is taken from the speech of some lovers when asked: 'What do you desire?' He said: 'The eyes of watchers, the tongues of slanderers, and the livers of the envious.' Another said: 'I have a wish from them on the day of connection... O assembly of sitters and drinking companions: That I roast with it the hearts of the envious... and the tongues of slanderers and the eyes of watchers.' The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: 'The most hateful of you to me are those who walk with gossip, who separate loved ones.' And he (peace be upon him) said: 'Four types of people harm the people of Hellfire in addition to the harm they already suffer... among them: a man who eats the flesh of people and walks with gossip.' Waddah al-Yaman said: 'So disobey the slanderers, for... the speech of slanderers is temptation (Fitnah). Indeed, if slanderers come to you... they advise you and forbid you from [love].' It is narrated that Ma'n sang in the presence of Sultan Imad al-Din Zanki, the ruler of Sham, the words of the poet: 'Woe is me from the angry one who turned away when... the slanderer conveyed to him a hadith entirely false. I greeted him, but he turned away, bending the bow of his eyebrow... as if I were a bow of wine and he was drunk.' The Sultan admired them and said: 'Whose are they?' It was said: 'Ibn Munir.' So he ordered him to be brought to make him a boon companion and elevate his status in his presence. Al-Sari said: 'I meet you with beautiful cheer, flattering... but I have no flatterer in you, as far as I know. You are, regarding what I entrusted to you, like a glass bottle... the thing inside it is seen as visible while it is hidden.' Shihab al-Din al-Athir said: 'I am madly in love with you... and other than your love is forbidden to hearts. Do not listen to the words of slanderers, for they... added to speech, decreased it, and completed it [with lies]. My wish is that you be pleased, even if by my death... any divorce three times is binding upon me.' Another said: 'A sheikh who views the five prayers as voluntary... and deems the blood of pilgrims permissible in the Sanctuary. I cannot count his traits due to their abundance... but they are gathered in Nun and the Pen.' He refers to the Almighty's saying: 'A slanderer, going about with calumnies, a hinderer of good, a transgressor, sinful, cruel, and after all that, base-born (zanim).' It came in the interpretation that the 'Hammaz' is the one who backbites people, meaning mentions them with unpleasantness and eats their flesh through defamation and gossip. Al-Hasan said: 'He is the one who twists his jaws at the backs of people.' It is said the 'Humaza' is the one who criticizes to the face, and 'Lumaza' behind the back, and it is said the opposite. It is also said 'Humaza' is openly and 'Lumaza' is secretly with the eyebrow and eye. The 'Nammam' is the transporter of bad speech. Poets have frequently censured him, but Ibn Rashiq disagreed with them, saying: 'Why do our brothers hate the slanderer... my brothers have done evil and not good. If he is a slanderer, then his reverse (Ma'kus)... without lying to them, is a safe haven (Ma'man).' [Note: This is a wordplay]. Another said:

'Listen to the advice of a knower... who combined advice with affection. Beware and be cautious of being... confident in those who are trustworthy.' Another said: 'A gathering is pure, but a slanderer muddies it... and a watcher causes pain with blame. There is no striver (sa'in) in it except the cupbearer, and there is no slanderer (nammam) among the drinking companions except the basil (rayhan).' [Note: pun on 'nammam' which means slanderer and a type of plant]. Another said: 'For my exposure in his cheeks... there is a cause, and people are blaming. How can I hide what I endure... when the one I love is a Nammam (slanderer/basil)?' Sheikh Sadr al-Din ibn al-Wakil said: 'I hid your love from all my limbs... but my eyes told on me (washat), and slanderers are eyes. I wished that my ribs and limbs... were eyes that could see you, but they have no eyes. O would that Qays were in the time of my ardent love... so I could show him how love should be.' 

Chapter Fifteen: Reproach upon the Meeting of Loved Ones, and what relates to that of Contentment and Pardon for what has passed. 
I say: We have dedicated this chapter to mentioning the reproach that... [text unclear]... and spreading a passion softer than the languid breeze. Yes, in reproach there are many benefits and the removal of distress, so let not your affair be a source of blindness to you. It is of sections: Reproach that confirms affection and obtains the result, reproach to belie the conveyor [of gossip], and reproach to distinguish truth from falsehood. It is known that reproach between loved ones has a root and merit, cutting and connecting; it is inevitable and indispensable. Except for those who do not see it at all, or only reproach the beloved as a slip, like Al-Buhturi when he says: 'I reproach the beloved for what came once... then peace be upon him, I will not reproach him.' In the proverbs of the Arabs: 'The worst of manners is excessive reproach.' Al-Ahnaf said: 'Reproach is the key to hatred, but reproach is better than malice.' Bashar said regarding minimizing reproach: 'If in all matters you are reproaching... your friend, you will not find one whom you do not reproach. If you do not drink repeatedly over specks [in the water]... you will thirst, and which people's drink is pure?' Sa'id bin Hamid the scribe said: 'Lessen your reproach, for remaining [together] is brief... and time acts fairly once and leans [unfairly] another. Perhaps the days of life are short... so why should our reproaching increase and lengthen?' Another said: 'Some reproach, if you raise it... distances abandonment or brings closeness. So reproach your brother and do not shun him... for every station has a speech.' Among the wittiest things I heard regarding one who shunned loved ones then initiated reproach is the saying of some of them: 'You reproached me, but I have no sin... regarding what the sin is in, and no doubt belongs to you. You feared my blame, so you hastened... to blame me before I could hasten to you. So we were as it was said in the past... "Catch the thief before he catches you."' Some of them dislike reproach entirely and say it is the key to abandonment and the means to repulsion and estrangement, as was said: 'Do not acknowledge listening to whom... you love by recounting sins. None debates loved ones except... one who lives without a lover.' Some see it and do not refuse it, as was said: 'Two lovers reconciled upon reproach... and they did not separate until the Day of Judgment. There is no life like union after abandonment... and nothing is more delicious than reproach. Neither this one tires of the other's speech... nor that one tires of the answer.' Another said: 'The best days of love is your day in which... you threaten with abandonment and reproach. If there is no anger or contentment in love... then where is the sweetness of messages and letters?' Al-Hasan wrote a letter to a boy seeking his sympathy, but the boy signed on his letter: 'Increased in abandonment until the Day of Resurrection.' So Al-Hasan said: 'I wrote to the beloved a verse of poetry... reproaching him, but my answer angered him: "Answer me, O bored one, to my letter... for the soul finds rest in the answer." So he signed on the letter: "Increased in abandonment... and distance until the Day of Reckoning."' I mentioned here the saying of Ibn Rashiq: 'My heart belongs to a boy of the scribe class who captivates... the hearts of lovers with his eyes. I raised [a petition] to him seeking his satisfaction... and asking him for deliverance from his hands. So he signed: "The heart of this one has been rejected... pardoned, so let there be no aggression against him."' The erudite Sheikh Abu al-Thana Shihab al-Din Mahmud said, incorporating [verses]: 'We spent the night under the rule of ardent love, my ambition... my sighing and my guts, and drinking tears. And my love hands me cups of blame... and recites to me while worry splits the heart:'

'Do you hope for union from Layla, while... the hopes cut the necks of men? So I spent the night as if a slender snake... of the speckled ones attacked me, in whose fangs the poison is soaking.' I said: This incorporation contains insight and a lesson for those who take heed. How not, when its sayer mixed poison with saliva, and attached the beloved to the snakes? He became desperate, likening his beloved's mouth to slender fangs, meeting the purity of his reproach with turbidity. O you of hard heart, are you iron or stone? I do not think he filled the cups of this blame except from the water of Abu Tammam's blame, where he exceeded the limit in metaphor and went out carrying blame on his shoulder reluctantly, saying: 'Do not give me the water of blame to drink, for I... am a lover who has found the water of my weeping sweet.' Why did he not refrain from engaging in this path and follow the saying of Ibn Sana al-Mulk: 'I hope for a reproach that is found sweet, so would that I... prolonged my sins so his reproach would prolong. And in my ghazal (love poetry) is the mention of Al-Udhayb and Bariq... and it is nothing but his mouth and his saliva.' Or [why did he not] adopt the manners of people and follow suit? Abu Firas says: 'He did evil, so the evil increased him in favor... a beloved, despite what comes from a beloved. He counts his sins against the female slanderers... and from where does a beautiful face get sins?' However, may Allah have mercy on him, it is possible he intended a meaning of high value; in that case, my speech would be 'the talk of Khurafa, O Umm Amr.' 'How many a fault-finder of correct speech... while his bane is from his sick understanding.' Another said: 'And if the beloved comes with a single sin... his beauties come as a thousand intercessors.' Better than that is the saying of Atiq bin Muhammad al-Warraq: 'Whenever he sins, his face shows... an argument, for he is rich in arguments. How can one who, if he wished, exits from the sin... be excessive in his crimes?' Al-Hakam bin Qanbar al-Mazini said: 'As if the sun flashed from his sides... in beauty, and the full moon rose from his buttons. He is met with what he desires, and even if his evil deeds increase... he is excused for what he did. In his face is an intercessor that wipes out his evil... from hearts; a distinguished one wherever he intercedes.' This is taken from the saying of Abu Nuwas in his context: 'My face, if I approach, intercedes for me... and the tribulation of your eye is the beauty of my behind.' There is an addition mentioning what is behind her, but Al-Hakam's verse is a structure and sweeter praise. Abu Firas said: 'Say to our loved ones, the criminals against us... you have trained us to endure boredom. Do good in your deeds or do evil... we will not lack you in any case.' He also said: 'O you criminal, while we ask him for satisfaction... and O you sinner, while we repent. May Allah curse the one who observes you only when near... and does not regard the unseen when you are absent.' Another said: 'If we fall ill, we come to visit you... and you sin, yet we come to apologize.' Another said: 'And if I get angry at him one day... for sins about which speech would be long. The emotions of love bend me until... I seek his satisfaction so that boredom may cease.' Another said: 'My arguments against you when alone are many... but when you are present, I am defeated. I cannot say "You wronged me"... while Allah knows that I am the oppressed.' Al-Qarra' said: 'If this were a place for reproach, my heart would be healed, but reproach has its places.' Ibn al-Mu'tazz said: 'Accept the excuses of one who comes to you apologizing... whether he is truthful in your view in what he said or lying. For he who satisfies you outwardly has obeyed you... and he who disobeys you secretly has honored you.' I said in my letter 'Knocking on the Door and Waiting for the Answer': We seek refuge in Allah from the slip of the wise, and declare innocence to Him from persisting in falsehood. 'This truth has no obscurity... so leave me from the side roads.' The truth has become manifest, and reproach knocked on the door ring, saying 'knock'. Another said: 'Grant that he refrained after the reproach; was not... his affection natural, then became affectation?' It is as if I see our master standing at the threshold of reproach saying 'Who knocked on the door heard the answer', so he answered them: 'If you find in that a burden... leave me to die of passion and do not burden yourselves.' 

Section on Pardon and Contentment, and Forgiving What Has Passed. 
It came from Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, regarding the Almighty's saying 'So overlook with beautiful forgiveness' that it means contentment without reproach. The Almighty said: 'And let them pardon and overlook. Do you not like that Allah should forgive you?' The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: 'Whoever does not accept from an apologizer, whether truthful or lying, will not come to the Basin [in the afterlife].' The poet said:

'My sin against you is great... and you are greater than it. So take your right first... then forgive it by your grace. If I am not in my deeds... of the noble, then you be [one of them].' Another said: 'How beautiful is pardon from the capable... especially towards one with no helper. O goal of intent and furthest wish... and best pasture for the eye of the beholder. If I have a sin—and I have no sin... then it has no forgiver but You. I seek refuge in the affection between us... that you do not spoil the first by the last.' Abu Muhammad al-Yazidi used to drink with Al-Mamun, and wine overcame him one night, so he became rowdy. Al-Mamun ordered him to be carried to his home gently. When he sobered up, he was ashamed and stopped riding [to the court] for days. When it went on too long, he wrote verses to Al-Mamun, including: 'I am the sinner, the frequent wrongdoer, and pardon is vast... if there were no sin, pardon would not be known. I got drunk, so the cup revealed some of what... I hated; and drunkenness and sobriety are not equal. Especially if I was with a Caliph... and in a gathering where nonsense is not permitted.' When Al-Mamun read them, he signed on the note: 'Come to us, for we have pardoned you, so there is no blame on you; the carpet of wine folds what is with it.' The poet took it and said: 'The gathering of drink is but a carpet... so when it is over, we fold its carpet.' Ibn Sana al-Mulk said: 'And that is not the beloved, for he attended graciously and came humbly, not coquettishly, and sought refuge in the sanctuary of respect, and lowered the wing of humility out of mercy. He apologized that coquetry led him to arrogance, dropped him into matters, and brought him out of darkness into light. So he accepted his excuse, kissed his mouth, obeyed his command, and turned the rein of the heart to him with good turning, and the sweetness of gathering his saliva removed the bitterness of his transgression.' 'And if the beloved comes with a single sin... his beauties come with a thousand intercessors.' Another said: 'You claimed that I am unjust, so you abandoned me... and shot into my heart a penetrating arrow. Yes, I wronged you, so excuse and overlook... this is the station of the one seeking refuge, the returning one.' Ibn Zaydun said: 'O moon whose rising place is the West... the way has become narrow for me in your love. You compelled me to the sin I committed... you spoke truth, so forgive, for I am the sinner. For one of the strangest things I have encountered... is that my torment in you is sweet.' Another said: 'I did not meet your pardon with an excuse... but I say as you say. I will knock on the door of your pardon with an apology... and let beautiful tolerance judge between us.' 

Chapter Sixteen: Aiding the Poor Lover When the Knife Reaches the Bone. 
I say: We have dedicated this chapter to mentioning the most chivalrous of people, the most abundant in manliness, the softest in heart, and the best in upbringing among those who have become, among lovers, old in abandonment and migration, and for whom a thousand intoxications touch him from the cups of love. No doubt he helped the people of love and balanced himself against the grain of passion in his heart, striving to fix his condition and equating him with himself and his wealth. Allah is the Sayer in this meaning: 'Stand longing, or aiding, or sad... or helping, or excusing, or blaming. If you are free from all that... I mean with false hopes in distance. If you do not fight, O coward, then encourage.' I said: Or not less than that, O daughter of Malik. And [text unclear] the Sayer in that: 'If people knew of my longing and who is sufficient... I would not have spent the night teaching them to pray for rain by appointment. And they would intercede for me to my beloved, all of them... and their visitor would come leading [others].' Among the most amazing things I heard regarding aiding the lover and taking revenge for him is what Al-Jahiz narrated: He said, 'It reached me that a lover died in India out of love, so the King of India sent for the beloved and killed him.' Al-Khara'iti said: 'There was a copper merchant who had a slave girl; he had no comfort other than her. He used to display her in seasons, and people bid high for her until she reached a large amount of money while he asked for increase. A poor man became attached to her, and his mind almost went. When [the merchant] learned of this, he gifted her to him. He was reproached for that, so he said: "I heard Allah say: 'And whoever saves one - it is as if he had saved mankind entirely.' Should I not save mankind entirely?"' Al-Khara'iti narrated that one of the Caliphs had a boy servant and a slave girl among his servants who loved each other. The boy wrote to her one day: 'I saw you in a dream as if... you gave me your cold saliva to drink. And as if your hand was in my hand, and as if we... spent the night together in one bed. So I began to pretend to sleep throughout my sleep... to see you in my sleep, though I was not sleeping.' The girl answered him:

'You saw good, and all that you saw... you will attain from me despite the envious. I hope that you will be my embrace... spending the night above a swelling breast. And I see you between my anklets and bracelets... and I see you above my collarbones and body.' The news of them reached the Caliph, so he married them and treated them well despite his intense jealousy. Abu al-Faraj ibn al-Jawzi said: Al-Muhallab heard a youth singing about a slave girl of his, so Al-Muhallab said: 'By my life, I am merciful to lovers... and I am worthy of kindness to lovers. I will gather your scattered union... and I am capable of what you hope for.' Then he gifted her to him along with five thousand dinars. It is narrated about Uthman bin Affan, may Allah be pleased with him, that a slave girl came to him seeking justice against a man from the Ansar. Uthman asked her, 'What is your story?' She said, 'O Commander of the Faithful, I love his nephew, and I constantly watch over him.' Uthman said to him, 'Either you give her to your nephew, or I will give you her price from my money.' He said, 'I call you to witness, O Commander of the Faithful, that she belongs to my nephew.' A boy from the Arabs was brought to Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah honor his face, found in a people's house at night. He said to him, 'I am not a thief, but I will tell you the truth. I became attached in the house of Al-Riyahi to a young woman... the sun and moon humble themselves to her beauty. She has beauty and lineage among the daughters of the Romans... if she boasts of beauty, glory confirms her. When I knocked on the house out of the heat of a soul... I spent the night while in it was an ember of its burning. The people of the house rushed at me then shouted... "He is the thief," destined for killing and capture.' When Ali heard his poetry, he felt pity for him and said to Al-Muhallab, 'Allow him to have her, and we will compensate you for her.' He said, 'O Commander of the Faithful, ask him so we know his lineage.' He said, 'Al-Nahhash bin Utbah Al-Ajli.' He said, 'Take her, she is yours.' Al-Tamimi narrated in his book 'Imtizaj al-Nufus' that Muawiyah bin Abi Sufyan bought a slave girl from Bahrain and admired her greatly. One day he heard her reciting verses, including: 'And I parted from him like a branch shaking in the moist earth... a handsome youth with a first beard growth.' He asked her, and she told him, 'He is a cousin of mine.' So he returned her to him while sparks of fire were in his heart [from jealousy/loss]. Al-Khara'iti mentioned that Al-Mahdi went out for Hajj. When he was at Zubala and sat down for lunch, a young Bedouin entered upon him and wept, saying, 'O Commander of the Faithful, I am a lover,' and raised his voice. He said to the doorkeeper, 'Woe to you, what is this?' He said, 'A person shouting that he is a lover.' He said, 'Bring him in.' So they brought him in. He said, 'Who is your beloved?' He said, 'My cousin.' He said, 'Does she have a father?' He said, 'Yes.' He said, 'Why does he not marry you to her?' He said, 'There is something here, O Commander of the Faithful.' He said, 'What is it?' He said, 'I am a Hajin (mixed breed),' and a Hajin is one whose mother is not Arab. Al-Mahdi said to him, 'So what?' He said, 'It is a defect among us.' So he sent for her father. He was brought. He said, 'Is this your nephew?' He said, 'Yes.' He said, 'Why do you not marry your noble daughter to him?' He said to him like his nephew's statement. There were a group of Abbasid children with him. He said, 'All of these are Banu Abbas, and they are Hajins (born of slave mothers); so what harm does that do them?' He said, 'It is a defect among us.' Al-Mahdi said to him, 'Marry him to her for twenty thousand dirhams: ten thousand for the defect, and ten thousand as her dowry.' He said, 'Yes.' So he praised Allah and extolled Him, and married him to her. He brought two bags of money and gave them to him. The young man recited: 'I bought a doe at a high price, and... high prices are only paid for her likes by my likes. I left the markets of the ugly to their people... for the ugly, even if cheap, are expensive.' Khalid bin Abdullah Al-Qasri inspected his prison one day, and in it was Yazid bin So-and-so Al-Ajli. Khalid said to him, 'Why were you imprisoned, O Yazid?' He said, 'Suspicion, may Allah reform the Emir.' He said, 'Will you return if I release you?' He said, 'Yes, O Emir.' He hated to expose his story lest his beloved be exposed. Khalid said, 'Bring the men of the tribe so we may cut off his hands in their presence.' Yazid had a brother who wrote poetry and sent it to Khalid: 'O Khalid, this is a distracted lover... glances struck him, he is not a thief. He confessed to what he did not do... he saw cutting [of the hand] better than the scandal of a girl. If what I feared of his hand being cut happened... you would have found regarding his matter no speaker. If banners appear for racing in highness... then you, O son of Abdullah, are the first winner.' When Khalid read the verses, he knew the truth of his statement. He summoned the guardians of the girl and said, 'Marry your girl to Yazid.' They said, 'But after what appeared about him?' He said, 'If you do not marry him willingly, you will marry him unwillingly.' So they married him, and Khalid paid the dowry from his own wealth. Ahmad bin Al-Fadl the scribe mentioned that a boy and a girl were in a school; the boy loved her. He kept being kind to his teacher until he placed him near her. One day, when the other boys were unaware, he wrote on the girl's tablet:

'What do you say regarding one whom sickness has wasted... from the length of loving you until he became bewildered?' When the girl read it, her eyes filled with tears out of mercy for him, and she wrote beneath it: 'If we see a lover whom the length of ardor has harmed... we bestow kindness upon him.' The teacher came and heard that from their whispering, so he took the tablet and wrote these two verses: 'Connect the monitor ('Arif) and do not fear anyone... the monitor has become young and lovestruck. As for the Faqih (teacher), no harm will assault him... for he has been worn out by love of various kinds.' Al-Khara'iti mentioned from Abu Assaf, who said: Abu Bakr, may Allah be pleased with him, passed by a slave girl saying: 'I loved him before my amulets were cut... walking together like a soft branch.' He asked her, 'Are you free or a slave?' She said, 'A slave.' He said, 'Who is your love?' She hesitated. He swore upon her, so she recited: 'I am the one with whose heart passion played... I was killed by the love of Muhammad ibn al-Qasim.' So he bought her from her master and sent her to Muhammad ibn al-Qasim ibn Ja'far ibn Abi Talib and said, 'These [women] are the temptation of men; how many a noble man, by Allah, has died because of them, and a healthy one perished.' Azza entered upon Umm al-Banin, sister of Umar bin Abdul Aziz, who was a worshiper. She said to her, 'What is the meaning of Kuthayyir's saying: "Every debtor paid his creditor... and Azza is procrastinating, her creditor is suffering." What was this debt?' She said, 'I promised him a kiss and I deferred it.' Then she [Umm al-Banin] went out from her [presence] and said, 'Fulfill it, and the sin be upon me.' Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Abi Mulaykah narrated from his father from his grandfather, saying: Abd al-Rahman ibn Abi Ammar, who was then the Faqih of Hijaz, entered upon a slave trader displaying slave girls. He fell in love with one of them and became famous for it, to the point that Ata, Tawus, and Mujahid walked to him advising him. His answer was: 'People I sit with blame me regarding you... I do not care if the blame flies or lands.' His news reached Abdullah bin Ja'far, who had no concern other than him. He sent to the master of the slave girl and bought her from him for forty thousand dirhams, and ordered the keeper of his slave girls to perfume her, which she did. People entered upon him. He said, 'Why do I not see Ibn Abi Ammar?' He was told he was secluded in his home due to his excessive state. Ibn Ja'far went to him. When he saw him, he wanted to rise, but he made him sit and said to him, 'What has the love of So-and-so done?' He said, 'It is in the flesh, blood, nerves, and bones.' He said, 'Would you recognize her if you saw her?' He said, 'Would I recognize anyone else?' He said, 'We have added one to her; by Allah, I have not looked at her.' He ordered her, and she came out to him immediately. He said, 'Is this her?' He said, 'Yes, may my father and mother be your ransom.' He said, 'Take her by her hand, for I have made her yours. Are you satisfied?' He said, 'Yes, by Allah, and above satisfaction.' Ibn Ja'far said to him, 'But by Allah, I am not satisfied to give her to you like this. Boy, carry one hundred thousand dirhams to him.' 

Chapter Seventeen: Mentioning the Cure for the Illness of Passion. 
I say: We have dedicated this chapter to mentioning the cure of love which has baffled the physicians, leaving them bewildered and drunk, though not from wine. However, what they agreed upon and pointed to is that there is no cure for this incurable disease except sweet union, such as pressing the breasts, knocking the lips, and the adhesion of bodies. [Poetry]: 'I saw that love has no cure... except placing chests upon chests.' Especially from one whose breasts have appeared, cheeks have rosed, taste is sweet, and embrace is good. 'I embrace him while the soul is still longing... for him; is there closeness after embrace? And I kiss his mouth so my heat may cease... but the bewilderment I encounter intensifies. As if my heart's thirst is not quenched... except by seeing the two spirits mix.' Another said: 'The cure of love is kissing and smelling... and placing bellies upon bellies. And a shaking from which eyes shed tears... and taking by the shoulders and the horns (locks of hair).' Another said: 'He sickened my heart then did not cure it... a tier of a belt (zunnar) on his waist. My spirit does not meet with his body... until I see my chest upon his belly.' Abu Ja'far al-Adawi said: 'The drunkenness of passion is more healing for my bones and joints... when the drinking companion gets drunk from the pleasure of wine. And better than the strumming of the second strings and plucking them... is the return of the voice of the mouth knocking against the mouth.' Abu Dihqan said: Abu Hilal our Sheikh narrated to us from some of his Sheikhs from Sharik: 'The lover is not cured of what ails him... by smelling and kissing until...'
