And in 'Al-Aghani', Abu al-Ayna said: I recited to Abu al-Ibar the saying of Al-Mamun: 'Love is nothing but a kiss... and a squeeze of a hand or a bite. And whoever's love is not like that... seeks only children. Love is nothing but this... if love is copulated with, it spoils.'

Then he said: Al-Ma'mun lied and ate … two and a quarter pounds by weight, and erred and behaved poorly. Why didn’t he say as I did: 'And love overflowed in my heart … woe if it hatches, love will not benefit me … if I do not break the obstruction, and if it does not remove the bald spot … then push it away from the kitchen.' Then he asked me what I thought, and I said, 'I am amazed.' He said: 'I thought you would say something else.' I raised my hand and said: 'Say what Al-Ma'mun said: if love marries, it spoils.' This is according to those who hold this view. Al-Marzubani narrated that a Bedouin said: 'I was involved with a woman I used to visit. Nothing between us caused suspicion, except that I saw the whiteness of her hand on a dark night, so I placed my hand over hers. She said: "Do not ruin what is solid, for only marrying love spoils it."' It was narrated from some literati that a man loved a slave girl. She said: 'You have true love with full fidelity?' He said yes. She said: 'Go with me wherever you wish.' When he took her to his house, his only concern was to lift her legs and engage her with all his parts. She said to him while restrained: 'Divert your desire … and consider … the benefit … be gentle, for gentleness is praised.' He responded while in the act: 'I do not … the remaining affection … but this … is effort.' She pulled away and said: 'O sinner, you contradict your words. It seems you make my body the reason for the disappearance of your love. By God, I will never unite with you again.' According to this view, love spoils if consummated, and some say love only stabilizes after intercourse, and that love increases with consummation, calling it the 'nail of love.' As it was said: 'Love does not satisfy two lovers who have not tasted … union, for it surpasses all pleasures.' Hedbah ibn al-Khashram said: 'By God, the wandering heart is not healed … by incantations or tying charms, and the story persists … if you are connected and attached.' Another said, referring to Atikah: 'In a glance, the desire is resolved. I want you for marriage … not for sight. If you were satisfied with …, this would be for the moon.' Zuhair ibn Muskan loved a slave girl and pursued her. When he managed to possess her, she found nothing satisfying, so she left and never returned. He wrote many poems about her, including: 'You speak, and I kissed you a thousand kisses … is that all you have besides kisses?' I told her: 'Love is preserved in the heart … through long wakefulness, the eyes overflow for it.' She said: 'By God, the joy of a youth … from love is in a heart that contradicts action.' As for 'marrying the phantom' (imaginary love), there was disagreement. Abu Tammam al-Tai said it does not spoil love, unlike real marriage. Others disagreed. Some, when approaching their beloved, limit themselves to sipping, maintaining chastity and fear of sin if the beloved is unlawful. As it was said: 'Perhaps the delight of one night you had … forbidden by its lawful counterpart.' Another said: 'May I pour in your visit … for your heart and eyes’ desires, not intending harm … long observation maintains purity, but sinful sight.' Another said: 'Take free women without suspicion … like Meccan gazelles; their pursuit is forbidden. They think gentle talk is licentiousness … and it prevents them from sin.' Scholars said that lust of the heart is intertwined with the pleasure of the eye and love of the self, unless love is forced, in which case desire and pleasure are in proportion to indulgence. When eye, heart, and self align with the beloved, love dominates and sexual desire diminishes. If the woman dislikes the man, the outcome is negative, as said: 'My love saw Saad without union … she said our rope is a rope of separation.' Some claimed that traveling heals those deprived of their beloved, as it was said: 'If you want to forget a lover … count the nights without them.' Another said: 'They claimed the lover grows weary with closeness … and distance cures longing.' However, proximity did not cure our pain … though being near home is better than being far away.

However, nearness of the house is not beneficial... If the one you desire possesses no affection.
Another said: They said the cure for love is a love that removes it... For another, or long persistence in abandonment.
Another said: I treated myself for Laila with Laila, from desire... Just as the drinker of wine treats himself with wine.
Al-Hafiz Abu Abdullah Al-Bukhari mentioned in his history with his chain of narration that Muhammad bin Dawood made a ring and engraved two lines on it. The first: 'And We found no covenant for most of them.' The second: 'So do not let yourself perish over them in regret.' When he saw a man persisting in looking at youths, he would say to him: 'Read what is on the ring,' perhaps he would desist from that. And Allah knows best.
Shams al-Din Ibn al-Akfani said in his book 'Ghunyat al-Labib 'inda Ghaybat al-Tabib' (Sufficiency of the Intelligent in the Absence of the Doctor), the text of which is: If the lover drinks a decoction of wild rue (Harmal), he forgets the love. Likewise, Indian indigo, if he drinks four grains of it with water before the love takes firm hold, he forgets. Likewise, the stone found sometimes in the bellies of chickens, if thrown in water and the lover drinks it, he forgets; and likewise if it is hung upon him. Also, the Salwan stone (stone of solace) and rubbing it with milk. And whoever hangs the stork stone upon himself while in love will forget, and if he is sad, his sadness will vanish. And whoever is in love with a male and rolls in the resting place of a female mule, his love will vanish. End quote.
Note: Treatment by intercourse is not permitted by Islamic law in any way if the beloved is someone whom it is not permissible to marry. As for treatment by embracing and kissing, if a cure is realized by it, it is analogous to treatment with wine according to those who permit it; rather, this is lighter than that, for drinking it is among the major sins, while this act is among the minor sins.

A Prescription: Use kissing, embracing, and thin lips in a hall, an Iwan (arched hall), with a pool and a fountain, food of seven colors, violet, narcissus, myrtle, wallflower, roses, basil, jars of old wine, a thousand dinars in a bag, and a slave girl from the children of the Turks with a plump leg and a kohl-rimmed eye. Use these needs on a red leather mat with green engravings. After this, enter the bathhouse, for it is tested and effective. Farewell.

Another Prescription: Take three weights (Mithqals) of the pure union of the beloved, a weight of the sticks of aversion and fear of the watcher, three weights of the kernels of meeting cleaned of the chaff of abandonment and interruption, an ounce of pure affection and concealment stripped of the sticks of repulsion and desertion. Take the perfume of incense, the kissing of mouths, and the embracing of waists, two weights of each. Take one hundred pomegranate-like kisses, rubbed and bruised; fifty of them small and sugary, thirty pigeon-style, and twenty sparrow-style. Take Aleppo coquetry and Iraqi snorting, two weights of each. Take two ounces of tongue-sucking and kissing the mouth with the lips. Pound everything, mix it, and sprinkle over it the weight of three Dirhams of Egyptian lust, adding to it the beauty of folded belly creases. Boil everything with the water of love over the syrup of intimacy and the firewood of mirth in the cauldron of haste. Strain everything over a Damascene Royal cloth, and dissolve in it two ounces of the syrup of satisfaction. Drink it on an empty stomach for three days. The diet should be a broth of the gourd of longing, adding to it the heart of the almond of embracing and the juice of the lemon of agreement. After that, consume three pounds (Ratls) of wine, followed by two pounds of leg-lifting, and enter the bathhouse. For it is beneficial. Farewell.

A cutting sword and a shining, bright lightning regarding the treatment of the illness of passion: This is what the masters of mathematics recounted regarding the number 284. It is called the Lover Number, and its form in the natural pen (notation) is this. Its dot letters are D, F, R. In numbers, the Beloved is called 220, and its form in the natural pen is this.

And its dot letters are K, R. The number 220 is loved forever by the number 284. If a person has a ring or a silver tablet or whatever is possible of metals weighing 220, and another person has a second ring or tablet weighing the second of the two numbers, then the one who has 284 will love the one who has the number 220. If you want to solicit affection, attract hearts, and capture souls, write on a piece of paper the image of the numbers 284 in the natural pen described previously, and write on another piece of paper the image of the numbers 220. Hold the two papers between those who have hated each other, and they will love each other, and there will be no evil between them as long as the two papers are with them. If that is not possible, cast the two papers in a clean container, write the name of each of them or their famous title, and place the container in a place they pass over; they will love each other. If you write the loving numbers with water and sugar and give it to both of them to drink, they will love each other. More amazing than that is if you feed a person who has hated another 284 pomegranate seeds, and feed the other hated person at that very time 220 pomegranate seeds, they will love each other.
Among what confirms love, as some wise men mentioned, is that if moisture from the saliva of each of the lovers reaches the stomach of the other, that mixes with the whole body and reaches the mass of the liver. Likewise, if each of them breathes into the face of his companion, something exits from that breath and mixes with the particles of the air. If they inhale it, it enters the nostrils and some of it reaches the brain, flowing in it like the flow of sleep in the mass of the heart. Some of it reaches the lungs, then the heart, then creeps into the pulsing veins in the entire body. Thus, what dissolved from the body of this one knots in the body of that one, becoming a temperament (mixture), so passionate love is generated and love is confirmed. Sheikh Mughlatay said: This is what I incline towards; it is likely to last and remain, unchanged by the passing of nights. 'At the time of the test, a person is honored or humiliated.'

Section

The Jurists differed on whether it is obligatory for a husband to have intercourse with his wife. A group said: It is not obligatory upon him because it is his right; if he wishes, he exacts it, and if he wishes, he leaves it, like one who rents a house—if he wishes he lives in it, and if he wishes he leaves it. This is one of the weakest opinions because the Quran, the Sunnah, custom, and analogy refute it. Allah Almighty said: "And they (women) have rights similar to those against them in a just manner." If intercourse is the husband's right over her, then it is her right over the husband by the text of the Quran. Allah Almighty said: "And live with them in kindness." It is contrary to kindness that he has a young woman whose desire equals his desire or exceeds it manifold, and he does not make her taste the pleasure of intercourse even once. Whoever claims that this is from kindness, his own nature suffices in refuting him.
A group said: It is obligatory for him to have intercourse with her once every four months. The woman is given the choice after that: if she wishes, she stays with him, and if she wishes, she leaves him. Had she had a right to intercourse more than that, the husband would not have been allowed to leave it for that period. This is the more appropriate of the two opinions, despite what is in it.
A group said: It is obligatory for him to have intercourse with her according to kindness (Ma'ruf), just as he spends on her, clothes her, and lives with her in kindness. They said: He must satisfy her with intercourse if he is able, just as he must satisfy her with food. Ibn Taymiyyah used to prefer this opinion and choose it. His student Ibn Qayyim al-Jawziyya said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, urged the use of this, encouraged it, attached reward to it, and made it a charity for the doer. He said: "And in the sexual act of one of you is a charity." In this is the perfection of pleasure, the perfection of benevolence, the attainment of reward, the joy of the soul, the departure of its bad thoughts, the lightness of the spirit and the departure of its density and coarseness, the lightness of the body, the balance of temperament, the bringing of health, and the repelling of bad substances.
If that coincides with a beautiful face, a gentle—meaning easy—character, abundant love, complete desire, and seeking reward, then that is the pleasure which nothing equals, especially if it meets its perfection. For it is not complete until every part of the body takes its share of pleasure. The eye finds pleasure in looking at the beloved, the ear in hearing his speech, the nose in smelling his scent, the mouth in kissing him, and the hand in touching him. Every limb devotes itself to what it seeks of its pleasures, and the beloved meets him with the like of that. If anything of that is missing, the soul remains looking forward to it, demanding it, so it does not settle completely. Therefore, the woman is called a "Sakan" (dwelling/peace) because the soul finds peace in her. For this reason, daytime intercourse was preferred over nighttime intercourse. It has another natural reason, which is that the night is a time when the senses cool down and seek their share of rest, while the day is the locus of the spreading of movements. That is His Almighty's saying: "And it is He who has made the night for you as clothing and sleep [a means for] rest and has made the day a resurrection."
Muhammad bin al-Munkadir used to pray in his prayer saying: "O Allah, strengthen my penis for me, for in it is righteousness for my family." Abdullah bin Salih said: Al-Layth bin Sa'd, when he covered his family (had intercourse), used to say: "O Allah, tighten its root for me, raise its chest for me, make easy its entry and exit, grant me its pleasure, and grant me righteous offspring who fight in Your way." He said: He was loud-voiced, so that was heard from him. Ali bin Asim said: Khalid al-Hadhdha' told us: When Allah created Adam and created Eve, He said: "O Adam, find peace in your wife." Eve said: "O Adam, how sweet this is! Increase us of it."

Chapter Eighteen: The Obstinacy of the Beloved against the Yearning Lover, and other divisions of Abandonment and the patience of the one holding onto embers in it.
I say: We established this chapter to mention accusation and the beloved saying "Away with you." It is a chapter, for one whom it passes, sweet to taste, fragrant in character by agreement. Its taste is known only to one who has tasted it and known the union of the beloved and his separation. Lovers have never ceased finding the beloved's accusation sweet, saying: "The beloved's hitting is raisins... The condition of love among the masters of passion is that the beautiful one is loved for his accusation." No limit deters them, nor do they stop at a limit from the swords of glances. How often they saw the beloved's injustice as justice, and said to his cheek when it approached: "Welcome and hello." No blamer's blame takes hold of them regarding him, nor do they count the injustice of the cold tyrant among injustices: "Whoever does not taste the injustice of the beloved like his shadow... Sweet, has been ignorant of love and made a false claim."
The famous standard in this chapter is the saying of 'Ulayya bint al-Mahdi: "Love was molded upon injustice, so if... The beloved were fair in it, it would be ugly. In the law of passion, it is not deemed good... For a lover to be good at composing arguments." It is as if she went in the first verse to the saying of Al-Abbas bin al-Ahnaf: "The best days of passion are your day in which... You are frightened by abandonment and admonition. If there is no anger nor satisfaction in love... Then where is the sweetness of letters and books?"
Al-Numayri added to this, saying: "My comfort is in the speech of the blamers. And my cure is in their saying: Do not exaggerate. Passion is not pleasant nor is love good for a lover... Except with five qualities:

Hearing harm, the blame of an adviser... Admonition, a secret enemy, and procrastination."
Jamil bin Ma'mar said: "There is no good in love that stops, moved not by... The obstacles of despair, nor relaxed by greed. If I had her patience or the ability to swallow (grief) she has... I would possess what I bring and what I leave."
Among the most eloquent things said regarding the obstinacy of loved ones is the saying of a Bedouin regarding his beloved: "I complained, so you said: All this is out of boredom... With my love? May Allah relieve your heart of my love. When I concealed the passion, she said obstinately... You were patient, and this is not the act of a grief-stricken heart. I draw near so she distances me, so I move away seeking... Her satisfaction, but she counts distancing as my sin. So my complaint hurts her, or my patience displeases her... And she panics at my distance and flees from my nearness. O people, is there a trick you know?... Advise (me) with it and merit the reward from my Lord."
They divided Abandonment (Hajr) into four types. They said: Abandonment of Coquetry (Dalal), Abandonment of Boredom (Malal), Abandonment as a penalty for a sin, and Abandonment necessitated by hatred established in the chests.
As for the Abandonment of Coquetry, it is much more delicious than Union. Upon it I established this chapter. Kushajim said: "Were it not for the chase of the prey, there would be no pleasure... So prolong the chase for me with union a little. This drink is the brother of life, and it has no... Pleasure until it hits a burning thirst."
Al-Mutanabbi said: "The sweetest passion is what its owner doubts regarding union... And in abandonment, for he is forever feared and guarded against." He also said: "Increase my soul in harm, I will increase you in love... For the most ignorant of people is a hateful lover." Another said: "If it grieved me that you attained me with an offense... It surely pleased me that I crossed your mind."
It is recommended for one marked with beauty, capturing the hearts of women and men, to be very humble and little in self-debasement. Ibn Waki' said: "They said: You loved one of much arrogance, inaccessible... I said: Far from it! The best of him is absent from you. If he were generous, he would be easy and his callers would be few... But he is mighty only because his demand is mighty." If he debases himself and answers everyone who calls him, he becomes subject to suspicions because the free soul is not detached from jealousy. Al-Abbas ibn al-Ahnaf said: "O people, I did not abandon you out of boredom... From me, nor due to the speech of an envious slanderer. But I tested you and found you... Not patient with a single food."
As for the Abandonment of Boredom, the passing of days and nights dampens it, either by the distance of the abode or by the length of testing. It is told that Mutayyam al-Hashimiyyah, when Ali bin Hisham bought her, became favored by him and he loved her intensely. It happened that she got angry at him at one time and persisted in her anger. He tried to please her but she was not pleased. So he wrote to her: "Coquetry calls to boredom. Many an abandonment called for patience. The heart (Qalb) was named Qalb only for its turning (Taqallub). The saying of Al-Abbas bin al-Ahnaf has proven true to me: 'I do not see myself but that I will abandon whoever does not... See me capable of abandonment when he bores of me. And I protect myself with good brotherhood against... The most harmful thing brotherhood brings to a human.'" When she read the note, she went out to him immediately and was pleased.
As for the Abandonment generated by a sin, repentance removes it from the heart upon confession of the sin, especially if the beloved is: "His kingdom is a kingdom of mercy, in which there is no... Tyranny from him nor arrogance. He fears Allah regarding the lover, and successful is he... Whose concern is piety (Taqwa)."
As for the Abandonment necessitated by natural hatred, it is the one that has no cure. Al-Husri said: This is not valid between those of sincerity and those of distinction, since the reality of resemblance prevents it and the validity of suitability repels it. What I say also is that this type is a disease whose cure is impossible and whose bitter water is not sweet. The beloved in it is not to be blamed, and loving him is like one who dances in the dark and greets one who does not return the greeting: "His loved ones, how much they do to his heart... What his enemies do not do to him." Al-Arjani took it and said: "O our loved ones, you did not wound with your abandonment... A heart that spends the eternity saddened by worry. If you wanted my killing while you are loved ones... Then there is no difference between loved ones and enemies." Another said: "My heart demands you of me every hour... If the debtor goes bankrupt, the creditor persists. It yearns for you with the yearning of one touched by thirst... While the watering places have been unjustly forbidden to him. If you wanted my killing while you are loved ones... Then the enemies are one with the beloveds."

Chapter Nineteen: Supplication against the Beloved, and the Inverted Jurisprudence therein.
Like my saying: "I prayed against the beloved due to the love of a fawn... From whom I endure types of harshness. So He united him (with me) and he exaggerated in turning away from me... So my prayer was, therefore, against myself."
I say: We established this chapter to mention one who neared the arrival of his grave and wanted to pray against his soul (beloved), so he prayed against himself. He desires and complains, seeks cure and gets hurt. He does not remain firm on a state, nor does he distinguish with the sword of the glance between the past and the present. While he complains about his beloved, behold he complains to him; and while he prays for him, behold he prays against him. Among the best said in supplication for the beloved is the saying of our compatriot Muhammad bin al-Afif al-Tilimsani, may Allah have mercy on his youth and make the sealed nectar his drink: "May Allah strengthen the supporters of the eyes... And perpetuate the rule of those eyelids. And they lost power due to languor... Even if they weakened my mind and religion. And may He protect the veil of those front teeth... Even if they turned the heart to sorrows. And may He extend the shade of that hair one day... Over the slender branches of his stature. And perpetuate the state of the sides (curves) within us... Even if they acted unjustly against the stabbed heart."
And his saying also: "May Allah perpetuate the days of union... And make eternal the life of those nights. And extend the shade of the branches of leisure... And increase the statures in good moderation. May the fruits of intimacy therein not cease... To increase in subtlety in every state. And may eyes not cease for us therein... Flirting with the eyes of the gazelle's fawn."
Ala' al-Din Ali bin al-Muzaffar al-Kindi said: "May Allah perpetuate the days of the cheek-hair... And bless its short nights. And may Allah enrich the garden of every cheek... When it shies away from the heavy rains. And may the smiling places of every mouth not cease... To be smiling for the one observing its lightning. And may the trailing robes of shame not cease to cover lovers... In the casting off of restraint."
Ibn Abi al-Hadid said: "May the right hands of all creation not embrace you... And may your waistband not tie. No, nor may your saliva be sipped after what... I tasted from your mouth, except by your mouth."
Another said: "O Lord, if You decreed him for a kisser... Other than me, then let it be the toothstick or the cups. And if You judged for us the company of a third... O Lord, let it be a candle in the gathering. And if You judged for us the eye of a watcher... O Lord, let it be from the eyes of the narcissus."
Among the best said in supplication against the beloved is the saying of Shihab al-Din bin Ghanim: "By Allah, I do not pray against the one abandoning me... Except that he goes deep into love until... He sees the extent of what happened... From him and what was done regarding my right."
Another said: "O you who every day... Increases my mind in insanity. You bewildered me regarding him until... You returned my guidance to error. I pray against you while my heart... Says: O Lord, no, no."
Another said, and excelled as he wished: "I said: You blamed until... I see you in love like me. But I said in secret within me... No, O Lord, do not answer me."
Another said: "O you who turns away... From my address and my answer. The loss! May Allah not remove my life... Or He shows me in you what is in me. My Lord, make it a prayer... Disappointed, unanswered. My heart softened (fearing) to see... Your heart in the like of my torment."
Another said: "O Lord, if there is no hope in his union... And no relief from the length of his cruelty. Then heal the illness that is in the glance of his eye... And cover the beauty of his cheeks with his beard."
Another said: "How often he shunned me, so I intended to pray against him... But I stopped, then called out bewildered: May Allah not heal his glance from illness... And show me his cheek-hair while it is flowing."
Ibn Sana' al-Mulk said: "I am captured by the length of my captivity in his hands... So he gets angry when I am captured by the length of my captivity. I asked Allah that he be afflicted with love... So he becomes a lover, but of my abandonment."
Ibn Waki' said: "If you knew what is in me... While you do not care about me. And your heart became my heart... And you became in the like of my state. Nay, you lived in a good life... My soul and wealth ransom you. I prayed when my chest narrowed... Against you, then it appeared (better) to me."
And his saying also: "He understood a mistake from me, an understanding... He came to me asking about what he knew. Swearing that what I informed him of my illness... I am a liar, by Allah, in what he claimed. The oppressed is granted mercy from us... Then I do not pray against the one who wronged."

Ibn Munqidh said: "O oppressor who turns away from me when... I called out angry against my oppressor. I think it is you, otherwise why... Do you fear my prayer to the exclusion of this world? O Lord, do not hear him regarding it, even if... It was the prayer of the wandering lover."
Another said: "I said to my beloved when his beloved passed by me... Like the moon travelling at night: This is the one whose glance takes for me... From your drowsy glance, revenge."
Another said: "When it appeared to me that he is not visiting me... And that his desire is not clearing away from me. I wished that he loves someone else, perhaps... He endures the bitternesses of love so he softens for me."

Chapter Twenty: Submission and the Shedding of Tears
I say: We established this chapter to mention one whose tear became poured upon poured, so he spent the night while it flowed like a spear (tube), as was said: 'Tube upon tube.' Especially if the abandonment persisted or there was some restriction upon him. There, lessons are seen from the pouring of his tear, and he recites when the mixture (companions) resolve to travel: "And a separator from the dwelling of hearts... So the abodes were not empty of him. He sent the messenger and said to me... And I am the hearer, obedient to him: By Allah, tell me what flowed... After me? So I said to him: The tears."
Another said: "The one I loved said to me, while separation was serious... And in my vitals was the flame of fire: What will you do in the road after me? I said: I will weep over you the length of the road."
How excellent is the saying of Judge Al-Fadil, may Allah have mercy on him: "... I employed thoughts to travel at night... And you did not release for me a wage by union. And I did not see myself over the days except... I tied affection and untied a bundle (of money). And I did not ask the clouds of the eye for rain except I became with my tears in the sun a squeezed juice."
And his saying also, which is from his prose that became scattered among the stars: "So be patient until this flood clears, and the clouds of this drunkenness lift, and the handkerchiefs of the eyelids dry, for they have become a squeezed juice by tears. May Allah fight Separation! How great is its meddling by entering between lovers."
In this dazzling meaning, Ibn Abd al-Zahir says: "Do not ask me about the beginning of Love, indeed I... Am in it old of abandonment (Hijr) and delirium (Hujrah). From my tears and from your forehead I wanted... My passion with a pouring rain and a blaze."
Among Al-Mutanabbi's strange meanings is his saying: "Do you think she, due to the abundance of lovers... Thinks tears are a creation (natural part) in the tear-ducts?"
And his saying also: "Do not blame the yearning one for his longings... Until your vitals are in his vitals. Indeed the wick dyed with its tears... Is like the slain dyed with his blood."
And his saying also: "I gifted consolation to the one who blamed me... And spent the night occupied by longing. As if the eyelids upon my eye... Are clothes torn over a bereaved mother."
The saying of another: "The hand of sorrow tore upon him... The robe of tears down to the hems."
Another said regarding Submission and Shedding Tears: "And I did not forget, I will not forget that submission... And the overflow of tears and the squeezing of the hand. And my cheek added to her cheek... Standing until the morning, we did not sleep."
Ibrahim bin al-Mi'mar said: "And I have an angry one whom nothing pleases except... Tears pouring continuously. So his sides did not bend with union... While there was a drop in my eye after abandonment."
Another said: "A female sayer: What is the matter with your eyes since they saw... The beauties of this person, their tears are pouring? I said: My eye committed adultery by looking at a countenance... So it had a right, from the flood of its tears, to a Ghusl (ritual washing)."
Al-Sari al-Raffa' said: "My soul be the ransom of one who returned the greeting laughing... So he renewed a greed for union after despair. And the tears of the eye came between me and him... As if the tears of the eye love him with me."
Ibn Waki' said: "And a cloud, when the water poured in it... The thunder ignited the lightning in its vitals. Like the water of the eyes, it did not flow except... It kept fueling the fire upon the hearts."
I said from a Hijazi poem: "O my two friends, the garden of Al-Raqmatayn, its embroidery... If the Hijazi lightning flashes, is gilded. So do not wonder at the clouds of my tear if they poured... For not every lightning that appeared to the eye is deceiving."
I said from another Hijazi poem: "My ulcerated eyelid upon the cheeks has dripped... So suffice it what flowed from my tears, suffice. If the arrangement of my tears is difficult when I scatter... For pearls are what is difficult until it passes the oyster shell."

Do not wonder at the stopping of my tear the morning there flowed... From his eyes what flowed, for the sea has fulfilled in it. I ceased not to weep over the valley of Al-Aqiq until... It was said: That one has bled from his eyes.
I also said from a poem: "I wept over a land in which I was walking... So I resembled in my tear its solid rock (Al-Khansa' - also poetess famous for weeping). You dared, O my tear, but did not dare always... So O tear, how flowing! And O heart, how hard!"
I also said from a poem: "Indeed my eye upon Al-Aqiq, if... My tear did not resemble in its color a red (wine). Since the silver of my tear became gold... Alchemy became valid for me for my eye. Do not ask what flowed of tears when... It became boldness against my blamer. The night brought forth my tears upon my cheek... Just as the stars come forth to the sky."
I said from a poem: "If my eye cooled the sea of its tears... Then the mouth of the one I desire, as is said, is cold. And if my glance untied its water-skin strap with tears... Then the breast of the one whom my glance greeted is tying."
I said from a poem: "I watered with the sea of tears the cold of her land... And sent them into it at a time of lassitude. O glance, if you do not aid the lover with weeping... You have cut the ropes of tears from where they were thin."
I said from a poem: "I contradicted regarding you a scolder and an adviser... And obeyed an eyelid ulcerated with tears. So make a report for my killing, for my tears... Have written to my heart explained with blood. A lover poured his tear on the slope of Al-Muqattam... The eyes flow with it as spilled blood. If your eyes witnessed his red tear... You would have vindicated the witness of his wounded heart."
I also said: "The glance, from the loss of sleep... Complains sorrow to it. And the cheek, from the excess of weeping... Oh what ran upon it!"
I said: "And who will have mercy on my anguish... And send a phantom in the slumber? And the tear of my eye, do not ask... About its state, oh what flowed!"
Al-Mas'udi, the commentator on the Maqamat, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, often recited: "She said: I knew you weeping... Blood out of fear of separation. So why did you replace it... After the blood with water? I said: That is not from me... For solace and comfort. But my tears turned grey... From the long life of my weeping."
Another said: "A female sayer: Why is your tear white... I said to her: O high one, this is what remained. Did you not know that weeping, its life prolonged... So my tears turned grey just as my hair turned grey? And soon neither my tears nor my blood... Will be seen, but my anguish and burning."
Another said: "A female sayer: Why is your tear black... While it used to be white and you are emaciated? I said to her: My tears dried up from weeping... And this is the black of the eye flowing."
Another said: "My tears were red on the day of their separation... But since they distanced, I bleached them after them with burning. I picked with the glance roses from their cheeks... So separation distilled rose water from my pupils."
Al-Nashi' Al-Akbar said: "She wept for the separation, and startled me... The weeping of the beloved for the loss of the abode. As if the tears on her cheek... Are the remains of dew on a pomegranate blossom."

Chapter Twenty-One: Promises and Wishes, and what relief of meanings is in them.
I say: We established this chapter to mention the wishes which are inevitable and indispensable, so there is no less than them: "I distract my heart with wishes, perhaps... I relieve the worry from myself with wishes. And I know that your union is not hoped for... But there is no less than wishing."
Lovers have never ceased distracting themselves with wishes and filling their cups with the wine of their palm/comfort. Among them are those who won the wish before the arrival of death. And among them are those who died with the greatest choking grief, and the beloved did not fall to him on a story: "Whoever attained a wish from his world... The days dropped the Alif from it (Muna -> Maniyya/Death)."
This last type is numerous, and the one sick with it among lovers is a large multitude: "He whose pasture of determination and worries is... The garden of wishes ceases not to be emaciated."
Yes, among them are those who spent the night robbed of sleep by the beloved's promise, far from meeting death on an appointment: He believes the beloved's saying and disbelieves it, tests him and tries him, and says: "I am still waiting for your promise, my lady... In the house, turning towards the knocking of the door. O liar whose promise is with his tongue... Who is for me with some of your lying tongue?"

book_title: Diwan al-Sababa (The Anthology of Ardent Love)
text:
Do not wonder at the shielding of my tears in the morning when they flowed... from his eyes flowed what flowed, for the sea is loyal in it. I continued to weep over the valley of Al-Aqiq until... it was said, 'That one is bleeding from his eyes.' I also said in a poem: I wept over a land where I was walking... so the Khansa [a poetess famous for weeping] resembled the rocks in my tears. You were bold, Oh my tears, but you are not always bold... Oh tears, how flowing you are, and Oh heart, how hard you are. I also said in a poem: My eye is indeed upon Al-Aqiq if... my tears do not mimic its red color since evening fell. My tears are molten gold... Alchemy has been proven true to my eyes. Do not ask what flowed of tears when... my censurer became bold against me. The night brought forth my tears upon my cheek... just as the stars come forth to the sky. I said in a poem: If my eye became lukewarm in the sea of its tears... then the mouth of the one I desire is, as is said, cold. And if my gaze untied the distinct cord of tears... then the breast of the one whom my gaze greeted is knotted [firm]. I said in a poem: You watered its land with the sea of cold tears... and sent them upon it during a time of languor. Oh gaze, if you do not aid the lover with weeping... the ropes of tears will be cut where they were thin. I said in a poem: I opposed a critic and an advisor concerning you... and obeyed an eyelid sore with tears. So work for my killing, bringing it present, for my tears... have written an explanation for my heart in blood. He poured his tears upon the slope of Mokattam... the eyes causing blood to flow forth. If your eyes witnessed his red tears... you would have vindicated the witness of his wounded heart. I also said: The eye, from the loss of sleep... complains of sorrow to him; And the cheek, from excessive weeping... Oh, what has run upon it! I said: And who will have mercy on my anguish... and send a phantom in the slumber? And regarding the tears of my eye, do not ask... about their condition, Oh what has occurred! Al-Masudi, the commentator on the Maqamat, may God Almighty have mercy on him, often recited: She said, 'I knew you to weep... blood in fear of separation; So why have you substituted it... with water after the blood?' So I said, 'That is not from me... due to solace or consolation; But my tears have turned gray [white]... from the long life of my weeping.' Another said: A woman asked, 'Why are your tears white...?' I said to her, 'Oh High One, this is what remains. Did you not know that weeping has lived a long life... so my tears turned gray just as the hair on my head turned gray? And soon, neither my tears nor my blood... will be seen, but only my anguish and burning.' Another said: And she asked, 'Why are your tears black... when they used to be white, and you are emaciated?' I said to her, 'My tears dried up from weeping... and this is the blackness of the pupil flowing out.' Another said: My tears were red on the day of their departure... but since they distanced themselves, I bleached them with burning. I plucked a rose from their cheeks with a glance... so the separation distilled rose water from my pupils. Al-Nashi Al-Akbar said: She wept for the separation, and I was startled by... the weeping of the beloved for the loss of the dwellings. It was as if the tears upon her cheek... were the remnants of dew upon a pomegranate blossom. 

Chapter Twenty-One: Promises and Wishes, and the comfort of meanings contained therein.
I say: This is a chapter we have dedicated to mentioning the wishes that are inevitable and indispensable, for there is nothing less than them: I distract my heart with wishes, perhaps... I can relieve myself of worry through wishes. I know that your union is not to be hoped for... but there is nothing less than wishing. Lovers have never ceased distracting their souls with wishes and filling their cups with the wine of its comfort. Among them are those who attained the wish before the arrival of death, and among them are those who died with the greatest lump in their throat, and the beloved did not drop a story upon him: He who obtains a wish from his world... the days drop the 'Alif' from it [turning 'umniyah' (wish) to 'maniyah' (death)]. This latter type is common, and the sick among lovers are a vast crowd: He whose pasture of determination and concerns was... the garden of wishes, never ceased to be emaciated. Yes, among them are those who spent the night robbed of sleep by the beloved's promise, far from meeting, yet having an appointment with death: He believes the beloved's word and disbelieves it... and tests him and tries him. He says: I remained waiting for your promise, my lady... in the house, turning toward the knocking at the door. Oh you whose promise is false on his tongue... who will give me part of your lying tongue?

How often he despaired of the beloved's promise, and held on from seeing his leg to the promises of 'Urqub, as was said: "And the attainment of wishes in their promises... Is but like Ash'ab hoping for the promise of 'Urqub."
Note: Their saying in the proverb "Promises of 'Urqub" is said to one who made a promise and broke it. The origin of the mentioned proverb is that 'Urqub had a brother who asked him for something. 'Urqub said to him: "When my palm tree pollinates." When it pollinated, he said: "When it becomes small green dates (Balah)." When it became Balah, he said: "When it becomes colored dates (Zaha)." When it became Zaha, he said: "When it becomes fresh ripe dates (Rutab)." When it became Rutab, he said: "When it becomes dried dates (Tamr)." When it became Tamr, he took it at night and gave his brother nothing. So it became a proverb for breaking promises, so it was said "Promises of 'Urqub."
Al-Shammakh said: "And she promised me what I do not try to benefit from... The promises of 'Urqub to his brother in Yathrib."
Ibn Hajjaj said: "I ransom one who met me just as... I met him, and the truth is not difficult. I said: O 'Urqub, you gave me hope... He said: Why do you tire yourself, O Ash'ab?"
I said from a Hijazi poem: "He threatens me with abandonment every night... I believe his union in it and disbelieve. When we arrived at the water of Madyan, he said to me: By the right of Shu'ayb, you are Ash'ab in love."
People are of two opinions regarding wishes: Among them are those who see the comfort of their heart and the venting of their distress, so they comfort the soul with them and hang on from their light to the ropes of the sun. And among them are those who say: "Hoping is not what saves..." So he sees wishes as deception and falling into conflict. Each of the two opinions has proof and a school of thought with a traveled path.
Among the best I heard in the first opinion is the saying of some of Banu al-Harith: "Wishes from Su'da are beautiful, as if... Su'da watered us with them, upon thirst, cold water. Wishes, if they inhabit truly, are the best wishes... Otherwise, we have lived by them for a time in comfort."
And the saying of the other: "And when we settled in a dwelling bedewed by moisture... Elegant, and a garden adorned with blossoms. The pleasantness of the place and its beauty created for us... A wish, so we wished, and you were the wishes."
Plato said: "Wishes are the dream of the awake and the solace of the sad." Another said: "Wishes are a comforting companion; if they do not benefit you, they have distracted you." A Bedouin was asked: "What is the most enjoyable of worldly pleasures?" He said: "Joking with the beloved, conversing with the friend, and wishes by which you cut your days."
Judge Al-Fadil said, and excelled as he wished: "I found the scent of his letters and the spirit of his nearness, so we returned to the habit, and our days returned, and we proceeded to the best, and our speech softened, and wishes returned to us. They almost did not occur, and if they occurred, they were but speech of us: 'I wish for those illuminating nights... And the effort of the lover is to wish.'"
Yaqut al-Rumi said: "By Allah, days passed with you... How sweet and pleasant they were! They passed and nothing remained for us after them... Except that we wish for them."
Sheikh Fath al-Din bin Sayyid al-Nas said: "I yearn for the Ban tree from which my abandoning one departed... Distracting myself with the nights of her union in it. An age passed and the robes of youth were new... Nothing remained of its goodness except wishing for it."
Al-Afif said: Is the scribe of construction for Al-Nasir Dawood worthy? "Were it not for promises of hopes I live by... I would have died, O people of this tribe, long ago. But the gaze of my hopes is cheerful in it... Running with the promise of wishes, loose of rein."
Ibn Khafaja said: "And a night, when I said it has parted and ended... It revealed a promise from false thought. I do not forget but that I laugh for an hour... At the mouths of wishes in the faces of demands. I thought the darknesses in it were black braids... Having the neck of hopes, white of upper chests."
Another said: "In wishes is comfort, even if she distracted us... Regarding her love with some of what will not be."
I said: "Be gentle with a lover who became, due to what he struggles with... Of his pouring tear running in its streams. Nothing remained in him but a spirit he repeats... Were it not for wishes, he would have died, O furthest of his wishes."
I also said: "O good scent that traveled from towards them at dawn... Were it not for its remedy, my heart would have perished in love. How often I distract my heart with the breeze while... I do not see a cure for the disease of my passion in air."
Ibn Zaydun said: "I will surely graze my eyes... In that fresh garden. And I will eat you with wishes... And I will drink you with the conscience."
Another said: "Distract me with a promise... And procrastinate as long as I live with it. And let me win from you... A secret talk asking for it. Perhaps time will stumble... Upon my luck and wake up."
Another said:

"And a fawn to whom I said... Do you have (interest) in drinking companionship? He said: How many a lover... Have I shed his blood in wishes?"
Abu Bakr al-Hatimi said: "I have a beloved, if it were said to me: What do you wish? I would not have transgressed him even with death. I desire to settle in every eye... To see him with the glance of all eyes."
He also said: "As for the wish of my heart, you are all of it... Would that I became some of your wishes. Your visit draws near when distance makes it far... And a concern by which I almost kiss your mouth."
Al-Husayn bin al-Dahhak said: "The full moon described the beauty of your face until... I imagined that I, while not seeing you, see you. And when the fresh narcissus breathed... I imagined it the breeze of your scent. Deceptions for wishes distracting me regarding you... With the radiance of this and the splendor of that."
Among what the proponents of the second opinion argued with: "And most acts of beautiful women are bad... And most of what you meet of wishes are liars."
Al-Khalidiyyan said: "And do not be a slave of wishes, for wishes... Are the capital of the bankrupt."
Ibn Sharaf al-Qayrawani said: "Uncircumcised (hearts/minds) wished wishes in the houses... And all the lives of the mean are wishes."
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said: "Do not grieve in the world over a hope... For its remainder is but like its past."
Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah honor his face, said: "Avoid wishes, for they remove the joy of what you have been granted and belittle the gifts you have been provided."
A man said to Ibn Sirin: "I saw as if I was swimming without water and flying without wings." He said: "You are a man who multiplies wishes."
It is told that Al-Hajjaj passed one night by a dairyman's shop. He had a jar with milk in it, and he was saying wishfully: "I will sell this milk for such and such, and buy such, then sell it and gain such and such in it. My wealth will increase and my condition will improve. I will propose to Al-Hajjaj's daughter and marry her. She will bear me a son. I will enter upon her one day and she will quarrel with me, so I will strike her with my foot like this." He kicked with his foot, broke the jar, and the milk spilled. Al-Hajjaj knocked on the door. He opened for him. He lashed him fifty times and said: "Is it not so that if you kicked my daughter like this, you would have pained me regarding her?"
Ali bin Ubaydah said: "Wishes are the signs of ignorance." Another said: "Wishes deceive you and at the realities leave you."
It happened that Al-Zaki Abd al-Rahman al-Qusi attended the gathering of Al-Malik Al-Muzaffar before he governed Hama and recited to him: "When will I see you and the one you desire while you are as... You desire, despite them, two spirits in a body? There he recited while hopes were present... Congratulations on the kingdom, the loved ones, and the homeland." Al-Malik Al-Muzaffar promised him that if he possessed Hama, he would give him a thousand dinars. When he possessed it, he recited to him: "My master, this kingdom, you have attained it... Despite creatures, from the Creator. And time is submissive to what you wished... So this is the time of the truthful promise." He signed for him a thousand dinars. He stayed with him, and travels became necessary for him, so he spent the money he gave him in them and did not acquire an increase over it. So he said: "That which they gave me as a lump sum... They have taken back little by little. Would that they had not given and not taken... And Allah is sufficient for us, and He is the best Disposer of affairs." That reached Al-Muzaffar, so he expelled him from a house he had lodged him in. He said: "Do you expel me from the break of a dilapidated house... While I have regarding you houses of good praise? For if I live, I will not lack a place to contain me... And if I die, you know the mention of whom will die." So Al-Muzaffar imprisoned him. He said: "What is my sin against you?" He said: "Your saying 'Allah is sufficient for me, and He is the best Disposer of affairs'." So he ordered him strangled. When he sensed that, he said: "You gave me the thousand out of honor and generosity, I wonder, or did you give me my blood money?" I said: The Sultan was faulted for his malice against him because of his saying "Allah is sufficient for me and He is the best Disposer of affairs" until he killed him. There is no power nor strength except in Allah the Most High, the Great. His state with him was as was said: "So I was like one wishing to see a dawn... Of the morning; when he saw it, he went blind." And the one who said: "And perhaps one from whom a youth hopes for a youth's benefit... His fear is more fitting for him than his hope. Many a one through whom you hope to repel harm... Harm will come to you from before him."
I mentioned here the saying of the other: "When the cloud (cheek-hair) appeared on his cheek... I brought glad tidings to my heart of the enduring bliss. And I said: This is a cloud raining... But therein came to me the painful punishment."
Ibn Sana' al-Mulk said from a letter: "The beloved! You are the one who shook me off his hand and rejected me from his mind. You are the one who weaned me before the union completed its term of pregnancy and weaning. You are the one who broke to me what you promised me... And made those who blamed regarding you gloat over me.

Perhaps an eye (evil eye) hit us, so it did not look... Or a slanderer said lies between us. Perhaps your admonition has praiseworthy consequences... And perhaps bodies become healthy by illnesses. Perhaps satisfaction from you—and how is its attainment?... Pleases a heart your abandonment offended. Perhaps a thirst in the soul quenches its burning... And an ember of passion in the heart extinguishes its fire. Perhaps an affection draws near to a hope... A heart confused between despair and greed. Perhaps the eye of satisfaction from the one I was tasked with... One day refutes what my enviers said. Perhaps a time that has turned away will bend back... To us, and a heart that has hardened will soften. Perhaps the tails of pardon—and pardon is wide... The harsh one drags them over the parting of the sin. Perhaps the forgetting of the heart returns... And this is a mistake; far be it from my heart to forget. Perhaps! And what does 'Perhaps' avail? It is but... The distraction of a lover and the rest of a wanderer. And there is no less than distracting oneself with 'Perhaps', and how little is its enrichment and how much is its trouble.

Chapter Twenty-Two: Satisfaction from the Beloved with the Easiest Request
I say: We established this chapter to mention the printed lover and the content admirer, who is satisfied with the beloved by looking if he is present, and pleased with him by a greeting even once in a year. He is, in satisfaction with him, with the scant little, as was said: 'Your little cannot be called little. I am satisfied from you with the easiest thing... That a beloved is satisfied with from a lover. With a greeting on the road if... The road brings us together by chance.'
Al-Ma'arri said: 'He met you in the year that passed and did not... Ask you except for a kiss in the coming (year). Indeed, the miser, if the duration extends for him... In generosity, the giving of the giver becomes easy for him.'
Jamil said: 'I turn my glance in the sky, perhaps... My glance agrees with his glance when he looks.' He also said: 'And I am satisfied from Buthayna with what... If the slanderer were certain of it, his anxieties would settle. With "No" and with "I cannot" and with wishes... And with the hoped-for hope whose hoper has failed. And with the hasty glance, and with the year passing... Its ends not meeting its beginnings.'
I said: Look at this witty poet and chaste lover; he was content from the watering places of his loved ones with a trickle, and sufficed with the glance from the gaps of curtains and nets.
Of this extracted meaning is the saying of Ibn al-Mu'tazz: 'Do I not see the star which is rising... Over her? This is beneficial for lovers. Perhaps my glance and her glance meet in the horizon... So it gathers us since there is no gatherer on earth.'
The famous standard in this chapter is the saying of a Bedouin: 'Does not the night gather Umm Amr... And us? So that is a nearness for us. Yes, and I see the crescent as she sees it... And the day rises over her as it rose over me.' Sheikh Athir al-Din Abu Hayyan used to say about the author of these two verses: 'This is the content lover.'
Another said: 'To the flying eagle (star) I look every night... For I am looking at it in the evening. Perhaps my glance and your glance meet at it... So we complain together of what the consciences hide.'
Some Bedouin said: 'And I did not attain from her her union other than that I... If she urinated, I urinated where she urinates.'
I mentioned here what is told about someone who saw a beautiful woman in a window and loved her. He stuck to standing at her door and passing under the window until he became weary, his patience decreased, and he attained despair of her. He knocked on her door. The slave girl came out to him. He gave her a bowl and said: 'Let your mistress urinate in this.' So she urinated for him in the bowl. She said to the slave girl: 'Follow him and see what he does with that.' She did not cease following him until he entered some ruins, put... in that urine, and said: 'O unlucky one, if you miss the meat, drink the broth.'
Ibn al-Jawzi narrated in the book 'Al-Adhkiya' (The Intelligent Ones) that the Hoopoe said to Solomon, peace be upon him: 'I want you to be in my hospitality.' Solomon said to him: 'Me alone?' He said to him: 'Rather, with the army on such island on such day.' So Solomon and his soldiers went there. The Hoopoe ascended to the sky, hunted a locust, strangled it, and threw it in the sea. He said: 'O Prophet of Allah, eat! For whoever missed the meat attained of the broth.' Solomon and his soldiers laughed at that for a full year. Some took this meaning and said: 'And be content, for a proverb has run... If you miss the meat, drink the broth.'

Chapter Twenty-Three: Mixing of Bodies/Forms, Mixing of Water with Wine

I say: We established this chapter to mention one who was excessive in embracing when leg wrapped around leg, so he and his beloved became like a single thing in the view of the eye, even to the cross-eyed who sees one thing as two. That is due to the excess of love whose owner's heart is not cured by union, nor do the ropes of his tears break by connection, as was said: 'And I almost, while he was my bedfellow, said to him... From the intensity of love: You have become distant, so draw near.'
Ibn al-Rumi said: 'I embrace him while the soul is still longing... For him; is there closeness after the embrace? And I kiss his mouth so my heat may vanish... But the wandering I suffer intensifies. And the amount of ardency in me was not such... That nothing but the two lips would cure it by sipping. As if my heart's thirst is not quenched... Except by seeing the two souls mix.'
Another said: 'I traveled to him while the darkness was as if it were... A victim of sleep, and the star in the horizon was a witness. Even if my soul mixed then with his soul... I would have said: Come near me, O distant one.'
Abu al-Husayn al-Tunisi said: 'Then we embraced, so you see us together... In the darkness of the night and the light of admonition. Two bodies became in love one... Like two vowel marks mixed in a book.'
Khalid the Scribe said: 'As if I embraced a basil plant... Breathing in its cold night. If you saw us in the shirt of darkness... You would have thought us in one body.'
Niftawayh the Grammarian said: 'And when we met after distance in a gathering... In which eyes of fresh narcissus flirted. I made my reliance his hugging and embracing... So he did not separate until I imagined him part of me.'
How excellent is the saying of Abu Bakr al-Irbili: 'The watcher intended to strive for our separation... At night, while he spent the night embracing (me) out of desires. I embraced him so we united, and the watcher came... When he saw one, he turned away in anger.'
Sayf al-Din al-Mashad said: 'And when the one I love visited at night... And we feared that an observer would descend upon us. We embraced to hide him, so we became... As if we were one in a writer's knot.'
Another said: 'A slanderer imagined his visit was between us at night... So he intended to strive for distance between us. So I embraced him until we united in embrace... When he came to us, he saw only one.'
Chief Judge Kamal al-Din bin al-Adim said when he heard these two verses: 'He held him with the hold of a blind man.'
Abu al-Fadl said: 'May a life that passed be watered, while time gathers us... And we resemble in embrace the shape of Tanwin (double vowel mark). So I became, when my palm hung onto your ropes... With the arrow of your abandonment you shoot (Tarmi) then intend (Tanwin - also means to make Nun sound).'
Similar to this saying in lack of safety and directing blame is the saying of Ibn Sana' al-Mulk: 'And a night we spent after my drunkenness and his drunkenness... I cast aside my pillow then pillowed him my hand. And between us, like one body from our embrace... Or like a letter in speech with Shadda (doubled).' If he had said 'like a letter in verse (Nizam)', he would not have fallen into blame, because the letter with Shadda in pronunciation is counted by prosodists as two letters, but in writing no. So according to this, what he wanted is not complete for him, even if he made his forearm for the beloved like the pillow. He has no excuse because the meter helped him and aided him in obtaining this benefit.
Some poets of 'Al-Dhakhira' said: 'We spent the night behind the veil, covered by... A cloak of dignity, and the reunion gathered. Two, from the intensity of embracing, have... Become like an individual connected by the spirit. If the rain of the sky rained on us... Wetness would not hit the ground beneath us.'
Muhammad bin 'Arus said: I met Ali bin al-Jahm in a ship while we did not know each other. We conversed and I found him sweet in conversation. In some of what he said was: 'I am the most poetic of people.' I said to him: 'With what?' He said: 'With my saying: Behold, many a night gathered us after a slumber... And brought a heart near to a tortured heart. So we spent the night together; if a bottle... Of wine were spilled between us, it would not have been drunk (soaked in).' I said to him: 'By Allah, you have done well, but I am more poetic than you.' He said: 'With what?' I said: 'With my saying: No, by the dwellings of Najd! And our night... Was restricted since our two bodies were a body between us. Slumber sought in us a place of subtle passage... One day, but neither a cheek nor an upper arm separated.' The origin of this is the saying of Bashar bin Burd, and it is of royal poetry: 'And one of shaking buttocks, slender waist... She moves with the magic of her eye and spins. If she looks, she pours upon you ardent love... And the hearts of lovers almost fly. I was alone with her; water could not pass between us... Until the morning, without me being a barrier and curtains.'
I mentioned in my saying 'that in the beginning of the chapter (is) the cross-eyed who sees one thing as two' the saying of some Maghrebis regarding a handsome one having a cross-eyed watcher: 'By my father! A fawn possessing with beneficence... An ownership whose subject is human. Dark-lidded, having a cross-eyed watcher... The thing in his perception is two equal things. Would that he left what I am seeing... And he is the one chosen in the second gazelle.'
Ibn Isra'il said in a Dubayt (couplet): '... He exaggerated in his speech with lies, whoever said: I saw his like with the eye. His like is seen only by a cross-eyed one... From the aspect that he sees the one as two.'
And the saying of Sadr al-Din bin al-Wakil: 'They say to me: Why are you fond of a cross-eyed one... Who inverts the two spouses (couplets)? I said to them: An excuse! Each eye saw the beauty of its sister's attributes... So it returned, through the length of time, looking at it askance.'

Chapter Twenty-Four: The Lover's Body becoming like a Toothpick (Khilal) and a Phantom of Imagination, and what carries that meaning regarding the slenderness of the beloved's waist and comparing the buttocks to a sand dune.
I say: We established this chapter to mention one whom emaciation led to withering, so he became like the ruin among ruins. He is, from the intensity of harm, as Sarr-Durr said: 'And how many an emaciated one among those tents... You think him among its ropes.' So his beloved in aversion is one like the Alif, and he in his thinness is like the phantom walking backward. 'And when she saw me like the stick of a toothpick... And my body as the spider weaves. She said: You die, until when... So I said: I... until I die.'
The famous standard in this chapter is the saying of Al-Mutanabbi: 'Passion wore out my body with grief on the day of distance... And abandonment separated between the eyelid and slumber. A spirit repeated in the likeness of a toothpick, if... The wind blew the robe off him, he would not be seen. Enough of emaciation for my body is that I am a man... Were it not for my addressing you, you would not see me.'
He also said: 'And if a pen were thrown in the split of his head... From illness, it would not change the handwriting of a scribe.'
He also said: 'Until when is the greed of the blamer... While there is no opinion in love for the rational? It is desired from the heart to forget you... But natures refuse the transfer. And I love, of your love... My emaciation and every emaciated youth. Even if you ceased then I did not weep for you... I would weep for my vanished love.'
Al-Mi'mar said: 'My yellowing and emaciation, both... In love, my body warns the lovers. So it is like an Alif in gold script... The darkness made me papers for it.'
I said from a poem: 'As if the mist of the horizon is incense carried by... The breeze of the East from towards the land of loved ones. As if the echo between the mountains is a lover... And nothing remained of him but a voice and a moan.'
Al-Mutanaqqil said: 'If slumber shunned me and joined a people... It has an excuse in staying behind me. Passion did not leave a figure in my body... So when slumber came to me, it did not find me.'
Ibn Lu'lu' said: 'And a phantom of a beloved kept me awake... His house was distant when he saw me. Due to my sleeplessness, he visits but I do not see him... And due to my illness, he circles but does not see me.'
Muhyi al-Din bin Abd al-Zahir said: 'O hunter with the glance, and who... Is a hunter of other than mankind. Do not wish for the bird of my heart to flee... Indeed, it is within my ribs in a cage.'
Mudar al-Maghribi said: 'Love melted him until if you imagined him... With imagination, imagination would not be able to imagine him. Were it not for moaning and anguishes moving him... The one speaking to him would not know him by sight.'
Mahasin al-Shawwa said: 'I withered and the one I desire was stingy with union... And the phantom treated me as an enemy while it was a visitor. So I resembled that which is a decrease (Naqs) for illness... Even if connection (Silah) and obstacle (Arid) contradicted it.'
Al-Arjani said: 'Were it not for her light, they would not have seen me from emaciation... Nor would they have become my adversaries for her sake. But she manifested like a shining sun... So I loomed through the light like dust particles.'
Another said: 'I had in the past a ring... My body became thin so I used it as a belt. And the illness increased in me so if I were thrust... Into the eye of a sleeper, he would not wake up.'
Abu al-Atahiya said: 'Nothing remained but the little in me... And I do not think she will leave what remained.'
Another said:

book_title: Diwan al-Sababa (The Anthology of Ardent Love)
text:
I was alone with her, the water not flowing between us... until the morning, without a doorkeeper or curtains in my way. I mentioned in my speech that in the beginning of the section on 'States'—regarding one who sees one thing as two things—the saying of a Maghrebi poet about a beautiful one who had a cross-eyed observer. By my father, a gazelle who possesses, along with benevolence... a kingly quality whose subject is human. He has brown eyelids and a cross-eyed observer... The object in his perception is two equal things. Would that he left the one I am looking at... and he can choose the second gazelle. Ibn Israel said regarding a verse... where he exaggerated in his speech with lies: Who said 'I saw the likes of him' with the eye: None sees the likes of him except the cross-eyed... since he sees the one as like two. And the saying of Sadr al-Din bin al-Wakil: They say to me, 'Why have you become enamored with a cross-eyed one... who turns [things] into pairs?' I said to them, 'An excuse: Every eye saw the beautiful attributes of its sister... so it returned, throughout time, looking at it askance.'

Chapter Twenty-Four: The Lover's Gauntness like a Toothpick, and the Phantom Image, and what carries that meaning regarding the thinness of the beloved's waist and likening the buttocks to a sand dune.
I say: This is a chapter we have constituted to mention those whom emaciation led to weathering away, becoming like a ruin among ruins. He is, from the severity of harm, as Sarr-Durr said: How many a thin one among those tents... whom you would think was one of the tent ropes. So his beloved is unique in cruelty like the letter 'Alif', while he, in his thinness, is like a phantom walking backward. And when she saw me like the stick of a toothpick... and my body as if a spider weaves it; She said, 'You are dying,' to which... I said that I... until I die. The famous banner in this chapter is the saying of Al-Mutanabbi: Passion wore out my body in sorrow on the day of separation... and abandonment separated my eyelid from slumber. A spirit wandering in something like a toothpick; if... the wind blew the garment off him, he would not be visible. It is sufficient emaciation for my body that I am a man... were it not for my speaking to you, you would not see me. He also said: And if a pen were thrown into the split of his head... from sickness, it would not change the handwriting of a scribe. He also said: Until when is the greed of the censurer... and is there no opinion for the wise regarding love? It is desired of the heart to forget you... but nature refuses the transporter. And I adore, from your love... my emaciation, and every young man is emaciated. And if you ceased to exist and I did not weep for you... I would weep for my love that ceased. Al-Mi'mar said: He left my yellowing and emaciation, both of them... in love, my body warns the lovers. As if it is an 'Alif' in gilded script... The darkness made it the thinnest of papers. I said in a poem: As if the fog of the horizon is incense traveled by... the breeze of the east wind from the direction of the land of the loved ones. As if the echo between the mountains is a person enslaved by love... and nothing remains of him but a voice and a groan. Al-Munaqqil said: If slumber shunned me and connected with others... then it has an excuse for lagging behind me; Love did not leave a person in my body... so when slumber came to me, it did not find me. Ibn Lu'lu' said: A phantom of a beloved kept me awake... whose house was distant when he saw me. So from my wakefulness, he gathers but I do not see him... and from my sickness, he circumambulates but does not see me. Muhyiddin bin Abd al-Zahir said: Oh hunter with glances, and one who... is a predator to all mankind; Do not mark the bird of my heart for flight... for it is in a cage within my ribs. Mudar al-Maghribi said: Love melted him until, if you imagined him... with the imagination, the imagination would be incapable of conceiving him. Were it not for the groaning and pangs that move him... the one speaking to him would not know him by sight. Mahasin al-Shawwa said: I wasted away, and the one I desire was stingy with union... and the phantom visited me, acting as a visitor; So I resembled that which belongs to sickness as a decrease... even if a link and an obstacle contradicted it. Al-Arjani said: Were it not for her light, they would not have seen me due to emaciation... nor would they have become my adversaries because of her. But she appeared like a shining sun... so I loomed through the light like dust motes. Another said: I had a ring in the past... then my body became thin, so I used it as a belt. And the sickness increased in me, so if I were thrust... into the eye of a sleeper, he would not wake up. Abu al-Atahiya said: Nothing remains except a little in... and I do not reckon she will leave what remains. Another said:

'I saw lovers having bodies... Longing whittled them; if they were blown upon, they would fly.'
Ibn Abd Rabbihi said: 'And when my family saw my illness... Exceed its limit, the limit of the sick. I blocked the outlets of breezes from me... Fearing that I fly with the breeze.'
Another said: 'And if a visitor approached to speak to me... His breaths played with me in the bed.'
Another said: 'The hands of emaciation tampered with him so he is like... A hidden secret in a concealing conscience. Your love emaciated me, O my destroyer... And longing increased me so I was not known. And I melted until if passion threw me... Into the pupil of the beholder, he would not blink.'
Nasir al-Din al-Faq'asi said: 'My body says to my emaciation, while... Excess of illness and depression has exceeded in me: O illness, you have done to me what was not... By Allah, worn clothes upon.'
Falling into this category is what poets described of the waist regarding slimness. Ibn Isra'il exaggerated in it where he said and spoke well: 'Alas for the slender waist! Only... His trusted speech cut the way. A waist upon which a wrist of a kiss was encircled... So it was as if my kissing it was an embrace.'
Sheikh Safi al-Din al-Hilli said: 'A handsome one whom the branch envies at its swaying... And the full moon is ashamed of at its rising. There is no deficient meaning in him except his waist... And there is nothing cold in him except his saliva.'
I said: He took it from the saying of our compatriot Muhammad bin al-Afif al-Tilimsani, and wanted to restrict it to beauty, so he fell short. He ran behind him to stumble upon the meaning, but he did not stumble upon it, rather he stumbled. The difference between them is as between bitter water and Kawthar, and the waist and the little finger. Do you not see the saying of Ibn al-Afif and the sweetness of his witty logic: 'How much his waist withdraws while it is thin... And how sweet his saliva becomes while it is cold. And how much he claims protection while these eyelids of his... With their languor make promises to lovers.'
He also said: 'I complained to that Beauty of an ardent love... Which tasked my eyelid that it never sleeps. So the sides softened for me and the waist pitied me... But the hair and the transporter of the buttocks withdrew.'
He also said: 'The playing of hair on his buttocks... Dropped my heart into the long and wide (trouble). O buttock that dragged on his waist... Gently with it! You are but heavy.'
Mentioning the buttocks, how excellent is the saying of the other: 'The full moon has a spot from his cheek... And in the fawn is a listlessness from his glance. If he walks, his buttocks pull him... As if he walks backwards.'
Sheikh Safi al-Din al-Hilli said regarding a dancing handsome one: 'He came, and in his stature is moderation... Slender, having no equal. A north wind lightened his side... And wine made his eyelid heavy. Then he bent dancing with a stature... Toward which minds bent. He roams between us with a face... In which waters of modesty roam. And the dance swayed a side of him... By which subtleness and entry became light. So his side (waist) is inside, light... And his buttock is outside, heavy.'
Ibn Rashiq said: 'I carry my weights on his buttocks... And hold the waist lest it gets lost.'
Sheikh Jamal al-Din bin Nubata said: 'I asked the dune (Naqa) and the Ban tree resembling to my sight... Buttocks or sides of one whose repulsion was long. The gloomy sand said: I am not its load... And the Ban branch said: I am not its size.'

Chapter Twenty-Five: Mention of what Loved Ones endure of Difficult Matters, and other things they suffer of bearing hardships and the pain of separation.
Like his saying: 'People before me complained of the pain of separation... And distance frightened the living and the dead. But the like of what my ribs enclosed... I have not heard nor seen.'
I say: We established this chapter to mention what the lover measures of riding dangers in seeking desires. He ceases not to be busy with his state, turning under his loads, enduring in seeking the beloved terrors heavier than mountains, and being generous in exchange for a slight glance from him with soul and wealth.
Al-Tughra'i said: 'And whoever seeks loved ones is more generous... With the sacrifice of the soul than Ka'b bin Mamah. And whoever seeks spoils does not fear him who... Drew his sword before his demand.'
He also said: 'I do not hate the wide stab followed... By a volley from the arrows of wide eyes. Nor do I fear the white blades aiding me... With a glance from the gaps of curtains and nets.'

Imam Muhammad bin Dawood al-Zahiri said: 'I carried mountains of love regarding you, while I am... Unable to carry the shirt and weak. Love is not from beauty nor from generosity... But it is something with which the soul is tasked.'
This last verse is like the saying of the other: 'How much beauty is in people, but... Upon you, for my misery, my choice fell.' This lover was fair for admitting that there are those more beautiful than his beloved, but the dominance of desire and the inclination of the soul dropped him into his love.
Among the best I heard regarding seeking desires and riding dangers is the saying of Ibn Khafaja: 'I traversed before the tribe every desert... In which the vulture of the sky circles over a nest. And I waded the darkness of the night, black as coal... And stepped on the lion's den looking from an ember. And I came to the dwellings of the tribe while the night lowered its head... The robe of the horizon embroidered with bright stars. I look in it at the cold of iron, and perhaps... I stumbled on the tips of the straightened brown spears. I did not meet the spears over armor... But I said: A branch that shaded over a river. Nor did I see the blaze on a sorrel horse... But I said: Bubbles circling on wine. So I walked while the heart of the lightning throbbed in jealousy... There, and the eye of the star looked from there askance.'
I said: Look at these verses which were poured into a wondrous mold and strange style. While its owner describes the blackness of the night when horses inclined on him every inclination, and while he fights lions, behold he sighs over breasts. And while he sets up the statures of beauties in the place of spears, behold he says to their cheeks: 'Whoever turned away from their fires... Then I am Ibn Qays (Majnun), no departure.' He excelled in metaphor in them, and traveled with their high organization and number the seven planets. So his organization is in the stars, and the tear of the flame-wearer in his state is like meteors. Of his poetry in this pattern and his pearl entering this string is his saying also: 'And a night I knocked on the Malikiyyah under it... I renew, by the rule of youth, a visit. So I mixed the tips of spears with stars... And trod with the halos of full moons, dwellings.'
He also said: 'A phantom of his distracts me with a promise of a sip... Creating desire with procrastination and softness. I split for it a deep sea of sharp swords... Upon which are bubbles of spearheads of ash wood.'
Ibn Bassam said: 'I endured the hateful I hear... From a group regarding you; were it not for you, they would not have spoken. And regarding you, I flattered a people who have no morals... Were it not for you, I would not know they were created.'
Another said: 'Our souls become easy to us in (seeking) heights... And whoever seeks highness, the dowry does not fatigue him.'
Another said: 'He dives in the sea who seeks pearls... And whoever seeks highness stays up nights. You desire glory then sleep at night... You have made your soul hope for the impossible.'
Al-Mutanabbi said: 'You want to attain heights cheaply... And the honey is not without the sting of bees.'

Chapter Twenty-Six: The Goodness of Mentioning the Beloved

I say: We established this chapter to mention one who assaulted and roamed, and remembered his beloved when blades broke, in every position where standing is defeat and death is booty. Especially if bows were set up in the place of eyebrows, the helmet was confused with the breasts of buxom girls, spears resembled statures, and swords (resembled) the redness of cheeks. There, he places his indicated beloved before his eyes, and the striking of the sword does not distract him from him, nor does making him a target for arrows.
