Regarding this is the story of Al-Tughra'i, in which he exceeded Antara al-Absi and increased in loyalty to the condition of love over every Jinn and human. It is what more than one historian narrated, of those who knew and reported and undertook and led. That is that Mu'ayyad al-Din Fakhr al-Kuttab Abu Ismail al-Husayn al-Asbahani the Creator, known as Al-Tughra'i, the scribe of construction for King Mas'ud. Between his brother Sultan Mahmud near Hamadan and Rayy, King Mas'ud was defeated. Al-Tughra'i was the first to be taken. When the Sultan, the brother of his master, resolved to kill him after things were said to him about him, among them that he was a heretic and that he loved such-and-such Mamluk of the Sultan's Mamluks whom the Sultan loved and inclined towards. So they incited him against him until he ordered his killing, and that he be tied to a tree and a group stand facing him to shoot him with arrows. That was done. He positioned a person behind the tree without Al-Tughra'i sensing him, and ordered him to listen to what he said. He said to the archers: 'Do not shoot him until I signal you.' So they stood, arrows in their hands notched to shoot him. Some of the people of literature who told me this story informed me that the first who notched the arrow at him was the Mamluk he was enslaved by loving. Al-Tughra'i recited in that state saying: 'And I say to the one aiming his arrow... Towards me, while the tips of death are pointed. And death is in the glances of his dark-eyed gaze... Before me, and my heart before it is cut to pieces. By Allah, search my heart, do you see... In it a place for other than the love of loved ones? Welcome to it (death) if there were not within its fold... The covenant of the beloved and his entrusted secret.' The Sultan ordered his release and the untying of his bonds when he saw the steadfastness of his heart and the magic of his expression. This lover exceeded those before him characterized by this description, like Ibn Ata al-Sindi where he says: 'I remembered you while the spear walked between us... And the straightened brown spears had drunk from me. By Allah, I do not know, and I am truthful... Is it a malady that afflicted me from your imagination or magic?'
Antara said: 'I remembered you while spears were drinking... From me, and the white Indian swords were dripping with my blood. So I wished to kiss the swords... Because they shone like the lightning of your smiling mouth.'
How tender is the saying of Al-Tughra'i also: 'I remember you when thirst has reached... Me, so I choke on the cold fresh water. And I say: Would that I saw my loved ones... Before death, even by one day.'
Another said: 'I remembered Salma while the heat of battle... Was like my heart the hour I left her. So I likened the brown spears to her stature... When they inclined towards me, so I embraced them.'
Ibn Tamim said: 'Lo, who will inform the beloved that I... Stood while the flame around me was slight. And that I roamed the army of enemies... With my spear while he roamed in my thought.'
He also said: 'And I remembered you while the sharp swords were shining... Around us and the Samhari spears were pointed. Despite fighting the enemy, there is in the vitals... A longing for you which the ribs are too narrow for. From youth and onwards, my trait is... Preserving affection, so how can I return from it?'
Al-Sharif al-Bayadi said: 'And I remembered you while the doctor was frowning... And the probe was immersed in the wound. The skin of my face, his iron had cut it... And his right hand was cautious over a left. So you distracted me from what I encountered, although... The regions narrow from it despite their width.'
Ibn Rashiq said: 'And I remembered you in the ship while death... Was crashing, anticipated waves. The atmosphere pouring and winds storming... And the night black of braids, dark. On the coasts for the enemies was an army... Waiting for a raid and commotion. A clamor rose for the companions of the ship... While I and your memory were in the sweetest secret conversation.'
Abu al-Thana Mahmud said: 'And I remembered you while swords were shining... And death watched under the fortress of the watchtower. Beauty in the twilight of armor, you think it... A beauty strutting in a gilded robe. Death plays with souls while my mind... Amuses itself with the goodness of your sweet memory.'
Safi al-Din al-Hilli said:

'And I remembered you while the dust was as if it were... The procrastination of the rich and the bad living of the poor. And death was between one thrown on stones... Among us, and one helmeted in a helmet. I thought I was in a shining morning... By the light of your face, or a moonlit evening. The land of struggle was perfumed as if... The land of combat was opened for us with ambergris.'
He also said: 'I remembered you while skulls were falling... Under the hooves and palms were flying. Heads in the horizon of the dust hovered... As if they were eagles above eagles. So a euphoria from the goodness of your memory accustomed me... And cheerfulness and joy appeared on me. So I thought I was in the gatherings of my pleasure... While wine was presented and cups circulated.'
Another said: And he has a story like the story of Al-Tughra'i mentioned previously in 'Manazil al-Ahbab': 'And I remembered you while spears were seizing me... Before the Imam while my forearm was shackled. And I remembered you, by the One whom I am His slave... While the sword was drawn above my forelock.'
Abu Talib al-Raffa' said: 'And I remembered you while the darkness was like... The day of separation and the heart of one who did not love.' People have discussed this verse.
Sheikh Athir al-Din Abu Hayyan said: 'And I remembered you while the vast sea, its waves... Transgressed, and mankind from it was on a journey. In a night that lowered the curtain of its darkness... And its star sank from the eyes of humans. And the ship in the middle of waves, you think it... An eye that has closed an eyelid upon an eyelid. The soul, out of sadness, went having arrived at... My chest (Sadr - also means return from water), so oh for a generic arrival (Wird) without a return (Sadr). This, while your figure does not detach from my mind... And in my heart and in my hearing and in my sight.'
I said in the Ramal meter on the road from Egypt to Sham from a Maqama: 'And I remembered you at Raml (sand), its fright... Is in the heart of every easterner and westerner. While the sons of Bayada were like locusts around us... With their blackness they blocked the wide ropes. And the sharp swords cut the heads of every armored one... From the hand of a bold one disciplined in wars. The tips of spears shine in the darkness... Like the flash of lightning in the darkness flaming. And upon the lances every vulture falling... Tears the skin of the lion with a claw. Thunder for the spears is a crashing thunder... And the sea roars like the conquering lion. The land is a sea of blood and the sea is land (beneficent)... With the Franks and every mangy dog. On the coasts is a blind raid, there is not... therein for one hoping safety any escape. And I, with the strings of bows, am as if I... Am singing in it of Al-Rabab and Zaynab. And I say: Would that my loved ones knew what... I am in of amusement and pleasant life.'
Majnun Laila said: 'I remembered you while the pilgrims had a clamor... In Mecca, and hearts had a throbbing. I said, while we were in a Sacred Land... In it hearts became sincere to Allah: I repent to You, O Merciful, from what... I committed, for sins have multiplied. As for the love of Laila and my leaving... Her visit, indeed I do not repent.' People have comments on this last verse.
It is told regarding Laila al-Akhayliyyah that she passed with her husband by the grave of Tawba bin al-Humayr. He said to her: 'This is the grave of the liar who said: "If Laila al-Akhayliyyah greeted... Me while rocks and slabs were upon me. I would have greeted with the greeting of cheerfulness or... An owl crying from the side of the grave would shriek to her."' She said: 'Leave him.' He said: 'I swear upon you, you must approach it and greet him.' She refused, but he repeated it to her. When she advanced to the grave and said: 'Peace be upon you, O Tawba,' a bird flew from the side of the grave that was there and shrieked. Laila's camel shied from it, so she fell from its top, broke her neck, and died instantly. She was buried next to Tawba. This is among the wonders, because he fulfilled for her what he committed to after death.
The other reached (a limit) where he said: 'If my head were cut with a sword for her affection... My head would pass falling quickly towards her. If my body rotted under the layers of soil... I would rot while my heart is not forgetting you. If Allah seizes my soul, your mention becomes... A soul I live by as long as I remain among people.'
Another said: 'And I remembered you while the darkness frowned... And I was sitting in the houses, my loneliness. The atmosphere whistles from my sitting in the air... There is no friend in it to be my obstinate one. Bugs and mosquitoes around me are an army... Twisted against a drinking companion, my ugly one.

And the mouse plays in the corners constantly... And jumps like Al-Qa'qa' over my turban. And the spider weaves the suit of a tent... Hunting a fly passing my window. The food is bread like my head, dry... And the drink is bitter from an intruder, my stupidity. Hearing my tunes is the hum of a mosquito... And the squeak of a cockroach and the whistle of a little owl. So I wished to embrace the little mouse whenever... It jumped, because you are like it in lightness. And I envied the hands of the spider for their resemblance... To fingers you have, their resemblance in thinness. And I was delighted by the voice of the cockroaches, a melody... Since they resembled the melodies of my beloved's voice. So I wept out of longing since you are not with me... Enjoying my luxury in my room.'

Chapter Twenty-Seven: A Small Portion of Excellent Stanzas and Elegant Ghazal (Erotic Poetry), containing roses of cheeks and pomegranates of breasts and other things.
I say: We established this chapter to mention a small portion of Ghazal, Nasib, and the beauties of Tashbib (erotic prologue), which delights its hearing and is taken for the rising of the ascendant of beauty. Like the saying of our compatriot, the witty poet Muhammad bin al-Afif: 'Does a rising one aid me, O rising of the full moon... While from my misery a line is descending on your cheeks? Yes, it reached the limit in harshness, prolonging... And at the limit, the one prolonging falls short. I was not mad in love before was seen... For my heart from your temple curls a rational one in captivity. Were it not for a spearhead from your glances, killing... I would not have known that your glance is languid. And why should passion not be valid regarding you while a viewer... Facing a copy of beauty from your light? Even if Qays (Majnun) were describing a cheek of yours... A plant in it would disable him (pun on Baqil/greenery and Baqil/inarticulate).'
Yes, this chapter is one of the widest of these chapters in scope, boldest in running - no - and best in address and sweetest in origin. In it, the fat of poetry is distinguished from its lean, and its new from its worn out. Only that one excels in it, and only one of much knowledge and "what makes you know" perceives it. It was previously mentioned that the most flirtatious verse Arabs said is Bashar's saying: 'I, by Allah, desire the magic of your two eyes... And fear the death-grounds of lovers.'
Muhammad bin al-Afif said, and excelled as he wished: 'And eyes that sickened my body... And kindled for my heart the burning of anxiety. And cheeks like gardens, shining... The days of their roses have no decline. I was not of its gardens, I know... Allah, and I am roasting in its ember today.'
He also said: 'He resembles the gazelle in glance and turn... Who saw him coming and was not tempted? The best of Allah's creation in utterance or mouth... If he is not the most worthy of beauty, then who? In his mouth and cheek and form are... Water, greenery, and the beautiful face.'
These verses have a story that happened to Ibn Taqi who was killed in Cairo.
He also said: 'Whenever I intended untying the banner (band), his sides said... Our sanctuary is not lawful (yuhall - to be untied/lawful). If wine settled (hallat) in his cheek... Its cycle (dawrah) and descent (nuzul) are seen for his cheek-hair.'
He also said: 'His face appeared from above his brown stature... While he loomed from black braids in darkness. So I said: Wonder! How did the darkness not go... When the sun of the day rose on a spear?'
He also said: 'Sweeter than honey is the one I loved, and how often... Bitternesses in love were charmed by him. How can his saliva not be found pleasant... While his mouth is sugar (Sukkar), years (Sininat - pun on teeth/years)?'
Another said: 'A handsome one said: Describe me... You are eloquent in speech. I said a saying in brevity... Everything in you is handsome (Maliḥ).'
Ibrahim al-Mi'mar said: 'A handsome one said: My beauty... Increased in joy. How many meanings did my eyelid contain... I said: A thousand and fractions.'
He also said: 'I judged in the law of love my killer... And I have blood shed (Tall - also dew) on his cheek. The judge accused a glance of his... Verifying the sedition from him. And he inclined to the truth (Haqq), so when he saw... The stature of my adversary, he inclined with his stature.'
Khatib Samhud said: 'He whom I loved said to me: Compare my stature... Since it shook with beauty, coquetry. I said: A branch on a pouring sand dune... The hand of the breeze shook it, so it leaned.'
Al-Siraj Al-Warraq said: 'I said to the slender one who shamed... The little branch: The speech of the slanderers is not fitting for you.

He said: The speech of slanderers is a gain to me... I said: I fear, O branch, that they will incline you.'
Another said: 'The slender of sides said to me: Describe my... Unjust treatment. I said: O graceful of stature, yours is a stature. Were it not for the predators of your glance... The doves would have sung on it.'
Al-Nur Al-Is'irdi said: 'We are content with wine, water, greenery... And the slender one, graceful of stature. And we left the positions of people out of asceticism... So why do they harm us with speech?'
Ibn Khafaja said: 'And a slender one, folding the vitals... Like the branch, he struts if he struts. So if he gazes, and if he sings... And if he gives drink, and if he unveils. He shamed the gazelle and the dove... And the cloud and the moon.'
Kuthayyir Azza said: 'Allah knows, if I wanted an increase... In Azza, I would not find an increase. The monks of Madyan and those I knew... Weeping out of fear of punishment, sitting. If they heard as I heard her speech... They would fall down to Azza bowing and prostrating.'
He also said from verses, and it is the best said regarding good speech, and it has a story Al-Mubarrad recounted in 'Al-Kamil': 'Of the shy white women, her sitter wishes... Whenever a story ended, that she would repeat it.'
Ibn al-Rumi said: 'And her speech is the lawful magic, were it not that... It committed the killing of the guarded Muslim. If it is long, it is not boring, and if she summarized... The spoken-to wished she had not summarized.'
Ibn Hamdis said: 'Speech from her is not tired of when repeated... Like inhaling air, it is not tired of.'
Ibn Abi al-Hadid said: 'By Allah, put your feet on my eye sockets... For I am content regarding union with that. And prolong conversing with me, for my ears... Desire your speech just as I desire you.'
Another said: 'And a handsome one to whom I said: What is the name... My beloved? He said: Malik (Owner/King). I said: Describe to me your glowing face... And describe the softness of your moderation. He said: Like the full moon and like the branch... And what resembles that.'
Al-Atawi said: 'Possessor of two soft cheeks, stingy... With what is in them of apples. And teeth and saliva like a pool... Of wine and a garden of chamomiles.'
Imru' al-Qais said: 'O my two friends, pass by Umm Jundub with me... We fulfill the needs of the tormented heart. Did you not see me, whenever I came knocking... I found goodness (perfume) in her even if she did not wear perfume.'
Al-Numayri said and excelled in description: 'And a white, lazy, buxom virgin... Her embracing is delicious to the one of the full moon night. As if the flash of lightning is between me and her... When her smiling comes from some of the houses.'
Ibn Abi Rabi'a said: 'A young girl, cold of summer when... The heat of summer becomes critical in Najd. Hot of winter, a quilt for the youth... Under a night when the cold covers him.'
Al-Mutanabbi said: 'She loosened three braids of her hair... In a night, so she showed me four nights. And she faced the moon of the sky with her face... So she showed me two moons at a time together.'
Ibn al-Mustawfi al-Irbili said: 'She saw the moon of the sky, so she reminded me of... The nights of her union at Al-Raqmatayn. Both of us are looking at a moon, but... I saw with her eye and she saw with my eye.'
I say: People have discussion on it and crowding on understanding it, to the point that some wrote a book on it.
Another said: 'By my spirit and body, that cheek-hair which... Became, its musk flowing over the temples. Her cheek knew that I am going mad from love... So it showed me chains before madness.'
Sa'd al-Din Muhammad bin Arabi said: 'When his two cheek-hairs appeared in a pattern... It was said: Darkness mixed with light. And it was said: Ants fell upon ivory... And a group said: It is the Lam only.'
Another said: 'I saw the crescent on the face of one... I saw the crescent on his face.'
Another said: 'She appeared, so a mirror of beauty polished by beauty... Met my gaze from her face. I weep, so I look at my tears on her cheek... Running, so I think she is weeping for me.'
Ibn Qalaqis said: 'Above your cheeks is a proof... That your breasts are fruits. The pomegranate did not hide except... The pomegranate blossom appeared.'
Al-Khabbazrazi said: 'I saw the crescent and the face of the beloved... So they were two crescents upon looking. So I did not know, out of my confusion between them... The crescent of darkness from the crescent of humans.

Were it not for the rosiness in the cheeks... And what startled me of the blackness of hair. I would have thought the crescent the beloved... And thought the beloved the moon.'
Muhammad al-Salami said: 'Marvels of beauty are dispersed in him... And the eyes of people are agreed upon him. The arrows of his glances are notched... So everyone who sought his glance, he sipped him. Beauty wrote above his cheek... This is a handsome one, by the truth of Him who created him.'
Ibn Rashiq said: 'Moderate of stature and size... Rosy of cheek and cheek. Say to the one whose beauty amazes him... Read upon him Surat Al-Hamd.'
He also said: 'I complained of love to my oppressor... So he said to me mockingly: What is it? I said: A constant passion. He said to me... Read upon it: Say, He is Allah (Surat Al-Ikhlas).'
Sheikh al-Shuyukh in Hama said: 'I asked him for a drink of his saliva... To cure with it a heat in my liver. He said: I fear, O intensely thirsty one... That you follow the drink with the jar (Jarra - pun on dragging/sin/jar).'
Yahya al-Khabbaz said: 'I asked him for a kiss. He said to me... Beware of coveting nearness. The kiss (Baws) is a scout (Shawish), and I have feared... That the scout be followed by the heart (Qalb - pun on core/army center).'
Ibn Asad said: 'Is it saliva (Riq) that your mouth revealed or nectar (Rahiq)?... I sipped, for I am not sobering from my drunkenness. And wine has names, but... I was ignorant that among the names is Riq (Saliva).'
Al-Siraj Al-Warraq said: 'He who compared my saliva... To fresh sweet water erred. My saliva is but honey... I said: That is sweeter in your mouth.'
Another said: 'A fawn, you see your face in his face... And drink wine from his mouth.'
Another said: 'They were not fair when they nicknamed (it) drinks... After it became an eater of my heart.'
I said: 'O friend, my drunkenness is from the love of a slender one... His stature is like the branch if it sways. A cupbearer, whenever his cup appears to me... His mustache reminds me of the myrtle.'
I also said: 'A girl, when she visited me at night... I saw the sun at night in the middle of my house. The rose of her cheeks did not appear except... It burned its lovers with pomegranate blossoms (Julnar - implies fire). Describe to me her hair as night and long... And say regarding the waist a saying with brevity (Ikhtisar - pun on shortness/waist). Her lips circulate for us a wine... Close in era to a circulating cup.'
And from it: 'I lacked you, O my blamer regarding him, tell me... If the cheek-hair appears, what is my excuse? As if you did not feel that my love... Became with his cheek-hair good of emblem (Shi'ar - pun on hair). I became corresponding regarding him in a script... Close in shape to the dust pen (fine script). He gave me drink from his kiss a potion... Pure, not soiled by pressing. And followed his union with abandonment, so my heart... Is on the verge of abandonment, crumbling. Whenever his desire leads me one day... I walked while the drops of my tears were like the train (Qitar). Does my time make me covet a life of ease... While dragging tears in it over the neighbor (Jiwar - pun on running/neighbor)?'
I also said from a poem praising our Master Sultan Hasan: 'Congratulations and joy followed in succession... And a bringer of glad tidings announced your arrival to us. And at the Citadel of the Mountain there was expansion... And joys and loved ones and presence. Towers of the horizon, in it is a single full moon... And full moons agreed with its towers in it. Gazing with glances in its darkness... So languor did not sleep nor slacken.'
And from it: 'I am jealous of the breeze with her whenever... Its palm shakes the curtains in it. If she spreads her braids, she shows... To the dead of love in the world a resurrection. She has a mouth that guards pearls... A guard spends the night over it out of modesty. And a difference between the light of morning when... It appears and between him is a big difference.'

Chapter Twenty-Eight: Mention of a small portion of the news of Excellent Singers among men and secluded women (slave girls), and what carries that meaning regarding their Mawwals and describing their instruments.

I say: We established this chapter to mention one who rested from trouble by listening to singing, from every lover who mentions youth in poetry and sings with the Rebab. He plays the Oud and combines, from the masculine and feminine, between a thing and its opposite. Nothing inflames him but his musical instruments. Especially if he is, in singing, among those who know correctness, establish syntax, saturate melodies, balance meters, hit the genres of rhythm, give the note its right of saturation, steal the places of beats, fulfill what resembles them of strikes, excel in stealing (breaths/notes), fill breaths, and other things known to the masters of this affair of weights, among those who combined in that beauty and benevolence, as was said: 'She did not sing except worry was relieved... From my heart and sorrows took off. Singers are preferred in goodness and beauty... Just as seeing is preferred over hearing.'
People in singing are all slaves of Ma'bad and Ishaq al-Mawsili, who are the most naturally gifted of the ancients in singing according to what more than one historian narrated. Regarding Ma'bad, Habib (Abu Tammam) says: 'The beautiful descriptions of singers are many... But the canes of precedence are only for Ma'bad.' Al-Buhturi said describing the neighing of a horse: 'Trilling in neighing, in his tones were... The tones of Ma'bad in the first neigh.' This Ma'bad was devoted to the Barmakids and died in the days of Al-Rashid. His news is too famous to be mentioned; the author of Al-Aghani and others mentioned it.
As for Ishaq al-Mawsili, he was of the people of knowledge, literature, narration, and precedence in poetry. His virtues are too famous to be described. He is the one who corrected the genres of singing and distinguished its methods with a distinction no one before him or after him was capable of, in terms of scrutinizing the courses and distinguishing the categories which they made one category, while they are in themselves so, but they separate for an alert one like him. Of his words: 'The limits of singing are four: Note, Composition, Rhythm, and Division.' He had asked Al-Ma'mun that his entry be with the people of knowledge and literature, not with singers, and if he wanted him for singing, he would call him. He granted him that. Al-Wathiq said: 'Ishaq never sang to me except I thought my kingdom was increased. Indeed, Ishaq is a favor among the favors of the King which no one has been lucky to have the like of. If life and vigor could be bought, I would buy them for him with half my kingdom.'
He sat with Ibrahim bin Mus'ab to drink. The boys gave drink to those present. An ugly-faced boy came with a cup to Ishaq, but he did not take from him. Ibrahim said to him: 'Will you not drink?' He said: 'Your drinking companion has become (desiring) cups chained... From the cool wine, and I follow them with cups. From the hand of a fawn, beautiful of coquetry, whose saliva... After sleep is like musk in struggle. Do not drink wine except from the hands of our Lord (Idol/Beloved)... Kissing his palm is more desirable than the wine.' So he called for a maidservant of perfect beauty in the guise of a boy, wearing tunics and a belt. She gave him drink until he was drunk, then he ordered her sent to him with everything with her to his house.
Among what Ishaq composed, and it has a witty story: 'Tell me who turned away blaming... And distanced his side from you. You have attained what you wanted... Even if you were playing. And confess what you claimed... Even if you were lying.' I have left the story of these verses fearing elongation. This amount is sufficient regarding the news of Ishaq in this place.
Abu al-Faraj narrated that a slave girl of utmost beauty was gifted to Al-Rashid. He secluded himself with her in his palace one day and drank in the morning. Those of his slave girls present for singing and service exceeded two thousand, in the best attire of clothes and jewels. The news reached Umm Ja'far (Zubaydah), and that was great upon her (distressed her). She sent to 'Ulayya, Al-Rashid's sister, complaining to her. 'Ulayya sent to her: 'Let this not anger you. By Allah, I will return him to you. I have resolved to compose poetry and craft a melody for it and cast it to my slave girls. So send to me every slave girl you have and dress them in types of clothes and jewels so I can teach them the voice (song) with my slave girls.' Umm Ja'far did what 'Ulayya ordered her. When Al-Rashid prayed Asr, he did not realize until 'Ulayya had come out to him from a palace, and with her were more than two thousand slave girls wearing strange clothes, and all of them in one tune singing these two verses: 'Separated from me, while... My heart is not separated from him. O my cutter, tell me to whom... Did you intend to connect after me?'

He said: So Al-Rashid was delighted and stood on his feet until he met Umm Ja'far, and 'Ulayya was with him, and he was in utmost joy. He said: 'I have never seen joy like today.' He said to Masrur the servant: 'Do not leave any money in the treasury except that you scatter it.' The amount of what he scattered that day was six thousand thousand (six million) dirhams. The like of that has never been heard of.
It is told regarding Judge Abu Abdullah Muhammad bin Isa that he went out to attend a funeral. A man from his brothers had a house near a graveyard, so he invited him to turn to it. He went down and food was brought to him. A slave girl sang: 'The cups became pleasant by the goodness of your gums... And the apples boasted of the redness of your cheek. And if the spring's spirits breathed... Souls grew by the scent of your breeze. And if darknesses let down their gloom... Then the light of your face in the dark is a lamp.' The Judge wrote it on the back of his hand out of delight with it, then left. His narrator said: I saw him saying Takbir over the funeral while these verses were on the back of his hand.
How excellent is the saying of Ibn Tamim regarding a female oud player: 'And a young woman who tamed the Oud until... It became, after recalcitrance, submissive. It feared the rubbing of its ear when it disobeyed her... For this reason, it says as she says.'
Another said: 'May Allah water a land that grew your wood (Oud) from which... Branches thrived and planting places were good. Birds sang on it while the wood was green... And soft maidens sang on it while the wood was dry. So there ceases not to be upon it or by it a delight... Stirred by the two mutes: the bird and the string.'
Ibn Hajjaj said: 'This, and one doing good with the Oud, her lover... Is pleased with that perfume in doing good. When she bent and sang behind her stature... A branch upon which, before dawn, is a blackbird.'
Another said: 'And a slave girl, if she sang you a voice... You have no escape from parting with clemency. As if her left hand on the Oud is lightning... And her right hand when she strikes it is thunder.'
Another said: 'She pointed with slender tips as if they were... Tubes of pearls capped with carnelian. And she circled on the strings probing as if they were... The fingertips of a doctor on the probe of veins.'
Al-Nur Al-Is'irdi said regarding a female harpist (Jankiyyah): 'The harp (Jank) of the daughter of Sha'ban, when she makes it speak... Becomes mocking of the types of melodies of mankind. No wonder if it hunts the hearts of men for her... Do you not see it resembling the claw of the hawk?'
Al-Salah al-Irbili said and excelled as he wished: 'The harp (Jank) is a boat of intellect in its shape... And the neck is the knocking, to it the strings are ropes. It runs with the wind of longing in seas of desire... Heading for a coast of union in which are loved ones.'
Ibn Daniyal said regarding a female tambourine player (Daffiyyah): 'Possessor of the stature which a branch of a dune shakes... If a bird passed over it one day, it would chirp. She shows on the tambourine her wrist like the palm heart... To tap it with fingertips resembling the Balaj (brightness). Her singing mixes with the saliva of the wind... So it does not dot except every one who sweated.'
Ibn Adim said regarding a female singer: 'By Allah, if peoples were fair to themselves... They would give you what they hoarded in them and what they preserved. You are not, when you sing in their gatherings... Anything but the breeze of the east, and the people are branches.'
I said: 'And a songstress perfect in meanings... With kindness upon which there is no increase. If she delighted us with the second strings... She bent between the pomegranates of breasts. The brown spears are jealous of her when she appears... Like the branch of the Ban tree in green robes. With fingertips red from henna... And glances black like Indian swords. Her side-locks are of basil, fresh... The anemone of the cheeks fraternizes with them.'
Another said: 'By my father! Songs of a singer... Whom souls always accept. He sings, so we gaze with cups... At him and dance with heads.'
Another said: 'And a piper sends in his piping... Joys to the hearts of people. As if Israfil in his flute (Nay)... Is blowing souls into the dead.'
Another said regarding a flute player (Mushabbib): 'And a singer, we have seen in his fingertips... A flute (Shabbaba) worthy of the joy of the soul. As if he is a lover whose beloved arrived... So he embraced her with his hands then kissed her.'
Ibn Qarnas said regarding a handsome flute player: 'A flute player (Mushabbib), with his harshness went to kill us... Then he rectified us with blowing sometimes. I loved his erotic poetry (Tashbib) before seeing him... And the ear loves before the eye sometimes.'
I said: 'May Allah guard the masters of the reed (Yara' - flute), for they... Removed my excuse regarding them with Udhri love. Their connectors (flutes/fingers), from their blowing every hour... Brought us love from where I know and do not know.'
I also said riddling about a flute (Shabbaba): 'And a mute one, if she spoke we saw... The contradiction of her deed, a strange matter. Veiled, and she has no wrapper... She comes to us and did not fear the watcher. A girl, if my companions were alone with her... You would see they have a share in her with me. Every lover disputes with me over her love... Even if she does not resemble the nurtured fawn. How many a lover she exposed among us... And how often she gathered a beloved in her session. She renews for me, if she speaks, a joy... That returns my worn-out time new. Softer than the moist breeze in voice... And faster among mankind than it in blowing. She flirts always with her eyes with whoever... Exchanges erotic poetry and love poetry with her. So leave blaming me if I wandered in love with her... And recited to me of the strange poetry. And sing erotically for me with her always and say to me... Types of people are lovers of types. The most treacherous of them is a lover possessing boredom... And the most excused of them is the most resembling a beloved.'
Al-Musais the Tailor said satirizing an Oud player: 'And when he sat cross-legged, he did not sit cross-legged after it... And began moving his Oud sluggishly. As if all the rats of the city... Are in his Oud nibbling dry bread.'
Another said: 'Abu al-Fadl sang, so we said to him... Glory be to Him who emptied him of Fadl (virtue/talent). His singing is a Hadd (punishment) upon his drinking... So drink, for you are today lawful (to kill/punish).'
The most eloquent said in dispraising the singer is the saying of Kushajim: 'And a singer, cold of tone... Impaired of hands. No one saw him in... The house of a people twice.'
Another said: 'And a cold singer... Took pleasures away from us. We asked him for silence... But he refused to be silent for us. So we cursed him, and he sang... So the pimp took revenge on us.'
Another said: 'A singer, the badness of her words... Kills joy and revives distress. Ugly of face, gap-toothed... Neither for marriage nor for music.'
Another said: 'And many a female piper, her piping stirs... The wind of bellies, so would that she did not pipe. I compared her fingertips on her beats... And her ugly, hideous, bad-breathed mouth. To beetles that intended a corpse and went... Striving towards it on a cucumber of Shanbar.' This is like their saying in the proverb: 'He saw the carrier and the carried and the house of agency.'
Another said: 'She is in the state of viewing... Beetles crawling on a snake.'
How excellent is the saying of Al-Wajih Al-Darari regarding one who sings with the Rebab and unites loved ones: 'Do not send anyone but the tortured Ja'far... For the Sheikh in all matters is polite (Muhadhdhab). Sometimes he sings with the Rebab, and at times... Al-Rabab and Zaynab come at his hand.'

Chapter Twenty-Nine: Mention of those afflicted in this time with the love of women and boys.
I say: We established this chapter to mention the lovers of this time of ours, and they are what you know by their marks. Among them are those characterized by fairness and followed the path of the predecessors in chastity. This type, as it appears, is rarer than red sulfur; I have not seen him nor seen one who saw him. Even if I found his name, where is his named entity? 'So testify to the truth of my speech... Or no, belie me with one.' Far from it! Rather, the utmost of the people of this age is that one of them falls in love in the morning, unites at noon, and forgets in the afternoon. Regarding this is the story of some scholars of Medina as recounted by Amr bin Shaybah. He said: A man would love a young woman, so he would circulate around her house for a year, rejoicing if he saw one who saw her. If he attained her in a gathering, they complained to each other and recited poems. Today, he signals to her and she signals to him, so he promises her and she promises him. If they meet, he does not complain of love nor recite poetry, and rises to her as if he is, regarding her marriage (intercourse), the trustee of trustees, as was said: 'He does not step from inside the vestibule leaving... Except her anklet has approached the earring.'
Al-Asma'i said: I said to a Bedouin woman: What do you count as Love among you? She said: Hugging, squeezing, winking, and conversation. Then she said: O city-dweller, how is it among you? I said: He sits between the legs of his beloved then strives against her. She said: O son of my brother, this is not a lover; this is a seeker of a child.

book_title: Diwan al-Sababa (The Anthology of Ardent Love)
text:
I loved his description before seeing him... and the ear falls in love before the eye sometimes. And I said: May God tend to the masters of the reed pen, for they... removed my excuse regarding them with Udhrite [chaste] love. Their continued blowing into them every hour... brought us love from where I know and where I do not know. I also said, speaking in riddles about a flute (shababa): And she is not a mute; if she speaks, we see... her action contradicting a wondrous command. A female companion who has no veil... she comes to us and does not fear the observer. A young girl, if I am alone with her, my companions... see that they have a share in her with me. Every lover disputes with me over her love... even if she does not resemble the raised gazelle. How many a lover she has exposed among us... and how often she gathered a beloved in her assembly. She renews joy for me if she speaks... making my worn-out time return new. Thinner in voice than the moist breeze... and faster in blowing among mankind than it. She always flirts with her eyes at the one who... casts songs of love and genealogy at her. So leave off blaming me if I fall in love with her... and recite to me strange poetry. And play the flute for me always and say to me... 'Types of people are lovers of types.' The most treacherous of them is a lover possessed of boredom... and the most excused of them is the one who most resembles a beloved. Al-Masis the Tailor said satirizing a lute player: And when he sat cross-legged, may he not sit cross-legged after it... and began to move his lute sluggishly; It was as if all the rats of the city... were gnawing on dry bread inside his lute. Another said: Abu al-Fadl sang, so we said to him... 'Glory be to the One who emptied him of virtue (fadl).' His singing is a punishment for his drinking... 'So drink, for you are lawful today.' And the most extreme thing said in dispraising a singer is the saying of Kushajim: And a singer with a cold melody... with defective hands; No one ever saw him in... the house of a people twice. Another said: And a cold singer... drove pleasures away from us. We asked him for silence... but he refused to be silent for us. So we insulted him, and he sang... so the pimp took revenge on us. Another said: A female singer of evil whose words... kill joy and revive distress. Ugly of face, gap-toothed... neither for marriage nor for delight. Another said: And perhaps a flute player whose playing agitates... the wind of bellies, would that she did not play. I likened her fingertips upon her strikes... and her ugly, hideous, bad-breathed smile; To beetles that aimed for a pile of dung and began... scurrying toward it upon the best cucumber. This is like their saying in the proverb: 'Look at the carrier, the carried, and the agency house.' Another said: It is as if she is, in the state of visible reality... beetles crawling upon a snake. How beautiful is the saying of Al-Wajih Al-Darari regarding one who sings with the Rabab and unites loved ones: Do not send anyone but the tormentor Ja'far... for the Sheikh is polished in all matters. At times he sings with the Rabab [instrument], and at times... al-Rabab and Zaynab [women's names] come upon his hand.

Chapter Twenty-Nine: Mentioning those of the people of the time afflicted by the love of women and boys.
I say: This is a chapter we have constituted to mention the lovers of this time of ours, and they are those you know by their marks. Among them are those characterized by fairness who followed the path of the predecessors in chastity, but this type, as it appears, is rarer than Red Sulphur; I have not seen it, nor have I seen anyone who saw it, and if I found its name, where is its named reality? So testify to the truth of my speech... or else deny me with a single instance. Far from it! Rather, the utmost of the people of this era is that one of them falls in love in the morning, connects at noon, and forgets by the afternoon. Regarding this is the story of some scholars from the people of Medina, as narrated by Amr bin Shaybah. He said: A man used to love a young woman, so he would circulate around her house for a year, rejoicing if he saw someone who had seen her. If he triumphed in meeting her in a gathering, they complained to each other and recited poetry. Today, he points to her and she points to him, he promises her and she promises him. But if they meet, he does not complain of love nor recite poetry, but stands over her as if he were the Trustee of Trustees over her marriage, as was said: He did not step out from inside the vestibule departing... except that her anklet had approached his earring. Al-Asma'i said: I said to a Bedouin woman, 'What do you consider love to be among you?' She said, 'Embracing, squeezing, winking, and conversation.' Then she said, 'Oh urban dweller, how is it with you?' I said, 'He sits between the legs of his beloved and then exhausts her.' She said, 'Oh nephew, that is not a lover; that is someone seeking a child.'

A Bedouin was asked about that. He said: 'It is sucking saliva and kissing the mouth, and taking a share of the pleasant parts of conversation. So how is it among you, O city-dweller?' He said: 'Severe biting, joining the knee and the jugular vein, and shaking (intercourse) that wakes the sleepers and necessitates sins.' He said: 'By Allah, an enemy does not do this, so how about a beloved?'
I said: It has been mentioned previously that Kings are like others in Love, and that a great King may love but his love does not lead him to abandon the management of his kingdom. There is another class below Kings; if they love, they do not have free time due to their busyness with their crafts. And another class are stingy with their religion and minds to occupy their hearts with what is not lawful for them and is forbidden to them. As for other than these, their love is a symptom among symptoms, nay a disease among diseases. If they reach him, they hasten to turn away from him, and perhaps it becomes abandonment, nay enmity until the end of life. This is the dominant trait of the people of this time of ours. It is the most corrupt type of love, for it exists at leisure and goes at busyness, occurs at the dominance of lust and vanishes with its vanishing. It is the weakest of them inevitably. Its owner's matter is easy, for he forgets with aversion and loves with little loyalty. Whoever's state is this, his matter is easy and his ember is extinguished by urination.
Among the people of this age are those who restricted themselves to the doll of the palace, so he wandered with the beautiful among women. Among them are those who cast off restraint regarding the beardless boy, and said to consolation regarding his red cheek: Fire and not Shame. Among them are those who coupled between the two groups and combined, from masculine and feminine, between the two opposites. You see him coming upon what is present and not stopping at any form of forms, as was said: 'I am the man having insight into every matter... I entered every door of youthfulness. My heart desires beardless boys and youths... And does not refuse the connection of buxom girls.'
Dik al-Jinn exceeded this where he said: 'I love beardless boys, fuzz-bearded ones, and grey-haired ones... And with the like of sons, the daughters. Take what is desired and loved by me... An animal in which life has settled.' He also said: 'I am, regarding my saying handsome... Or ugly, at rest. Everyone who walks on the face... Of the earth is handsome to me. The definition of what is married (intercourse) by me... Is an animal in which is a spirit.'
Ibn Tamim said, including: 'And a group blamed when I rode upon... A dark one, his beauties made their deed ugly. Let them blame as they could, I am a man... If I could, I would ride all people.'
Some Sheikhs of the age said: 'And a critic who blamed regarding a cheek-hair (Arid)... And a stabber stabbing at his age. He said to me: His chin (hair) has come out. So I said: I do not think about his chin.' He also said: 'My passion was ignited by a grey-haired one... Brighter than the light of the full moon. Whenever he turns grey, he bows... May Allah whiten his face.'
Also some Sheikhs of the age said: 'They reprimanded me for his love saying... The chin will appear from him, so have patience on the sadness. I said to them: Desist, for I have fallen... By your right, with passion in him up to the chin.'
Also some Sheikhs of the age said: 'And one full of cheek-hair, I kissed him... So he repelled me and turned away from my kiss. And said: How often do I forbid you from doing this... While you do not think about my beard?'
I wrote to some of them: 'Let our master be congratulated by a beloved who ceases not... In his union doing every good (Muhsin). How his beard adorned him in his face... Allah made it grow a good growth (Nabatan Hasana).' He wrote to me the answer to that: 'O praiser of the beard, our forgetting... The garden of it when it flourished will not be good. Since He made a good growth grow in it... I accepted it from him a good acceptance.'
So he was as was said: 'Far be it for one like me to repent from his love... He is a beloved below all worlds. I love him as a child in swaddling clothes, and beardless... And with a beard, and if greyness ascends him.'
Also some Sheikhs of the age said, having loved an old man: 'I was tasked with him, an old man; his greyness was... Upon his cheeks like jasmine on a rose. A possessor of intellect knowing what is wanted from a youth... I felt safe regarding him from a watcher and an adversary. They said: Mankind is two parts in the law of desire... For black beards are people, and people for beardless boys. I said to them: If I were to desire a beardless boy... I would desire a slender female, swaying of stature. Black beards, I saw in them a partner... So I preferred to remain with their white one alone.'
Another said, having loved an old woman: 'I was tasked with her, a grey-haired woman whose newborn has aged... And people have schools of thought in what they love.'

Yaqut al-Hamawi said: Those who singled out the people of Mosul with the attribution to sodomy wronged them, until they became a proverb. The poet said about them: 'Cheek-hair wrote on the page of his cheek... A line appearing to the contemplating onlooker. I exaggerated in extracting it, so I found it... No opinion (Ra'y) except the opinion (Ra'y) of the people of Mosul.' I have traveled the lands between Jayhun and the Nile, and whoever I saw does not depart from this school of thought. So I do not know why the people of Mosul were singled out with it. It was said the matter is not as Yaqut claimed in every aspect, because the mere inclination to the male is not devoid from any spot. But the people of Mosul add to that by inclining to those with beards, and perhaps they incline to one whose cheek-hair is grey. They say here: 'A hair and a hair', meaning a black hair and a white hair. Some of them call him 'Zarzuri' (Starling-like). This is rarely found in other than their land. They have been accused of this among the people of the lands, and the people of Alexandria, because they say: 'We do not give our small penny (Filaysa) except to one who spends it on his family and little children; we do not give it to one who eats Halawa with it.'
Sheikh Shams al-Din Ibn Qayyim al-Jawziyya said in his book 'Rawdat al-Muhibbin', after mentioning the story of 'Ad and what desire led them to of horrible destruction and continuous punishment, then the story of the people of Salih likewise, then the story of the lovers, the sinful debauchees, mounters of males and leavers of women (People of Lot), and how He seized them while they were playing in their immersion, and cut off their remnant while they were wandering in the drunkenness of their love, and how He combined punishments upon them that He did not combine on any of the nations. He made them predecessors for their brothers, the sodomites of the early and later times. He said: When they dared upon this disobedience and rebelled and paved a way for their brothers and established it, the angels cried out to Allah regarding that with a clamor, and the earth roared to its Lord regarding this matter a roar. The angels fled to the regions of the heavens and complained of them to all creatures. He, Glory be to Him, had judged that He does not seize the wrongdoers except after establishing the proof against them and presenting the promise and threat to them. When they opposed the Messenger sent to them and the proof fell upon them, Allah Almighty did to them what He informed of in His Mighty Book: "So when Our command came, We made the highest part [of the city] its lowest and rained upon them stones of layered hard clay, marked from your Lord. And Allah's punishment is not from the wrongdoers far removed." This is the consequence of sodomites, lovers of the form (image). They are the predecessors, and their brothers are after them on the trail.
'If they are not the people of Lot themselves... Then the people of Lot are not far from them. And they are waiting for them in the eclipse... At a watering place of murky oil and pus. They say: No welcome nor hello to you... Did your Lord not promise you with a threat? They said: Yes, but you have enacted... A path for us in love that is not praiseworthy. We approached the male with it out of our love for them... So they brought us, this love, an evil arrival. So you are more deserving of double the punishment than... Your follower in that, unguided. They said: And you, your messengers warned you... Of what we have met of a truthful threat. So you have no merit over us, for all of us... Taste the punishment of humiliation, a taste of increase. Just as all of us tasted the pleasure of their union... And our meeting place in the Fire is not far.'
Chief Judge Shams al-Din bin Khallikan narrated from Al-Asma'i that he said: I entered the mosque one day, I and Abu Ubaida. Behold, on the pillar where Abu Ubaida sits was written at a height of about seven cubits: 'May the God bless Lot and his followers... Abu Ubaida, say by Allah: Amen. For you are, to me, without doubt their remnant... Since you reached puberty and you have passed seventy.' He said to me: 'O Asma'i, erase this.' So I mounted his back and erased it after I burdened him. He said: 'You burdened me and broke my back, get down.' I said to him: 'The Ta remains.' He said: 'It is the worst letter of this verse.' It was said that when he mounted his back and burdened him, he said to him: 'Hurry.' He said: 'Lot remains.' He said: 'From this one flees.' The one who wrote that was Abu Nuwas. I said: It came in the interpretation of His saying Almighty: "Indeed Gog and Magog are corrupters in the land," that their corruption was sodomy.

Section: Looking at the face of the Beardless Boy (Amrad).
Hafiz Muhammad bin Nasir mentioned...

...from the Hadith of Mujalid from Al-Sha'bi, he said: Abd al-Qays came to the Prophet, peace be upon him, and among them was a beardless boy of apparent beauty. He, peace be upon him, sat him behind his back and said: 'Looking was the sin of those who passed.' In 'Al-Kamil' from Abu Huraira: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, forbade that a man stare sharply at the beardless boy. Sa'id bin al-Musayyib used to say: 'If you see a man persisting in looking at a beardless boy, then accuse him.' Sheikh Muhyi al-Din al-Nawawi declared in 'Al-Minhaj' the prohibition of looking at the face of the beardless boy with desire or without desire. Al-Khatib mentioned from the Hadith of Abd al-Rahman bin Wafid from Amr bin Azhar from Aban from Anas, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: 'Do not sit with the sons of kings, for souls yearn for them with a yearning they do not have for young free women.' Ibrahim al-Nakha'i, Sufyan al-Thawri, and others of the predecessors used to forbid sitting with the beardless boy. Al-Nakha'i said: 'Sitting with them is a Fitnah (trial), and they are in the status of women.' It is told about Abu Sa'id al-Jazzar, who was among the Sheikhs known for asceticism and worship, that he said: I saw Iblis in my sleep passing aside from me. I said: 'Come.' He said: 'What can I do with you? You have cast off your souls what I deceive people with.' I said: 'And what is it?' He said: 'The world.' Then he said: 'However, I have a trick among you.' I said: 'And what is it?' He said: 'The company of youths.' I took the stick to hit him. He said: 'I do not fear the stick; I only fear the light of the heart.' Fath al-Mawsili said: 'I accompanied thirty Sheikhs of the Abdal (Substitutes/Saints); all of them said: Beware of associating with youths.' Abu Abdullah Ahmad bin al-Jallad narrated: I was walking with my teacher and saw a youth of beautiful form. I said: 'Do you think Allah will punish this form with Fire?' He said: 'Did you look at him? You will see its consequence.' He said: 'So I forgot the Quran after twenty years.' It is known that looking at the beardless boy drops one into the drunkenness of love, as the Almighty said about the lovers of forms: "By your life, indeed they were in their intoxication wandering blindly." So looking is a cup of wine, and love is the drunkenness of that drink. The drunkenness of love is greater than the drunkenness of wine, for the drunkard of wine sobers up, while the drunkard of love does not sober up except when he is among the army of the dead. 'Drunk with the drunkenness of desire and the drunkenness of wine... And when does a youth sober up in whom are two drunkennesses?'
Some Sheikhs of the age recited to me: 'O you who became having anguish for beardless boys... You are not right in loving them. In the wide-eyed virgins is what you desire... Of them, and they excel with the love of the beloved.'
Another said: 'Your love of boys, if... Women are possible for you, is fraud. One only fornicates in the back... If a belly is lacking.'
However, the love of women also, and looking at whom it is not permissible to look at, contains what it contains of what cannot be remedied. It is established in the two Sahihs from the Hadith of Usama bin Zaid that the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "I have not left after me a trial more harmful to men than women." I said: Especially the women of this time, from every sun of a chamber rising from her pimp between the horns of a devil, and others who occupied themselves with Lesbianism (Sihaq) and going out after her husband from the door or window, as was said in the meaning of that: 'Love of beardless boys occupied the substitutes (men)... And the occupation of the women of people became Lesbianism. Every gender with its gender has sufficed... So condolences, O assembly of sinners.'
It is told about some that he said to a slave girl practicing lesbianism: 'Return to the Truth (Haqq).' She said: 'Al-Haqq is some of my desire.' She means that Al-Sahq (Lesbianism) shares some letters with Al-Haqq. This is one of the witty answers. How worthy she is that it be said in her right: 'Fond of lesbianism, she became... Weeping over it with every eye. She was not content in disgrace except... To add Isaac (Ishaq) to Hunayn.'
It is told that a man entered a house and found two women in lesbianism. He pulled the one on top and sat in her place and said: 'This is a work that needs ropes and men.' Our Sheikh Zayn al-Din Ibn al-Wardi said regarding the women of the people of the age this poetry: 'Say to her who loves lesbianism which... Allah forbade and in which there is no good. You erred, O complete of beauty, when... You set up Isaac (Ishaq) in the place of Al-Zubayr.'
Another said: 'Say to her who claims lesbianism... Until when will you be a lesbian? Nothing cures your thirst... Among all creatures. Except a bald, poor man... Shaven, wandering.'
Ibn Sana' al-Mulk said: 'O this one, do not be shy... Of me, the covered has been revealed. If... yawned... stretched.'
Some Sheikhs of the age said: '... If I called him... For a need specific to me. He stood for it himself... It is nothing but my nerve.'

Some friends asked me to compose something like this for them, so I said, seeking forgiveness from Allah and repenting to Him: 'She delayed due to her menstruation... I said to her: Advance... This is my nerve... It enters with you in the blood.'
Some Sheikhs of the age said: 'And I used to, if I saw even an old woman... Hasten to stand up out of heat. So I became not standing for a full moon... As if misfortune had taken over the ministry.'
I said: 'O... If the beloved passes greeting... And points towards you excluding all people. Then rise to serve him, and because you are stupid... There is no harm in your standing for an hour.'
I also said, seeking forgiveness from Allah the Great for every sin: 'When Love fulfilled the fast, he recited to me... And said: Stipulate what you wish and judge. For the command is your command, I have no opposition... If you fast, we fast, and if you break fast, we do not fast.'
Chief Judge Shams al-Din Ibn Khallikan narrated, after refuting the saying of some: 'My friend said to me when... He saw me harmed by bankruptcy. Stand and beg with this pole, for this... ... is hoped for with its like and headed.' I said: 'This was, but my time... Its people are all mean, base. Where is he who used to raise with them... ... And on the palms then dryness. Where is he who was knowing of measures... ... The great ones, people died.' He said: It was said that Emir Fakhr al-Din Ibn al-Shaykh saw these verses written on the back of a book in the handwriting of Sharaf al-Din Ibn Qayyim al-Sham, so he wrote under them: 'Whoever left the like of you did not die.'
Another said: 'They claimed that I lost on her... I wish I knew from where that loss is. From the yield of my estate, from my fabric... From the remains of the money of that trade? She attended me, so... stood at that time... Imitated by a cotton pod or a cucumber.'
Another said: 'Woe to you O... Do you not feel shy... Shaming me among my sitters? You come out of my collar like this intentionally... Tilting the turban from my head.'
Ibn Matruh said: 'I asked one whose emaciation commanded... For a kiss to cure the pain. He said: No, no, never... I said to him: Yes, yes. He said: By force? I said: No... Except by permission and generosity. He said: Then travel. I said: No... Except on the head of a flag. He said: Then take it with satisfaction... From me, lawful, and smile. So do not ask about what happened... And ask forgiveness of Allah and sleep.'

Chapter Thirty: Mention of those Characterized by Chastity and Best Attributes

I say: We established this chapter to mention the most inclined of lovers, the clearest of them in proof, the best of them in conduct, the purest of them in conscience, and the most chaste of them despite ability. Especially Banu Udhra, who are the most intense of people in passion and the greatest of them in wandering. Therefore, I said: The saying of Love with Chastity in Banu Udhra is abundant, and those killed among them by love are a large multitude. If one of them is mentioned for chastity, then Jamil (is mentioned), beautiful (Jamil) of attributes, truthful of resolves. We will present of his news in this place what verifies this claim and confirms that finding solace in the beloved from others is a type of comfort. Of that is what Muhammad bin Ja'far al-Ahwazi recounted. He said: Jamil fell ill in Egypt with the illness in which he died. Al-Abbas bin Sahl entered upon him. Jamil said to him: 'What do you say about a man who never drank wine, nor fornicated, nor killed a soul, nor stole, testifying that there is no god but Allah?' I said: 'I think he has been saved and I hope Paradise for him. Who is this man?' He said: 'Me.' I said to him: 'I do not think you are safe while you have been flirting with Buthayna for twenty years.' He said: 'I am in the first day of the days of the Hereafter and the last day of the days of the world; may I not attain the intercession of Muhammad on the Day of Resurrection if I ever placed my hand on her for suspicion.' We did not stand until he died in the year eighty-two of the Hijra. Among the strange things Al-Zubayr recounted of Jamil's news is that the mentioned Buthayna was from Banu Udhra. Banu Udhra is a tribe famous for love among the Arab tribes, and Udhri love is attributed to them because they are the most loving of all Allah's creation. Sa'id bin Uqba said to a Bedouin: 'From whom are you?' He said: 'From a people who, if they love, die.' He said: 'Udhri, by the Lord of the Kaaba.' Then he said: 'Why is that?' He said: 'Because in our women is beauty (Sabaha) and in our young men is chastity.' A man said to Urwa bin Hizam: 'O you, by Allah, is it true what is said about you that you are the softest of people in hearts?' He said: 'Yes, by Allah, I left thirty youths in the tribe whom death has infected; they have no disease except Love.' A man from Banu Fazara said to a man from Banu Udhra: 'You count your dying of love a merit and a virtue, but that is weakness of constitution, narrowness of thought, and thinness and frailty found in you, O Banu Udhra.' He said to him: 'By Allah, if you saw the large black eyes, above them the arched eyebrows, beneath them the spaced smiling teeth, and the dark lips revealing the white serrated teeth, you would have taken them as Al-Lat and Al-Uzza.' Then he recited: 'I followed the throwing of the wild animals until they shot me... From the Nile, not with the swerving missing arrows. Weak ones killing men without blood... So oh wonder at the weak killers.' It was said to some of them: 'What would you do if you triumphed over whom you love?' He said: 'I would untie the veil and respect what is behind the wrapper, and show for love what pleases the Lord.' Hafiz Abu Muhammad al-Umawi said that a woman he trusts told him that a youth became attached to her and she to him, and their matter spread. They met one day alone. He said to her: 'Come, let us verify what is said about us.' She said: 'No, by Allah, this will never be while I recite: "Close friends, that Day, will be enemies to each other, except for the righteous."' It was said to some of them whose love for a slave girl of his people had prolonged: 'What would you do if you triumphed over her and none sees you two but Allah?' He said: 'By Allah, I would not make Him the least of observers. I would not do with her alone except what I do in the presence of her family: long yearning and a glance from afar, and I leave what the Lord hates and what corrupts love.' It was said to another: 'What would you do if you triumphed over your beloved?' He said: 'Embracing her and kissing her, and disobeying Satan regarding her sin. I will not spoil the love of twenty years with the pleasure of an hour that vanishes and its reckoning remains. Indeed, if I did, I would be mean and a noble would not have birthed me.' I said: Among those characterized by chastity with the best attributes among the Caliphs is Harun al-Rashid. That is because he loved a slave girl. When he solicited her for herself, she said: 'Your father was intimate with me.' So he left her, and was enamored with her until he almost went out on his face. He used to recite: 'I see water and I have intense thirst... But there is no way to the watering place.'

The Judge said to him: 'Do you believe her saying every time a slave girl says something?' Al-Rashid said: 'There is no rank above the Caliphate.' So look at how beautiful the chastity of the slave girl was and the abstinence of Harun al-Rashid despite his intense fondness for her. Mansur bin Ammar entered upon him, so he brought him near until he touched his knees to his knees. Mansur said to him: 'O Commander of the Faithful, your humility in your honor is dearer to us than your honor.' He said: 'Admonish me.' He said: 'Whoever is chaste in his beauty, comforts with his wealth, and is just in his authority, Allah writes him among the righteous.' Al-Rashid wept and said: 'Increase me.' He said: 'If you sought a drink of water and did not find it except for half the world, would you buy it with it?' He said: 'Yes.' He said: 'If it became difficult for you after drinking it, would you buy its exit with the other half?' He said: 'Yes.' He said: 'May Allah make ugly a world bought with a drink of water and a urination.'
It is told regarding Sultan Malik Shah the Seljuk that a female singer came before him. He admired her and found her singing pleasant, so he intended her. She said: 'O Sultan of the World, I am jealous for this handsome beautiful face that it be punished in the Fire. The Halal (lawful) is easier, and between it and the Haram is a word.' He said: 'You spoke the truth.' He summoned the Judge and married her, and she remained in his bond until he died, may Allah have mercy on him.
Suhayl, the greatest servant of Sultan Nur al-Din the Martyr, recounted that the mentioned Sultan bought a Mamluk for five hundred dinars, a robe of honor, and a mule. He was beautiful in form. He handed him to me, and I had raised the Sultan. I said to myself: 'To Allah we belong and to Him we return. He never bought a Mamluk for fifty dinars, so why did he buy this one for five hundred dinars?' Then he left me for days and said: 'Bring him with the Mamluks to stand in service every day.' After some days, he said: 'Bring him after Isha (night prayer) to the tent, and you and he sleep at the door of the tower.' I said to myself: 'This Sheikh, in the time of his youth, did not commit a major sin, and when his age advanced he falls into it? By Allah, I will kill him (the boy) before he falls into sin.' I took a strangling cord and prepared it, and came with the Mamluk while I was anxious. I stayed awake most of the night, and Nur al-Din was at the top of the tower. Then my eye overcame me and I slept. I woke up and my hand fell on the boy's face, and behold he was like an ember and had a high fever. I returned with him to my tent and brought the doctor, but he died at noon. I washed him, shrouded him, and buried him. Nur al-Din called me the second day and said: 'O Suhayl, indeed some suspicion is sin.' I was ashamed. He said: 'You have known my condition and you raised me. Did you find a slip in me?' I said: 'Far be it from Allah.' He said: 'Then why did you carry the strangling cord and your soul spoke evil to you? I am not infallible. When I saw the Mamluk, something like fire fell into my heart from him. I said: I will buy him, perhaps he removes from me what I am in. But it did not go away. My soul said to me: I want to see him every day. So I ordered you to bring him. It said: I want you to bring him to the tower at night. So I ordered you to bring him. When he attended, the soul did not let me sleep, and we remained in war until dawn. I intended to bring him up to me, but Allah overtook me with His mercy. I uncovered my head and said: My God, Your servant Mahmud, the Mujahid in Your path, the defender of the religion of Your Prophet, peace be upon him, who built mosques, schools, and ribs (hospices), ends his deeds with the likes of this? I heard a caller saying: We have sufficed you, O Mahmud. So I knew that something happened to him. As for you, may Allah reward you with good on my behalf. By Allah, that he be killed with me is lighter than disobedience.' Then he treated me well.
It is told regarding Fatima bint al-Khath'ami that she offered herself to Abdullah bin Abdul-Muttalib, father of the Prophet, peace be upon him, for the light she saw between his eyes. He refused and said: 'As for the Haram, death is before it... And the Halal, there is no solution so I clarify it. So how about the matter you desire?... The noble protects his honor and religion.' I said: The story of Abdullah with this Fatima is like their saying in the proverb: 'One desires the fig and another picks it.' His state with her is like the state of Tawba with Laila al-Akhayliyyah, which is what is told that he solicited her for herself, so she shied away from him and recited: 'And a possessor of a need, we said to him: Do not reveal it... For there is no way to it as long as I live. We have a companion whom we should not betray... And you are for another a companion and friend.' So she was as was said: 'We went mad for Laila, and she went mad for other than us... And another is mad for us whom we do not want.' And like the saying of the other: 'I was attached to her accidentally, and she was attached to a man... Other than me, and another woman was attached to the man.'

Among those characterized by chastity among the people of love is the Imam son of the Imam, Muhammad bin Dawood al-Zahiri. He has famous stories regarding that, and this is the place to present them and spread their garments. Of that is his saying: 'Everything has a Zakat, and the Zakat of the beautiful face is enabling the people of chastity to look at it.' His beloved Muhammad, and it was said his name was Wahb bin Jami' al-Saydalani, recounted that he entered upon the Commander of the Faithful, who asked him about Ibn Dawood: 'Did you see from him what you dislike?' He said: 'No, O Commander of the Faithful, except that I spent a night with him, and he would uncover my face then say: O Allah, You know that I love him and that I observe You regarding him.' He said: 'What extent did your care for him reach?' He said: 'I entered the bathhouse. When I came out, I looked in the mirror and found my image beautiful beyond what I knew. So I covered my face and swore that no one would look at my face before him. I hastened to him. When he saw me with covered face, he feared an affliction had befallen me. He said: What is the news? I said: I saw my face in the mirror just now, so I wanted no one to see it before you. So he fainted.'
Al-Layth bin Sakra said: Muhammad bin Wasi' used to spend on Muhammad bin Dawood. No beloved was known in the past time who spends on his lover and draws near to his heart with types of kindness except this one, with what he is upon of maintenance (of dignity) and good religion. Praise be to Allah that we saw in our time one who adopts the morals of (noble) people. This lover has a strange story with this beloved; I omitted it fearing elongation.
Muhammad bin Dawood had written the book 'Al-Zahrah' for the sake of his beloved Muhammad bin Jami' mentioned. It is a collection of literature in which he brought every strange and rare thing and elegant poetry. He said in its beginning: 'And how do you deny the change of time while you are one of its changers, and the roughness of brothers while you are the leader in it? Among the strange things days bring is an oppressor complaining, a cheater regretting, an obeyed one seeking help, and a conqueror seeking aid.' From his speech: 'I have not detached from desire since I entered the Kuttab (school). I started the book Al-Zahrah while I was in the Kuttab, and my father looked into most of it.'
Among the subtlest told about him is that he and Abu al-Abbas bin Surayj met in the gathering of Abu al-Hasan bin Isa the Vizier. They debated a question of Ila' (oath of abstention from wife). Ibn Surayj said to him: 'You, by your saying "Whoever's glances are many, his sorrows endure," are more skillful than speaking in Fiqh.' Muhammad bin Dawood said to him: 'If you say that, then I say: I declare my eye above the garden of beauties... And forbid my soul from attaining a forbidden thing. And I bear of the weight of passion what if... It were on the deaf rock, it would demolish it. And my glance speaks for the interpreter of my thought... Were it not for my snatching its rejection, it would have spoken. I saw love as a claim from all people... For I do not see a true, safe love.' Ibn Surayj said to him: 'With what do you boast over me? If I wished, I would have said: And kept awake by the coquetry of his glances... I spent the night preventing him the pleasure of his slumbers. Out of pity for the beauty of his speech and admonition... And repeating glances at his cheeks. Until when the morning showed its column... He turned away with the seal of his Lord and his innocence.' Muhammad said: 'Preserve against him, O Vizier, what he admitted of the meeting until he establishes proof with two just witnesses of innocence.' Ibn Surayj said to him: 'Binding on me in this is what is binding on you in your saying: I declare my eye above the garden of beauties... And forbid my soul from attaining a forbidden thing.' He said: The Vizier laughed and said: 'You have combined knowledge, understanding, wit, and subtlety.'
Among the subtle things told about Muhammad also is what Abu al-Qasim al-Sa'igh recounted. He said: Muhammad bin Dawood said to me: 'I have not entered the mosque of the city from the side of the gate of Khurasan for twenty years.' I said: 'Why?' He said: 'Because I entered one day and saw two youths of the most beautiful people in face admonishing each other. When they saw me, they separated. So I swore not to enter from a gate where I was the cause of separation between two lovers.' Tha'lab entered upon him and said to him: 'Let us hear something of your youthful passion.' So he recited: 'May Allah water days for us and nights... That have playing fields in the regions of youth. When life was fresh and time was unaware... And the witness of the banes of lovers was absent.' Of his poetry: 'For every person there is a guest he rejoices in his nearness... And I have no guest but sorrows and worry. My friend says: How is your patience after us?... I said: Is there patience so it be asked about "how"?'

Ibn al-Sarraj said in the book 'Masari' al-Ushaq' (Death-grounds of Lovers): And from Abu Abdullah Ibrahim ibn Muhammad bin Arafa al-Nahwi, he said: I entered upon Muhammad bin Dawood al-Zahiri in his illness in which he died. I said: 'How do we find you?' He said: 'The love of whom you know has bequeathed to me what you see.' I said to him: 'What prevented you from enjoying him while having the ability to do so?' He said: 'Enjoyment is of two types: One is the permissible look, and the second is the prohibited pleasure. What prevented me from it is what my father told me; he said: Suwayd bin Sa'id told me, he said: Ali bin Mushir told us, from Abu Yahya al-Qaffaf, from Mujahid, from Ibn Abbas, from the Prophet, peace be upon him, that he said: "Whoever loves, conceals, remains chaste, and is patient, Allah forgives his sin and admits him to Paradise."' Then he recited: '... Look at the magic running in his glances... And look at the intense blackness in his calm gaze. And look at hairs above his cheek-hair... As if they are ants crawling on ivory.' And he recited to us for himself: 'Why did they deny blackness in his cheeks... And did not deny the blackness of the eyes? If the fault of his cheek is the seed of hair... Then the fault of eyes is the hair of eyelids.' I said to him: 'You negated analogy in Fiqh and affirmed it in poetry.' He said: 'The dominance of desire and the possession of the soul called for it.' He died in his night, may Allah have mercy on him. I said: People differed regarding his saying, peace be upon him: "Whoever loves, conceals, and remains chaste..." the Hadith. Some said: Concealed his love from people. Some said: Concealed the name of his beloved. Al-Husri said: Loved and concealed, and was united and remained chaste, and was abandoned and died, he is a martyr. Uthman bin Zakariya the Tutor, one of the narrators of the Hadith from Suwayd, said: Concealed from his beloved that he loves him.
The Sheikh, Imam, Allama, Hafiz Ala' al-Din Abu Abdullah Mughlatay said in his book 'Al-Wadih Al-Mubin': This Hadith has a Sahih chain, even if a group of scholars found fault with it with what is not a fault by which it is rejected, meaning his saying peace be upon him "Whoever loves and conceals..." the Hadith. He also reported in his mentioned book that this Hadith's chain is like the sun; there is no doubt in its authenticity nor confusion.
I said: For this reason, a group of jurists counted the dead of love among the martyrs, taking this Hadith, among them Al-Rafi'i and others. Some of them stipulated the mentioned conditions, and some generalized, like Sheikh Muhyi al-Din al-Nawawi, for he generalized and did not stipulate anything. He said: 'And the dead of love, and the woman dying in labor,' meaning among the martyrs. This is despite his strictness in religion and lack of leniency in these things. How excellent is the saying of Ibn al-Athir: 'The tear of the lover and the blood of the slain are equal in simile and representation, except that between them is a difference because they differ in color.'
The Imam, Allama Abu al-Walid al-Naji said: 'If the lover dies of ardency and love... Then that is martyrdom, O friend, truly. Trustworthy ones narrated it to us from trustworthy ones... Rising to the Ink (Scholar) Ibn Abbas.'
Abd al-Karim al-Qushayri said: 'Indeed the lover, if he dies patient... His dwellings are with the martyrs. People narrated it who became in their truthfulness... A banner; and suffice you with this disease.'
Al-Hasan bin Hani said: 'And we had narrated... From Sa'id from Qatada. From Sa'id bin al-Musayyib... That Sa'd bin Ubada. Said: Whoever dies loving... Is among the people of martyrdom.'
Ibn Rawaha al-Hamawi said and excelled as he wished: 'They blamed regarding you and did not know... That desire is the cause of happiness. If it is union, then it is the wish... Or if it is abandonment, then it is martyrdom.'
He reversed his saying here and said: 'O heart, leave desire and rest... You are not in a praiseworthy matter in it. I wasted my world by his abandonment... If I attain a union, the Hereafter is lost.'
Another said: 'O my two friends, have you been told or heard... That the victim of beautiful women is a martyr?'
I said as if present addressing him: 'Yes, we have heard that whoever conceals desire... And remains chaste until he dies, he is a martyr. So take a saying in which you are wavering... For that is what you used to deviate from. The context of what the caravan of lovers narrates... By it every day is a driver and a witness. They circle the loved ones behind their houses... Among them standing around it and sitting. They swim in the sea of tears when... The ships of desire tilt with them and sway. Do you weep for less than a year a year away from them... While Labid set a year for weeping?'
I said: The speech on these chapters has ended; Tight of knots, pure of coins, set of fractures, high of palaces. Each chapter of them containing a verse of a poem (Bayt Qasid) and a long meter (Bahr Madid).
