It waters the fruit of its plantings and quenches the dry of its parchments. 'With two large eyes, if you shone them... At the rising of the Pleiades, its clouds would pour.' Nothing remains but the mention of the death-grounds of lovers, and the news of those among lovers who became dead of longings. 'If I do not die in the love of eyelids and eyes... Then oh my shame before lovers and oh my embarrassment. How good is death in the love of beauties like this... Especially by the swords of wide eyes. O my two companions, if I die between you two... Short of the two delicious ones: the rose of the cheek and the kiss. Then ask forgiveness for me and say: A lover of ghazal... Died slain by slender statures and eyes.'
Our compatriot Muhammad bin al-Afif al-Tilimsani, may Allah have mercy on him, said: 'For lovers, in the rulings of passion, is satisfaction... So do not be, O young man, objecting with blame. My soul be the ransom for my loved ones, even if they broke... The covenant of loyalty to one who did not break the covenant. Stop and listen, being merciful, to the news of those who were killed... So he died in their love not attaining the purpose. He saw, so he loved, so he sought union, but they refused... So he sought patience, but attaining it exhausted him, so he passed away.'
Jarir said: 'Indeed, the eyes in whose glance is intense contrast... Killed us then did not revive our dead. They strike down the one of intellect until there is no movement in him... While they are the weakest of Allah's creation as pillars.'
Another said: 'My heart ceased not to desire the eyes... Until it was killed. Praise be to Allah who... died and it was not said he forgot.'
Another said: 'You see lovers slain in their dwellings... Like the Youths of the Cave; they do not know how long they stayed. A people, if they were abandoned after they were united (with)... Died; if those they desire returned, they would be resurrected.'
Muhammad the Preacher said: 'Leave my blame, for the blame of you two is returning... And the killing of lovers has a Return (Resurrection/Hereafter). If desire killed the people of youthful passion... They would not die; if they were returned, they would return.'

Conclusion of the Book: Mention of those who died of their love and came to their Lord, small and great, rich and poor, despite their different types and varying quests. For the sake of mentioning them, I established the foundations of this book and entered it from a door and exited from a door, to arrive from it to the mention of one whom abandonment drove to the throes of death, and who bore of love what he had no power for, from the door to the window. From here I begin mentioning their death-grounds and presenting their goods, for among them is the loser and the winner, the righteous and the corrupt. Among them is wretched and happy, and among them is slain and martyr.
Abu al-Faraj ibn al-Jawzi narrated saying: Our Sheikh Abu al-Hasan Ali bin Abdullah mentioned to me that a man loved a Christian woman until he was overcome in his mind, so he was carried to the hospital (Bimaristan). He had a friend who acted as a messenger between them. When the matter increased on him and death descended upon him, he said to his friend: 'The term has approached and I did not meet so-and-so in the world, and I fear dying upon Islam and not meeting her.' So he converted to Christianity and died. His friend went to the Christian woman and found her ill. She said: 'I did not meet my companion in the world and I want to meet him in the Hereafter. I bear witness that there is no god but Allah and that Muhammad is His servant and Messenger.' Then she died.
I said: I have not heard stranger than this story nor greater than this injury. The Book (Decree) preceded its owner, and a wall with a door was struck between him and his beloved. He was afflicted by the separation of his beloved and his religion with two diseases, and the circle of evil turned upon him in the two abodes. How not, when he arrived with his stagnation in love at the abode of ruin, and became with his disbelief and her Islam on the brink of a collapsing cliff? 'She traveled east and I traveled west... What a difference between an easterner and a westerner.'
I was reminded by this story of the saying of Abd al-Wahhab al-Azdi mourning a Christian friend of his, and he excelled as he wished where he said: 'My brother in affection, not my brother in religion... And many a brother in affection is like a relative. They said: Do you weep today for one who is not a companion... Tomorrow? Indeed this is the action of one not intelligent. I said to them: Is this or my sorrow... And the intensity of my wailing and excess of my weeping? And from where do I weep for a beloved I lost... If my share of him in the Hereafter failed?'

This Christian was marked with beauty, a wine-seller. Abd al-Wahhab mentioned became attached to him and became famous for him. He stayed spending the night in the tavern for three years, entering the church with him on festivals and Sundays throughout this period, until he memorized much of the Gospel and the laws of his people. He (the Christian) abandoned him once, and he found no way to him. He claimed he had a strong oath not to speak to him for a period of a month. When he despaired, he called for the phlebotomist and bled one of his hands, and called another phlebotomist and bled the other hand. He entered his house, locked the door of his home, and opened the phlebotomies (veins). His family did not sense anything until the blood pushed from the threshold of the door of the place he was in. They reached him when he was on the verge of death. His Christian beloved reconciled with him fearing for his life. Of his poetry regarding him: 'Look at the mole on the cheek of one whose... Glances are, by the glance, his wounds. As if, from its beauty, it showed... A grain of musk atop an apple.'

And among them is a martyr. Yaqut said in his History: Mudrik bin Ali al-Shaybani was a poet, a man of letters, virtuous. He used to frequently visit the Monastery of the Romans (Dayr al-Rum) in Baghdad and associate with its Christians. In the Monastery of the Romans was a boy from the children of the Christians called Amr bin Yahya. He was of the most beautiful people in form and most complete in character. Mudrik bin Ali loved him. Mudrik had a gathering where youths gathered, no others. If an old man or one with a beard attended, Mudrik would say to him: 'It is ugly for you to mix with youths and boys, so rise in the protection of Allah,' so he would rise. Amr used to attend his gathering, and Mudrik loved him and wandered for him. Amr came one day to the gathering. Mudrik wrote a note and threw it in his lap. He read it, and behold in it: 'By the gatherings of knowledge which... By you the beauty of their crowds is complete. Will you not have mercy on an eye... Drowned in the flood of its tears? Between me and you is a sanctity... Of Allah regarding wasting it.' He said: He read the verses, and those in the gathering stood upon it and read them. Amr was ashamed and stopped attending. The matter overwhelmed Mudrik, so he left his gathering and stuck to the abode of the Romans, and began following Amr wherever he wished. He said much poetry about him. Al-Hariri said: 'I saw Amr white of head and beard.' Of Mudrik's poetry regarding him is this strange, wondrous, famous Muzdawija (poem with rhyming hemistiches) which is: 'From a lover, his desire is far, near... Speaking of tear, silent of tongue. Tortured by repulsion and abandonment... Bound of heart, released of body. Without a sin his hands earned... Complaining of a desire his eyes revealed. Longing for the sight of who made him miserable... As if he healed him who made him ill. Woe to him, a lover, what does he encounter... From pouring tears that do not stop? Speaking and they did not perfect speech... Telling of a love to which he was enslaved. Nothing remained of him but a glance weeping... With tears like the arrangement of a thread (necklace). The fire of desire extinguishes them and kindles... Resembling the drops of the sky. Towards a gazelle from the sons of the Christians... The cheek-hair of his cheeks captured the virgins. And left the lions because of him confused... In the noose of love for him, captives. A Reem (white antelope) in the Abode of the Romans intended my killing... With a kohl-rimmed eye, not from kohl. And a forelock by which my mind flew... And a beautiful face and an ugly deed. A Reem by whom any lion is hunted... Killing with the glance and not fearing retaliation. Whenever he says "Ha" (Behold), the glances said "Qad" (Enough)... As if it is his humanity (Nasut) when it united (with Divinity). People altogether did not see a full moon... Nor saw a sun and a fresh branch. More beautiful than Amr, and I ransomed Amr... A fawn who with his eyes gave me wine to drink. Here I am, cut by his stature... And the tear on my cheek has a trench for it. What harm to one whose loss exists in him... If his repulsion did not make ugly his deed. If my sin with him is Islam... Then days have striven to dismantle it. And I broke (rules) for prayer and fasting... And the forbidden became permissible for him in religion. Would that I were for him a Cross... Being near to him forever. Seeing beauty and smelling perfume... Fearing no slanderer nor watcher. Would that I were for him an Offering (Qurban)... He kisses from it the mouth and fingertips. Or were I a Catholicos or a Metropolitan... So he sees obedience to me as faith. Would that I were for Amr a Scripture (Mushaf)... He reads from me every day letters.

Or a pen with which he writes what I encounter... Of beautiful literature that has been authored. Would that I were for Amr his Oud... Or a suit his slender body wears. Or a pool in his name prepared... Or a church (Bi'ah) in his house witnessed. Would that I were for him a belt (Zunnar)... He turns me on the waist however he turned. Until when the night folds the day... I become for him then a wrapper (Izar). Oh my liver from his reddened cheek... Oh my liver from his spaced teeth. Nothing is like the black-eyed glance of his... Go away for asceticism and refrainment. To you I complain, O gazelle of humans... What is in me of loneliness after intimacy. O you whose face is my crescent and my sun... Do not kill the soul without a soul (retaliation). Be generous to me as you were generous with good affection... And observe as I observed the old covenant. And turn away like an echo from long turning away... For there is no passion from you like my passion. Here I am in the sea of desire drowning... Drunk from your love, I do not sober up. Burning, while no fire touched me... The enemy and the friend pity me. I wish I knew regarding you, do you pity me... From illness and long emaciation? Or is there a way to your union... For a lover of a thin body? In every limb of his is sickness and pain... And an eye weeping with tears and blood. Longing for a sun and a moon and an idol... To him is the complaint if he wronged. I say when he rose in my heart and sat... O Amr, O populator of my heart with grief. I swear by Allah the oath of the striver... Indeed a man you made happy has become happy. O Amr, I adjured you by the Messiah (Christ)... Will you not listen to the saying of an eloquent one? Revealing about a heart of his, wounded... Wailing from what he encounters of hardship. O Amr, by the truth of the Divinity (Lahut)... And the Spirit, the Holy Spirit, and Humanity (Nasut). That one who in his hewn cradle... Compensated with speech for silence. By the right of a humanity in the womb of Mary... That settled the place of saliva from her in the mouth. Then transformed into the ancient Qayyum (Self-Subsisting)... Speaking to people and not yet weaned. By the right of the one who after death wore a shirt... Mixed according to his measure what he cut. And was pious, sincere to Allah... Heals and cures the blind and the leper. By the right of the Reviver of the form of birds... And the Resurrector of the dead from the graves. And the One to Whom matters belong... He knows what is in the land and seas. By the right of who is in the lofty hermitages... Of one prostrating to his Lord and bowing. Weeping when every sleeper sleeps... Out of fear of Allah with shedding tears. By the right of a people who shaved heads... And treated misery the length of life. And rang the bell (Naqus) in the church... Using it, worshipping Jesus. By the right of Mari (Saint) Maryam and Paul... By the right of Simon Peter (Al-Safa) and George. By the right of Daniel, by the right of Jonah... By the right of Ezekiel and the Bayt al-Maqdis (Jerusalem/Temple). By the right of what is in the flask of Myron (Chrism)... Of healer of ailments for madness. By the right of what is transmitted from Simon... Of the blessings of palm leaves and olives. By the right of the festivals of the shining Cross... And the two festivals: Nawsard (New Year?) and the Festival of Breaking Fast (Fitr - Easter?). And by the Hosannas (Sha'anin - Palm Sunday) of great destiny... And the Festival of Marmari (?) of great mention. By the right of Sha'ba (?) and the Temples... And the incense held in the hand of the carrier. By which every confuser of mind is healed... And internal sickness in joints. By the right of seventy of the worshipers... Who established the religion of Allah in the lands. And guided people to guidance... Until he who was not guided was guided. By the right of twelve of the nations (Disciples)... Who marched to the regions reciting wisdom. And his saying 'fa-aqsata' (was just/equitable), the correct is 'fa-qassata' (became priests/hardened?). Reflect: Until when the darkness dawned, he cleared the injustice... They marched to Allah and won the judgment. By the right of what is in the decisive Revelation (Gospel)... Of decisive prohibition and permission.

And other great news... A generation narrating from a generation that passed. By the right of Mar (Saint) Eid the compassionate adviser... By the right of Luqadhi (?) the doer of good. By the right of Tamlikha (one of the Seven Sleepers) the wise preponderant... And the martyrs in the deserts and plains. By the right of the Baptism of souls... And the famous Altar in the regions. And who is in it wearing hairshirts... And a weeping worshiper and a wanderer. By the right of your approaching (communion) in the festivals... And your drinking of coffee (wine) like berries (Farsad). And the length of your crumbling of livers... By what is in your eyes of blackness. By the right of what has been sanctified striving in it... With praise to Allah and glorification. By the right of Nestorius and what he narrates... From every law (Namus) having a jurist. By the right of a group of Sheikhs of knowledge... And some pillars of piety and forbearance. They never spoke without understanding... Their death was the life of the adversary. By the sanctity of the Bishop and the Metropolitan... And the Catholicos, the Divine Scholar. And the Priest and the Deacon and the Monastic... And the Grand Patriarch and the Monks. By every law having a leader... Teaching people and he did not know. By the sanctity of the Great Fast (Lent)... And what the parting of the head of Mary contained. By the right of the Day of Sacrifice in the radiance... And the Night of the Nativity (Christmas) and the Epiphany. With gold the needle adorns the leaves... At Easter, O refiner of morals. Will you not desire the satisfaction of a writer... Whom love distanced from the beloved? He melted from longing for the tormentor... His highest wish is the easiest of the near. So look, my Prince, into the reform of my matter... Seeking reward in the great recompense. Clothed in beautiful thanks... In prose of words and verse of pearls.' It was said he weakened, his body wasted, his mind went, he cut off from his brothers, and stuck to the bed. Hassan bin Muhammad bin Isa said: I attended him visiting with a group of his companions. He said: 'Am I not your companion of old association with you? Is there no one among you who will aid me with a look at the face of Amr?' He said: So we went all of us to Amr and said to him: 'If the killing of this man is our religion, then reviving him is chivalry.' He said: 'What happened to him?' We said: 'He has reached a state we do not think you will catch him.' He said: So he put on his clothes and rose with us. When we entered upon him and Amr greeted him, he took his hand and said: 'How do you find yourself, O my master?' He looked at him then fainted. Then he woke up saying: 'I am in health except... From longing for you. O visitor, what is in me... From you is not hidden from you. Do not visit a body and visit a heart... Pledged in your hands. How does one shot... With the arrows of your eyes not perish?' Then he gasped and departed the world in it. We did not leave until we buried him, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him.
Among them is a slain one. The Allama Abu al-Qasim Muhammad bin Abd al-Rahman al-Shirazi said in the book 'Rawdat al-Qulub wa Nuzhat al-Muhibb wal-Mahbub': I witnessed a woman who was from the people of Shiraz who married a Persian soldier. She found intense passion for him such that she could not bear patience from him for a moment. If he walked to his shift at the Citadel, she would wrap herself and remain standing opposite him until he left. If he entered upon her, he played with her and kissed her, so some of what she found would subside. He entered upon her one day angry from words that passed between him and his commander. When he entered, she wanted the habit from him, but he did not pay attention to her. She thought that was for a reason that happened from her, so she was frightened and panicked. He stayed an hour away from her not raising a glance to her, so imagination strengthened in her. When he went out, she went out behind him as was her habit. He scolded her, so she did not doubt that his anger was because of her. She returned, put a rope around her neck, tied it to the ceiling, strangled herself with it, and died.
Among them is a martyr. Al-Wada'i said: Emir Shihab al-Din Ahmad al-Uqayli recounted that Sharaf al-Ula loved a Christian boy and exposed himself in him until he wore haircloth and dressed in the garb of monks, following the boy wherever he went. It happened that King Al-Zahir Salah al-Din heard of his state. While he was hunting in the environs of Aleppo, it was said to him that Sharaf al-Ula was in this land. He sent for him to bring him in his condition. When he attended, and the Sultan was in a drinking gathering, he said to some of his boon companions: 'Fill a large cup and throw Sharaf al-Ula into it (or give it to him).' When he saw the cup, he took it with his hand, drank it, and recited immediately, improvising, addressing King Al-Zahir: 'You gathered my reunion with the cup... So may Allah gather your reunion.

By the right of your head, let me... Until I kiss your sandal.'
Among them is a slain one, and it is something my eyes saw, my ears heard, and my heart retained. That is that when I was in Damascus in the year seven hundred and fifty-two, it happened that a youth from the sons of Damascus, beautiful of form, assaulted a person who loved him and killed him. He was carried to the Wali (Governor). When he asked him, he denied. He stripped him to beat him with whips. A person who loved that youth stepped forward and said to the Wali: 'Do not beat him, for he did not kill him, but I killed him.' The Wali brought witnesses and wrote a report against him of his confession to the killing, and released the youth. Aytamish was the Deputy of Damascus that day. When I told him this story and he looked into its interior, he paused regarding his killing and ordered his imprisonment. Only a few days passed until Arghun al-Kamili arrived from Aleppo replacing Aytamish in his deputyship in Damascus. The first thing he judged in blood cases was the hanging of that poor lover according to the report written against him. I saw him under the Citadel while he was hanged, and people around him were regretting for him, mentioning his story, and wondering at it. I told this story to Judge Kamal al-Din bin al-Nahhas, and he wondered at it. He told me on the authority of Judge Zayn al-Din bin al-Saffah and his brother Judge Shams and a group of the people of Aleppo present now, that they told him that Nasir al-Din Muhammad bin Yaktub, one of the scribes of the Mansub (script), known as Al-Qalandari, used to love a female singer whose Zarmuza (shoe) never left him, in a satin silk bag hung on his neck under his clothes. If he attended a gathering and her presence in it did not happen, he took out the Zarmuza from the bag, placed it before him, and began to weep. If intense weeping did not happen for him, he recited: 'Let the eye of a lover not enjoy what... Pleases it if it does not shed tears. Over a beloved, his soul perished... From hardships, and he did not burn.' When he read it, he could not control himself out of fear and panic. His left eye aided him (with tears) but his right did not. He swore not to look with it as long as he lived in the world if it did not aid him with weeping over his beloved. It is stronger in sensation than the left. So he was called Al-Sabir (The Patient/One-eyed?).
I said: Among the strange things told is that Nasir al-Din al-Qalandari mentioned previously used to place the inkwell in his left hand and the volume of the book on his forearm, and write from it while singing and striking the ground with his foot. He wrote in this state whatever he wished without mistake or grammatical error. Some who wrote about him told me that among the strange things he witnessed of his state is that he used to love a youth from the sons of the soldiers in Tripoli; he used to write about him. The last thing he recited as a proverb and died after it in the year seven hundred and thirty-five is the saying of Al-Sahib bin Abbad: 'O you to whom I gifted my soul so he tortured it... And I intended its release from him but could not. Overtake a remnant of a soul in you that has perished... Before death, for this is the last breath.'
I said: Let this be what the choice fell upon, and by which desires became pleasant for Ibn Abi Hajalah when he landed in Egypt. How not, when I have landed from it upon the Expert, and brought from the news of those whom Allah forgave us and them with the large multitude? Its martyrs are among the notables of the scenes, and its slain ones, even if the causes of their death differed, their ransom is one. In that, praise be to Allah, is sufficiency, even if the explanation fell short, unintentionally, of the goal. However, in my journey 'Nashr al-Alamayn fi Ziyarat al-Haramayn' is what is like the stone of the ring to this conclusion, and the great waves to these crashing seas. No wonder I did not mention of the news of the people of Hijaz except what this book pointed to with the fingertip of its statement, and began from its paper and pen on the pages of its face and the slips of its tongue. How many in the mentioned Journey, in the mention of those who died in this form, of the news of an enslaved one who was prevented from his slumber and became drowned in the clouds of his tears? 'At the Samura trees of the tribe is a lightning conversing with him... Reminding him at the Thagh (frontier/mouth) what he remembers. ? By his mention the covenant of Al-Udhayb and what it contained... Upon Hajir, his eye sockets flowed on it. Whenever the Yemeni lightning appeared to his eye... A cloud watered the slope from the tail of Al-Muqattam. So how many a lover in it, and his passion... My night lengthened in his love, and if he wishes... So oh for Udhri love, what is the excuse when... He sobered up, and he did not sober up who lost his mind in love? Does what I encounter cool down, O my neighbor... While I attempt union from him every hour? Were he not a Sultan of Beauty, he would not travel... He is generous to them when his steed travels. Were it not for him, the Prince of Lovers would not have executed... And were it not for the attack of the Sultan in Egypt, he would not have walked. He is Al-Nasir the Victorious and the Just who... Has in the path of Allah the best provision. And his antidote in the frontier is the scorpion of his arrows... May Allah reward him for Egypt what he is worthy of. A steed, graces became near with us... It did not fault him that the soldiers are leading horses for him. From the whiteness of morning and the night is black...'

'So there is no mender one day for what he is breaking... For Allah is a secret in his sublimity for the sake of this. And hopes face the Kaaba of his generosity... So which gift have his suns not illuminated? He is the Sea, except that the watering place of his generosity... Even if it does not run, and my poetry is its pearls. Praise is best in him every evening... If my praise gets lost in the darkness of the night of itself. I crossed the Sirius Passage so I signaled... So my praise for him is the praise of the lover for his beloved. And my love for him is not to be compared with another... And my heart died at the beginning of love and ended.'
